name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The first item is the debate on the report by Ángela Vallina, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015 (2016/2146 (INI)) (A8-0366 / 2016)

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: speaker. - Madam President, first of all, of course, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their collaboration for the debate we have had to prepare this report and which reflects the annual activity of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. This parliamentary committee is the responsible for the treatment of direct demands from citizens, as well as from residents of the Union. As far as we can say, without a doubt, that it is the best thermometer this House has to measure what the real concerns of the population are. Thus, we can see that, although the requests registered last year have been considerably reduced, environmental complaints are always repeated, which reflect how the precautionary principle is continuously being violated, and which deal, in particular, with waste, the management of hydrographic basins and natural parks —as in my own region, in Asturias—, in addition to the controversial extraction through fracking. Also noteworthy are the violations of consumer rights, complaints of discrimination against people with functional diversity, those related to the free movement of people, employment regulation files, animal abuse or the right to vote, such as the so-called "voting begged ». On the other hand, I would like to recall that the Committee on Petitions is a member of the European Network of Ombudsmen, and that is why we must expand its role as an interlocutor within this Parliament as well. Likewise, it is necessary that, through the intra-parliamentary network, the other committees become more involved. We also call on the Member States to apply Union law correctly. I would like to recall, for example, that during 2015 this Parliament, at the proposal of the Committee on Petitions, had to call the attention of the Spanish Government for the scandalous legislation on mortgage and risk financial instruments, with hundreds of thousands of families affected by evictions, land clauses and preferential ones. Now, without a doubt, it is the European Commission at which the most criticism is directed in this report. The European Commission must ensure respect for the Treaties and Union law, also with regard to the right to petition. Thus, in this report we ask that the European Commission become more involved in the handling of petitions, that it study the cases more carefully, and that the face-to-face responses to the petitioners are not so concise and add additional information. I also ask you, Commissioner, to review the Directive that regulates European citizens' initiatives, which are another fundamental tool for participatory democracy. Procedures should be facilitated and regulatory changes proposed, not as in the case of the initiative on the right to water, which did not obtain any commitment from the Commission, or when the category of citizens' initiative was also denied the campaign of « Stop TTIP ”, with more than three million signatures. Another issue that concerns us is that there is opacity in investigation procedures and infringement procedures. In this report I ask that the information that has to do with open petitions be declassified. I also regret that you, Commissioner, interpret Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights so strictly on the application of EU law. I believe that sometimes it is necessary to intervene by expanding rights where it is not currently possible. It is the only way to advance in this society. And I give you as an example the cases of patients with hepatitis C or victims of thalidomide. Finally, I would like to remind you that we must reinforce that the right to petition be respected, with a good treatment of petitions and, when necessary, explaining well the reasons for their closure to their petitioners.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Vallina, for her interesting and comprehensive report on the work of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. Like its predecessors, the report bears witness to the breadth of issues that petitioners bring to the attention of the Committee on Petitions each year and to the committee’s efforts to ensure that the voices of those petitioners are heard. The Commission agrees that the right to petition has to be a key element for our participatory democracy, in which the right of every citizen to play a direct part in the democratic life of the Union is effectively protected. As my colleague, Frans Timmermans, stated in his last exchange of views with the committee in April, petitions are one of the few instruments where the institutions come into direct contact with citizens. At a time when Europe is facing many challenges, such direct contacts with citizens are more important than ever. The citizens who turn to the committee for help feel in many cases that they have exhausted all other avenues. They are real people with real problems. If we are to have any chance of bridging the gap that seems to have opened up between European institutions and the public, it is crucial that we – and by ‘we’ I mean the Commission and Parliament – can demonstrate that we take citizens’ seriously and show them what solutions exist at European or at national level. As the statistics in the report make clear, the Commission remains the Committee on Petitions’ principal partner when it comes to handling petitions. Of the petitions that are not closed in the early stages of the procedure, nearly 90% are referred to the Commission for an opinion. I am therefore pleased to have this opportunity to reaffirm the Commission’s commitment to providing the Committee on Petitions with meaningful replies to each request for an opinion, and to do so in a timely manner. The Commission also remains committed to sending its most competent officials to the committee’s meetings to ensure that the committee and the petitioners receive the latest information and proper explanations of the issues under discussion. This is perhaps the right moment to turn to one of the issues raised by you, Ms Vallina, in your report, namely the Commission’s interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I know that this issue has been raised in previous reports and is one where many Members of this House consider that the Commission’s interpretation is unduly narrow. It is clear that the Charter’s scope has its limitations. Defined by the Treaty, they result from the principle of conferral of powers, a cornerstone of the European Union. However, as reflected in the report, the Charter is one element of the architecture of fundamental rights protection in Europe. It complements national systems for fundamental rights protection, but does not replace them. The Commission shares your concerns about how to ensure that citizens’ expectations as regards the protection of their fundamental rights are upheld. The Commission attaches particular importance to increasing individuals’ understanding of how they can avail themselves of their fundamental rights, and whom to approach to enforce them. It is crucial to dispel misunderstandings and avoid raising false expectations. A concrete step in this direction was the introduction last October, in the e-Justice Portal, of a fundamental rights page, which helps individuals seeking to enforce their fundamental rights to identify the competent national non—judicial bodies with a human rights remit. The Commission will also make the best possible use of existing financial programmes to empower civil society organisations and human rights bodies, which work on raising awareness about the Charter and ensuring its application at national level. Let me thank Ms Vallina once again for her report. I look forward to hearing the views of Honourable Members.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, as shadow rapporteur for the European People's Party, I welcome the report and thank Mrs Vallina and the shadow rapporteurs from the other parties for their cooperation. I believe that the report, while not flawless, contains acceptable compromises and is of an overall better quality than some similar documents adopted in the past. That’s certainly good news, but I don’t think that’s the point. The point, though, is that this report reflects a good job, a good teamwork. I have been a Member of the European Parliament and Vice-Chair of the Committee on Petitions for two and a half years. I have seen the state of the petitions two and a half years ago, and I see the current situation. The positive development is very clear, and it is due to a teamwork, a good teamwork, which includes the work of the chair of the committee, the very good professional work of the secretariat, and also the work of the coordinators and political advisers, they are close. meaning they carry these themes on their shoulders. I also welcome the cooperation with the European Commission, I feel that the prestige of the Committee on Petitions is also growing in the eyes of the European Commission, although, in terms of efficiency, there is indeed something that can and should be desired. I also call on the Commissioner and the Commission to pay more attention to the fate of European citizens' initiatives in particular. Most importantly, I feel that we should all be aware that this is a very serious service to European citizens, as we are the only committee that has a direct relationship with them. That is why it is also important that our negotiations take place in a good atmosphere in most cases, and the invited drafters of the petitions see that Members of the European Parliament are interested in their problems and try to help them to the best of their ability. Madam President, finally, allow the Committee on Petitions to do so at the end of the year As Vice-Chair, I would like to thank all the members and staff of the committee for their cooperation so far and wish them a lot of energy and commitment to this important work for the future.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President! The subject of the 2015 annual report is an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions, thanks to which every citizen of the European Union, acting individually or with others, may at any time exercise his right to lodge a complaint with the European Parliament pursuant to Art. 227 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Annual statistics for 2015 show that most petitioners turn to Parliament for help in matters related to the environment, justice, internal market and fundamental rights. Last year, Parliament received more than 1,400 petitions, down by 47% compared to 2014. Unfortunately, the report does not analyze the reasons for this. Of the petitions received, 943 were declared admissible and 483 were inadmissible. The percentage of inadmissible petitions decreased by more than 6% compared to 2014, while the percentage of petitions deemed admissible increased - by almost 6%, which proves that citizens understand our competences better and better. The Committee on Petitions in 2015 also managed to eliminate the existing delays in dealing with petitions. The European Commission is still the largest partner of the Committee on Petitions when it comes to dealing with complaints that have not been closed in the early stages of the procedure and which are almost 90% sent for consideration and opinion to the European Commission. In 2015, the most petitions were sent by Spaniards, followed by Italians, Germans, Romanians and Poles. The rapporteur, Ángela Vallina, has prepared a very good report, congratulations and thanks for your effective cooperation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, we have heard many wishes and weights have been set for the action of the Committee on Petitions. It makes sense, since those who judge the committee are at the same time its members who made the decisions. But things are not so rosy. And this is true for handling many reports. Here are some examples of Greek interest: The rapporteur of the European Left in her report does not mention a single word on the issue of war reparations owed by Germany to Greece, an issue that has preoccupied the work of the coordinators and the Committee on Petitions repeatedly. my initiatives. The Committee on Petitions has rejected at least five times my proposals for a public hearing on German compensation. In fact, on 29.11.2016, the committee rejected my amendment no. 172 which referred to this issue. The European Left in this case abstained from voting, supporting in practice the position of the SYRIZA government, which has not only abandoned the fight for German compensation but also where it can undermine it. The rapporteur of the European Left does not mention the important decision of the Committee on Petitions of October 2015, which accepted my suggestion and deemed acceptable the report of the fighters of the National Resistance PEAEA-DSE on the issue of Germany's debts to Greece. This is the first time that Germany has been asked to make a public statement to a European semi-jurisdiction body, such as the Committee on Petitions, on German reparations. However, the SYRIZA-ANEL government in practice undermined our struggle for German reparations and was content to send only one overdue intervention of the Greek Parliament through an MEP. Thus the Committee on Petitions took the opportunity and, with a politically unacceptable decision, rejected the objection I submitted to leave open the report of the National Resistance fighters on the German compensation.This issue and many more make ECR vote against the Committee on Petitions' 2015 action report.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am convinced that the petitions, and the petitioners that we invite to the committee to have an exchange with them, help us in the long run to better assess the impact that EU legislation has on people’s daily lives and can also help us to find loopholes in the implementation of EU legislation. By acting as a bridge between citizens and the EU institutions, our committee can therefore contribute to both better legislation and helping citizens in their everyday lives. It is therefore crucial that we ensure that petitions are treated seriously and efficiently. In 2015 we agreed on new internal guidelines in the committee and this reform has enabled us to improve the work efficiently and substantially; the backlog of hundreds of untreated petitions that existed in 2014 is now gone. I am extremely proud of that and the committee is up to speed with the treatment of the petitions. As the Chair of the committee I am very happy and proud about this development. I am pleased with the results that we have achieved together and especially the excellent work done by the secretariat during these last years. The backlog that existed before created substantial frustration and disappointment. I therefore believe that the 2015 annual report should include also a special reward to the Head of Unit, Virpi Köykkä, and all the staff of the Petitions Committee for their effort and good work. Thank you very much. We can always do better; together we should strive to improve our support to the citizens even further. I look forward to continue this work together with you, colleagues, in the next coming years.  Especially in these days of increased populism, it is our paramount duty to work together to respond to expectations of EU citizens, and make sure that we do our utmost to bridge the perceived gap between citizens and the EU.  And with that I wish all of the colleagues and the Secretariat and you, Madam President, a very good Christmas and let us look forward to a happy new year 2017.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Many petitions we receive in Parliament are about animals: for example bullfighting, about the endless dragging of animals in overcrowded cattle trucks, about the force-feeding of ducks and geese for foie gras production, about the killing of stray dogs in Romania, about the structural cutting of piglets' tails, about the gruesome fate of horses for slaughter and about putting an end to animal testing. In short, citizens are very concerned about the way we treat animals in Europe and that makes sense because it is one of the few values ​​that we still share in Europe. This collective value is expressed in Article 13 of the European Constitution. Animals are beings with consciousness and feeling that we must take full account of. However, the majority of these petitions are dismissed by the Commission with the words “That is not our competence”. How can the Commission be surprised that citizens are turning their backs on Europe? Europe is faltering because you are completely ignoring the concerns of citizens. If you want people to consider the European Union important, then give them a reason. Make good rules for animals and make sure they are enforced. Do what you should and protect our animals. Because we were still progressive in the field of animal welfare 15 years ago, we are now far behind and if we stand still longer, we will be overtaken by China. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should end.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I want to thank especially my friend and colleague, Ms Vallina, for this report which is a very good one and takes us forward in our work. I would first underline that petitions are not solely the responsibility of the Committee on Petitions, but should rather be a shared concern of all Parliament’s committees. In this sense we heartily welcome the creation of the petitions network with the involvement of Members from all committees.  The outcome of our work, furthermore, is highly dependent on a fruitful dialogue with the Commission. This is why it is important that this report insists on the need for maximum transparency and prompt feedback by the Commission on the development in EU pilot and infringement procedures. It is also crucial that relevant cases get visibility in the plenary. In this sense, I want to highlight Article 29 of the report which refers to a plenary resolution of 8 October 2015 on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in Spain, which the Committee on Petitions brought on its own initiative to the plenary session, as has been reported by Ms Vallina.  Our Group also welcomes the articles that emphasise the role of the fact-finding visit as a specific prerogative of the committee and a fundamental part of this work. A good example of this is the report on the fact-finding visit to the Ebro and Tagus rivers that was adopted this year, and called on the European Commission to revise the Spanish Government hydrological plan. I want to draw attention, particularly to one amendment that our Group tabled, Amendment 15, asking for a change in the Commission’s approach concerning animal welfare with regard to Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  And finally, as foreseen in the report, we call on the Commission, in view of the various weaknesses identified and the functions of the European Citizens’ Initiative, to present a new proposal as soon as possible. I wish you all the best for the New Year.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from the overall analysis of the report in question, the positive aspects, the criticalities and the shortcomings, sometimes even serious ones, found in the course of 2015 in relation to the activities carried out by the Petitions Committee are fully understood. Basically, it can be emphasized that, in the development of the works carried out, the role of listening to the relevant problems that have afflicted citizens has been carried out in a satisfactory manner. However, the mere discussion of the requests submitted in the petition exercise recognized by the treaties cannot represent the only response that the European institutions are able to provide. The credibility of the petition tool and the citizens' conviction about its effectiveness resides predominantly in the ability to concretely put an end to the very serious violations reported, especially if, as we have seen, the complaints involve a plurality of very delicate areas and matters that in fact, they are placed in direct correlation with the overall number of fundamental rights, on which the duty of the European institutions applies to full and unfailing protection. On this question, the existence of glaring shortcomings is evident. The reaction of the European institutions continues to show itself to be weak and late, if not ineffective, despite the content of the petitions revealing an increasingly amplified social and economic unease, with the persistence or aggravation of even highly critical situations. The right to petition therefore remains a crucial tool to allow citizens to continue in the work of denouncing and in the work of democratic control. It is clear, however, that only the political will to guarantee effective protection of fundamental rights, to guarantee full transparency, to guarantee the direct involvement of citizens in decision-making processes, genuinely adopting more warned, it can allow us to believe that the European Union still has a social vocation, endowing itself with a real democratic governance.I am very grateful for Mrs Vallina's work because this report is a truly excellent report and I thank all my colleagues for their cooperation.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). - Madam President, the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions is not an instrument of democratic scrutiny, but an instrument of enforcing the reactionary EU policy, as the report acknowledges, and of manipulating popular protest. Its role, and that of other European Union bodies, was unacceptable and provocative in the joint initiative of the Communist Party of Greece and the Panhellenic Union of National Resistance Fighters - Democratic Army of Greece to report on war reparations, disasters and casualties in Greece 1941 - 1944, which Germany has been refusing to pay for seventy years. The Committee on Petitions, with the intervention of the European Commission and the assistance of the SYRIZA government, the GUE and other forces, closed the case, claiming that the issue concerns transnational relations and not the European Union. While, with selective sensitivities in your interests, you submit resolutions on war crimes, on the other hand, you deny the implementation of international agreements for the compensation of victims of Nazism, condemning again, seventy years later, the victims again, giving pardon to the Nazi gangs clicking on this policy.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: - The Committee on Petitions is the only committee of the European Parliament which guarantees direct contact with citizens. Only one vote of a citizen or president in the form of an e-mail or letter is enough to submit a petition, as the Treaties on the European Union make it possible to address the European Parliament with various problems that citizens encounter in their daily life, provided, however, that the issues raised fall within the scope of the Union's activities European. Each month we examine such petitions in the presence of those submitting them, and this allows us, as parliamentarians, to find out what difficulties exist in implementing EU law in the Member States. That is why we cooperate with the European Commission, the Council, the European Ombudsman, the Legal Service and the authorities of the Member States at various levels. As a committee, we also organize - or we have the right to organize - public hearings and go on observation missions. In the context of the annual activity report of the Committee on Petitions, I would like to highlight a few aspects. First, our priority should be to process petitions within a reasonable time frame to avoid leaving the petition unresolved for too long. Secondly, we should improve the petitions process by digitizing the procedure, making the work of both Members and the committee secretariat easier. And the last point, which is very important, because we must pay attention to the fact that the discussed issues actually concern European law, and not serve as a tool for political struggle. In recent years, political parties during election campaigns have very often tried to use this commission as a tool in the fight for political votes. We must clearly and firmly say no - we do not agree to this. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card question. – Thank you Mr Wałęsa. When I was a journalist, before I became an MEP, I was working for a paper called the Daily Express in the United Kingdom. We raised a petition of 363 000 readers demanding David Cameron grant an in-out referendum on the EU, and we were a key part of ensuring that that referendum took place; that glorious act of democracy took place in June. Does that not show that if your cause is just and commands popular support, nothing can really hold back the power of a popular petition?

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: blue-card answer. – Well, I have to agree that if you really believe in something, then nothing can stand in your way to achieve this goal. With the Petitions Committee the situation is even simpler because you do not have to gather additional signatures; you do not have to establish any organisation. Just one voice, one e-mail or a regular letter to our Committee is needed and we look into the issues. So you do not even have to have larger support. One voice is enough for our Committee to look into the issue.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 2015 was the first year of work of this legislature in the Committee on Petitions that we can describe as complete. I believe that it has been a positive year, both from the point of view of the forms and the issues that have been discussed. I think it has been positive in the sense of order and the organization that we have made of the commission, which has allowed this commission to bring this commission even closer in time and form to the public. More than 190 citizens have been received into the commission and 500 petitions have been directly responded to. But I also want to exemplify to really show the usefulness that this commission has for the citizenship, or that it has had precisely in this year 2015. I want to recall that the first Resolution was presented before the Plenary, responding specifically to a claim Regarding the situation of economic crisis, with regard to abusive clauses in countries like mine, which, today, has led to the elimination of these abusive clauses. It is also important to remember that people's claims regarding the cost of a drug - specifically, the new drug for hepatitis C - prompted us to draw up an initiative report today on how to improve access to drugs in the European Union . Today a Resolution is also voted here that recognizes the victims of thalidomide in Europe for the first time after fifty years. I could also continue with the work we are doing on issues such as disability. In short, I consider it very useful and I encourage us to continue working, and I would like to especially thank the will of the colleagues.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: - Madam President, Commissioner. Many thanks to Mrs. Vallina for the effort made. And I must also acknowledge the effort that the new president of the commission has made, giving, with the help of all the members, a new orientation and a new impulse. And 2015 - as my colleague Cabezón has said - has been very symptomatic because I believe that it has marked a new path by insisting on finding the true site of this very important commission, which is always tempted or to replace the Ombudsman, That is not the case, or to replace the courts of law. We must not forget that always, all parliamentarians, when we vote, when we work, when we are here, we are working for the citizens. There is a big difference between working for citizens and using citizens for electoral and political interests. Our commission must be legislative and attend to all citizens who complain about the laws that are lacking and those that are very poorly developed, and that's where we are. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Colleague, we saw two days ago a vote to reduce the MEPs’ remit with the Corbett report. Your Committee is so important in reconnecting the institutions and EU citizens by directly involving them; do you not think it might be time that Parliament should give this Committee more power, more instruments and more political tools in order to achieve its main goal?

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: "blue card" response.- The commission can be refined.The commission can, of course, gain access to citizens more easily, although it has already been said here that a signature is enough.But I do not agree with reviling the Corbett report, because we must combat - we are adults - parliamentary filibustering, and a democracy are also procedures, rules, norms that facilitate and make effective the intervention of citizens, and it is not a system fordirect action, more or less activist.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, what is the Committee on Petitions for European Citizens? The gateway to communication with the European Parliament, which brings citizens closer together. It helps us MEPs to understand the problem that afflicts European citizens in all 28 countries. From this committee we learn to get closer, not only with Crete in the South of Europe but also with Denmark in the North. The Petitions Committee helps us all become a little better people, listening and looking for the right answer. From there, we encourage citizens to exercise their democratic right to criticism and denunciation, that is, to operate more democratically. Έκθεσηngela Vallina's report proves in the best way how important the work of the committee is, how serious the work of its secretariat is. That is why I welcome its proposal to strengthen the Committee on Petitions with more technical resources and staff. He is our democratic face and we must strengthen him in every way.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: - Madam President! First thanks to Ángela Vallina for a good report and also thanks for many good contributions here. Sorry I'm now going to concentrate on the places where we're having problems. We have problems with the Commission, which has a tendency to investigate whether petitions can be brought before a court and what it looks like. Hence this overly narrow interpretation of Article 51, where it should be an experience that citizens can talk to us about the whole area of ​​the EU, including its values, and we must be very careful not to stifle them at Article 51. I think , that it is one of the reasons why we have received so many fewer petitions this year. Then there is also the formality - it is affected, for example, by what is said that if a case is pending before a national court, it cannot be processed by us. We clearly believe that it can do well, that it cannot be barred by a national court. That is why I would very much ask that we support Amendment No 12 today, so that it becomes clear that we can, of course, deal with these matters. And let me finally mention a problem that also affects our citizens, namely that we in our own committee have been gripped a bit by an efficiency craze, as if it was the most important thing to close the cases and get rid of them. So it is not the most important thing when dealing with citizens. The most important thing is that they feel they are being heard! As a very last point, I must add that we are also affected by a bureaucracy with our important fact-finding visits. We must have done something about it!

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, today I’m launching a petition very dear to the hearts my constituents in Thurrock. Four months ago, we and the Nicky Mason Memorial Fund, a military charity in my constituency, went about putting up the Union Flag and St George’s Cross in Thurrock. The response was overwhelming. We had people coming into my office saying the constituency looks brighter; there was civic pride; the streets were cleaner; everybody felt that the borough was going in the right direction. Then enter the killjoys. The Tory MP, Jackie Doyle-Price, wrote in the local paper that the flags were inappropriate; she attacked them. The Labour Party called our national flag offensive. And let me just remind my constituents, when they attack our flag they attack every single one of us. Join my campaign today, sign my petition. We can turf out those killjoys, those politically correct bigots who would do our country and our community down. We can turf them out. Join us, and together we can turn Thurrock around.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Madam President, my first words are to give support to Ángela Vallina for this report, for her effort and dedication to the committee, and to our President Cecilia because I think she has made a mark and has made this committee a useful instrument. It is true that with the Committee on Petitions, with what we are debating today, we have a barometer to find out what citizens are asking for, what citizens need, what citizens are complaining about and how we can build a better Europe. And it is true that it indicates to us in some way that where they put the accent is where we have to intervene. They present petitions on such disparate subjects as the environment, fundamental rights, justice, transportation or the internal market. It is true that in this report we can observe that Spain leads in the origin of petitions, followed by Italy and Germany; And it is true that this Committee on Petitions has been very useful on such important issues as the Marrakesh Treaty - the fact of being able to unblock it - or the unblocking of the Directive against discrimination. It is also true that many requests have been refined. I do not share the opinion of my colleague Auken. I believe that the important thing is to resolve the petitions, but not to give the petitioner false hope, because having an open petition for four, five or six years knowing that we are not competent is to deceive the petitioner. Therefore, it is important that in what we are competent we go upside down, but in what we are not competent we do not give false expectations. Digitization is also very important, because that has allowed us and the petitioner to be more efficient and closer when it comes to exchanging information, and it is also very important not to politicize the petitions. In this last year there has been a campaign in Spain and there has been a tendency - because there is a majority of Spanish coordinators - to put the accent on Spain. Accent no It has to be about the electoral campaigns, but about the requests of the citizens, because they have to be the true protagonists.(She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue.- Thank you, Madam President.Thank you for accepting my blue card question!I just want to make it clear: then you want to make the Committee on Petitions a kind of formality?

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: "blue card" response.-  Yes thanks.I pretend to be serious.And I intend that the Petitions Commission give an effective response: as it did with the Coastal Law;how she found it with breast prostheses;as it has in many disability issues with the Marrakesh Treaty.But don't fool people.Having a petition open for eight years, the petitioner thinking that we are competent when we all know that we are not, does not make any sense.And what I want with this commission is that we really be serious.That we do not use it to make politics, but that we use it in the service of the general interest, at the service of citizens.That is what I intend.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: - Sur President, iċ-ċittadini Ewropej għaddejjin minn żmien ta ’nuqqas ta’ fiduċja u sodisfazzjon fil-proġett Ewropa. Għalhekk il-Kumitat tal-Petizzjonijiet hu important aktar minn qabel għax hu l-aktar kumitat qrib taċ-ċittadin. Wasal iż-żmien li l-Ewropa tibda tagħti ċ-ċans liċ-ċittadini billi tersaq lejhom u taħdem fuq it-tħassib u l-aspirazzjonijiet tagħhom. Il-Kumitat tal-Petizzjonijiet jagħti s-saħħa lin-nies bid-dritt li jsemmgħu leħinhom fil-Parlament Ewropew fuq kwistjonijiet li huma important għalihom jew dwar problems li jħossu li għandhom jirrikorru għal millea soluzzjoni. Important Huwa li niftakru li l-esperjenzi u t-treatments pożittivi jew negattivi li jiksbu l-petitioners ikomplu jifformaw l-attitudni u l-opinjoni tar-relevanza tal-Unjoni Ewropea u tal-Parlament Ewropew. Għaldaqstant, irridu nkunu ċerti li npoġġu liċ-ċittadin fil-qalba tal-ħidma tal-Kumitat PETI. For eżempju, irridu nagħtu respons fil-ħin lill-petitioners, filwaqt li niżguraw tweġibiet ċari; irridu nagħmlu follow up tal-ilmenti tal-petitioners, mhux inħalluhom ma jafux x’sar bl-ilmenti tagħhom; irid ikollna laqgħat regular mal-kumitati nazzjonali fuq petizzjonijiet bil-għan li jkun hawn aktar għarfien tat-tħassib taċ-ċittadini tagħna; iridu ntejbu s-sit tal-PETI biex il-proċedura biex tiġi submissive petizzjoni, u jinkseb tagħrif dwarha tkun eħfef, ċara u aktar transparent; Il-Kumitat tal-Petizzjonijiet u d-dritt li tissottometti petizzjoni lill-Parlament Ewropew huma pont important bejn iċ-ċittadini u l-Parlament li jista 'jwassal biex il-ħidma tal-Unjoni Ewropea tkun aktar magrufa rufa.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Madam President, I want to express my gratitude to the rapporteur of this report for her work and also for collecting not only a summary of activity but also a critical approach to all the problems that we face and that citizens face. I also want to express my gratitude to the petitioners —those groups that fight—, to thank their work and their efforts in this system that often little listens to the citizens. Not in vain the petitions referring to environmental matters are still the most numerous. Complaints against fracking or against facts that refer to the incorrect application of the Directive on environmental assessments, which contrasts with problems such as obstacles to electricity self-consumption. Environmental conflicts are violations of rights. These conflicts continue to show that society is ahead of the institutions and certain private organizations in regard to considering the environment as an ally of society and not as a barrier to progress, the traditional developmental perspective. It shows that European institutions are distancing themselves from the people and that senior officials like Barroso continue to turn revolving doors greased by corruption.

name: Julia PITERA
text: - Madam President! The right to petition is one of the fundamental rights of citizens, enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Every citizen can turn to the European Parliament to raise a problem with which he or she is confronted in their daily life when this problem is part of the activities of the European Union. The right to petition not only builds citizens' trust in the European Union - petitions are also an important source of knowledge for Members of the European Parliament. Knowledge that allows legislation to be improved. The analysis of the reported problems also allows the identification of difficulties in implementing EU law in the Member States. In order to achieve these goals, citizens' knowledge of the right to petition and the way of submitting them must be widely disseminated, but equally important is the effectiveness of solving reported problems. Therefore, cooperation with national parliaments' petition committees is essential. Unfortunately, not all national parliaments have set up petitions committees. Their absence makes it difficult to submit petitions that do not fall within the scope of the European Union's activities. I am therefore asking the parliamentarians representing these countries to get involved in setting up petitions committees in their national parliaments. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: question "blue card".- Madam President, I respect the work of the Committee on Petitions and its chair, Mrs Wikström, but I wonder, listening to you, whether this committee is not being given too much importance.To believe you, it would be the only intermediary between the citizens and the Union.However, I believe that the intermediary between the citizens and the Union is the MEPs.I heard a figure of 190 citizens received earlier.Me, in a weekend, I get more.Don't you think, Madam, that we are bureaucratizing the mediation system between the Union and the citizens?

name: Julia PITERA
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Absolutely not.A Member's individual work is one thing and a complaint made to a body like Parliament is another.Therefore, I do not think it is a bureaucratic body, especially since the achievements of the Committee on Petitions - tangible achievements that sometimes even result in a change of law in a Member State - prove that it is an effective instrument.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start with a fact: in 2015 the petitions received by the European Parliament were 1 431, which is a good 43% less than in 2014. One might think that the reasons for starting a petition, that the citizens are therefore satisfied, but we know that this is not the case. Instead, in my opinion, this figure is an indicator of mistrust, of the distancing of European citizens from Europe and its institutions and this is also affected by a democratic, transparent and effective tool such as the possibility for citizens to initiate a direct dialogue with Parliament by submitting a petition. The Petitions Committee works hard, very hard, and works well. Petitions declared inadmissible are reduced and processing times are speeded up. It is the window, the front office of European citizens, it must continue its work, indeed it must have more possibilities, more means, this work must be strengthened because we often work with so many difficulties and only in this way will we bring Europe closer to its citizens.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Madam President! Thank you to our fellow Members for taking part in today's morning debate. That is very important and it also shows a little bit of the discussion where our main problem in the Committee on Petitions lies. Firstly, I would like to emphasize - thank you to the secretariat - that our work has improved in 2015. We have become more efficient, we have new challenges. I would like to reiterate the main problem in the Committee on Petitions: from my point of view it is simply a matter of defining and determining the competences and responsibilities. To put it in a nutshell: From my point of view it is simply not fair to tell a petitioner after three years: Sorry, we cannot help because we are not responsible. In this sense, it would be better to have bad news quickly than news that comes very late. But this quick message should of course also take into account helping the petitioner find out who is actually responsible for his problem. Second: If we are responsible - this has also been touched on - we have two problem groups. One is the most beautiful: we can help the petitioner. But the second is the long way. We note that the petitioner is in and of itself right with his concerns, we are with him with our hearts, but the legal situation speaks against it, and here the Petitions Committee has an extremely important task to help, if necessary, to change the legal situation. Work with the Commission and with the relevant technical committees must be improved here. We and our famous network are currently working on that. We are also a little bit of a feeler to the citizens when it comes to determining where the laws are not having the same effect as we would like them to. I wish all of us a Happy New Year and Merry Christmas.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President. Commissioner, colleagues! This year, in the referendums and elections in the countries of the European Union, we received a strong signal from the people of Europe. A signal that they want to be involved in the decision-making process, that they want a fair solution to the problems that concern them, including at European level. There are sometimes many intermediaries between the European Union authorities and the people of Europe, and much is lost in this chain. As a result, people - citizens - feel alienated. Because they do not understand what the European institutions are doing and why they cannot take anything. The European Parliament, as the only directly elected body in the EU, must not only play a legislative role, but also work directly with specific citizens and groups. A petition is a powerful tool for carrying out this work, and it must never turn into another empty formality. Therefore, I will always support any proposal that would increase the impact and authority of this important instrument of democracy.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, statistical analyzes show that the majority of petitioners declared inadmissible continue to confuse European and national competences and the EU institutions with those of the Council of Europe or the European Court of Human Rights. However, this is not surprising, as the European Commission interprets EU competences in this area rather narrowly. When citizens feel that their fundamental rights have been violated, but this has not been done in the context of EU competence, they can turn to the European Court of Human Rights as soon as national remedies have been exhausted. European citizens are not lawyers, they only see that European law declaratively protects their fundamental rights, but when they turn to the European institutions in specific cases, they point to the authorities of the Member States and say: this is not an EU competence. Violations of fundamental rights affect citizens at their most sensitive point, and a much broader interpretation of the law and more active action by the European Commission would be needed.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, the right to petition is a valuable tool that allows every European citizen to actively participate in the democratic life of the EU by drawing the attention of the MEPs, the institutions and Member States to issues that concern them. The right to petition is of great importance since it strengthens the constructive dialogue between citizens and the EU institutions. In this context, I would like to congratulate my colleagues working in the Committee on Petitions and particularly the Chair, Cecilia Wikström, for their tireless efforts to preserve EU democracy and to engage European citizens, to safeguard fundamental rights and to improve the well-being of our societies.  I personally submitted a petition on the total ban on use of languages other than Bulgarian in election campaigns, which is already supported by over 20 000 people. I did this as an EU citizen because I would like to live in a truly democratic EU where all Member States preserve and protect human rights, including minority rights.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Madam President! Mr Jahr made an impressive statement that there are major difficulties in the Committee on Petitions, but that improvements are being made - I think that is important. I am not on your committee. But precisely because it was said from the right-wing front that these are inquiries from the MPs that are piling up. Yes of course! But when it comes to difficult things, when legal matters have to be dealt with, when the details have to be right, then we always turn to our colleagues in the Committee on Petitions, and I think it is an important area. There is careful research, there is information for the citizens that they cannot get in the fast-track process. I actually wanted to say thank you - and not just because Christmas is imminent - to all of those who really take care of every detail there. It is a very important area in which the citizens also feel that they are getting competent answers. That is the most important thing of all: we take it seriously, we make sure that legal issues can really be dealt with. I just wanted to say my heartfelt thanks to all those who really do an incredible and immense amount of detailed work.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I will respond to some questions which were raised in the discussions.  Ms Vallina mentioned the situation regarding the European Citizens’ Initiative. The Commission has already implemented important measures to improve the functioning of the European Citizens’ Initiative instrument in several areas, such as the European Citizens’ Initiative register and website, to offer organisers the possibility to use the Commission’s own servers for their own online collection system free of charge, and the improvement of the open-source software for the collection of signatures, and many issues which will be addressed in the future.  Ms Hazekamp raised questions about animal welfare. The Commission receives indeed many petitions on animal welfare, which shows the interest of European Union citizens in this issue. These petitions often refer to Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, on animal welfare, asking the Commission to act in various areas. You are right: Article 13 obliges the Union and the Member States to pay full regard to the welfare of animals in formulating and implementing certain Union policies. However, it does not itself constitute a legal base for legislative action; therefore actions on animal welfare are only possible if they are at least related to one of the Union policies such as agriculture or the internal market.  We are listening to citizens’ concerns, but it is not within the competence of the Commission to extend its own powers to cover all animal welfare issues. The protection of animals in the EU is subject to detailed rules. The main problems are related to an insufficient level of enforcement and differences in interpretation between Member States. As a consequence, the enforcement of existing rules is a priority for the Commission. The Commission is working with Member States to improve the implementation and the enforcement of rules through various actions. Against this background, I am pleased to confirm that the Commission is preparing to establish a European Union animal welfare platform, which should be operational next year. The platform is indeed to improve animal welfare in the EU, in particular through the strengthening of various stakeholder dialogues.  Mr Terricabras touched on questions regarding EU Pilot cases. It would be premature to disclose information being examined at EU Pilot stage before opening a formal infringement procedure. This is because a possible breach of European Union law has been identified, but not confirmed. The complaint has to be investigated and this involves a dialogue with the Member States via European Union Pilot. No Commission decision has been taken. This work is preparatory work for the Commission services. EU Pilot supports the work of the Commission services to establish the complete factual and legal background of a case. National authorities must be contacted very often in order to clarify facts and the application of rules. The dialogue between the Commission and the Member States concerned is confidential, as confirmed by the Court of Justice. I hope, Members of Parliament, you will agree with me that the number of speakers and the range of issues addressed during this morning’s debate provides proof, if proof were needed, not only of the importance of the right to petition in our Union, but also of the importance of our collective efforts to respond to the concerns that citizens bring to our attention. My choice of the word ‘collective’ in this context is a deliberate one, since both Parliament and the Commission have key roles to play in this area. The Commission very much sees itself as a natural partner of the Committee on Petitions in its work. On behalf of the Commission, I would like to reassure you of our continued and strong commitment to cooperate closely with Parliament in the handling of petitions. We are not trying to find possibilities to look at it from a narrow Commission approach, rather to be partners and to see how to extend our capacities to solve those petitions. Thank you very much indeed for your attention and for your excellent cooperation.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: speaker. - Madam President, to conclude, I would just like to say that this report does indeed include a call for greater transparency, for more participatory democracy mechanisms in the Union, because I believe that in order to carry out real work, of service to citizens, We have to be self-demanding in order to improve our activity. I thank you, Commissioner, and we encourage the Commission to make these changes that you have just announced, because it is necessary to help remove bureaucratic obstacles and administrative obstacles to citizens, in order to offer better access. I believe that the debate has raised the concerns of the Petitions Committee as a whole and that they must be taken into account. I am sorry, Mr Marias, that you do not remember that, on the five occasions that the hearing on war reparations has proposed, we have supported you from the GUE / NGL Group and we have voted in favor. Sorry, we don't have a majority to get this going. I end as I began, truly thanking everyone for their collaboration and all my colleagues, and also reiterating the appreciation of all the work of the secretariat and of our president. Therefore, I hope that we can conclude with a favorable vote this report on the activities of 2015 and I also hope that next year we will not reiterate the same concerns again, given - I believe - the key moment in which the European Union finds itself today, because it is our obligation to listen to the demands of our citizens. That is what we are here for. Thank you very much to all of you for your collaboration and for this debate.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR).- Madam President, the rapporteur has referred to me.I must remind her that in her report, which she is drafting, she did not mention a word on the issue of German reparations.That's what I told her.This issue is serious.(The President cut off the speaker).

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you very much, Honorable Member.You can talk calmly without a microphone, perfect.There is no way to do that.Representative, do not shout in this Chamber.There is no such thing.Mr Member is attending the committee meeting, Mrs has indicated that this has not happened, [shouting] they are discussing.Well, ladies and gentlemen, this is a well-done report with a bad ending.I close the debate.The vote will take place today, Thursday 15 December 2016.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - 2015 The purpose of the annual report is to provide an overview of the activities of the Committee on Petitions, which gives an accurate and detailed account of the work of the Committee on Petitions. This report provides statistics on the number of petitions received, closed or pending before the committee, the parties involved in the petitions and the issues dealt with. The report also addresses other aspects, such as relations with other EU institutions, national and regional authorities. From the annual 2015 Statistics show that a majority of citizens turn to the European Parliament for help with environmental, justice, internal market and fundamental rights issues. Some petitioners turn to Parliament to make proposals for the development of European Union policies, others to appeal against decisions taken by national authorities and to appeal against decisions of national courts. Some citizens complain about gaps in the application of EU law, such as incorrect transposition or non-compliance with European Union rules. The Committee on Petitions has an opportunity and an important role to play in the dialogue with citizens following the recent events in the United Kingdom, as it can bring the institutions closer to EU citizens again. The Committee on Petitions must listen to and help resolve the problems faced by citizens, as petitions can be used to assess the impact of Union legislation on citizens' daily lives, as it increases the European Parliament's ability to react by addressing issues mainly related to EU law.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing.- I welcome the fact that the Committee on Petitions pays special attention to people with disabilities.I am pleased, for example, that the public hearing held by the Committee on Petitions on 15 October 2015 entitled "Protecting the rights of people with disabilities from the point of view of the petitions received" was unhindered.However, I believe that there are still few petitions submitted by citizens with disabilities.The reason for this, in my opinion, is that the complaint mechanism is not yet sufficiently known among stakeholders.I would like to ask that the way of making a complaint be communicated to people with disabilities in an accessible and comprehensive way.I am convinced that the European Parliament must set an example in this too!

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - I note with sadness, following the analysis of the report, that in 2016, the citizens of the Member States do not know that they have the opportunity to address the European Parliament directly to draw attention to issues that affect and concern them. In the context in which the European Union is going through the most difficult moments since its creation, the 47% decrease in the number of petitions indicates a worrying situation. I believe that this decrease is due to the lack of promotion of the instrument of petitions among citizens. Both the European Parliament and Members of the European Parliament should make more efforts to inform citizens about the existence of the right to petition. It is also important to cooperate with the European Ombudsman, who can check the work of the European institutions on citizens' complaints. The Committee on Petitions and the European Ombudsman are two special bodies, which directly serve the interests of European citizens, and I therefore believe that they should be provided with the necessary means of information to be able to directly promote their role among them.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the case of Larung Gar Tibetan Buddhist Academy and Ilham Tohti (2016/3026 (RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, China’s destruction of certain buildings at the Larung Gar Buddhist Academy is just the beginning of a plan that will see the influential centre reduced in size by half. Such wanton destruction is totally unwarranted and represents part of an incredibly hard-line approach taken towards the Tibetan question under President Xi Jinping. Early in September, we witnessed that the postponement of the European Parliament delegation visit to the PRC in response to the visit of the Dalai Lama to Brussels and his meeting with President Schulz. More recently, we have seen ties between Mongolia and China being strained after the Dalai Lama visited Ulaanbaatar last month. China has responded by closing and disrupting travel at the border between these two countries, in a move that threatens the important economic links that they share. As the direction of US policy towards China becomes increasingly unpredictable, following the election of Donald Trump and his pledge to scrap the Trans-Pacific Partnership, we will see a more assertive stance from the PRC in the region. Such an approach can only be detrimental to Tibet and Xinjiang, where unfortunately Ilham Tohti – who is also in the resolution – is in prison for his advocacy rights for the Uyghur minority, and of course Taiwan. So clearly things are looking extremely uncomfortable in Tibet right now.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: author. – Madam President, once again we take note of this serious violation and restriction that the Chinese Government casually adopts in the implementation of its policies to all those who stand apart from and oppose the line dictated by the state. In Tibet the latest violation is this time against nuns and monks who inhabit one of the most representative Buddhist institutions, that of Larung Gar. Here the Chinese authorities have decided to reduce the number of inhabitants by more than half, which amounts to nearly 10 000, and then to begin on major indiscriminate demolition work.  I would also recall here the case of Ilham Tohti, the Uighur university professor sentenced to life imprisonment by the Chinese authorities, who on 11 October was awarded the 2016 Martin Ennals Award for Human Rights Defenders. He was also a victim of the tyrannical intransigence of the Chinese Government and he gave voice to the Uighur people, which is a Muslim minority in the Xinjiang region strongly discriminated against by the central government.  It seems that the Government always decides to respond with extreme and unsuitable means when it comes to situations of political dissent. This is highly unacceptable. For years, China has made a mockery of international treaties aimed at the defence and protection of human rights and mocks its own Constitution. We must ensure that they are fairly respected instead and, to do so, bring our political dialogue with this country to a new level.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: author. – Madam President, with strong cross-party agreement this resolution draws attention to human rights abuses for which the People’s Republic of China is responsible. The two cases highlighted, the Tibetan Buddhist Academy of Larung Gar and the Uighur intellectual, Ilham Tohti, reveal the continuing failure of the Chinese Government to live up to its international responsibilities for human rights.  The destruction of the Larung Gar Buddhist Academy is an example of the way that China, as an occupying power, engages in attacks on Tibetan religion and culture to try to break the spirit of the Tibetan people. Subjecting former monks and nuns to so-called ‘patriotic education exercises’ is a failure to respect freedom of religion and an unacceptable humiliation. For this year’s Sakharov Prize I was proud to nominate Ilham Tohti, an economics professor and member of the Muslim Uighur minority in western China. Following a flawed legal process where he did not have a proper defence, he is serving a life sentence. We call for his immediate release.  This resolution reminds European governments of their responsibility to address human rights abuses when engaging with the Chinese Government, giving human rights a priority over economic interests – a principle that the British Government has forgotten in recent years. Earlier this year, I was honoured to meet His Holiness the Dalai Lama, whose example of peaceful resistance offers important lessons to a world in turmoil. Our resolution calls on the Chinese Government to reopen the high-level dialogue with his representatives that was unilaterally suspended in 2010.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: author. - Madam President, on December 15, 1989, just today, the protest in front of the Hungarian Reformed Church in Timisoara began, which, together with the Romanians and national minorities, led to the outbreak of the Romanian revolution and the fall of the communist dictatorship. How interesting that, following his visit there, dictator Ceaușescu introduced the Chinese model to Romania, when his anti-minority homogenization policy sought to break the Hungarians of Transylvania and Szeklerland in the same way that the Chinese communist regime tapped the Tibetans. Nearly three decades have passed since then. The Chinese assassination attempt to demolish and destroy the Tibetan Buddhist center in Larung Gar is reminiscent of the infamous village destruction plan by the Romanian National Communist dictator. Our emergency resolution today warns that the Union and Parliament must continue to fight against the divine and inhuman rule of the surviving totalitarian communist regimes. This time, I would like to raise my voice separately for the release of the Uyghur opposition fighter Ilham Tohti, who was nominated for the Sakharov Prize.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: author. - Madam President, the resolution concerns above all and above all the key question, which is that of respect for the rights of minorities in China and the reiterated wish for a constructive and inclusive dialogue between China and the minorities. Their situation is very worrying after the demolition of the largest Buddhist academy in the world, after the so-called “patriotic” forced re-education campaigns or even the life imprisonment without trial of Ilham Tohti, after the constant restrictions on fundamental freedoms of meeting, religion, thought, expression and all arbitrary arrests. I ask you, Commissioner, on behalf of the Commission, to make these violations of human and fundamental rights elements and, above all, even priorities of the Europe-China dialogue by asking China to respect engagements. In Tibet, with all this bullying and these violations, we are witnessing a proliferation of self-immolations, especially of young people. At the same time as the threats to Tibetan culture, all these repressions explain the despair of the Tibetan people, who only ask for their territorial autonomy and respect for their culture. The resolution is therefore a call for solidarity, for resistance, it is a call against oppression and violations of human rights.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: author. – Madam President, the Constitution of China gives the right of freedom of cultural expression and religious belief, freedom of speech and expression, and the right to peaceful assembly and association. The reality in China is, of course, a completely different one. There is an increasingly suppressive system that affects minorities in particular. Under the pretext of counter-terrorism, there is a package of laws that again is restricting civil society and putting minorities under special control. We asked the Chinese Government to revise these laws and to give more space and more freedom to civil society, religious communities and minorities. They should continue to take up dialogue with representatives of the Tibetan people. It is not good, neither for Beijing nor Tibet, of course, that they have no dialogue and are not speaking with each other. In the case of Ilham Tohti, we asked for his release, for the release of his supporters, and for him to have permission to teach again. It is very arbitrary that this man is in prison, and both the Commissioner and I have asked the EU to have this issue as a priority in dialogues with China in all forms and all formats.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, the PPE Group has insisted on the adoption of an urgent resolution on the demolition by China of the Tibetan Buddhist Academy of Larung Gar. Under the pretext of alleviating a health problem, China violates one of the fundamental principles enshrined in its own Constitution, namely religious freedom. This is again a direct attack on Tibetan religion and culture. The human rights situation in Tibet continues to deteriorate, and China has just adopted a whole legal arsenal of security laws, which allow it to attack minorities, such as Tibetans and Uyghurs. As for Ilham Tohti, his place is not in prison, but in university, where he has endeavored to teach and promote the values ​​of tolerance and living together among different communities. I deplore the fact that the human rights dialogue between the European Union and China did not take place in 2016, when there is no shortage of topics for discussion. It would seem that one of the reasons is the visit of the Dalai Lama last September to Strasbourg, which has rightly aroused tremendous interest from our colleagues.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President! Buddhism is an integral part of the Tibetan identity, so recent reports of restrictions on religious freedom in this area are of great concern. At the request of the Beijing government, the demolition of the largest Tibetan Buddhist study center in Larung Gar in Sechuan began. Chinese authorities are threatening to completely demolish the facility if it does not halve the number of monks and nuns as part of the so-called restructuring of Buddhist centers. About 1,000 people have been displaced so far. Monks are increasingly carrying out dramatic self-immolation in protest against the destruction of Tibetan culture and religion. Most of the more than 6,250 monasteries in Tibet were demolished during Chinese rule. We expect the Chinese authorities to end the unjustified demolition of Larung Gar and the eviction of residents, restoring respect for religious freedom in line with international human rights standards. Too rarely do we raise the issue of Tibet in the European Parliament, while human rights violations have become a daily reality there. I hope that the international community will do more to restore respect for the law and civil liberties in Tibet.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, the largest Buddhist center in the world is being demolished by the Chinese authorities. So far, more than 4,500 people have been evacuated from the center and about 1,500 homes have been destroyed. Many of those evacuated, especially children, are taken to schools where they are taught only in Chinese, leave school without knowing the Tibetan language and where they are practically brainwashed, as they say. They are trying to destroy a culture, they are trying to create a generation that no longer has the memory of Tibetan culture. These generations must be saved, and this also depends on the European Union's relations with China. I would like to say that, in fact, what China has been doing for years, for many, many years, is to wage a war against Tibetan culture, to annihilate it, and I hope it will not be needed, as in 2011, as the people. to set fire to their voices.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, unfortunately the cases of the Larung Gar Tibetan Buddhist Academy and Professor Ilham Tohti, who was nominated for the Sakharov Prize, once again show us that China systematically violates a wide range of fundamental human rights, including freedom of expression, association, religion and minority rights.  I therefore call on the Chinese authorities to end all cases of human rights violations, and particularly arbitrary arrests, political intimidation and violations of freedom of expression. China is an important partner of the EU but the country has to respect and protect the rights and freedoms of its citizens and stop the persecution and the marginalisation of Tibetan and Uighur people, and all ethnic minorities. In light of this, I urge the EU to bring the protection of freedom of religion and language, and the cases of Larung Gar and of Ilham Tohti, to the top of the agenda of the next EU-China dialogue on human rights.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Only totalitarian regimes or political structures with totalitarian traits can afford to disregard or aggressively treat the national identities of people living under their authority.That is certainly the case for communist regimes and it is one of the reasons why I have always been an anti-communist.In these years of historical change with the growing contribution of national identity in an ever-shrinking world, we must side with the Tibetan people, who are peacefully seeking to prevent its downfall in the face of a Chinese regime, where we are both literallyas figurative can and can do business.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, thank you very much once again for addressing this subject. Now we all agree that respect for religious belief and culture and language are fundamental human rights that should be protected and respected across the world; yet again we are here, we are talking shop and we are addressing an issue. Where that does not happen, of course, we then have an individual that we want to cite and I am going to give that recognition to Mr Tohti for his incarceration, which is just unfounded and unjustified.  But what is the issue here? It is this issue of China, the big global elephant in the room. Even this week, in terms of Mr Juncker’s speech in this Chamber, he did not once mention that country. Now we could take a leaf out of Mr Trump’s lexicon and I am no big supporter of Mr Trump, but in the last few weeks he has actually challenged the ‘One China’ policy, which is universally recognised around the world, and he is prepared to actually stand up to that country. I am going to cite that in this Chamber this morning and suggest that if the EU is serious about this, it needs to take a leaf out of that book and learn from it.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Madam President! The so-called eight-point plan of the Chinese has led to a tragedy in Tibet - colleagues have pointed this out. The world's most important and influential Buddhist institute, Larung Gar, was largely destroyed. Nuns and monks were forced to leave the monastery on the pretext that fire protection rules had not been observed. Since July, local authorities have been ensuring that prayer rooms and houses are razed to the ground. At this place, of all places, where Buddhism is practiced peacefully. The attempt to cover up the illegal practice failed thoroughly. Despite the blockade of information, photos were made public. The interest group of the European Parliament expressly supports today's resolution, which calls on the Chinese authorities to finally stop the activities. Freedom to practice one's religion is a basic right: repression against Tibetans must stop. Arbitrary arrests, forced relocations and so-called patriotic re-education rob Tibetans of all cultural identity. China must finally show insight.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I support the call for an end to demolition in Larung Gar, Tibet. We observe with concern how China is trying to restrict the free development of religion and independent spiritual life not only here, but also of other religions, and also in this great institute, the monastic city of Larung Gar. Demolition and expulsion of monks under the pretext of rehabilitating an overcrowded place is a serious violation of Tibetan cultural autonomy. If we think that monasteries outside the Tibetan Autonomous Region enjoy more freedom, this is not the case. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Culture and Education, I see not only the human rights aspect of this issue, but also the cultural dimension. Tibetan culture, Tibetan Buddhism and places associated with them are an important world cultural heritage and inspiration for many people in the West. China should realize that it cannot dispose of these goods arbitrarily, but must protect and care for them. The so-called Tibetan separatism, which China is still talking about, is, in fact, just a non-violent effort for cultural and religious autonomy that has our support.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, when the Chinese authorities began arbitrarily bulldozing thousands of homes in Larung Gar, it was not only buildings that were destroyed in the process but, more importantly, thousands of lives.  At least 2 000 residents have been expelled without any compensation and forced to sign documents pledging that they will not return. Many of them were forcefully evicted to far-off desolate camps. Nuns Rinzin Dolma, Semga and Tsering Dolma, who committed suicide because of harassment by the authorities, were only the last to join the depressing numbers of victims of Chinese repression – including more than 140 Tibetans who have set fire to themselves since 2011. The European Parliament is right in urging the Chinese government to reverse course, stop the demolitions and evictions and permit the practice of Buddhist faith and Tibetan culture without interference.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, I would like to say to Mrs Vallina, who is not here, that what she did not do was record and mention in her report the activities we did for German compensation. So he did not write anything about the rejection of my proposals in relation to the public hearing on German compensation and did not write anything about the Commission's decision to proceed with the admissibility of the German compensation report following my proposal in October 2015. Madam President, when I asked you to speak, I asked you to speak on a personal and not a procedural point, and you had to give me the floor. Instead of ordering my colleagues who would not let me speak, you also make remarks to me that I am supposedly tarnishing the discussion! This is not a proper procedure on your part, because I wanted to defend my honor and reputation in this case from what my colleague said.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Of course I should have protected you.Of course, I should have stopped you now, as this is not the subject you have received from me in good faith in the catch-the-eye procedure, and you have abused my floor, but you, as a Member, have the right to talk about whatotherwise wishes in the catch-the-eye procedure, of course.And now Mr Turmes is on my list.Did you sign up or did we just misinterpret the signal?Yes that is fine.

name: Claude TURMES
text: - Madam President, dear citizens of China, dear Chinese leaders, the twenty-first century will be a century of great tension, stress, upheaval and acceleration.Places where we can sit and breathe calmly, where we can take root, where we can get out of the everyday hassle, where we can meditate, these are places that are important.and, dear Chinese people, you who come out of a thousand-year-old spiritual tradition, you, who - perhaps more than any other people - are propelled with incredible speed into a frenetic modernity, destroying monasteries, persecuting those who,in Tibet, do nothing but seek spirituality, calm, a better world, you are destroying what you, as the Chinese people, may need most tomorrow.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the European Union is concerned at the deteriorating status of human rights in China, not least with regard to the rights of ethnic and religious minorities in Tibet and Xinjiang.
