The European Union upholds its one-China policy, while regularly calling upon the Chinese authorities to address the concerns of Tibetans and Uighurs through dialogue. This includes non-use of force, allowing peaceful protest and respecting human rights. The European Union has continued to emphasise to China the importance of fostering dialogue with, and between, different ethnic groups and, in the case of Tibet, of resuming a meaningful dialogue with the Dalai Lama’s representatives.  The demolition of the Larung Gar Buddhist academy and the expulsions and so—called ‘patriotic re-education’ of monastic individuals are a matter of considerable concern to us. According to the Chinese authorities, the demolitions are for health and safety reasons. However, the religious leaders and the monks and nuns concerned were not consulted. The lack of information and dialogue, and the restrictions placed on access to Larung Gar and on the movement of nuns and monks in the area, have been causing much distress in the community and have even prompted suicides. The European Union underlines that, while safety and health concerns may be legitimate, they should not be used as a pretext for repression or forced displacements of religious adherents.  What about Ilham Tohti? Professor Tohti worked peacefully within Chinese law to promote equality and understanding between different ethnic groups. The European Union believes that the charges against him were unwarranted and that the due process of law was not respected during his trial, especially regarding his right to a proper defence. The European Union considers his life sentence for separatism to be completely unjustified. We call for the immediate and unconditional release of both Professor Tohti himself and the students detained in connection with his sentencing.  We urge the Chinese authorities to respect the rights to freedom of expression, religion and belief of all persons belonging to minorities in line with Chinese international and human rights commitments and its own constitution.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is debate week seven, The situation of the Rohingya minority in Myanmar.on the motion for a resolution (2016/3027 (RSP))

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: author. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my gratitude to my colleagues for their help in giving the plight of the Rohingya people the attention they deserve. Their situation is a shocking reminder that, though Westerners live in a time of unsurpassed wealth and prosperity, for some human beings even living in Third World conditions would be an improvement over how they are forced to live now. Recent reports go so far as to refer to instances of ethnic cleansing. This is spine—chilling when one thinks of what happened just a stone’s throw away from here, in Bosnia 20 years ago.  It is high time for the Government of Myanmar to stop hiding behind excuses to gloss over the unspeakable abuses taking place. They range from the deliberate destruction of property to rape and outright murder. If it wants to be a respected member of the international community, Myanmar must play its part in ending the violence. It must end social discrimination and take steps to ensure that the universal rights of the Rohingya people are fully guaranteed. In addition, international observers must also be given the access needed to monitor living conditions. Ultimately, citizenship must be restored to the Rohingya, giving them access to health care, education, property, marriage rights and jobs. Immediate action must be taken to end the oppression and prevent more children from being born into the miserable conditions they are forced to live in today.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: author. – Mr President, as my colleague has already mentioned, the Rohingya community have suffered discrimination and violence in the country of Burma for many years, and so I welcome the fact that we are able today to agree this urgency resolution in this House. The current wave of violence and repression has been described as ethnic cleansing, a term that should fill us all with dread in this continent as we have experienced it all too recently, and it has also been described as involving crimes against humanity.  In our resolution we urge the country of Bangladesh, which has already provided refuge to many thousands of Rohingya who are fleeing Burma, to keep their border open and we call on the international community to support the Government of Bangladesh in offering refuge. We also call upon the Government of Myanmar, which must stop the repression, condemn violence against the Rohingya and allow international observers into the area. We call too on the EU governments to always view their relationship with Myanmar through the lens of human rights.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. - Mr. President, the three attacks at the border post near Bangladesh served as a pretext for the Burmese army to launch a new wave of repression against the Rohingya. NGOs speak of the massive destruction of homes, other buildings and even entire villages, causing the Rohingya population to flee once again. 25,000 Rohingya are reported to have arrived in Bangladesh and 30,000 displaced. These events once again highlight the recurring discrimination suffered by the Rohingyas and recall the violence of 2012 and 2015. In his report of June 2016, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights is severe. He rightly denounces the arbitrary deprivation of nationality, threats to their life and security, denials of the most fundamental rights, such as health and education, forced labor, sexual violence and the limitations of their rights. political rights. Since March 2015, the Rohingyas have been deprived of their white card (temporary identity card), and children of a birth certificate since 2012, making them institutionalized stateless people. The coming to power of the National League for Democracy and the appointment of Aung San Suu Kyi, Nobel Peace Prize winner, as special advisor - she could not be appointed Prime Minister due to her marriage to a foreigner -, haven't changed anything. The attitude of neighboring countries is making the situation worse. Bangladesh is increasingly pushing back the Rohingyas, Thailand is instrumentalizing the situation, talking about genocide, while the Rohingyas are just as persecuted there. We remember the mass graves discovered in 2015 in Thailand and, above all, in Malaysia. The establishment of a working commission, under the leadership of Kofi Annan, on development issues in Rakhine State can be a source of hope, provided that this commission can look into violations of rights. of man. It The same goes for the peace talks which are due to take place in February 2017, if the Rohingyas are involved and therefore considered part of the Burmese people. There is an urgent need to set up an independent commission of inquiry into what happened in October 2015. The EU-human rights dialogue must be used to put pressure on the Burmese authorities, to change the law of 1982 on nationality, as well as the so-called protection of races and religions - quite a program - which were adopted in September 2015. The SGP, like the negotiation of the investment agreement, are other instruments available to the EU, as well as dialogue with Burmese parliamentarians. Yes, the situation is difficult. Yes, some progress has been made, but military power remains omnipresent. We cannot be silent. It is up to the European institutions to act by using all the means at their disposal to put an end to the discrimination and the massacres of Rohingyas.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: author. – Mr President, let me also take this opportunity to welcome the Ambassador of Myanmar, who was present here today, and also thank the delegation of the Parliament of Myanmar for their visit to Brussels last week. I think this is a showing of willingness to engage in a constructive dialogue with us, and constructive dialogue is exactly what we need at the moment.  We are, as all our colleagues have said, extremely worried about the discrimination and the repression of the Rohingya minority in Myanmar who suffer, in the words of the UN High Commissioner Al-Hussein, from: deprivation of nationality which renders them stateless; severe restrictions on freedom of movement; threats to life and security; denial of the rights to health and education; forced labour; sexual violence; and limitation on their political rights.  Last year we hailed the elections in Myanmar as a historic moment and an important step towards an inclusive democracy. That was one year ago; we now urgently need to see a commitment from the Myanmar Government, a commitment to the basic human rights of all its citizens.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Mr President, we had the resolution on the Rohingyas in July this year. There has been no improvement in their situation; it has actually got much worse. The Rohingyas are facing serious human rights abuses, indiscriminate reprisal attacks, security forces firing at villages, the torching of entire villages and people carrying out arbitrary arrests and raping women and girls.  We do not have all the information because Myanmar does not allow international observers into the region, but we have satellite images, pictures and videos of burned bodies, and testimonies from abused people. With all of this going on in Myanmar, people are frantically fleeing to Bangladesh, only to be pushed back, which is a violation of international humanitarian law.  We must acknowledge that the Myanmar Government has not done much to help the situation of the Rohingyas. Also, Aung San Suu Kyi, a Sakharov and Nobel Prize winner, has not been helpful in her capacity. We cannot just watch these atrocities happen; the EU must use all the influence and means it has to bring an end to the abuse of the Rohingyas and those responsible for the attacks must be brought to justice.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Author. - Mr President, if the government out of elections in Myanmar wanted to build democracy in the country, it would have to have a plan to combat discrimination against the Rohingya and other ethnic and religious minorities. But the stigmatization and systematic violation of the human rights of minorities and, in particular, of the Rohingya in the state of Rakhine, has worsened with arbitrary executions, burning villages and mass violations - in short, a true ethnic cleansing. The Government announces a commission of inquiry, but must allow independent and international access and investigation. I am deeply sorry to have to say this, but Sakharov and Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi have added responsibilities as a member of this government. After so long and so much violence, we continue to wait for you to act to protect the Rohingya, facilitate international organizations' access to the State of Rakhine and propose the necessary legislative and other reforms, namely restoring citizenship to the Rohingya. The European Union must put pressure on the Government of Myanmar to end violence against minorities and create conditions for genuine national reconciliation. It must also pressure the Bangladeshi government to stop forcibly returning the Rohingya when they take refuge in their territory.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group.- Mr President, in the European Union, it goes without saying that we are doing everything we can to ensure that minorities living on our territory are not discriminated against, let alone persecuted or prosecuted.But all this is not happening in all parts of this world, such as Burma or Myanmar.It is completely unacceptable how the local Muslim minority of Rohingya is treated.Its members are being killed for no reason and their rights are being severely curtailed.So I am glad that we have this resolution, which is an appeal to the Burmese Government to not only strengthen respect for human rights in its country, but also to prevent any expression of religious or racial hatred, especially against the Rohingya minority.The European Union considers Burma to be its partner and certainly wants to work with it in the future.But such cooperation is not possible if we ignore this human rights violation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I am glad that the concerns of human rights violations are finally finding space on the agenda of Myanmar’s Government. However, harassment, killings, religious persecution and other discrimination against Rohingyas continue. The establishment of a commission of inquiry into the cases of these violent attacks is welcomed, but we expect more concrete actions from the Burmese authorities, and especially from Mrs Suu Kyi. Security forces need to be brought under control and held to account. Otherwise, the democratic gains made in the country risk being rolled back again.  It is time to speak of a political solution for this community. Rohingyas must be recognized as an official ethnic group and granted full rights as Burmese citizens. The European Union must also push neighbouring countries to address the condition of Rohingya refugees to ensure that they are not turned back and are integrated into society. The situation of the Rohingya population is a major test for the new democratic Government of Myanmar.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, this is not the first time we have discussed the plight of the Rohingya in this House. What more can I say, other than that we need to continue demanding that the Burmese Government do its duty and protect – instead of persecute – these people? Whether or not you view them as your citizens, you have a duty: a duty to protect the lives and livelihoods of people who reside on your territory. These people are not foreigners. The vast majority are people who were born and raised in Myanmar, as were their fathers and mothers before them. Sadly, if the Burmese Government does not do its duty, they are likely to perish not peacefully, as all humans should, but instead at the hands of their fellow countrymen and the military. The Rakhine State is, and always will be, part of Myanmar. It is time the Rohingya can truly feel that they are part of that State.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group.- Mr. President, dear colleagues, everyone is sensitive to the fate of this population persecuted because of their identity, but we must also be particularly vigilant about initiatives to exploit their fate.So it is with the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, which is known to play a harmful role in the radicalization of Muslim societies, under the control of Saudi Arabia.But the Islamist preacher al-Zawahiri had also taken hold of the issue by calling for jihad on their behalf.This is why, given what we have observed in Bosnia and Herzegovina or elsewhere, I urge the European Parliament, on this issue, as on many others, to be more cautious.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, the Rohingya continue to suffer persecution, arbitrary detention, torture, forced displacement, abuse and severe legal, economic, social and religious discrimination in Myanmar. They continue to be arbitrarily deprived of their citizenship and therefore remain stateless. Their inhumane conditions must come to an end. Undoubtedly, human rights abuses against the Rohingya communities and refugees constitute a threat to regional security in South—East Asia, and a lasting solution to their extremely vulnerable situation can only be found in a regional framework with the participation of all countries concerned.  At the same time, we have to address this issue in a very balanced way, considering outside extremist influences. I therefore support the call on the Government of Myanmar to investigate and, through concrete steps, to counter all forms of persecution, arbitrary detention, torture, forced displacement, abuse and discrimination against the Rohingya, to fulfil its responsibility to protect them against violent attacks, intimidation and harassment, and to solve the problem of their legal citizenship status.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Mr President, sovereign State, Burma is also a mosaic country made up of various religious minorities, including the so-called Rohingya Muslims, but also the Christians of the Karen people who have never interested the moralists that you are. Nobel Peace Prize winner and Sakharov Prize, Aung San Suu Kyi is the right person to ease tensions in Burma. It is time for the European Union to learn from its past mistakes. As soon as we intervene somewhere, in the name of our conception of human rights, the tragedies accumulate. Lately, Syria and Libya have sank, accelerating the demographic crisis which threatens our nations with a migratory invasion. In addition, the case of the so-called Rohingya Burmese is revealing of an unknown or rather obscured reality: the vitality of the umma. Radical Islamists from the French suburbs are leaving to help these populations solely because of their religious affiliation. The BarakaCity association also works in Syria; some of its members are suspected of deep sympathy for the Islamic State. For all these reasons, I call on Parliament to respect the sovereignty of Burma.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, we have discussed several times the oppression of the Rohingya minority in Myanmar, where human rights are now being openly violated and the minority is being persecuted. Basic laws of the country now violate international conventions: the penal code, the law banning peaceful gatherings and peaceful demonstrations, the law on telecommunications, the law on the media. In addition, more than 130,000 displaced Rohingya remain in camps in other areas, and Myanmar authorities have made inadequate access to humanitarian aid in the area. In the face of the continuing violation of Rohingya human rights, the Myanmar authorities must finally put an end to religious and racial hatred, and the European Union must condemn all forms of discrimination against them.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I want to support this resolution and how my colleagues are doing. On the other hand, I want to express some skepticism. I spoke on the subject of the Rohingya in this House a few months ago. We adopted a similar resolution that made clear and expresses how the Rohingya are being discriminated against in their country, Burma. After a few months, the situation is the same and even worse. Following the incident on October 9, the situation of this minority has deteriorated significantly and the area where these people live is closed by government troops. In principle, we only have transferred information. I am ready to support this resolution again, but I must say openly here that I am very disappointed with the way the Burmese Government is behaving at the moment. I am very disappointed that the Sakharov Prize winner, Mrs Suu Kyi, is basically doing nothing to improve the situation of this minority, and I am afraid that this resolution will probably not bring much progress. So much more international pressure is needed on Burma to start actively addressing the situation of this minority.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the current upsurge of violence in northern Rakhine State, resulting in the loss of lives, population displacement, interruption to humanitarian aid, and reports of grave human rights violations are a deeply worrying development. The European Union has consistently called on the Government of Myanmar to guarantee respect for human rights and pursue durable solutions, including on the status of the Rohingya. The EU Ambassador was part of the first diplomatic mission which, in early November, visited the affected areas after the outbreak of violence. On 20 and 24 November 2016, EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, travelled to Myanmar for the Third EU—Myanmar Human Rights Dialogue. He also met with State Chancellor, Aung San Suu Kyi and the Commander—in—Chief of the Myanmar armed forces.  With these interlocutors, the European Union Special Representative called for the urgent resumption of humanitarian assistance in northern Rakhine State and the setting up of an independent, credible investigation into the 9 October assaults and subsequent operations. He underlined the need for transparency to address allegations of severe human rights violations and emphasised the continuity of initiatives launched by the State Chancellor to tackle the underlying issues in Rakhine State.  With the Commander—in—Chief, Mr Lambrinidis urged a proportionate response to violence, a requirement under international humanitarian law. ECHO Director Androulla Kaminara visited Myanmar during the same period. In her meeting she strongly called for full humanitarian access to northern Rakhine State, where the suspension of activities has deprived some 130 000 vulnerable people of life-saving assistance for over two months now.  On 2 December, the EU issued a statement reiterating the call for the immediate resumption of humanitarian activities in the area. While the formation of an investigation commission is a welcome step, its objectivity remains to be seen. It is equally important that those fleeing violence in Myanmar are not deported or turned back by Bangladesh, but are provided with assistance and protection until the situation in Myanmar allows for their safe return. In response to regional pressure, Myanmar has called for an extraordinary meeting of ASEAN Foreign Ministers on 19 December to discuss Rakhine State. Steadfast EU advocacy has contributed to the resumption of humanitarian activities, albeit limited, and we will continue to reach out to Myanmar. We stand ready to consider further humanitarian assistance for northern Rakhine State, based on the independent needs assessment of our partners. The EU will also continue our human rights cooperation with Myanmar, including in the United Nations Human Rights Council.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 15 December 2016

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on mass graves in Iraq1 (2016/3028 (RSP)).1See Minutes.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, many of us have used the term ‘shocking’ to describe the discovery of mass graves in Iraq, but tragically their discovery only confirms our worst fears: ISIS has carried out the most horrendous crimes against humanity, in a campaign that bears all the hallmarks of a genocide, particularly for Yazidis. In order to at least attempt to achieve justice for the victims and their families, it will be important to secure the sites as much as possible. Although we must be mindful of the limited resources and difficult circumstances that those on the ground militarily face in trying to do this. Such crimes and atrocities, unfortunately, are not unique to either Iraq or to ISIS. As the Syrian Army concludes its campaign to retake Aleppo, harrowing accounts of summary executions against innocent civilians are already beginning to surface. As the battle for Mosul continues, particularly as it reaches its most difficult stages of street-to-street combat, I fear that such atrocities will become only too familiar in the Middle East.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: author. – Mr President, the European Union and its Member States must immediately define the atrocities against Yazidis as genocide and the EU must bring the Daesh criminals to justice, possibly applying the principle of universal jurisdiction. Daesh crimes are appalling and target not only, but especially, Yazidi women and girls in Iraq. They are victims of torture and sexual slavery. We heard a first-hand testimony in this Parliament when the Sakharov Prize was awarded to Lamiya Aji Bashar and Nadia Murad.  The UN Secretary-General has found out that Daesh has raped women in pursuit a plan of self-perpetuation, and that women’s bodies are being used as biological weapons to alter the demography of the region. These women, wounded and sick in battle, need a full range of options for medical care to be provided to them, in accordance with international humanitarian law. Our partners working on the ground need to know that we stand firmly behind our position and that international humanitarian law has to be fully respected.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Author. - Mr President, we fully support the investigation and prosecution of the terrible crimes committed by Daesh terrorists in Iraq. We have always supported the prosecution of war crimes, especially after the illegal invasion of Iraq in 2003, whose destruction of the Iraqi state was the perfect fertilizer for the irruption of terrorist extremism. That is why it is important to learn from mistakes. We have added two amendments to improve this Resolution: one that condemns the military interventions of recent years in the Middle East, as a guarantee of non-repetition, and another that recalls that the best support to the people of Iraq to combat terrorism is to drown their funding, stop the smuggling of oil that continues to flow through Turkey, stop arming the countries in the area. Weapons that, curiously, later appear in the hands of terrorists. And warn the States to stop using the terrorist letter as a form of interference and destabilization.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, Commissioner, Daesh has systematically murdered thousands of civilians and with the Iraqi advances towards Mosul, more and more mass graves are being discovered. They testify that crimes against humanity and war crimes are an essential part of radical Islam. We appeal to the UN Security Council and international organisations to consider Daesh-caused mass graves as additional evidence of genocide. It is urgent to refer Daesh, as a criminal organisation, to the International Criminal Court. It is important that these graves be preserved and that analyses be conducted to identify victims as well as perpetrators. The EU should also provide the expertise, means and assistance to do this. In the meantime, the Iraqi authorities have a responsibility to protect civilians during the anti-Daesh campaign, to avoid further human rights violations and vengeance.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: author. - Mr. President, Daesh is a monster, a criminal monster, no one doubts it. In addition to the testimonies of the still living victims, the mass graves that we discover every day in Syria and Iraq bear witness to this tragically. Daesh is a criminal monster, guilty of genocide, guilty of the whole panoply of crimes against humanity, for which the initiators, those responsible, the financiers, the accomplices and the executors will have to be accountable to international justice. But criminal monsters have other faces as well. How else to name those who, today, crush the women and children of Aleppo under bombs? How else to call those who today starve their population and bomb hospitals, in defiance of all the laws of war? In the face of such atrocities, declarations are not enough. I ask the European Council, meeting today, not to be satisfied with press releases, but to take decisions, to finally make Vladimir Putin understand that he has crossed the line and that the European Union is not. will not stand anymore. I'm proud to be European, I don't want to start being ashamed of it.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Daesh has long been the protagonist of atrocious crimes against humanity. The images of violence and oppression of minorities, as well as the destruction of sacred places, sites of cultural heritage of inestimable value are the symbol of the blind anger of these terrorists who want to erase everything that deviates from their fundamentalist dictates. The Yazidi population is among the main victims of the ethnic cleansing strategy that we have a duty to classify with the term genocide. When, in 2014, Daesh conquered the Sinjar region, between Mosul and the Syrian border, he halved the Yazidi minority, killing men and raping and selling their women as slaves. Seventy-two mass graves have been discovered in the region and about 15,000 bodies have been found. On Tuesday, the European Parliament awarded and handed the Sakharov Prize to the two young Yazidi women so that they can carry on and win the battle in defense of their people. We must be involved with this resolution to ensure respect for human rights and bring to trial, within the framework of the International Criminal Court, those responsible for these crimes against humanity.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: author. – Mr President, these mass graves tell a powerful tale of unspeakable cruelty, a barbarism of the type which we thought and had hoped had been wiped from the face of the earth last century with the total and utter collapse of the ideologies of those such as Stalin and Hitler. Every single person who is tortured to death in custody, every rape, every murder, every unspeakable act of brutality, puts our world to shame. Every genocidal act seems to drive the innocent Yazidis from the face of this earth and seeks to murder those of so many religions. Even as ISIS is being driven from Mosul in Iraq, even as that scourge is being removed, supposedly never to return, we see a chilling reminder that many of those same people who terrorised Mosul have gone to Palmyra in Syria, which was supposedly liberated just months ago, to force the same unspeakable horrors upon that ancient city once again.  In Iraq, there may be glimmers of hope; we may speak of war crimes and justice, of a response to the utter inhumanity of what happened and to what is happening there still. Those who are dead may never be brought back to life, but what we can do is seek justice and seek a world in which these things never happen again. Yet we see that however bad the situation in Mosul, the situation in Syria is even worse. The international community simply must work together. We must drive this scourge and the barbarous ideology from our planet. It is so sad that every day that this continues, yet more lives are being lost, more people are being tortured, and more people are being murdered. We must do whatever we can to stop these barbaric acts.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: for the PPE Group.- Mr President, Commissioner, it is clear that the so-called Islamic State has committed and continues to commit the crime of genocide.It attempts to systematically liquidate members of religious minorities who have lived in various parts of Iraq or Syria for centuries or millennia.In addition to the destruction of ISIS and humanitarian aid for victims, it must be ensured that these crimes do not go unpunished.I think there is room for the European Union, which unfortunately is not yet militarily actionable enough, but can make a vital contribution to gathering the maximum amount of evidence of ISIS crimes, maintaining the rules of international humanitarian law in the liberated territories and returningthe inhabitants were given all their rights so that they could fully restore their existence.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! I will never forget this moment, in June this year in the Sinjar Mountains. My Yezidi friends had taken me to a place off a main road. The remains of several hundred people were buried there. Nobody knows why they were killed here. They were on the run and they stood in Daesh's way. It is one of many places in Iraq and Syria. There are still nameless places - places that have to be given a name and will be given a name when the events are cleared up and the evidence is secured, such as in Katyn, Babi Yar, Lidice and Oradour. Grass must not grow over the crimes, it must become places of remembrance. We owe it to the people who were murdered here. And that is necessary so that people can lead a new life in the region. And - esteemed colleagues - it is a human right to be buried with dignity.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- It is both terrifying and alarming that Iraq is probably the only country in the world with an official “Society for the Preservation of Mass Graves”.This brings us to the shocking fact that the mass graves of IS are a continuation of an existing murderous practice: the mass graves of the Saddam Hussein era and then of Al-Qaeda.But the Shia camp in Iraq is also responsible for war crimes and mass graves in the inter-Islamic conflict with the Sunnis.This applies to the Iraqi army and police forces as well as to their Shia allies, the murderous and predatory militias of the “Popular Front”.With this situation in mind - a general atmosphere of revenge - hold your heart for new mass graves in Iraq after the liberation of Mosul.That is the reality.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, the mass graves in Iraq hint at the true scale of the inhuman atrocities committed by so-called ISIS and Daesh criminals against civilians in the Middle East. I strongly condemn these murderous acts. Allow me to express my most sincere condolences to the families of the victims. We need to stop impunity and ensure accountability as the new graves are being discovered. A transparent and impartial investigation against war crimes and crimes against humanity should be started. I call on the Iraqi Government to ratify the Rome Statute and to extend its cooperation with the International Criminal Court. An international criminal tribunal should be established by the United Nations and all possible assistance from the EU guaranteed. I think those atrocities which have been committed cannot be forgotten, indeed all colleagues who have spoken before emphasised this.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group.- Mr President, dear colleagues, obviously what is happening with Christians and Yazidis is absolutely abominable.I just want to recall that under Saddam Hussein or even under Assad, the Christian minority - I know it well - lived in peace.Need we recall that since 1991, three million deaths in Iraq are due to Western intervention?Should we also remember that since September 11, two million people have been killed, including 1.7 million as a result of our sanctions?So, I want these tears, and I suffer with Christians since, more particularly, I had a hospital in this sector, but I want to underline the hypocrisy of certain tears, because let's not forget that these countries weredestabilized by our interventions and that democracy was only a pretext.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, that is indeed the whole problem of this joint resolution, which contains excellent provisions and which, rightly, notes the horror of the situation in Iraq, in the Mosul plain, the genocide against the Yazidis, the genocide against the Christians of the East, who are the oldest inhabitants of this region, and this without any apparent cause. But - and this is the weakness of this resolution - it only addresses the symptoms - the symptoms today are the mass graves - and it goes much less back to the causes. As the previous speaker said, it must all the same be emphasized that the main cause of this situation was the chaos which resulted from Western interventions in general, American and Anglo-Saxon in particular, against regimes, of course, authoritarian, but which at least had the merit of maintaining a relative balance in this area. We wanted to attack these authoritarian regimes and in doing so we destroyed the only political force that could oppose Islamism, namely Arab nationalism. The resulting situation is chaos, hatred against the Western world, and we are, it must be said, partly responsible.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Daesh's crimes, especially against Yazidis and ethnic minorities in Iraq, are atrociously known.For our words not to remain empty, the access and work of international experts must be guaranteed, who collect evidence and data on the crimes that may be hidden in Iraqi mass graves.The risk to be averted is the cancellation of crucial evidence for a future trial, as well as the impossibility of identifying the bodies of the victims.In our recent history we have experienced genocide and in recent times, twenty years ago, we have remained helpless in the face of crimes committed on our doorstep and now we are living the plight of Aleppo with too much indifference.Yesterday we applauded the courage of two girls.From today we have the duty to do them and their people justice, which is why the debate and confrontation we are developing today is very important.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, the Yazidi military forces recently discovered another mass grave that was not yet listed as it was in an active battle zone. It showed that this horrifying story is not yet at an end. At the same time, Human Rights Watch reported that aid for these same Yazidis in the southern part of Sinjar is blocked by the Peshmerga of the KRG of President Masoud Barzani. This is consistent with what we have heard from the Yazidis ourselves. I have seen myself that so many Yazidis are in refugee camps in Iraq and they need aid. Can the Commission put serious pressure on the KDP in order to end the blocking of aid to Sinjar and to Syria? That is my question. Furthermore the continuous plundering of Isis recently hit the graveyards of the Chaldean Syriac Assyrians in Iraq. Desecration of the final resting place of human beings is widely seen as a crime. Plundering graveyards has a huge impact on living relatives, as it violates their integrity and honour. Therefore I call on the Commission to put the restoration of the graveyards into the EU aid programme after the liberation of Mosul.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I support this resolution, especially in those sections which, in principle, address the legal issues of the follow-up of the Islamic State's war crimes. I think it is very good that there are theses in the resolution such that the international community should send forensic experts to Iraq to assist in the exhumation of mass graves and to help secure evidence for subsequent court proceedings. against those who have committed these crimes against humanity. Equally important are those parts of the resolution calling on Iraq to join the International Criminal Court to become a signatory to this international organization, because this is very important for us to be able to effectively commit crimes against humanity committed by members of the Islamic State, condemn. Equally important is the general call for the international community to judge these crimes worldwide according to the principle of the universality of criminal law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, in the twelve mass graves discovered in the Tigris region of Iraq, more than 1,700 jihadist victims are believed to be buried. It is estimated that there are hundreds more mass graves in areas under ISIS control. The number of confirmed victims that may be found in these graves is shocking, as it exceeds fifteen thousand victims. ISIS has made no attempt to cover up the massacres it has committed. On the contrary, it is constantly trying to intimidate the world by posting videos of beheadings and torture, while launching threats to the West. The terrorist threat must stop. The European Union needs to take action against both the Arab countries that support Daesh in Syria and Turkey, which also supports Daesh and helps jihadist oil smugglers. Peace and social justice must be established in the Middle East. It is an issue that concerns us all.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am distressed to learn of ongoing discoveries of new mass graves in Iraq and Syria, which provide only an indication of the terror committed by ISIS/Daesh. I wish to use this opportunity to express my condolences to all those in Iraq who have lost relatives and to those who are still suffering as a result of the crimes against humanity and war crimes committed by ISIS/Daesh and its affiliates. I am particularly alarmed at the situation of women and children in this conflict, and I urge all international bodies to act to provide for their release and safety. The protection, preservation and analysis of all mass graves in Iraq, as well as in Syria, are essential for the preservation and gathering of evidence of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide committed by ISIS/Daesh, and to hold the perpetrators of the crimes to account. Thus we must ensure that we protect said gravesites in order to prove accountability at a later date. As an EPP Christian Democrat, I want to condemn the continuous targeting, torture and murder of Christians around the world. I stand with them and it must cease.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Daesh has committed unspeakable crimes and egregious violations of human rights in Iraq. As the Iraqi security forces advance in their operation to liberate Mosul, the true scale of Daesh atrocities is becoming apparent, with the troubling discovery of new mass graves. Daesh crimes have affected all Iraqis; however, some minorities have been particularly targeted, among them the Yazidi community. We all remember those horrific moments in August 2014 with the shocking exodus of the Yazidi population from Sinjar. Nadia Murad, the United Nations Office for Drugs and Crimes Goodwill Ambassador for the dignity of survivors of human trafficking, together with Lamiya Aji Bashar, winner of the Sakharov Prize 2016, have become the voice for the voiceless victims of human trafficking not just in Iraq, but around the world. We deeply admire their courage and strong determination.  Nadia and Lamiya can count on our full support in fulfilling their tasks as peace builders and as role models for women and girls. In the EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq as well as the ISIL—Daesh threat of 16 March 2015, we put special emphasis on sexual and gender-based violence. The EU has been at the forefront of calling for the respect of the rule of law and human rights in Iraq, in particular the fundamental rights of minorities. We believe that the preservation of a multi-ethnic and multi-confessional Iraqi society is the only way to put an end to the vicious circle of violence and to promote reconciliation. It is essential to bring people to account for committing atrocities such as those that befell communities in Iraq at the hands of Daesh.  In this regard, the EU is willing to support a global campaign to bring Daesh to justice, as suggested by the UK, Belgium and Iraq, and the idea of the independent investigative commission on Daesh crimes. As we speak, reports are appearing of reprisals and executions carried out against civilians and even humanitarian workers in eastern Aleppo, by forces who claim they are fighting terrorism but are themselves spreading terror among communities they are attacking. We want to underline here that those responsible will be held accountable for their actions. Such war crimes will not be left unrecorded or unpunished and the perpetrators need to be aware of that now.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 15 December 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: In written form. - Unfortunately, the extremist group Daesh continues to systematically violate international humanitarian law and commit serious crimes against humanity. Daesh is directly responsible for the sexual enslavement of women in its territories, the use of innocent people as human shields, the use of chemical weapons against civilians, the massacre of Christians, Yazidis and other religious groups and ethnic minorities. Evidence of the atrocities committed by Daesh is the ongoing discovery of mass graves in the territories that the group until recently controlled in Iraq and Syria. In this regard, I call on the EU to assist the Iraqi authorities in promoting the country's membership of the International Criminal Court. We also need to assist in the analysis and collection of evidence of all mass graves in Iraq. This will make it possible to seek criminal liability from Daesh for the crimes committed against humanity.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing.- Today we discussed a joint motion for a resolution on mass graves in Iraq.In the resolution, we draw attention to the difficult situation in Iraq, where the so-called Islamic State is committing war crimes and crimes against humanity, as evidenced by the findings of several mass graves.We also draw attention to the unprecedented abductions of women and young girls and their abuse, as well as to the need to help all family members of victims, including logistical and psychological support.In the resolution, we express the conviction that all perpetrators of these most serious possible crimes must be brought before an international criminal court.I unreservedly condemn such violations of international humanitarian law and international rules, so I can only fully agree with the resolution tabled.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to make an announcement on behalf of my group and make a request. But first let me wish you, Mr President, and colleagues a Merry Christmas and all the best for the New Year. Our group took note yesterday that Mr Dijsselbloem announced that he would stop short-term debt relief for Greece. The reason: There are efforts in the Greek government to pay out a Christmas bonus for the poorest pensioners. We consider this measure to be completely excessive and wrong. (Loud applause) We believe that the Greek people have done immensely in the last few months and, according to the statements and data that we have, the economic conditions of the agreement with the donor countries have been exceeded. Mr President, we would ask you to bring the following request to Mr Schulz: My group would like to see an extraordinary conference of presidents. My group would like to see Mr Dijsselbloem invited there to ask him to justify himself. (Loud applause) My group thinks that he should reverse this decision. But I also ask those who disagree to arrange for this extraordinary Conference of Presidents, because we as the European Parliament have taken on a special responsibility; to accompany the implementation of the treaty with Greece. So let's really clear things up and help us to have such a meeting as soon as possible, if somehow possible, in the next week. Mr Juncker should also be asked to make an official statement on behalf of the Commission on the empirical situation in Greece and on whether Greece has fulfilled its commitments. Thank you and please convey this to the President, Mr. Schulz.(Loud applause)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr.I will forward your opinion to the Bureau of the European Parliament.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: - Mister President! In view of the upcoming holidays, I ask you to maintain the dignity of the house and to treat one another with appropriate respect. We do that too. Ladies and gentlemen! As chairman of the GUE / NGL group, I would like to support this proposal, which came from the Social Democrats. We will also write a motion afterwards and ask that a corresponding additional meeting of the group chairmen be called next week and that Mr Dijsselbloem and Mr Juncker be invited there. It cannot be that Greece is required to meet conditions that go far beyond the EU acquis. And the way we treat Greece is how we decide the future of the European Union. Like it or not, this is about the lives of people in Greece and in this Union. And whether you like it or not, it is a question of mutual solidarity. It cannot be that individual gentlemen - Mr Schäuble or others - not only want to embarrass the Greek government, but that they deprive us all of the basis so that we can act together and expand the European Union.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I would like to invite colleagues to rise in solidarity with the children and the civilians who are being slaughtered right now in Aleppo and Syria. We will ask you to convey the message to the European Council today that it is time to act, and not only to deplore, and to ask for an immediate ceasefire and access to humanitarian aid and protection of children. Colleagues, please rise. (Applause) (The House rose)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, as far as I am concerned, this is a real point of order and even two for the price of one. The first, on the basis of Article 166: President Schulz, on leaving, bequeaths us a final manifestation of his authoritarian character, because he has no title to sanction a deputy on the grounds that he has gone freely in A strange country. Rule 166 - I have it here - only allows him to sanction a member who seriously disrupts the sitting. Did Mr Voigt seriously disrupt the session? No! So Mr Schulz once again committed an excess of power. Second point of order, Mr President - and I will be very brief - on the basis of Article 141 (4) of our Rules of Procedure, which governs the relations of our institution with the Court of Justice: it is explicitly provided for in this regulation that the President must be authorized by Parliament, by the Legal Committee, before going to court or the Court of Justice. However, what happened is the following: in a dispute between the administration of this Parliament and one of our colleagues, the Parliament was dismissed from its objection of inadmissibility. In a similar dispute, which pits me against the administration of Parliament, the legal experts of Parliament claim that they will appeal. However, so far, at least as far as I know, the rapporteur of the Legal Affairs Committee, Mrs Hautala, has considered this appeal to be unnecessary. Consequently, the jurisconsults of Parliament are exceeding their powers by announcing that they are going to appeal to the Court and they are not currently allowed to do so. They are officials, they are not from Parliament; Parliament is members of Parliament, not civil servants.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.(Results and other details of the vote: see minutes)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - Mister President!If there is a request for a check, you should follow it.And if you do keep talking, you have to say exactly which vote we are taking.It just wasn't clear now.Please try again!

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, the visa waiver mechanism for third countries whose citizens need visas to enter the European Union is much more flexible after the adoption of this regulation.We also have a new supervisory system, which the Commission can launch immediately and in a very short time.The reasons for suspending visas have expanded and I will mention some of the new reasons now introduced by this vote: the rapid and significant increase in the number of people staying illegally in the European Union, as well as unfounded asylum applications from their citizens.countries that have received visa waivers, risks and imminent threats to public order and the internal security of countries and Member States respectively.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I supported this proposal because it is really about implementing a more flexible and actionable visa policy.I would like to comment in particular on the issue of Ukraine and Georgia, because it was also very tended in plenary.I would like to point out that this is not a visa waiver at this time.The mechanism set out in the draft makes it possible for these two countries to be reassigned to a group where visa liberalization will take place more quickly.But it will not be until February on the basis of our next meeting, where we will possibly vote on this matter.It has already been written in the Czech Republic that the visa requirement has been abolished for Ukraine and Georgia.That has not been the case yet, but I look forward to being able to support these two states in the next vote as well

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The following report aims to implement a visa-free suspension system and reintroduce the visa requirement for third-country nationals entering Europe, even if only for short periods.Although the mechanism already exists, it is considered too complicated to be activated, hence the need to introduce a new one that is less complicated and easier to apply.Since I believe that the implementation of the proposed mechanism may prove useful in future visa waivers, I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against the visa suspension mechanism.I consider that mobility is a right of all people, which is why we not only reject the policies of Fortress Europe, but I have also supported the visa liberalizations that have been carried out.With this mechanism, the aim is to create a tool to restrict this visa freedom that is not very transparent, and which is also subject to the decision of only one of the two parties participating in the agreement.I reject that visas become a weapon of pressure and blackmail with which the Union can conduct foreign policy and that is why I have opposed it.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the proposal on third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas or whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (review of the suspension mechanism). Visa policy is an essential element of the European Union, affecting both external action and internal security. Changes in the political and migration situation have made it necessary to review the visa waiver mechanism in order to make it more favorable and flexible, while enabling the EU to respond to various specific circumstances arising from: a significant and sudden increase in the number of illegally staying third-country nationals; an increase in the number of unfounded applications for asylum from third-country nationals; threats to security on European territory. At the same time, it must be borne in mind that the reintroduction of the visa requirement for third-country nationals is one of the strictest possible policy measures that can be taken. I agree that this measure must go hand in hand with strong guarantees and the protection of human rights, including on the basis of statistical reports from European agencies and the competent forces and law enforcement agencies. This will guarantee the rights of third-country nationals and guarantee the application of the principles of Community visa policy. 2013 December 11 Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council The amendments to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 set out key aspects, such as the visa waiver mechanism, which is now being amended.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - The report adopted concerns the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the regulation on the list of third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement for crossing the external borders of the Member States and the list of third countries nationals whose exemption is exempt (revision of the suspension mechanism). A large majority of members of all political groups supported this agreement. I personally voted in favor of the above proposal, as this change will give Parliament a greater role in the visa waiver process.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- The European Union wishes to revise the European visa suspension mechanism for entering the Union.The aim is to make it easier to reinstate visa requirements in the event of a "peak in immigration".The European Union thus wishes to reassure public opinion, but its real objective lies elsewhere: it wants to give illusory guarantees to pass the abolition of visas for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.While we should be protected from the migratory wave by restoring controls at our national borders, the Union is doing the opposite by opening its borders even further.I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution is part of a larger package on visas which looks to bring in a number of changes over time that will give the Commission more powers over visa implementation rules. I do not believe the Commission should wield such power, as it should belong to individual Member States. Therefore, I voted against this resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text, because I believe that the Commission should be asked to apply reciprocity in matters of visa exemption between the Union and the United States and the Union andCanada.Following the notification of non-reciprocity in April 2014, the Commission should have suspended the visa waiver for citizens of these two countries from April 2016.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I approved this report, which reviews the mechanism for suspending visa waivers for nationals of certain countries. The activation of this mechanism may be requested by a Member State or the Commission itself in the event of a sudden and significant increase in the number of migrants from a third country and in an irregular situation, an influx of asylum applications. unfounded on the part of third-country nationals, less cooperation from a third country in matters of readmission requests and, hence, in cases of increased risk or imminent threat to public order or national security. The Commission will have to examine the request of the Member State concerned and render its decision in the context of a delegated act, which will require numerous consultations and a careful study of the situation. The European Parliament will also play a role, which was not the case before. He will be constantly informed by the Commission and may reject any proposal for an extension of the temporary suspension period made by the Commission.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - This Regulation amends Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001 which lists the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from this obligation. Since 2013 there has been a provision by virtue of which the Commission may establish a suspension mechanism for this "visa waiver" status. This report aims to strengthen this mechanism, making it easier and "flexible". Although some of our amendments have been taken into account when drafting the text in the Civil Liberties committee, regarding the protection of Human Rights, very problematic aspects remain, such as "the greatest risk or imminent threat to public policy or the internal security of the Member States related to the nationals of that third country ”and the substantial increase in“ denied readmission requests ”as a reason to activate the mechanism, which gives it a level of discretion and coercion with respect to the third country involved. , respectively. In the negotiations with the Council and the Commission, (trilogue) the text intensified, in line with the "fortress" Europe that I reject. For this reason, I have voted against.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I want to thank the rapporteur, Mr Díaz de Mera, for his work on this report on third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement or exempt from that obligation with the review of the suspension mechanism.The evolution of the political and migration situation, especially in light of the successive visa liberalization processes, makes it necessary to review the suspension mechanism to make it more agile and flexible, as well as to provide us with elements that allow the Union to respond to circumstancesarising from sudden and substantial increases of third-country nationals residing irregularly in EU territory, unsubstantiated asylum applications from third-country nationals, denied readmission requests or threats to security on European territory.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- This report concerns third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa obligation or exempt from this obligation with revision of the suspension mechanism.The EU therefore wants to revise this visa suspension mechanism for entering the Union.The aim is to make it easier to reinstate the obligation in the event of a "peak of immigration".The EU wants to give illusory guarantees to pass the visa suspension for Ukrainians and Georgians and to reassure public opinion in fact.The reality is that we need a real policy to fight immigration at our national borders and I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- Despite some positive aspects in this report, I do not agree with what are, in practice, the current developments in the management of immigration at European level and the geopolitical situation in the Eastern Partnership, which is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I supported this agreement reached with the Council to strengthen the mechanism for suspending visa waiver agreements with third countries in order to facilitate their suspension when a 'substantial' increase in the number of their nationals in an irregular situation in the Union is detected European Union, in the event of non-cooperation by the States of origin in the readmission of immigrants in an irregular situation or when there is a substantial increase in the risk to the security of the Member States or their public order. These new provisions will reduce reference periods and deadlines, from six to two months the period to verify the problems that allow the suspension with respect to the situation the year before or before the visa liberalization. The suspension mechanism can also be activated by the European Commission and not only by the Member States, as it has been until now. Furthermore, the agreement introduces a monitoring mechanism with the aim of ensuring that third countries for whose nationals visas are abolished continue to meet the criteria that they had to meet for this. The Commission shall submit annual reports to the Member States and to this Parliament confirming that they continue to meet the conditions.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (review of the suspension mechanism). Visa policy is an essential element of the European Union, affecting both external action and internal security. It is so important that it is made clear that in the field of legislation, the co-legislators share competences under the ordinary legislative procedure. The reciprocity mechanism, which replaces the suspension mechanism, was amended by the Interinstitutional Agreement, the legality of which was extended in 2015. July 16 confirmed by the Court of Justice of the EU. This ruling of the Court laid the foundations for the proper use of delegated and implementing acts, thus ensuring an institutional balance. Changes in the political and migration situation, in particular in the light of recent visa liberalization processes, have made it necessary to review the visa waiver mechanism in order to make it more favorable and flexible. Of course, elements need to be ensured to enable the EU to respond to various special circumstances. However, this flexibility must go hand in hand with strong guarantees and human rights safeguards, as well as statistical reporting by European agencies and competent forces and law enforcement agencies. Only in this way will it be possible to guarantee the rights of third-country nationals and guarantee the application of the principles of Community visa policy.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - At today's Strasbourg plenary session, MEPs voted on a report on the simplification of the visa liberalization and visa waiver suspension mechanism. According to the report, "the suspension mechanism will become simpler and faster, but progress can also be made on visa-free travel for Ukraine and Georgia". It is important that the granting of visa-free travel to Ukraine and Georgia strengthens cultural and economic cooperation with the neighboring countries of the European Union. As early as last December, the European Commission found that Ukraine met the criteria of the Visa Liberalization Action Plan (VLAP), but the introduction of visa-free travel is still pending. Ukraine began work in 2008 to meet and fulfill the conditions for visa-free travel, so it is legitimate for the EU to lift the visa requirement for its citizens as soon as possible and to allow them to enter the EU in a dignified manner, in line with their reform efforts. recognition.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on third countries whose nationals must have a visa or are exempt from this requirement.I see the agreement reached as the main success of the Report, in which the European Parliament has an important role to play in suspending the visa regime.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- The European Union wishes to revise the European visa suspension mechanism for entering the Union.The aim is to make it easier to re-establish visa requirements in the event of a "peak in immigration".The European Union thus wishes to reassure public opinion.But its real objective is elsewhere: it wants to give illusory guarantees to push through the abolition of visas for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.While we should be protected from the migratory wave by restoring controls at our national borders, the Union is doing the opposite by opening its borders even further.I vote against this text.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing.- Visa policy is a key issue for the European Union and has implications for both external action and internal security.It is by virtue of its importance that it is clearly regulated as an area of shared competence between the co-legislators through the ordinary procedure.Although the demand for greater security by European citizens is understandable and correct, the increased flexibility in visa suspension procedures must nevertheless be accompanied by a solid set of guarantees and measures aimed at protecting human rights, as well as reports and statistics.provided by European agencies and competent law enforcement authorities.This is the only way to guarantee the rights of third country nationals and to safeguard the principles of the EU visa policy.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - Visa policy is a key issue for the European Union, with repercussions for both external action and internal security. Its importance is so great that its treatment is clearly regulated as a competence shared between the co-legislators through the ordinary legislative procedure. Amendment of Regulation (EC) no. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 adopted by the European Parliament and the Council on 11 December 2013 introduced substantive elements, such as the "suspension mechanism", the amendment of which is referred to in this report, without forgetting the amendment of the reciprocity mechanism as a way to this first element. I spoke in favor of this report, taking into account the evolution of the political situation and migration, in particular in view of the successive visa liberalization procedures, which lead to a revision of the suspension mechanism, in order to make it more flexible.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The visa liberalization policy is an important part of the Union's foreign policy.It is therefore essential to update this policy to adapt it to the new challenges facing the European Union today.This is all the more true as discussions on visa liberalization are currently underway, notably with Ukraine, Georgia, Kosovo and Turkey.For these reasons, a revision of the suspension mechanism, in order to make it more flexible, was necessary.Now, several cases will lead to a reintroduction of the visa requirement for third-country nationals: when there is a sudden and consequent increase in irregular immigration, unfounded asylum requests, too many rejection of requests forreadmission or in the event of a threat to security in the territory of the Union.I voted in favor of revising the readmission mechanism.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: written.- I have abstained in the final vote on this report because the proposed regulation modifies another regulation in which Kosovo is recognized as a sovereign state.I cannot accept the sovereignty of a State whose independence has been unilaterally declared, something not recognized by a large number of countries, including Spain.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of changing the regulation in question which will make the visa suspension mechanism faster and more flexible. Visa policy is a key issue for the European Union due to the repercussions it has on both external action and internal security. The current level of migration, particularly in light of the subsequent visa liberalization processes, required a revision of the suspension mechanism. The approved regulation will equip the European Union with valid tools to cope with various circumstances, such as unfounded asylum applications, the refusal of readmission applications or the substantial and sudden increases in the number of irregular immigrants in the European territory. But the increased flexibility will be accompanied by a solid set of safeguards and measures to protect human rights, as well as reports and statistics provided by European agencies and competent law enforcement authorities. This is the only way to guarantee, at the same time, the rights of third-country nationals and to safeguard the principles of the Union's visa policy.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this file which is aimed at giving the Commission suspension powers over visas granted to third country nationals on bases beyond their competence.  This file would permit the Commission to suspend when nationals of the country concerned are found to be illegally overstaying in Member States, there is an increase in ‘unfounded’ asylum applications, the third country rejects readmission applications from the EU, there is ‘decreased cooperation on readmission’ from the third country, delays in issuing travel documents or refusing to accept EU travel documents and if there is a ‘substantial increase of serious criminal offences’ related to that third country. For all these reasons and the fact that this constitutes a blatant power-grab by the Commission on matters of national competence, I rejected the report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Visa policy is a crucial matter for the European Union, with repercussions for both external action and internal security. As we have witnessed in the last months, developments in the political and migratory situation, particularly in the light of successive visa liberalisation processes, make it necessary to revise the suspension mechanism to make it faster and more flexible. There is no doubt that we need to provide ourselves with the tools that will enable the EU to respond to circumstances, which all have their own specific features. This increased flexibility must nevertheless be accompanied by a robust set of guarantees and measures to protect human rights, along with reports and statistics supplied by the European Agencies and the competent law enforcement authorities. This is the only way of guaranteeing the rights of third-country citizens and safeguarding the principles of the Community visa policy. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The aim of the review is to facilitate and make more practical the activation of the visa waiver suspension mechanism and the reintroduction of the visa requirement for third country nationals traveling to Europe for short-term stays.The compromise reached by the institutions involves two stages: in the first stage, lasting nine months, an implementing act will be used to reintroduce the visa requirement for certain categories of people.During this first phase, the Commission will open a dialogue with the country concerned.After these nine months have passed without consequences for the dialogue with the country concerned, the Commission adopts a delegated act to reintroduce the visa requirement for all citizens.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and I welcome this much needed agreement on visa liberalisation with Ukraine and Georgia. It was about time for us to send the positive signal to both countries that the EU counts on them and keeps its word. Especially, in the case of Ukraine, we really need to show Ukrainians that the EU is not letting them down. If we did it, I am sure someone else would be more than happy to use this opportunity. I am glad we understand that and we are able to move forward on another level of partnership with these countries.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and consider that visa policy is a key issue for the European Union, with an impact on both external action and internal security.Precisely because of its importance, it is clearly regulated as an area of joint competence between the co-legislators in the ordinary procedure.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the report amending Regulation (EC) No. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 on the list of third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement for crossing the external borders of the Member States and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempted from this obligation (revision of the suspension mechanism). As I consider that this report contains anachronistic and disproportionate proposals that burden the citizens, while at the same time not meeting the European ideals, I voted against it.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- The main objective of this report is to modify the visa suspension and waiver mechanism.The positive aspects of the proposal relate to the increased conditions under which the visa requirement can be reintroduced.However, the European management of immigration and the current geopolitical situation do not allow us to support this relationship.Voting of abstention.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (revision of the suspension mechanism).

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The approval of this suspension mechanism will contribute to greater security, allowing the suspension of the exemption in the event of a substantial increase in irregular stays. As well, this suspension will also be possible in the case of disrespect for human rights in the third state. Equally important is the greater flexibility of the mechanism, providing greater and faster reaction capacity. Thus also reinforcing the role of the common European visa policy in the context of the Union's foreign policy. The commitment reached with the Council with regard to the role of the European Parliament should also be highlighted. In fact, not only was the interinstitutional equality in this matter confirmed by the Court of Justice, but the legitimacy of this institution in the application of such a severe instrument with evident repercussions in the Union is evident. By guaranteeing the use of delegated acts in more prolonged cases of suspension, the rapporteur has struck a good balance with the - initially - irreducible position of Member States.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the measure as political and migratory developments, in particular in the light of the subsequent visa liberalization processes, require a review of the suspension mechanism to make it faster and more flexible.However, the increased flexibility must be accompanied by a solid set of safeguards and measures aimed at protecting human rights, as well as the development of reports and statistics provided by European agencies and competent law enforcement authorities.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the new mechanism to suspend the visa-free regime for third countries in cases of emergencies or abuse of the system. This mechanism will allow a quicker reaction to crises, while ensuring that the suspension would still be used by Member States as a last resort. To ensure democratic legitimacy the European Parliament must be consulted to prolong the suspension after the first period of nine months. Now that the new suspension mechanism has been adopted, I call on the Council to adopt right away a visa-free regime for Ukraine and Georgia, as they already fulfilled all the benchmarks months ago. We need to show that there are no double standards for the people of Ukraine and Georgia. It is about the EU’s credibility!

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against the visa suspension mechanism.I believe that mobility is a right of all people, so I not only reject the policies of Fortress Europe, but I have also supported the visa liberalizations that have been carried out.With this mechanism, the aim is to create a tool to restrict this visa freedom that is not very transparent, and which is also subject to the decision of only one of the two parties participating in the agreement.I reject that visas become a weapon of pressure and blackmail with which the Union can conduct foreign policy and that is why I have opposed it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - In the context of the regulation listing third countries whose citizens must be in possession of a visa - when crossing the external borders of the Member States - and third countries whose nationals are exempt from this obligation, the mechanism for the suspension which allows to temporarily suspend the exemption from the visa requirement for third-country nationals in certain emergency situations. In line with this resolution, I support the revision of the suspension mechanism so that it is easier and quicker for Member States to notify the circumstances leading to the activation of the suspension mechanism. However, this flexibility must be accompanied by a set of safeguards to protect the human rights of third country nationals, as the imposition of the visa requirement is a very severe political measure, although necessary in some circumstances. In fact, I believe that the need of Member States to address the challenges in terms of security and the number of irregular residents in the EU territory must go hand in hand with the protection of the fundamental rights of third country nationals.

name: Andi CRISTEA
