text: signed up.- Visa policy is a key issue for the European Union, with repercussions for both external action and internal security.Developments in the political situation and migration, in particular in view of the successive visa liberalization procedures, make it necessary to revise the suspension mechanism in order to make it more flexible and flexible.We need to have the elements at our disposal to enable the EU to respond to circumstances with different particularities.I voted in favor of changing this mechanism, which must be more flexible and accompanied by a solid set of guarantees and the protection of human rights.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council. That regulation was amended once, in 2013, to introduce important factors such as the so-called 'suspension mechanism', which has itself been amended. Visa policy is a key issue for the European Union, as it is a key part of the Union's foreign policy and also has an impact on ensuring internal security. The 2013 amendment to the regulation introduced the so-called “suspension mechanism”, which allows, in certain emergencies, the temporary suspension of a visa waiver for third-country nationals as a last resort. The purpose of the current amendment is to strengthen the suspension mechanism by making it easier for Member States to notify the circumstances leading to a possible suspension and by allowing the Commission to activate the mechanism on its own initiative. It makes the whole system faster and more flexible. The visa waiver may be suspended if there is a significant and sudden increase in the number of irregular third-country nationals staying in the EU, the number of unfounded asylum applications lodged by third-country nationals or if the third country does not cooperate in the field of readmission. However, increased flexibility must be accompanied by a solid set of guarantees and measures to protect human rights.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (amendment to the suspension mechanism). I believe that the compromise reached in the negotiations on the changes serves to strengthen the strategy related to the migration policy. EU visa policy is a fundamental policy area of ​​the European Union with implications for both external action and internal security. The mechanism suspending the visa procedures needs to be changed in order to make it more effective and flexible. This will allow the EU to respond to the specific circumstances arising from a sudden and significant increase in the influx of third-country nationals staying illegally in the EU, as well as unfounded asylum applications and rejected readmission applications. In order to ensure that the rights of third-country nationals are respected and the principles of the common visa policy are respected, a robust set of guarantees should be established, as well as a system of reporting and statistics provided by the European agency and by the competent law enforcement authorities.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Developments in the political and migratory situation, particularly in light of successive visa liberalisation processes, make it necessary to revise the suspension mechanism to make it more flexible. Pertinent circumstances include substantial and sudden increases in the number of third-country nationals residing irregularly in EU territory; unfounded asylum applications from nationals of that third country; rejected readmission applications and threats to security in European territory. I am in favour of this report, as visa policy is a crucial matter for the European Union for both external action and internal security.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This legislative report concerns the reintroduction of a visa requirement by the Member States for third country nationals hitherto exempt from visa.This measure applies to nationals of Georgia and Ukraine, and responds to the exceptional situation facing Member States, namely the substantial increase in irregular immigration and security risks.This suspension could apply in the event of a significant increase in the number of Georgian or Ukrainian nationals being refused entry, or staying illegally in the territory of the Union.This flexibility instrument should enable Member States to ensure better management of migratory flows and to strengthen security on European territory, while guaranteeing respect for human rights;I therefore voted in favor of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing. - I supported the revision of the suspension mechanism within the framework of the regulation allowing the liberalization of visas with third countries. This mechanism had never been activated since 2013 due to the rigidity of the criteria and the complexity of the procedure. By re-establishing a more flexible visa waiver suspension mechanism, the European Union has finally abandoned its policy of unconditional liberalization. It will now be equipped with the necessary tools to be able to effectively temporarily restore the visa obligation for third-country nationals in the event of sudden spikes in irregular immigration, unfounded asylum applications, failure to cooperation with the European Union on readmissions or in the event of a threat to public order or internal security linked to nationals of the third country concerned. While the current discussions concerning new visa liberalizations, in particular with Turkey, but also Georgia, Kosovo and Ukraine, raise many concerns given the migration and security issues, we had to ensure the proper functioning of the mechanism.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the modification of the regulation establishing the list of third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States and the list of those whose nationals are exemptof this obligation.The proposals made by the European Parliament aim to ensure internal security through appropriate and effective measures, for example by reintroducing the visa obligation for third-country nationals in specific cases: peak of irregular immigration, requests forunfounded asylum, or failure to cooperate with the European Union.I welcome the compromise that has been found and which offers solutions to respond more appropriately to emergency situations.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- I am in favor of making the suspension mechanism quicker and more flexible in order to manage migratory flows entering the EU and security on European territory more effectively.However, I hope that greater flexibility will be accompanied by a set of guarantees aimed at protecting the human rights of third-party citizens and safeguarding the principles of EU visa policy.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposed revision of the regulation on the visa suspension mechanism. Since 2001, the Union has pursued a visa liberalization policy with many countries. It therefore has a common list of countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa to cross the borders of the Union and a list of countries whose nationals are exempt from this obligation. This review proposal is linked to the proposals to offer visa-free access to the EU to Georgia, Ukraine and Kosovo. Visa liberalization for an increasing number of countries makes it necessary to put in place a temporary visa reinstatement mechanism. It can happen, in fact, that the visa waiver leads to such a massive influx of third-country nationals that it becomes difficult to control. Security considerations may also have the effect of reintroducing certain forms of control, in particular through the reinstatement of visas. In reality, the visa liberalization policy and the temporary visa reinstatement mechanism are two complementary sides of a responsible policy for access to Union territory.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This is the review of the European mechanism for suspending visas for entering the Union, with the aim of facilitating the reinstatement of the visa requirement in the event of a "peak in immigration".In reality, it is a question of granting illusory guarantees preliminary to the abolition of visas planned for Ukrainians and Georgians.We are therefore opposed to this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - The development of the political situation and the migration situation, especially in the light of the forthcoming visa liberalization processes, requires a review of the suspension mechanism, with a view to increasing its speed and flexibility. There is a clear need for elements to enable the EU to respond to circumstances. This flexibility should be accompanied by robust human rights guarantees and measures, as well as reports and statistics provided by European agencies and competent security forces and bodies. Only in this way can the rights of third-country nationals be guaranteed and the principles of the Community visa policy be protected. That is why I voted in favor of the report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- What is urgently needed, due to the increased flow of illegal immigrants, extremists and members of transnational organized crime, is not the temporary suspension of the visa waiver for third-country nationals.The Community list needs to be completely abolished.Each Member State will decide which third-country nationals can be exempted from the visa requirement.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing external borders and those whose nationals are exempt. The revision is not needed, and the threat to end the visa waiver when there are no asylum seekers in the third country does not comply with the right to asylum as an individual right. I am working to make Wales a true country of sanctuary.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The proposal aims to revise the mechanism for restoring visa requirements for third-country nationals under certain conditions, such as in the event of a substantial increase in irregular migration.The new rules aim to make the suspension mechanism faster and more flexible, enabling a faster reaction by the Member States and the Commission.The new rules facilitate the notification by Member States of the circumstances leading to a possible suspension of visas and allow the Commission to launch this mechanism on its own initiative.Possible grounds for suspension are extended to include a decrease in cooperation on readmission (return of migrants) and a substantial increase in risks to public order or internal security.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: the European Union wishes to revise the European visa suspension mechanism for entering the Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing.- This report proposes to amend Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement when crossing external borders and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (ReviewSuspension Mechanism).This revision of the suspension mechanism is a response to the refugee humanitarian crisis and enshrines the intention of blackmail and pressure on third countries.If your migration policies do not match and align with the criminal policies of European Union migration, then the obligation remains in force.Either those countries accept EU policies, namely in terms of the return policy, or they may see limited obtaining short-stay visas for citizens of their country to access the EU.Unacceptable.We obviously voted against it.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against this report, as what is urgently needed, due to the increased flow of illegal immigrants, extremists and members of transnational organized crime, is not the temporary suspension of the visa waiver for third-country nationals.The Community list needs to be completely abolished.Each Member State will decide which third-country nationals can be exempted from the visa requirement.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that, after difficult negotiations, we have reached an agreement under which both Member States and the European Commission will be able to trigger the suspension mechanism. The Commission will be in charge of monitoring the situation in visa-exempt countries and reporting to Parliament and the Council on whether they still fulfil visa waiver conditions, such as respect for human rights. We reached a deal where the European Parliament could have an important role in suspending the visa waiver of a certain country while deblocking the related visa liberalisation files with important countries and partners, such as Georgia and Ukraine. Finally, the European Parliament will play an important role when it comes to re-imposing visa requirements.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) no. 539/2001 of the Council which adopts the list of third countries whose citizens must be in possession of a visa when crossing the external borders and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from this obligation (revision of the suspension) because, in the light of the significant migratory flows from third countries, it is necessary to revise the regulation on visa liberalization. I am convinced that the revision of the visa liberalization suspension mechanism for third country nationals must go hand in hand with the protection of individual rights and that a truthful and objective analysis of the data collected with respect to the applications submitted is the only way viable to protect and guarantee the rights of every individual and safeguard the principles of European migration policy. The political developments of migration need a strong involvement of the European Parliament which must be the protagonist in the definition of EU standards. The Court's ruling, therefore, which puts the two co-legislators on an equal footing is good.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The aim is to accelerate the suspension of the visa exemption and make it more flexible.New instruments should be able to respond effectively to sudden and irregular increases in the number of third-country nationals.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because the included changes are seen as cushioning part of a much bigger and rather controversial proposal to conclude visa-free travel agreements with Ukraine and Georgia.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - Despite a promising title, I voted against this report, which aims to reform the procedure for reinstating the visa requirement for nationals of countries which, until then, were exempt. It is in fact planned to facilitate this recovery in the event of massive immigration, unfounded asylum requests, rejected readmission requests or threats to security on European territory. The facts cited must be duly substantiated and proven, the protection of human rights guaranteed. Thus, by the rapporteur's own admission, it is above all a question of protecting the rights of citizens of third countries and of continuing to expand the list of countries whose nationals are exempt from visas. For the record, the Commission is preparing to grant this exemption to Ukrainians and Georgians, and Angela Merkel has promised Erdoğan the same for the Turks, although this promise is encountering some delays, which will soon be overcome. Rather than knowing how to react, badly and too late, to the foreseeable migratory consequences of this crazy European policy, I would rather stop visa liberalization immediately. Otherwise, this report is mostly window dressing.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - This Regulation amends Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001 which lists the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from this obligation. Since 2013 there has been a provision by virtue of which the Commission may establish a suspension mechanism for this "visa waiver" status. This report aims to strengthen this mechanism, making it easier and "flexible". Although some of our amendments have been taken into account when drafting the text in the Civil Liberties committee, regarding the protection of Human Rights, very problematic aspects remain, such as "the greatest risk or imminent threat to public policy or the internal security of the Member States related to the nationals of that third country ”and the substantial increase in“ denied readmission requests ”as a reason to activate the mechanism, which gives it a level of discretion and coercion with respect to the third country involved. , respectively. In the negotiations with the Council and the Commission, (trilogue) the text intensified, in line with the "fortress" Europe that I reject. For this reason, I have voted against.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: in writing.- On December 15, we voted in favor of putting in place an "emergency brake" in the visa waiver of citizens of third countries.The revision of the suspension mechanism allows the European Commission and the Member States to temporarily suspend the visa exemption granted to nationals of certain third countries, while respecting human rights, for the following reasons: substantial increase inirregular migrants from these countries, increase in unfounded asylum requests, restriction of cooperation on readmissions, or imminent threat to general European public order.More flexibility of this existing mechanism was necessary, and that is why I voted in favor of revising this mechanism.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - The visa suspension mechanism makes it possible to suspend the visa exemption granted to nationals of certain third countries in very specific cases (threat to internal security, non-compliance with the criteria used for visa liberalization - in particular violation of human rights). Today, I voted in favor of revising this mechanism because, even though the negotiations on this text were difficult, they resulted in each of the institutions now having a say in the triggering of this mechanism. , when Parliament was initially completely excluded from this process. Parliament will therefore have a full place to control that there is no abuse of the visa suspension mechanism. Finally, the closure of this file is one more step towards the liberalization of visas for Georgia and Ukraine, files which have been blocked for too long pending this review.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this visa requirement. Visa policy is a crucial matter for the European Union, with repercussions for both external action and internal security. It is because of its importance that it is clearly regulated as an area of shared competence between the co-legislators through the ordinary procedure.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - I am delighted that Parliament has supported the strengthening of the suspension mechanism in the context of visa liberalization. The mechanism existing since 2013 had never been activated due to the rigidity of the criteria and the complexity of the procedure. Since then, the European and international situation has evolved and we absolutely had to adapt our instruments to these new realities. Terrorist threats and migratory waves are challenges that Europe cannot face by unconditionally liberalizing visas with a vengeance. We have seen, after the agreement with Albania, an increase in the number of its nationals in an irregular situation on French territory. But visa waiver is not the same as an unlimited entry ticket! This is why, from now on, the suspension clause can be triggered in the event of a substantial increase in the number of nationals of a country concerned, in the number of unfounded asylum applications or in the absence of cooperation on readmissions. These restrictions may also apply in the event of threats to public order or internal security linked to the nationals of the third countries concerned. We must put an end to the abuses, especially as further liberalizations are planned with Georgia and Ukraine.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) no.539/2001 on the list of third countries whose nationals must have a visa when crossing external borders and countries whose nationals are exempt from this requirement (revision of the suspension mechanism) because I consider that visa policy affects the EU's external action and internal security and is one of the keytheme.Due to the development of the political and migration situation, the suspension mechanism needs to be revised to make the EU more flexible and flexible, especially after a significant increase in the number of third-country nationals in the EU, many asylum applications, security threats, etc., as the Report itself dictates, the said increase in flexibility should be accompanied by a set of guarantees and the protection of human rights above all.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- By wishing to reassure public opinion by revising the European visa suspension mechanism and better manage immigration peaks, the European Union wants above all to push through the abolition of visas for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.The final objective is therefore contrary to its promise: for the Union, it is a question of opening wider borders, which it nevertheless has the duty to protect more than ever.I voted against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ Visa liberalisation is a valuable political tool for the EU, which also offers significant advantages for citizens of the third countries concerned. At the same time, for the security of EU citizens, we need an efficient mechanism to avoid any abuse. This upgraded suspension mechanism makes it easier to alert the Commission about irregularities and emergencies that could justify a reintroduction of visa requirements. The Council made this agreement a prerequisite for approving new liberalisation agreements, such as those with Georgia and Ukraine. Both countries have made enormous efforts to reform and fulfil our criteria; it is up to us now to deliver and be a reliable partner. Parliament is more than ready, Member States should not delay the talks anymore.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which reforms the mechanism for suspending visa exemptions to make it faster and thus facilitate the exemptions currently under discussion, in particular with Ukraine and Georgia.We are introducing an emergency brake that can be triggered in the event of strong migratory pressure from a country benefiting from visa exemption, or in the face of a lack of cooperation from the country in terms of the readmission of its nationals or irregular migrants.having passed through its territory before joining the European Union.Visas could also be reintroduced if public order or internal security were threatened and if these threats were linked to nationals of the third country concerned.This text therefore makes it possible to reconcile free movement with the need for security and control of our European borders.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- This report concerns the revision of the visa waiver suspension mechanism.The rapporteur calls for the whole Commission proposal to be revised and confirms that the suspension should only apply to certain categories of third country nationals and that implementing powers for the suspension should be conferred on the Commission.This is unsatisfactory, as a suspension of the mechanism is only requested if the recognition rate of asylum applications is less than three percent.In 2016 alone, the recognition rate in Austria, for example, was 47.6 percent.I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - The report aims to strengthen the suspension mechanism for visa-free travel to the EU. The Commission would be in a position to suspend the visa-free entry of citizens of individual third countries itself if it were asked to do so by member states. A visa requirement increases the transaction costs of individual citizens, but at the same time ensures that immigration into the social systems through free entry is made more difficult. When a third country's visa requirement is lifted, a suspension mechanism is important in order to be able to react quickly in the event of a crisis by lifting the visa waiver. I am convinced that the report will make it easier for many citizens of third countries to enter the EU and that it will have a positive impact on tourism and the economy within the EU. At the same time, the EU can react quickly and suspend the existing visa exemption if there is an increase in the number of unwanted entries. For these reasons I voted in favor of the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Since 2013 there is a provision by which a mechanism could be put in place to suspend the ‘visa-free’ status by the Commission for a period of six months. Any Member States may trigger this suspension mechanism. I voted against this report because the Commission is using this mechanism as a migration tool and even tries to make it easier to implement the mechanism.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- The usual EU operating pattern can be observed in this proposal and in the process leading to its creation.So: ignore all early signals, threatening signs and do nothing.If the problem unfolds, try to make it minor through the press.If that’s not taken up by the public after all, then you’ll get to make some kind of legislation.Then sit back contentedly, as who would dare to vote against anything that is a solution, even if only a fraction of the problem.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal for temporary suspension of the visa exemption for the nationals of a third country for a short period of time, as a matter of urgency and on the basis of well-defined criteria, to solve possible difficulties faced by one or several Member States. In particular, I welcome the proposal that both EU Member States and the Commission will be able to trigger the visa waiver suspension mechanism in one or more of the following cases: a substantial increase in the number of nationals of the country are refused entry to or stay irregularly in EU territory, a substantial increase in unfounded asylum applications and a decrease in cooperation on readmissions (returns of migrants). I strongly believe that the approval of the suspension mechanism will not have a negative effect on the agreement that paved the way for visa waivers to Georgia and Ukraine.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- This regulation introduces criteria to help stem the distortions resulting from the implementation of the EU visa policy.Through the adoption of measures of immediate application, the European Commission will be able to temporarily stop the granting of short-term visas in the event that the application is not consistent with the potential for eligibility.In particular, I am gratified by the fact that the European Parliament obtained during the negotiation phase the derogation according to which, if the suspension of visas for a particular country is necessary for a period of more than 18 months, the same must be applied through theadoption of delegated acts.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report, which aims to give illusory guarantees (possibility of requiring visas) to push through the abolition of visas for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which facilitates the implementation of the visa waiver suspension mechanism. This "emergency brake" makes it possible to reinstate the visa obligation for third countries which are exempt from it, in the event of a substantial increase in the number of nationals of a country concerned, in the number of unfounded asylum requests or lack of cooperation on readmissions. These restrictions may also apply in the event of a threat to public order or internal security linked to nationals of the countries concerned. This simplification of the procedure will allow full application of the mechanism, which has not been activated since 2013. It is important that we can use it quickly and effectively, in view of security and migration issues, and in particular given the discussions initiated with a number of countries (Turkey, Georgia, Kosovo, Ukraine) requesting visa liberalization for their nationals.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against this report because it uses security arguments to make it difficult for third-country nationals to move to Europe, even in the case of asylum seekers, which represents a serious violation of fundamental rights.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written. - The report aims to strengthen the suspension mechanism for visa-free travel to the EU. The Commission would be in a position to suspend the visa-free entry of citizens of individual third countries itself if it were asked to do so by member states. A visa requirement increases the transaction costs of individual citizens, but at the same time ensures that immigration into the social systems through free entry is made more difficult. When a third country's visa requirement is lifted, a suspension mechanism is important in order to be able to react quickly in the event of a crisis by lifting the visa waiver. I am convinced that the report will make it easier for many citizens of third countries to enter the EU and that it will have a positive impact on tourism and the economy within the EU. At the same time, the EU can react quickly and suspend the existing visa exemption if there is an increase in the number of unwanted entries. For these reasons I voted in favor of the report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- By amending Regulation (EC) no.539/2001 introduced elements such as the "suspension mechanism".Due to the development of the political situation and the situation related to migration, a revision of the suspension mechanism is needed to make it more adaptable and flexible.Elements need to be put in place to enable the EU to respond to the circumstances that have arisen as a result of the sudden and significant increase in the number of illegally staying third-country nationals on its territory.Accordingly, it is necessary to amend the suspension mechanism with regard to the application of delegated acts and to adapt it to the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union regarding the reciprocity mechanism.As both mechanisms are balanced in legislative and political terms and have similar effects, the procedures within them need to be harmonized.I believe that this is the only way to guarantee the rights of third-country nationals and to protect the principles of EU visa policy, which is why I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The Council idea to connect the visa-free regime between EU and Georgia and Ukraine with a visa suspension mechanism was a bad idea, the result of which was the unpredictable delay of the visa-free regime with those countries. Georgia and Ukraine fulfilled all the conditions and are waiting for the EU to fulfil its commitments. In politics as in business, reputation of reliable partners is very valuable thing. So the reputation of the EU in this case was seriously damaged. We will not see the negative results immediately, but in connection with other cases of arrogance and our neglectful attitude towards our partners, this will return to us like a boomerang in the future.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- In the interests of the security and public order of the Union and the Member States, it is necessary to tighten visa procedures for applicants from third countries while ensuring the protection of human rights.The Union's visa policy instruments must respond flexibly to security threats posed by unfounded asylum applications or an increased number of illegally moving third-country nationals within the Union.The Commission is required to monitor the situation in these countries and report its findings to Parliament.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No.539/2001 for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/12/2016, as well as because this report is sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.Its objective is to revise the European mechanism for suspending visas for entry into the European Union.This revision aims to implement a lever that would make it easier to restore the visa requirement in the event of a peak in immigration.Obviously, this idea is attractive.Unfortunately, the real goal is elsewhere.Indeed, it is a question of reassuring the public opinion so that the abolition of visas for the millions of Ukrainians and Georgians is voted, which we are opposed to.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- This proposal aims to review the visa waiver suspension mechanism.Since this mechanism should only come about if the recognition rate of asylum applications is less than three percent, whereby this was 47.6 percent in Austria this year, should only extend to certain groups in a third country and, on the other hand, the implementing powers to suspend and thus theI have not endorsed this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor.In the light of the migration crisis, there is a need to review the visa waiver mechanism in order to make it more favorable and flexible.This will enable the EU to respond to a variety of exceptional circumstances arising from the significant and sudden increase in the number of illegal third-country nationals residing illegally in the EU, the increase in unfounded asylum applications from third-country nationals and the threat to security in Europe.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The European Union wants to revise the mechanism for suspending the visa requirement in the event of a peak in immigration.In trying to reassure public opinion, the Union has, in fact, another objective, which is to give illusory guarantees to pass the abolition of visas for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.Considering that states should be protected from waves of migration by re-establishing border controls, I opposed this revision.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of a text concerning the suspension mechanism applicable to visa liberalization agreements.It aims to facilitate the triggering of the mechanism as well as to speed up the procedure, since the visa waiver applicable to third-country nationals must be suspended.The reasons for a suspension have also been extended.I would also like to stress the establishment of a monitoring mechanism aimed at ensuring continued compliance by third countries with the conditions which prevailed in the liberalization of visas.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which reached a deal where Parliament could have an important role in suspending the visa waiver of a certain country while deblocking the related visa liberalisation files with important countries and partners such as Georgia and Ukraine. Parliament will play an important role when it comes to re-imposing visa requirements, which is essential.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- The European Union wishes to revise the European mechanism for suspending entry visas in the Union in order to be able to restore the visa requirement more easily in the event of a peak in immigration, and thus to reassure public opinion.However, the hidden aim of this revision is to give illusory guarantees to pass visa abolition for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.While we should be protected from the migratory wave by restoring controls at our national borders, the Union is doing the opposite by opening its borders even further.We are therefore naturally opposed to this revision.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- The European Union wishes to revise the European visa suspension mechanism for entering the Union.The aim is to make it easier to re-establish visa requirements in the event of a "peak in immigration".The European Union thus wishes to reassure public opinion.But its real objective is elsewhere: it wants to give illusory guarantees to push through the abolition of visas for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.While we should be protected from the migratory wave by restoring controls at our national borders, the Union is doing the opposite by opening its borders even further.I vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text on the modification of the regulation fixing the list of third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States and the list of those whose nationals areexempt.The report aims to allow the temporary reintroduction of the visa requirement for third country nationals in the event of sudden spikes in irregular immigration, misguided asylum applications, lack of cooperation in readmissions or threats topublic order and internal security.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The visa policy is an essential subject for the European Union with effects on external action and internal security. I am in favour of this report that will revise the visa suspension mechanism to make it more up to date and flexible in order to face current political and migratory situations.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out against the report before us because it calls for the mechanism to be suspended if the recognition rate for asylum applications is less than three percent.In 2016 alone, the recognition rate in Austria was 47.6 percent.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The visa waiver regime needs to be reviewed to make it faster and more flexible.This will allow the EU to react promptly in the event of a situation that threatens, for example, EU security, or a sudden increase in the number of illegally staying third-country nationals.The review of this regime will also remove obstacles to progress in establishing visa-free travel for Ukraine and Georgia.This is important because both countries have met the necessary criteria for some time and the decision to grant them visa-free travel must be taken quickly.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The "four freedoms" are one of the fundamental ideas and the highest values ​​of the European Union. It is about the freedom of movement of goods, services, people and capital without internal borders. It is precisely the freedom of movement of people that is guaranteed by visa policy, given that it affects both external action and internal security. The management of visa policy is clearly regulated as a shared competence of the co-legislators within the ordinary legislative procedure. 2013 by amending Regulation (EC) no. 539/2001, a “suspension mechanism” has been introduced, which is intended to be amended by this proposed amendment, and the amendment of the “reciprocity mechanism” as a counterbalance to the aforementioned element must not be forgotten. Both mechanisms represent two sides of the coin, are balanced in legislative and political terms and have similar effects, and the procedures within them need to be harmonized. Due to the development of the political situation and the migration situation, especially in the light of successive visa liberalization procedures with third countries, a revision of the suspension mechanism is needed to make it more flexible and flexible. I would like to remind you that the reciprocity mechanism still does not work fully for 5 member states, including Croatia. I believe that these amendments must not prolong the adoption of a delegated act which would guarantee the same rights for the citizens of the mentioned Member States as for other EU citizens.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing.- This report proposes to amend Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement when crossing external borders and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (ReviewSuspension Mechanism).This revision of the suspension mechanism is a response to the refugee humanitarian crisis and enshrines the intention of blackmail and pressure on third countries, if their migration policies do not correspond and do not align themselves with the criminal policies of European Union migration.Either those countries accept their policies, namely in terms of return policy, or they may see limited obtaining short-stay visas for citizens of their country to access the EU.We voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - I am pleased that, after lengthy negotiations, there has been an agreement between the Council and Parliament on the new terms of the visa suspension mechanism with the EU. The updating of the suspension mechanism was, among other things, a condition for the final abolition of visa relations with Georgia or Ukraine, which is otherwise already agreed. The suspension mechanism itself makes it possible, under precisely defined conditions, to temporarily suspend visa-free travel for third-country nationals. The current wording has been criticized by the Member States for being too rigid in terms of conditions, which did not allow this instrument to be used flexibly (this is also why the suspension mechanism has never actually been launched). I am convinced that the new wording gives the EU and its Member States sufficient scope for a speedy solution in the event that visa-free travel with a given country needs to be suspended. I have long supported the launch of visa-free travel with Ukraine and Georgia, and I would like to remind you that Ukraine was promised visa-free travel in the run-up to the 2012 FIFA World Cup in 2012. I believe that the abolition of short-stay visas will make a significant contribution to . In addition, visa-free travel is only possible for people with a biometric passport. In this regard, I would like to remind you that it is far easier to obtain a fake paper visa than to forge a biometric passport, so the impact on strengthening security in the EU is also clear.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. - The main aim of this proposal is to strengthen the suspension mechanism by making it easier for Member States to notify the circumstances leading to a possible suspension and by allowing the Commission to activate the mechanism on its own initiative. The agreement reached reflects the solution between the Council and Parliament positions, based on a three-stage approach. 1) The European Commission will adopt an implementing act to temporarily suspend the visa exemption for certain categories of nationals of the third country concerned for a period of 9 months. 2) If circumstances persist during this period, the Commission will adopt a delegated act temporarily suspending the exemption from the visa requirement for all nationals of the third country concerned for a period of 18 months. 3) Before the end of the validity period of the adopted delegated act, the European Commission will submit a report to the European Parliament and the Council, which may be accompanied by a legislative proposal to amend this Regulation in order to transfer the reference to the third country in question from Annex II to Annex I. to maintain confidence in future as well as existing visa liberalization agreements. Such a standstill clause is also important as it allows for a swift response to any emergency and does not require waiting for a solution in the legislative process.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the review of the visa waiver suspension mechanism for third country nationals.In view of the current political and migratory situation, we would indeed like greater flexibility in the suspension mechanism in order to be able to temporarily reintroduce the visa requirement for third-country nationals in the event of crises linked to an increase in irregular immigration.or in the event of a threat to public order or internal security.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I supported this agreement reached with the Council to strengthen the mechanism for suspending visa waiver agreements with third countries in order to facilitate their suspension when a 'substantial' increase in the number of their nationals in an irregular situation in the Union is detected , in the event of a lack of cooperation from the States of origin in the readmission of immigrants in an irregular situation or when there is a substantial increase in the risk to the security of the Member States or their public order. These new provisions will reduce reference periods and deadlines, from six to two months the period to verify the problems that allow the suspension with respect to the situation the year before or before the visa liberalization. The suspension mechanism can also be activated by the European Commission and not only by the Member States, as it has been until now. Furthermore, the agreement introduces a monitoring mechanism with the aim of ensuring that third countries for whose nationals visas are abolished continue to meet the criteria that they had to meet for this. The Commission shall submit annual reports to the Member States and to this Parliament confirming that they continue to meet the conditions.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I welcome the adoption of this tool, which should provide more flexibility and operationality. Under the new rules, visa-free agreements with third countries may be suspended, in which case citizens of those countries will again need a visa to travel to the EU. Both Member States and the European Commission will be able to trigger the suspension mechanism. The text voted on underlines that the decision to temporarily suspend the visa exemption must be taken on the basis of "relevant and objective data". After a notification from a Member State (or a request by a simple majority of Member States), or based on its own report, the Commission will have one month to decide whether or not to suspend the visa exemption for a period of nine months. This decision will take effect automatically. The Commission will also have the task of closely monitoring the situation in the countries benefiting from visa exemptions and of informing the Parliament and the Council, at least once a year, of whether or not the conditions for exemption are met (in particular by respect for human rights).

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- This mechanism is a very important instrument of the European Union's foreign policy.It is very important that the review of the mechanism does not harm our friends and colleagues, Europe's European neighbors.I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to monitor this review closely and to ensure that countries such as Georgia continue to benefit from visa-free travel, at least for certain categories of citizens.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text which allows the revision of the suspension mechanism under the regulation governing the liberalization of visas with certain third countries.Indeed, due to the complexity of its procedures, the mechanism has not been able to be activated since 2013. This revision thus makes it possible to temporarily restore the visa obligation for third-country nationals in the following circumstances: sudden peak inirregular immigration, unfounded asylum requests, failure to cooperate with the European Union on readmissions or threat to public order or internal security.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against the visa suspension mechanism.I believe that mobility is a right of all people, so I not only reject the policies of Fortress Europe, but I have also supported the visa liberalizations that have been carried out.With this mechanism, the aim is to create a tool to restrict this visa freedom that is not very transparent, and which is also subject to the decision of only one of the two parties participating in the agreement.I reject that visas become a weapon of pressure and blackmail with which the Union can conduct foreign policy and that is why I have opposed it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it is not for the EU to be involved in nation states’ visa regulation.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of this report, which is based on the suspension mechanism in Article 1(a) of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, which allows for the temporary suspension of the visa exemption for nationals of a third country in certain emergency situations, as a last resort. It can be triggered by any Member State by notifying the Commission that it is confronted with circumstances leading to an emergency situation which the Member State in question cannot remedy on its own. After several difficult trilogues, the European Parliament and the Council have reached an agreement, under which both Member States and the European Commission will be able to trigger the suspension mechanism. The Commission will be in charge of monitoring the situation in visa-exempt countries and reporting to Parliament and the Council on whether they still fulfil visa waiver condition, such as respect for human rights.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I did not support this report, but this reasoning of the vote is a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Undoubtedly, visa policy is one of the important instruments of the Union's external action and at the same time affects internal security. The recent revision of visa policy introduced new measures, which are the so-called suspension mechanism and reciprocity mechanism. They are two sides of the same coin and act as legislative and political counterbalances, which required their procedures to be harmonized. In particular, it was necessary to specify precisely the functionality of the suspension mechanism. As the visa liberalization process is ongoing and the EU is exposed to a complicated political and migratory situation, it has been necessary to make the suspension mechanism faster and more flexible. I supported this effort because I agree that we need to create tools that will allow the EU to respond to exceptional circumstances. In the event that a Member State is unable to cope with the sudden increase in the number of aliens on its territory, unfounded asylum applications or other security threats on European territory, it will be able to suspend the visa regime with a third country. However, as such a measure is one of the strictest policy measures for the interest of third-country nationals, it is essential that this increased flexibility goes hand in hand with guarantees for the protection of human rights.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a revision of the regulation on short-stay visas to the EU, which concerned the introduction of a mechanism to suspend the issuance of short-stay visas (the 'emergency brake'). It was a necessary condition for a visa liberalization agreement for Ukraine and Georgia. The EP has approved this mechanism and citizens of these countries will be able to travel to the EU without visas from next year (probably after formal approval after February). Ukraine and Georgia have complied with all contractual obligations set out in the action plans, including anti-corruption measures, border protection, investment in border guards and biometric passports. I am a strong supporter of the closest possible ties between the EU and the Eastern Partnership countries, especially Ukraine. It is visa liberalization that is a tangible benefit for citizens and businesses and will improve the perception of the EU in the countries concerned. We can reassure citizens that the mechanism under discussion is here to protect against sudden migratory flows and the abuse of the system for longer-term illegal stays.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written. - The report aims to strengthen the suspension mechanism for visa-free travel to the EU. The Commission would be in a position to suspend the visa-free entry of citizens of individual third countries itself if it were asked to do so by member states. A visa requirement increases the transaction costs of individual citizens, but at the same time ensures that immigration into the social systems through free entry is made more difficult. When a third country's visa requirement is lifted, a suspension mechanism is important in order to be able to react quickly in the event of a crisis by lifting the visa waiver. I am convinced that the report will make it easier for many citizens of third countries to enter the EU and that it will have a positive impact on tourism and the economy within the EU. At the same time, the EU can react quickly and suspend the existing visa exemption if there is an increase in the number of unwanted entries. For these reasons I voted in favor of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- In connection with the introduction of visa-free travel with Ukraine and Georgia, we are also strengthening the mechanism for suspending and temporarily reintroducing visas in the event of massive abuse or an unforeseen situation in one of the countries, which could have a negative impact on the European Union's ability to control people's movements.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: written. - N-VA is particularly in favor of a rigorously revised suspension mechanism, so that we can temporarily suspend and even withdraw the visa exemption that a certain country has if necessary. Unfortunately, what is on the table does not go far enough. Progress has been made. There will be stricter deadlines and additional grounds for suspension. The visa waiver can be withdrawn if a country refuses to take back rejected asylum seekers and economic migrants. However, several elements make us doubt the underlying political agenda. Is it really the intention to develop an efficient suspension mechanism? Would one use the introduction of this suspension mechanism as an argument for a quick visa exemption to eg. Turkey to be awarded? Are there sufficient guarantees that the correct use of the asylum procedure will not be circumvented by this? Why is the scope narrowed to only certain categories of passport holders as opposed to an entire nationality? A reinforced suspension mechanism is necessary, but must be efficient and implemented with the correct motivation. Too many questions remain open about this today. With its abstention, the N-VA calls on delegation to give a clear answer to these questions. In any case, we will consider the objections and concerns raised when considering all future visa waiver requests.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - Visa policy is crucial for the European Union. With the emergence of migration flows, especially in the light of successive visa liberalization processes, it seems necessary to revise the suspension mechanism more quickly and flexibly. There is no doubt that we must provide the tools to enable the EU to respond to all circumstances arising from the sharp increase in the number of third-country nationals residing illegally in the EU, unfounded asylum claims from third-country nationals and threats to security in European territory. . This increased flexibility, however, must be accompanied by a solid and durable set of guarantees and measures to protect human rights, as well as reports and statistics by European agencies and law enforcement authorities. This is the only way to guarantee the rights of third-country nationals and to protect the principles of Community visa policy. I support this Report because I believe that it is necessary and legally appropriate for the European Parliament to be involved in decision-making, as we must not forget that the re-imposition of visas for third-country nationals is one of the strictest policy measures that can be taken.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on the list of third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from this requirement.I support the amendment that the Commission should monitor the situation in these third countries and report regularly to the European Parliament and the Council.In this way, we will ensure the continued fulfillment of specific criteria relating, inter alia, to illegal immigration, public order and security, economic benefits, in particular in the fields of tourism and foreign trade.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.What is urgently needed, due to the increased flow of illegal immigrants, extremists and members of transnational organized crime, is not the temporary suspension of the visa waiver for third-country nationals, but the complete abolition of the Community list.Each Member State must decide which third-country nationals can be exempted from the visa requirement.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of approving the arrangements for an agreement between the Council and the European Parliament to amend the list of countries subject to visa requirements for entry into the EU more quickly, more flexibly, to take account of the number of entrants and the number of rejected applications and exceptional occurrences. , or to temporarily suspend the status of certain countries. However, on the basis of the proposal, I am confident that the procedure under the amended regulation will continue to give equal weight to human and personal rights, the right to a fair and transparent procedure, data protection in accordance with EU rules and humanities for all third-country nationals. I consider the new regulation to be an important concrete result that, among other things, it will soon make it possible for citizens of Georgia (Georgia), one of the European Union's important eastern neighbors, to enter without a visa.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The European Union's visa policy reflects its relations with third countries and the agreements signed for the visa waiver of nationals of those countries, at least in the short term. In some cases, however, unpredictable events that lead to a large influx of migrants wishing to enter the EU for asylum or readmission give rise to the need for special measures by Member States and the European institutions in order to strengthen internal security. Thus, since 2013, the concept of a "suspension mechanism" has been introduced, which provides for proportionate measures to reintroduce the visa requirement for citizens of certain third countries. These measures are to be temporary, for a period of 9 months, with the possibility of extension by 18 months in case of persistence or interruption in case of fulfillment of the necessary conditions, mainly respect for human rights. The Commission will work with the Member States and the third country concerned to remedy this situation. The European Parliament will be able to get involved in this procedure and express its position. This is clear progress, which meets the requirements of some Member States and which will create more security for European citizens. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I agree with the rapporteur that, from a legal point of view, it is desirable and essential that the European Parliament be involved in the decision-making process, given that the reintroduction of the visa requirement forthird country nationals is one of the most drastic policy measures that can be applied.In accordance with what has been indicated, the suspension mechanism with regard to the use of delegated acts should be amended by following the judgment of the Court of Justice of 16 July 2015, which has already ruled on thequestion related to the reciprocity mechanism.The two mechanisms are two sides of the same coin and constitute legislative and political counterweights with similar effects, the procedures of which must be harmonized.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The revision of the EU visa waiver suspension mechanism aims to reduce restrictions for EU citizens to travel to countries outside the EU, as well as facilitating travel to the EU for citizens of third countries, boosting tourism and businesses. Visa liberalisation also acts as a strong mechanism for promoting reforms in third countries, notably reforms on fundamental rights and the rule of law. I voted in favour of the EU visa waiver suspension mechanism for Georgia, Ukraine and Kosovo because visa liberalisation would greatly benefit the economic, social and political standing of the EU and the third countries alike.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a resolution on third countries whose nationals must have a visa or are exempt from that requirement: a suspension mechanism".As this is a topic that has direct implications for external action, but also for internal security, the European Union must pay close attention to the issue of visas and the suspension mechanism.All the more so when the liberalization of the visa procedure is taken into account in the face of the emergence of pronounced threats to European security.There is a need for an institutional response to the sudden and marked increase in the number of illegally staying third-country nationals, to the number of unfounded visa applications and to the terrorist threat to EU Member States.An adequately regulated suspension mechanism should respond more effectively to the challenges outlined above.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - The main objective of this proposal is to strengthen the suspension mechanism by making it easier for individual Member States of the Union to notify the specific circumstances that may lead to a potential suspension and also to enable the Commission to initiate that mechanism on its own initiative. The agreement that was ultimately reached represents a balance between opposing views - those who wanted this to be achieved through delegates and those who wanted it to be achieved through implementing acts. Although I must regret that the whole procedure is not based on implementing acts, the proposal has received my support because I firmly believe that it is indisputable and unquestionable that the suspension mechanism requires modification in the direction of strengthening. Only in this way can future confidence in existing visa liberalization agreements be built. Also, such an act is inevitable if one wants to react in a timely manner to potential crises because it does not require waiting until the legislative process is completed.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - Draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 I supported Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 on the list of third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (change in the detention mechanism). Visa policy is one of the key themes of the EU, as it affects external actions as well as internal security. It is important to the extent that its management is clearly defined as a shared competence of the co-legislators in the ordinary procedure. Developments in the political and migration situation, in particular following successive visa liberalization procedures, call for a revision of the retention mechanism to make it more effective and flexible. Elements need to be put in place to enable the EU to respond quickly to a sudden increase in the number of illegal immigrants from third countries, unfounded asylum applications, rejected readmission applications and security threats on European territory.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - The report aims to strengthen the suspension mechanism for visa-free travel to the EU. The Commission would be able to suspend the visa-free entry of citizens of individual third countries itself if it were asked to do so by member states. A visa requirement increases the transaction costs of individual citizens, but at the same time ensures that immigration into the social systems through free entry is made more difficult. If a third country's visa requirement is lifted, a suspension mechanism is important in order to be able to react quickly in the event of a crisis by lifting the visa waiver. I am convinced that the report will make it easier for many citizens of third countries to enter the EU and that it will have a positive impact on tourism and the economy within the EU. At the same time, the EU can react quickly and suspend the existing visa exemption if there is an increase in the number of unwanted entries. For these reasons I voted in favor of the report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- The European Union wishes to revise the European visa suspension mechanism for entering the Union.The aim is to make it easier to reinstate the visa requirement in the event of a peak in immigration.The European Union thus wishes to reassure public opinion.But its real objective is elsewhere: it wants to give illusory guarantees to pass the abolition of visas for millions of Ukrainians and Georgians.While we should be protected from the migratory wave by re-establishing controls at our national borders, the Union is doing the opposite by opening them even further.I voted against.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The main purpose of the proposal is to strengthen the suspension mechanism by making it easier for Member States to notify the circumstances leading to a possible suspension and by allowing the Commission to activate the mechanism on its own initiative.It is worth supporting the need for the existence and strengthening of a suspension mechanism in order to maintain confidence in both future and existing visa liberalization agreements.Such a standstill clause is also important as it allows for a swift response to any emergency and does not require waiting for a solution in the legislative process.I therefore supported the report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - This Regulation amends Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001 which lists the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from this obligation. Since 2013 there has been a provision by virtue of which the Commission may establish a suspension mechanism for this "visa waiver" status. This report aims to strengthen this mechanism, making it easier and "flexible". Although some of our amendments have been taken into account when drafting the text in the Civil Liberties committee, regarding the protection of Human Rights, very problematic aspects remain, such as "the greatest risk or imminent threat to public policy or the internal security of the Member States related to the nationals of that third country ”and the substantial increase in“ denied readmission requests ”as a reason to activate the mechanism, which gives it a level of discretion and coercion with respect to the third country involved. , respectively. In the negotiations with the Council and the Commission, (trilogue) the text intensified, in line with the "fortress" Europe that I reject. For this reason, I have voted against.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted against because the revision of the recently adopted suspension mechanism is not needed. The threat to terminate visa waiver when the third country does not contain asylum seekers does not comply with the right to asylum as an individual right. I regret that the Member States link their approval of visa waivers for the nationals of Georgia, Ukraine and Kosovo with the revision of the suspension mechanism.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: in writing. - Ukraine and Georgia are important partners of the European Union in the field of neighborhood policy. The current governments of both countries have made clear their desire to move closer to Europe and their strong commitment to reforms that are in line with European values, and have shown good capacity in implementing them. Unfortunately, the EU delayed for a very long time the granting of a visa-free regime, which in turn prevented Ukraine and Georgia from moving away from the Kremlin's political influence. Visa liberalization is an important step in strengthening neighborhood policy. I have always supported the introduction of visa-free travel with Ukraine, Georgia and Kosovo. The successful conclusion of the visa dialogue is now a key priority for cooperation between the EU and its neighbors. I support the report on the review of the visa regime, as such a visa suspension mechanism will allow Europe to respond in a timely manner to emergencies. EU Member States will be able to update the visa suspension mechanism if cooperation on the return of migrants has decreased or risks to Europe's internal security have increased.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this decision, the suspension mechanism that has existed since 2013 is updated. In this way, the Union intends to continue facilitating access to its territory, but being able to use this urgent procedure to restrict it if necessary if the agreed commitments are not fulfilled.with the countries of origin.In this way, they want to protect people and human rights, by continuing to demand their respect in those countries whose nationals obtain visa liberalization to travel to the Union.For all these reasons, I think it appropriate to vote in their favor.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted against the visa suspension mechanism.I believe that mobility is a right of all people, so I not only reject the policies of Fortress Europe, but I have also supported the visa liberalizations that have been carried out.With this mechanism, the aim is to create a tool to restrict this visa freedom that is not very transparent, and which is also subject to the decision of only one of the two parties participating in the agreement.I reject that visas become a weapon of pressure and blackmail with which the Union can conduct foreign policy and that is why I have opposed it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This report proposes to amend Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are subject to the visa requirement when crossing external borders and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (Review Suspension Mechanism). According to the report, "The evolution of the political and migratory situation requires - taking into account, in particular, the successive visa liberalization processes - that the suspension mechanism be revised, in order to become more rapid and flexible". In the context of the “migrant crisis”, the European Parliament wants to approve a report that takes the idea of ​​fortress Europe further. Having serious responsibilities in the wave of refugees who come to various European states seeking asylum, it is equally unable to deal with a a situation that is already one of the greatest humanitarian scourges at the dawn of this century, creating mechanisms of repulsion, aggression and repression.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- This proposal aims to review the visa waiver suspension mechanism.Since this mechanism should only come about if the recognition rate of asylum applications is less than three percent, whereby this was 47.6 percent in Austria this year, should only extend to certain groups in a third country and, on the other hand, the implementing powers to suspend and thus theI have not endorsed this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on third countries whose citizens are subject to the visa requirement or exempt from it - revision of the suspension mechanism.Visa policy is a key issue for the European Union and has implications for both external and internal action.The increased flexibility must be accompanied by a solid set of safeguards and measures to protect human rights, as per reports and statistics provided by European agencies and competent law enforcement authorities.This is the only way to guarantee the rights of third country nationals and to safeguard the principles of EU visa policy.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - Visa policy is an area of ​​activity of the European Union that builds on foreign policy as well as internal security. I voted in favor of the text because it is a revision of the visa waiver mechanism and seeks to make this instrument more effective. It gives both the Commission and the Member States the power to renew visa requirements for third-country nationals if necessary. The EU needs effective tools to respond to the exceptional circumstances resulting from the sudden and significant increase in the number of third-country nationals residing illegally in the EU or from the increase in unfounded asylum applications for third-country nationals. The visa brake should also be used if a third country rejects an EU Member State's readmission application, as well as in the event of security threats on European territory. At the same time, however, we must realize that the renewal of the visa requirement for third-country nationals is a strong political and diplomatic act that can have various consequences. It is therefore of the utmost importance that this mechanism is applied on the basis of factual and relevant evidence.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- The long migration crisis has shown that a large number of EU instruments are not working.In my opinion, it is therefore necessary to come up with a revision of these mechanisms and to react flexibly to current developments in the field of migration.I consider the possibility of reintroducing visas to be particularly important in the event that one of the Member States faces an unbearable influx of applicants.I also support the adoption of this proposal because it is an important step towards visa liberalization with Ukraine and Georgia, which have fulfilled all the contractual obligations set out in the action plans.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation amending the regulation listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders of the Member States and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement. The amendment to the regulation concerned the mechanism by which the exemption from the visa requirement may be suspended. The European Union has concluded a number of bilateral visa waiver agreements, and although the situation in a country is thoroughly examined before respecting any such agreement in terms of respect for human rights, the rule of law and the risk of illegal migration, the situation in these countries may change over time. change. That is why it was necessary to create a more flexible instrument by which the Member States and the European Commission could react more quickly to changing conditions and, for example, to jeopardizing the security of the European Union. I think that the approved mechanism will serve this purpose. The Regulation currently describes in detail the various stages of a proposal to suspend an exemption, as well as extending the reasons why this suspension can be applied. I believe that these changes will also help to strengthen citizens' confidence in the European Union and the agreements that the European Union concludes with third countries.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the report by Agustín Díaz de Mer García Consuegra on one of the important issues and problems of the EU, and that is visa policy. This implies the view that visa policy is one of the key issues in the European Union, as it thus affects external action and internal security. It is so important that its management is clearly regulated as a shared competence of the co-legislators within the ordinary legislative procedure. It is also legally relevant for the European Parliament to be involved in decision-making, given that the reintroduction of visas for third-country nationals is one of the strictest policy measures that can be applied. Accordingly, it is necessary to amend the suspension mechanism with regard to the application of delegated acts and to adapt it to the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union of 16 July 2015 on this issue, regarding the reciprocity mechanism. Both mechanisms represent two sides of the coin, are balanced in legislative and political terms and have similar effects, and the procedures within them need to be harmonized. Due to developments in the political and migration situation, in particular in the light of successive visa liberalization procedures, a revision of the suspension mechanism was needed to make it more flexible and flexible.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 882/2004539/2001 on the list of third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from this requirement (modification of the detention mechanism).Visa policy is one of the key themes of the EU, as it affects external actions as well as internal security.Developments in the political and migration situation, in particular following successive visa liberalization procedures, call for a revision of the retention mechanism to make it more effective and flexible.Such flexibility must, of course, be accompanied by a strong set of guarantees and measures for the protection of human rights, as well as reports and statistics provided by European agencies and law enforcement authorities.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
