text: in writing.- The changes proposed by this resolution aim to protect our market and our consumers.In particular, fruit placed on the European market is requested to be accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate, which contains information relating to the inspections carried out during the growth phase and the tests carried out on certain samples.More checks are also requested at points of entry into the territory of the Union.For these reasons I voted positively.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I have supported this objection because we Socialists do not accept any reduction in the phytosanitary controls applied to citrus fruits that enter or circulate through the Union. Above all, after the recent reform of the Union plant health regulation that has reinforced these controls, depending on the risk in the country of origin. We consider the citrus sector strategic for Valencia and Andalusia and in no way can we allow the implementation of a measure that unnecessarily threatens the continuity of European citrus production in the face of a certain risk of the spread and contamination of dangerous pests, such as "Black Spot" or the "Citrus Canker." We expect the European Commission to guarantee, in general, for all harmful origins and organisms, the complete traceability of the specified fruits for their introduction into the Union, accompanied by the supervisory documents of the national phytosanitary service. Regarding the fight against the «T Leucotreta» plague, we demand the «cold treatment» of imported citrus fruits, as recommended by EFSA and EPPO.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- With this Directive the Commission is going in the opposite direction to the legislation passed on "Protective measures against plant pests", as it is much less demanding than this, undermining the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruits susceptible to pests,particularly with regard to citrus black spot and citrus canker.Thus, this proposed amendment directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector in southern Europe, and underestimates the phytosanitary threat posed by citrus imports from third countries.The motion for a resolution proposes the amendment of this directive in such a way as to ensure that adequate controls are carried out against the entry of fruit, especially citrus, into the Union.That is why I have voted in favor of it.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Commission implementing directive amending Annexes I to V to Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community. In the light of the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority and the proposal of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, Parliament, in this resolution, takes the view that the Commission's draft implementing directive is contrary to Regulation (EU) No 182/2011. 2016/2031, as it weakens the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruit susceptible to harmful organisms, in particular citrus spot and citrus cancer. I support this position, agreeing that the Commission's draft implementing directive is incompatible with Union law, as it is incompatible with Regulation (EU) No 182/2011. The purpose of 2016/2031 is to define the risks posed by pathogens, animals or parasitic plants of any species, strain or biotype that are harmful to plants or plant products (referred to in the Regulation as pests) and to reduce those risks to an acceptable level.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - As regards protection measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community, I voted in favor of the objection pursuant to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure. In particular, the spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa in Italy and the importation of foreign plant species into Europe has once again demonstrated the need to ensure that all imported plant species and plant products do not contain any harmful organisms. We must be very careful, as only one infected plant is enough to destroy an entire industry or an entire economy of an area.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - The resolution proposed here aims to increase controls on the introduction into the European Union of fruit - in this case, citrus - originating in third countries. This proposal calls for the strengthening of controls on these fruits which could contaminate production in Europe. For traceability purposes, fruits will only be brought into the Union if they meet the following conditions: • the production field, packaging facilities, exporters and any other operator involved in the handling of the specified fruits must be officially registered; • during their transport from the production field to the point of entry into the Union, the specified fruits must be accompanied by documents issued under the control of the national plant protection organization; • in the case of specified fruits originating in third countries, in addition to the first two points, pre- and post-harvest treatments have also been proposed. I voted for this proposal, which is also a way to protect our citrus growers from the importation of cheaper products from third countries.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because I believe that if this resolution is passed, further amendments could be tabled to hinder the trade of North African citrus fruits that would only benefit the interests of Southern European businesses. The outcome of this resolution will have no impact on the United Kingdom.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this resolution, which considers that the proposal for a Commission implementing directive does not comply with Union law, as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) No° 2016/2031, which is to determine the phytosanitary risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogen, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants or plant products, nor with the measures aimed at reducing the risk toan acceptable level.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft Implementing Directive amending Annexes I to V of Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community against organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community. This resolution directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector for southern Europe. The resolution calls into question the phytosanitary agreement reached in relation to the importation of citrus from third countries. We consider it essential that the fruit that enters the Union complies with the consequent health processes, detailed labeling and packaging that also complies with the established standards. The European Parliament and the Council already voted in October to tighten the phytosanitary controls (we support it) so I believe that the citrus sector should be included in this process.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I would like to thank the members of the Committee on Agriculture for their work on this objection on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community.I supported both Modification 2 and Modification 4 and the amendment tabled in this regard against my group's line.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I support with my vote this resolution which intends to reject an amendment proposal from the Commission which, in an annex, actually wants to lower the control instruments with respect to the black spot of citrus fruits (black spot) and to the cancer of citrus fruits (citrus canker) incitrus fruits imported for processing into juice.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I have supported this objection because we Socialists do not accept any reduction in the phytosanitary controls applied to citrus fruits that enter or circulate through the Union. Above all, after the recent reform of the Union plant health regulation that has reinforced these controls, depending on the risk in the country of origin. We consider the citrus sector strategic for Valencia and Andalusia and in no way can we allow the implementation of a measure that unnecessarily threatens the continuity of European citrus production in the face of a certain risk of the spread and contamination of dangerous pests, such as "Black Spot" or the "Citrus Canker." We expect the European Commission to guarantee, in general, for all harmful origins and organisms, the complete traceability of the specified fruits for their introduction into the Union, accompanied by the supervisory documents of the national phytosanitary service. Regarding the fight against the «T Leucotreta» plague, we demand the «cold treatment» of imported citrus fruits, as recommended by EFSA and EPPO.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution on the Commission implementing directive amending the annexes to Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community. Directive 2000/29 / EC will be repealed and replaced by Regulation (EU) No 182/2011. 2016/2031 on plant protection products as soon as that Regulation enters into force. The Commission’s draft implementing directive contradicts Regulation (EU) No 2016/2031, as it weakens the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruit susceptible to harmful organisms, in particular citrus spot and citrus cancer. The European Parliament considers that the Commission's draft implementing directive is incompatible with European Union law, as it is incompatible with Regulation (EU) No 182/2011. The purpose of 2016/2031 is to define the phytosanitary risks posed by pathogens, animals or parasitic plants of any species, strain or biotype harmful to plants or plant products (referred to in the Regulation as pests) and the measures to reduce those risks to an acceptable level. In this context, Parliament recalls that, as soon as Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (14 December 2019) enters into force, 2016/2031, it will repeal and replace Directive 2000/29 / EC.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Objection.The outbreak of Xyllela fastidiose in Italy and the introduction of invasive alien species in Europe show that it is necessary to ensure all imports of plants or plant products without pests.One infected plant can destroy an entire sector or the economy of an entire region.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing.- Consumer protection must always be a priority in the action of the legislator.The European Union recognizes the right to health as a fundamental right of European citizens and promotes their promotion and protection first of all with prevention.And it is the precautionary and prevention principle that leads us to block the import and trade of organisms harmful to plants or edible plant products, making their list always clear and updated and the legislator vigilant.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The draft Commission Implementing Directive amending Annex IV to Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on measures to protect against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community is contrary to the objectives of the Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 as it undermines the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruit exposed to pests, in particular Phyllosticta citricarpa and Xanthomonas citri. It is not in line with Union law because it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031, which is to determine the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, strain or biotype of pathogens, animals or parasitic plants harmful to plants or products. (hereinafter referred to as "harmful organisms"). This non-conformity led me to vote in favor of this resolution. I believe that, in this context, over-regulation does not contribute to a better functioning of the system, but, on the contrary, leads to malfunctions that can lead to a number of risks.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I have supported this objection because we Socialists do not accept any reduction in the phytosanitary controls applied to citrus fruits that enter or circulate through the Union. Above all, after the recent reform of the Union plant health regulation that has reinforced these controls, depending on the risk in the country of origin. We consider the citrus sector strategic for Valencia and Andalusia and in no way can we allow the implementation of a measure that unnecessarily threatens the continuity of European citrus production in the face of a certain risk of the spread and contamination of dangerous pests, such as "Black Spot" or the "Citrus Canker." We expect the European Commission to guarantee, in general, for all harmful origins and organisms, the complete traceability of the specified fruits for their introduction into the Union, accompanied by the supervisory documents of the national phytosanitary service. Regarding the fight against the «T Leucotreta» plague, we demand the «cold treatment» of imported citrus fruits, as recommended by EFSA and EPPO.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing. - The European Commission has presented an implementing act amending Annexes I to V of Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Union of organisms harmful to plants and plant products , and their spread in the Union. The Parliament, having no binding powers in matters of execution, gives its opinion in an objection resolution. As it stands, the implementing act of the Commission is not consistent with the new Regulation No. 2016/2031 on protective measures against organisms harmful to plants, which repeals Directive 200/29 / EC. For this reason, the European Parliament's resolution calls for increased protection and more controls to ensure the protection of plants from organisms which are harmful to them. For example, we ask for more requirement for the importation of fruits originating from countries where Phyllosticta citricarpa is present. I voted in favor of this objection.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the objection to the draft implementing directive amending Annexes I to V of the directive on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread inCommunity.The draft directive in question, in fact, conflicts with the objectives of Regulation (EU) no.2016/2031, as it violates the requirements relating to the introduction into the Union of certain fruits susceptible to harmful organisms and is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) no.2016/2031 to determine the phytosanitary risks presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogens, animals or parasitic plants harmful to plants or plant products and measures to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.The objection calls for the directive in question to be re-examined by Parliament once it has been amended as suggested.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to a draft implementing directive. The issue is that that the draft implementing directive is not compatible with a Regulation recently agreed and voted on last October, and goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in the basic act. While inter-institutional negotiations for the 2016 Regulation were able to secure comprehensive controls on imported plant material to avoid the outbreak of future plant diseases, the draft implementing act reverses those gains with regard to fruits susceptible to pests, such as citrus black spot and citrus canker.  Even aside from the fact that the Commission is trying to water down the recently agreed phytosanitary rules, the 2000 Directive will be repealed as soon as the 2016 Regulation takes effect, in three years. So the legal basis for the implementing act will not even exist anymore.  For these reasons I supported the objection.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Resolution as I consider that the draft Commission implementing directive is not consistent with European Union law, in that it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031, which is to determine the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agents, animals or parasitic plants injurious to plants or plant products (‘pests’) and measures to reduce those risks to an acceptable level. I call on the Commission to modify its draft implementing directive in order to bring them in line.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The changes proposed by this resolution aim to protect our market and our consumers.Fruit entering the European market is requested to be accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate, which contains elements on treatments against Phyllosticta citricarpa, inspections made on fruit in the growth phase, sampling and tests carried out on certain samples.It is also requested to carry out more checks at points of entry into the territory of the European Union and to refuse entry if the fruit shows symptoms.Another important element of this resolution are the traceability requirements of all fruit entering the European market.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the objection report.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- We voted against the objection concerning protection measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community.I consider this to be a positive effort to protect the environment and the health of Europeans, and that is why I voted in favor.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Positive vote.The report intends to reject an amendment proposal by the European Commission that would decrease the control tools on harmful plant products that are imported.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution which considers that the Commission's draft directive is not in compliance with EU law, as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) No.2031/2016, which is to determine the phytosanitary risks of any species, strain or biotype of pathogens, animals or parasitic plants harmful to plants or plant products ("parasites") and the measures aimed at reducing these risks to an acceptable level.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- With this Directive the Commission is going in the opposite direction to the legislation passed on "Protective measures against plant pests", as it is much less demanding than this, undermining the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruits susceptible to pests,particularly with regard to citrus black spot and citrus canker.Thus, this proposed modification directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector in southern Europe, and underestimates the phytosanitary threat posed by citrus imports from third countries.The motion for a resolution proposes the amendment of this directive in such a way as to ensure that adequate controls are carried out against the entry of fruit, especially citrus, into the Union.That is why I have voted in favor of it.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted against the draft implementing directive which aims to amend Annexes I to V to Council Directive 2000/29 / EC.I believe that stricter controls on the import of citrus fruit will increase the risk of bringing a complaint to the WTO and will impose disproportionate and unjustified requirements on exporting countries where there have been no problems so far.Furthermore, the proposed changes to ensure stricter controls go beyond the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) recommendations.The sensible approach to protecting the market in citrus processing is to act through emergency measures rather than by general tightening of measures.Through the proposed changes to only use the Thaumatotibia leucotreta freezing process, the directive will halt research and prevent the use of new scientific processes.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The outbreak of the Xyllela fastidiosa in Italy and the introduction of invasive alien species in Europe highlight the need to ensure that all imports of plants or plants products are free of pests. I am in favour of this resolution, as one infected plant can destroy a whole sector or the economy of a whole region.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- The history of the 'Xyllela outbreak in Italy' and the introduction of invasive alien species into Europe show that it must be ensured that all imports of plants or products are free from pests.An infected plant can destroy the entire sector of the economy of an entire region.Therefore, I support the objection regarding the import of citrus, submitted by our colleague, Clara Aguilera.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This resolution aims to object in a non-binding manner and to propose amendments to a draft implementing directive of the European Commission amending Annexes I to V of Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures of plant health in the Union. This text comes in a context of transition between two pieces of legislation. Pending the entry into force of the new regulation 2016/2031 of the European Parliament and of the Council on protective measures against plant pests, adopted in October 2016, the European Commission proposes to amend via secondary legislation Council Directive 2000/29 / EC. The new legislation has been the subject of difficult negotiations for over three years and the Commission's draft implementing directive is not consistent with the political agreement reached under the new regulation; it has the effect of weakening the European system of protection against health hazards, in particular with regard to the importance of the preventive import strategy. Considering that it is necessary, in a context of globalization and global warming, to strengthen protection against health hazards likely to ravage our European plant productions, I voted for this objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this objection, which opposes changing the protective measures against the introduction into the Union of pests of plants.The European Commission wants to simplify and ease the import requirements for certain fruits from third countries, in particular affected by citrus black spot, and this is not acceptable.I support the proposals made in this resolution, which call for keeping the import requirements in place, regardless of the destination of the product.We must remain vigilant about what we introduce into the European Union, and maintain responsible and harmonized protection of our Member States.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this objection because, at the moment, the measures envisaged to prevent the introduction into the Union of new plant pests, which attack citrus fruits, are not strict enough to protect producersof the Union.The draft implementing directive, as proposed by the Commission, does not in fact reduce the risks of importing exotic parasites.There is therefore an urgent need to put in place stricter rules to protect citrus fruit in the Union and thus prevent the spread, in particular, of black spots on citrus fruits and false codling moth.We cannot adopt a wait-and-see or inert attitude to this problem.It is important to act quickly!

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.It concerns the proposal for a Commission implementing directive on organisms harmful to plants or plant products, with the aim of controlling the introduction into the European Union of fruits - in this case, citrus fruits..The measures necessary for traceability are in particular the following: official registration of any operator involved in the handling of the fruit and presence of certificates from the national plant protection organization for each delivery.We support these measures, which help protect our farmers from foreign competition.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this dossier. Several Members have objected to the draft implementing directive. However, stricter controls, as they propose, on citrus imports increase not only the risk of a WTO challenge, but will also impose disproportionate and unjustified requirements on exporting countries where there have been no issues to date. The proposed changes also go beyond recommendations by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). If there are persistent interceptions involving other third countries, these should be addressed through emergency measures, rather than by imposing stronger measures across the board. Therefore, I decided not to support this dossier, in its current form.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - The draft Commission Implementing Directive, which aims to amend Annexes I to V to Directive 2000/29 / EC, is contrary to the objectives of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031, as it undermines the requirements for the importation of certain fruits into the Union which are susceptible to harmful organisms, in particular black citrus staining and citrus cancer. The purpose of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 is to identify the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, strain or biotype of pathogens, animals or parasitic plants that are harmful to plants or plant products ("harmful organisms"), as well as measures to reduce these risks to an acceptable level. It is therefore necessary to amend the Implementing Directive proposed herein.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Strict controls are needed to prevent the entry of pests which can damage the livelihoods of producers and the environment. Plant pests have created significant problems for EU agriculture and biodiversity and it is important for the agricultural sector in Wales that it is protected from that.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- Regarding the import of plants and plant parts to the Union, it is important that we have a secure system that protects against diseases.What this resolution calls for, however, are protective measures that are far too disproportionate and costly unnecessary.This leads to what the resolution calls for is more or less disguised protectionism.The Commission's proposal in this regard is balanced and well balanced and I see no reason to oppose their proposal.That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- Citrus fruit imported into the EU should be subject to stricter phytosanitary controls to prevent the spread of pests, such as the black spot, to European citrus groves.The Commission's draft is contrary to the objectives of the new regulation on protection measures against plant pests.The Commission's project is not sufficient to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.In a resolution adopted today by 463 votes in favor, 168 against and three abstentions, the European Parliament asks the Commission to modify the draft implementing directive in order to strengthen controls on imported citrus fruits and prevent the spread of pests to European citrus groves.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - According to the European Commission's proposal, the entry of citrus fruits would only be conditioned to a mere visual inspection of the product and dependent on a declaration attesting the good health status of the fruit, and declaring that it comes from fields subject to treatment and control of Phyllosticta citricarpa (black spot). With this proposal, the Commission goes beyond its functions by proposing to weaken phytosanitary controls on imports, when Parliament and the Council agreed to strengthen these measures. This phytosanitary laxity promoted by the Commission can only be related to the enormous pressures of the processing and processing industry, namely for soft drinks in northern Europe, which intends to acquire raw material at low cost, thus increasing its profits. Moving forward, this measure will penalize citrus growers in two ways: first, through more than a certain increase in imports, with the consequent downward pressure on prices; second, calling into question the phytosanitary status of citrus groves, which are much more vulnerable to a number of pests, among which is Phyllosticta citricarpa, which the EU is still free from. We advocate strict controls on all imported citrus fruits, including sample analysis and traceability certificates.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- The purpose of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 is to identify the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, strain or biotype of pathogens, animals or parasitic plants that are harmful to plants or plant products ("harmful organisms"), as well asand measures to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.I therefore vote in favor of amending the implementing directive proposed herein as deemed necessary.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The outbreak of the Xyllela fastidiosa in Italy and the introduction of invasive alien species in Europe show that we need to ensure that all imports of plants or plants products are free of pests. One infected plant can destroy a whole sector or the economy of a whole region. The phytosanitary risk is particularly high for the warmer regions of Europe, while most of the citrus imports for processing are to regions less susceptible to being infected by pests coming from outside Europe. Nevertheless, the risk that pests arriving in the north of Europe could be transferred to warmer regions and thus infect citrus plants in Europe exists, and according to the recommendation of the EPPO (European and Mediterranean Plant Protection Organisation), the only effective treatment that guarantees a high protection is the cold treatment.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the objection under Article 106 - Protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community - concerning Community measures to help prevent 'introduction into the EU of new parasites that attack citrus groves because the current legislation is not sufficient to protect European producers. In fact, I believe that stricter rules and controls are needed to prevent the spread of parasites such as the black spot of citrus fruits and False Cydia. The Commission's draft implementing directive does not reduce the risk of importing harmful organisms into the EU to an acceptable level and therefore stricter rules are needed. For this reason I have argued that fruits originating in third countries should be visually inspected at the point of entry into the EU and such inspections should be carried out on samples of at least 200 fruits per 30 ton batch. I also shared the European Parliament's request that citrus fruits should be cold-treated or alternative, sustainable, effective and having the same effect before being imported into the EU, as well as measures to improve the traceability of imported citrus fruits.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this objection because the implementation of the directive against the introduction of harmful organisms to plants must be much more effective than what the Commission envisaged and the European Parliament must be vigilant. We have already suffered the catastrophic consequences of the entry into the European Union of plant viruses which have forced thousands of farmers to their knees. We still count the damage caused by Xylella, we strongly shout at the Commission to take more seriously the high number of intercepts of infected citrus fruit from South Africa. I voted in favor of establishing a more precise certification system and more effective border controls, visual checks on a sample of at least 200 fruits of each species. And then the traceability. All operators, from the production area to the transport operators, must be registered, as well as all movements and refrigeration treatments undergone by the products.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft Implementing Directive amending Annexes I to V of Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community against organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community. This resolution directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector for southern Europe. The resolution calls into question the phytosanitary agreement reached in relation to the importation of citrus from third countries. We consider it essential that the fruit that enters the Union complies with the consequent health processes, detailed labeling and packaging that also complies with the established standards. The European Parliament and the Council already voted in October to tighten the phytosanitary controls (we support it) so I believe that the citrus sector should be included in this process.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - I have supported this objection because we Socialists do not accept any reduction in the phytosanitary controls applied to citrus fruits that enter or circulate through the Union. Above all, after the recent reform of the Union plant health regulation that has reinforced these controls, depending on the risk in the country of origin. We consider the citrus sector strategic for Valencia and Andalusia and in no way can we allow the implementation of a measure that unnecessarily threatens the continuity of European citrus production in the face of a certain risk of the spread and contamination of dangerous pests, such as "Black Spot" or the "Citrus Canker." We expect the European Commission to guarantee, in general, for all harmful origins and organisms, the complete traceability of the specified fruits for their introduction into the Union, accompanied by the supervisory documents of the national phytosanitary service. Regarding the fight against the «T Leucotreta» plague, we demand the «cold treatment» of imported citrus fruits, as recommended by EFSA and EPPO.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- The report addresses protection measures to prevent the introduction of new pests affecting citrus trees and their fruit, as the existing ones are not sufficient to protect European producers.The report calls for stricter rules and controls to prevent the spread of citrus-infesting pests and expects the Commission to follow Parliament's recommendations.For these reasons we voted in favor of the report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Commission implementing directive amending Annexes I.-V.Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community, as I consider it necessary to exercise particular caution with regard to the introduction of organisms harmful to plants.The case of Xylella fastidiose in Italy has shown what consequences such pests can cause for plants, for the local economy, but also for biodiversity.Phytosanitary risks must be clearly and thoroughly analyzed and I therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- I welcome this proposal, which aims to improve control over the introduction into Europe of citrus fruits originating from third countries.This is an effective way to protect our producers from tough competition from southern countries and from potential contamination of their farms through better traceability from one end of the chain to the other.I voted for.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this non-binding objection, which calls on the European Commission to remove the possibility provided for in its initial text to lighten the requirements for the import of fruits intended for processing into juice and to strengthen,Conversely, those concerning the importation of fruits originating in countries where harmful organisms are present.This objection requires that the third country of origin carry out tests on the fruit before shipment in order to detect possible infections.Parliament is once again a defender of consumer health.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- This motion for a resolution concerns a draft Commission implementing directive on measures to protect against the introduction and spread of organisms harmful to plants and plant products.The rapporteur is of the opinion that the implementing directive proposed by the Commission is not in line with current EU law.Since the objections raised by the rapporteur are correct and protection against pests must not be subject to an incorrect legal assessment, I agree with this decision.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: written.- I voted against the resolution because, from a technical point of view, the European Commission's proposal is classified as sufficiently strict and the exceptions for the importation of fruits for industrial processing are already subject to strict conditions.Import requirements should always be technically justified in order to protect European citrus production from new diseases that have not yet occurred in the EU.The tightening proposed in the resolution - in particular the additional review by the EFSA and the expected process extensions - do not contribute to more plant protection, but rather point to a hidden import ban.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Through this report, the Commission wants to implement a directive in order to determine the phytosanitary risks posed by a strain or biotype of pathogenic agents, animals or parasitic plants injurious to plants at second level to reduce those risks. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - A resolution was adopted today in Strasbourg containing corrections to the European Commission's draft amendment containing a series of protective measures against the introduction and spread in our territory of organisms harmful to plants or plant products. These are measures that we here in Parliament want to correct and improve, also to bring them into line with a view to the entry into force of the new regulation containing the introduction of the so-called plant passport. Specifically, the proposal provides that fruits deriving from third countries must be accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate authorizing their entry, a declaration certifying that the fruits originate from a production area that has been subjected to adequate treatments against the Citrus black spot, that is the black spot, parasite that is able to destroy our citrus groves. The damage caused to our agriculture by plant diseases caused by viruses introduced with the importation of products deriving from third countries is enormous. Since this is a battle that I have been carrying on for some time to safeguard our productive-ornamental heritage from pathogens deriving from third countries, I believe that supporting this request will produce positive effects.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution, because it protects our producers against imports and the risk of contamination.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The object of this objection was to modify a proposal for an implementing directive presented by the Commission.In this case, the proposed text seeks to increase controls on imports from third countries of fruit, in particular citrus.The citrus fruits in question should be accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate, and full traceability of their production, harvest, packaging, export, transport, controlled.Our group supports this rigorous control, especially since it is also a way of protecting our citrus growers from the massive importation of cheaper products from third countries.I logically voted for this objection.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- With this Directive the Commission is going in the opposite direction to the legislation passed on "Protective measures against plant pests", as it is much less demanding than this, undermining the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruits susceptible to pests,particularly with regard to citrus black spot and citrus canker.Thus, this proposed modification directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector in southern Europe, and underestimates the phytosanitary threat posed by citrus imports from third countries.The motion for a resolution proposes the amendment of this directive in such a way as to ensure that adequate controls are carried out against the entry of fruit, especially citrus, into the Union.That is why I have voted in favor of it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- This motion for a resolution speaks of fruits that are susceptible to harmful organisms, ie black spot disease and bacterial cancer of citrus fruits.The current draft Commission implementing directive is not in line with European Union law, as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation 2016/2031, which first identifies phytosanitary risks posed by a particular type of pathogen and then mitigates those risks.I consider it important to take samples of as many fruits of each species as possible in order to identify and find a possible harmful sample, so I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- The amendments proposed by the Commission to the Council Directive on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms of harmful plants or plant products and against their spread are not in line with Union rules.The European Parliament is proposing changes to the procedures for importing fruit from third countries into the Union, increased requirements for their monitoring and pre-market control.These requirements must be accepted in order to protect human and plant health against the introduction of extraneous pests.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the motion for a resolution on the draft Commission Implementing Directive amending Annexes I to V to Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and againsttheir spread within the Community because, as indicated in the motion for a resolution, the draft Commission Implementing Directive in question is incompatible with Union law.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.Its objective is to intensify controls on the introduction into the European Union of fruit (in this case, citrus) originating in third countries.These controls are numerous (phytosanitary certificate, registration of fields and installations, etc.) and, in addition to sanitary protection, promote the protection of our producers against the importation of increasingly cheaper products.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The rapporteur is of the opinion that the implementing directive planned by the Commission is not in line with Regulation 2016/2031.Regulation 2016/2031, as the rapporteur also correctly recognizes, replaces the legal basis of the planned implementing directive, RL 2000/29, but not until December 2019. However, since the protection against plant pests must not be subject to an incorrect legal assessment, I havesupported this application.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament resolution.Following the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority and the proposal of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, Parliament opposes a Commission decision weakening the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruit susceptible to harmful organisms, in particular citrus blemishes and citrus cancers.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution by the European Parliament aims to strengthen controls on the introduction into the European Union of fruit, especially citrus, from third countries.Imported citrus fruits are expected to be accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate declaring that the fruits originate from a production field subjected at the appropriate time to treatments against various diseases.Other provisions are planned to strengthen the control of traceability.As this resolution seeks to protect our citrus growers from the importation of cheaper products, I voted in favor.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - During the summer months, Europe imports its citrus fruits from third countries. But just as in an open economy the EU sets high standards for food that is produced and harvested within the EU, we apply the same criteria for food that is imported. In the specific case of citrus imports, we must be able to offer consumers good quality fruit, but at the same time we must ensure that feared pathogens do not gain a foothold here. I attach great importance to the certification and labeling of foodstuffs. In this way, the producer can convince the customer of the best quality of his products and, when a food incident occurs, the problem can be tackled right at the source. That is also the proposal of advice that I have approved. By imposing preventive cold treatment on citrus imports for a period of 27 days, the Commission has taken a hasty action that excludes any other effective measure, is insufficiently scientifically substantiated and will drive up citrus prices on store shelves. I voted against this, partly because it is best not to prevent possible incidents with citrus fruits along the way, but at the source.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, which calls on the Commission to implement a directive, which seeks to amend Annexes I to V to Directive 2000/29/EC, which undermines the requirements for the introduction into the European Union of certain fruits susceptible to pests, in particular regarding citrus black spot and citrus canker.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- We vote for this resolution, which calls for citrus imports to be subject to more phytosanitary controls so as to prevent the import of harmful organisms into our plantations.Imported fruits should meet the following conditions: registration of the production field, packaging facilities, exporters and any other operator involved in handling the specified fruits, the presence of documents issued under the control of thenational organization for the protection of plants during transport and, for certain fruits, the use of pre- and post-harvest treatments.These controls, which will prevent contamination of our citrus fruit production, are also a way of protecting them against increasingly aggressive competition from many third countries.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- I am voting for this proposal, which is also a way of protecting our citrus growers from the import of cheaper products from third countries.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the objection to the implementing directive of the European Commission amending Annexes I to V of Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on measures to protect plant health in theUnion.The text asks the Commission in particular to give up reducing the requirements for the importation of fruit intended for industrial processing into juice, to strengthen its requirements for the importation of fruit originating in countries where Phyllosticta citricarpa is present, or even totake measures to avoid the introduction of the insect Thaumatotibia leucotreta.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution regarding protective measures against the introduction of organisms harmful to plants and plants products.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because it corrects a mistake with regard to the Commission's proposal for a directive, which would have run counter to other aspects of European legislation on protection against organisms harmful to plants or plant products.In this respect, I support the amendments made in this report to the original proposal and I believe that they make the necessary adjustments to make the relevant EU legislation coherent.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out in favor of this resolution because the rapporteur's intention is correct and protection against plant pests must not be subject to incorrect legal assessment.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- Did not support.The resolution would restrict trade in citrus fruit, as it recognizes only one fruit conservation measure.The resolution is over-regulatory and precludes many other equally useful conservation measures.As a result, imports from third countries may decrease, leading to a reduction in the availability of fruit and an increase in price volatility.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the objection concerning a proposal for a new implementing act on phytosanitary measures for the import of plants and plant products.The Commission plan will amend the existing rules for citrus fruits intended for processing in specific countries.The proposed amendments are not in line with the new regulation and will pose a high phytosanitary risk to Europe.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Caring for plant health is one of the main foundations for the development of sustainable and competitive agriculture, ensuring healthy and quality food, environmental protection in general. The progress of plant health also affects the stable and secure supply of food to the national population, and the introduction of plants and plant products in the Republic of Croatia is prohibited if they are infected with certain harmful organisms. We have recently witnessed the emergence of a dangerous disease that destroys olives, caused by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa (Wells et al.), Which originates from America. The deadly bacterium introduced into the European agroecosystem, destroys olive groves, is transmitted by insects - vectors, and its appearance and domestication on the Salento Peninsula in Italy represent the highest phytosanitary risk for olive growing in the Republic of Croatia. The EU should identify phytosanitary risks posed by any species, strain or biotype of pathogens, animals or parasitic plants harmful to plants or plant products as well as measures to mitigate those risks to an acceptable level. The old Council Directive 2000/29 / EC does not provide the right answers to threats from diseases such as black citrus and bacterial cancer of citrus. I therefore supported the EU resolution calling for an amendment to Annexes I to V. Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- The draft Commission implementing directive is not in line with Union law, as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 to identify phytosanitary risks posed by any harmful organisms and measures to mitigate those risks to an acceptable level.The Commission was therefore asked to amend its draft implementing directive.Phytosanitary risk is particularly high in the warmer parts of Europe.Although most imports of citrus for processing relate to regions that are less susceptible to infected pests coming from outside Europe, there is a risk that pests from northern Europe could be transferred to warmer regions and thus infect citrus plants.The epidemic of Xyllela fastidiosa bacteria in Italy and the import of invasive alien species into Europe show the need to ensure that all imports of plants or plant products are free from harmful organisms.One infected plant can destroy an entire sector or the economy of an entire region.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - According to the European Commission's proposal, the entry of citrus fruits would only be conditioned to a mere visual inspection of the product and dependent on a declaration attesting the good health status of the fruit, and declaring that it comes from fields subject to treatment and control of Phyllosticta citricarpa (black spot). With this proposal, the Commission goes beyond its functions by proposing to weaken phytosanitary controls on imports, when Parliament and the Council agreed to strengthen these measures. This phytosanitary laxity promoted by the Commission can only be related to the enormous pressures of the processing and processing industry, namely for soft drinks in northern Europe, which intends to acquire raw material at low cost, thus increasing its profits. Moving forward, this measure will penalize citrus growers in two ways: first, through more than a certain increase in imports, with the consequent downward pressure on prices; second, calling into question the phytosanitary status of citrus groves, which are much more vulnerable to a number of pests, among which is Phyllosticta citricarpa, which the EU is still free from. We advocate strict controls on all imported citrus fruits, including sample analysis and traceability certificates.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- The measures envisaged in the draft Commission directive on plant protection do not sufficiently prevent the risks of importing exotic pests.This is why I voted in favor of this resolution which proposes to amend this directive.We call for citrus growers to be better protected against pests by increasing the requirements when importing fruit for processing, especially when it comes from countries where exotic pests are present.Sample checks should be tightened and contaminated fruit should be treated before importing into the Union.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution, which urges the Commission to change its directive. The draft implementing directive, as proposed by the Commission, does not in fact make it possible, as it stands, to reduce the risks associated with the importation of exotic parasites to an acceptable level, which is why we want rules more stringent. With this vote, the European Parliament refuses to be wait-and-see and wants to put in place appropriate rules to avoid a tragedy similar to that of the Xylella bacteria in areas of the Union that produce citrus fruits. For example and now, to prevent the introduction into the Union of citrus black spot disease, a fungal disease, it will be necessary to prove that a sample of at least 600 fruits from each batch of 30 tonnes has been checked. before packaging, and fruits showing symptoms of the disease are properly tested. Citrus fruit potentially infected with a false codling moth larvae will then have to undergo cold treatment or other equally effective and long-lasting treatments before being imported into the Union. The text also intends to improve the traceability of imported citrus fruits.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this objection, believing that the measures envisaged to combat the introduction of plant pests are not strict enough to protect producers in the European Union.We cannot accept that the European Commission will not act by proposing simplified and lean measures.We must maintain the requirements for importing from third countries, regardless of the destination of the product.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- With this Directive the Commission is going in the opposite direction to the legislation passed on "Protective measures against plant pests", as it is much less demanding than this, undermining the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruits susceptible to pests,particularly with regard to citrus black spot and citrus canker.Thus, this proposed modification directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector in southern Europe, and underestimates the phytosanitary threat posed by citrus imports from third countries.The motion for a resolution proposes the amendment of this directive in such a way as to ensure that adequate controls are carried out against the entry of fruit, especially citrus, into the Union.That is why I have voted in favor of it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not wish to see even more EU laws.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of this objection, which concerns a proposal for a new implementing act on the phytosanitary measures for import of plants and plants products. The Commission draft would modify the existing rules for citruses for processing in specific countries. The outbreak of Xyllela fastidiosa in Italy and the introduction of invasive alien species in Europe show that we need to ensure that all imports of plants or plants products are free of pests. One infected plant can destroy a whole sector or the economy of a whole region.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this objection.I support strict import requirements so as to ensure the protection of the EU's territory.Applying "weaker" or lighter import rules increases the risk of pest introduction and thus increases the likelihood that Member States will have to spend enormous resources to eradicate diseases and consequently reduce the production of "domestic" citrus fruits from the EU, become dependent on imports and increasethe price of domestic (EU) citrus.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and success.actions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the objection to the Commission's implementing act on phytosanitary measures for imports of plants and plant products, as the Commission does not take into account the new rules applicable in this area. There are fears that certain harmful organisms could be introduced, especially in the southern regions of Europe. The Commission proposal concerns the adjustment of citrus processing rules in certain countries. Especially in Italy, where the bacterium xyllela fastidiosa is spreading, they realize that invasive species can have a detrimental effect on entire sectors of the economy. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to amend its decision so that it is also in line with the recommendations of the professional bodies responsible for the protection of plant species. Invasive species may be introduced for citrus imports even if the imported fruit is found in northern Europe. Therefore, rules must be applied to prevent such dissemination. I therefore expect the Commission to adjust its proposal in the light of current knowledge and expert advice.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- We must protect European crop production and nature from pests introduced into the European Union in the context of global trade.We are clarifying some provisions of the directive so that they are in line with other legislation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The resolution deals with the introduction of protective measures against the introduction of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and their spread within the Community.The introduction of safeguard measures should take place as soon as the Resolution is put into practice.The European Parliament considers that the Commission proposal is inconsistent with Union law and incompatible with Resolution (EU) 2016/2031.It therefore calls on the Commission to modify and adapt the proposal through the three modifications presented in the resolution to be forwarded to the Council and the Commission and to the governments and parliaments of the Member States.I support this resolution because I believe that food and production need to be better protected.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the draft motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing directive amending Annexes I to V to the Council Directive on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community.I agree that the Commission's draft implementing directive is not in line with Union law, as it is not in line with the aim of the regulation.It states, inter alia, that the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, species or biotype of pathogenic organisms, animals or parasitic plants that harm plants or plant products must be determined.In addition, measures need to be put in place to reduce risks to an acceptable level.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The EU must take all necessary measures to identify the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, strain or biotype of pathogens, animals or parasitic plants that are harmful to plants or plant products ("harmful organisms"), as well asappropriate measures to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion to object to the draft Commission implementing directive amending the Council directive on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community. According to the complaint, the draft Commission implementing directive jeopardizes the rules on the introduction into the Union of fruit susceptible to certain pests, in particular citrus black spot and citrus xanthomonas disease. Moreover, it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 to identify plant health risks posed by pathogens, animals or species of plants or parasites harmful to plants or plant products or to provide for measures to reduce those risks to an acceptable level. in order to. The outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa in Italy and the rise of invasive species in Europe show that we need to ensure that all imported plants or plant products are pest-free. An infected plant can destroy an entire sector, native wildlife, or the economy of a region.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The European Union must ensure food and plant safety in the Member States. In the case of imported products, there is a risk that certain organisms harmful to plants or plant products will enter the territory of the Member States and affect similar Union crops by spreading them. This is particularly the case for citrus fruits imported from third countries and whose pests, such as Xyllela fastidiosa, can destroy existing crops in the southern states of the Union. Therefore, it is necessary to take effective protection measures against the spread of these pests, such as cold treatment, according to the recommendations of the European and Mediterranean Plant Protection Organization (EPPO), but also to carefully check the quality of imported products. This is an important measure. The amendment to the regulation proposed by the Commission is not in line with existing European legislation and needs to be substantially improved. For these reasons, I support the adoption of this necessary resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I share the rapporteur's opinion.Indeed, I consider that the Commission's proposal for an implementing directive does not comply with EU law, as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031, which isto determine the phytosanitary risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants or plant products.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The protective measures against the introduction of citrus fruit organisms into the EU overrules decisions made by EU scientists and researchers. The resolution proposed unnecessary measures for third countries wanting to import citrus fruits into the EU, in the unfounded fear that the introduction of new organisms would be harmful to existing organism communities in certain regions. I voted against the resolution because, in reality, it would mean a total stop of citrus imports from some countries, decreasing the supply and availability of citrus fruits, and therefore would increase the prices for EU consumers. Further, the resolution would go against already existing legislation that is scientifically supported, and would impose futile, stricter and unnecessary measures.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a resolution under Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure: Safeguard measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants and plant products and against their spread within the Community" with regard to Articles 11 and 13 of Regulation no.Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down the rules and general principles concerning mechanisms for control by Member States of the Commission's exercise of implementing powers.The draft implementing directive is not in line with the objectives of Regulation 2016/2031.The draft must be amended in the sense that it is necessary to introduce a clause that fruits from third countries must have a phytosanitary certificate and a statement that the area of fruit production has been treated appropriately.It is necessary to attach an additional statement that the area of production of these fruits has been adequately treated against Phyllosticte citricarpe and that the cultivation methods have been carried out at the appropriate time since the beginning of the last cycle of vegetation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the draft motion for a European Parliament resolution on the draft Commission implementation directive amending Annexes I to V to Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community.The draft Commission Implementing Directive is not in line with Union law, as it is not in line with the objective of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031, ie.identify the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, species or biotype of pathogenic organisms, animals or parasitic plants that harm plants or plant products (pests) and measures to reduce those risks to an acceptable level.In this context, it would like to recall that Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 will repeal and replace Directive 2000/29 / EC as soon as it enters into force (14 December 2019).

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- The resolution proposed here aims to increase controls on the introduction into the European Union of fruit - in this case, citrus - originating in third countries.This resolution requires that citrus fruits originating in third countries be accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate proving that the fruits originate from a field of production which has been subjected, at the appropriate time, to treatments against various diseases which particularly affect citrus fruits..This proposal calls for the strengthening of controls on these fruits which could contaminate production in Europe.I choose to support this objection because it is a way of protecting our citrus growers from the importation of cheaper products from third countries.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- Tighter controls on the import of citrus fruit increase the risk of a complaint to the WTO and will impose disproportionate and unjustified requirements on exporting countries, which have not experienced any problems so far.The proposed changes also go beyond EFSA's recommendations.In the case of persistent third country acquisitions, this problem should be addressed through emergency measures rather than through a general tightening of measures.As regards the restriction to the use of the freezing process only, it is particularly prescriptive and would not allow testing and application of new scientific processes.I voted against the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft Implementing Directive amending Annexes I to V of Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community against organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread within the Community. This resolution directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector for southern Europe. The resolution calls into question the phytosanitary agreement reached in relation to the importation of citrus from third countries. We consider it essential that the fruit that enters the Union complies with the consequent health processes, detailed labeling and packaging that also complies with the established standards. The European Parliament and the Council already voted in October to tighten the phytosanitary controls (we support it) so I believe that the citrus sector should be included in this process.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution because prevention is better than cure: strict controls are needed to prevent the entry of damaging pests of permanent crops like citrus trees, to protect the livelihoods of producers and so as not to resort to environmentally damaging eradication measures.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I consider that the Commission's draft implementing directive is incompatible with Union law as it is incompatible with Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.The purpose of 2016/2031 is to define the phytosanitary risks posed by pathogens, animals or parasitic plants of any species, strain or biotype harmful to plants or plant products (referred to in the Regulation as pests) and the measures to reduce those risks to an acceptable level.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this resolution, this chamber expresses its rejection of the plans of the European Commission to reduce controls on pests from imports from third countries, asking the Commission to strengthen measures to prevent the spread of new diseases in the European territory.The safety of European productions depends largely on the operation of controls on imports from third countries.It is intolerable that controls are reduced, so this resolution is very necessary to be able to avoid these behaviors.For this reason, I think it appropriate to vote in their favor.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- With this Directive the Commission is going in the opposite direction to the legislation passed on "Protective measures against plant pests", as it is much less demanding than this, undermining the requirements for the introduction into the Union of certain fruits susceptible to pests,particularly with regard to citrus black spot and citrus canker.Thus, this proposed modification directly affects the citrus sector, a strategic sector in southern Europe, and underestimates the phytosanitary threat posed by citrus imports from third countries.The motion for a resolution proposes the amendment of this directive in such a way as to ensure that adequate controls are carried out against the entry of fruit, especially citrus, into the Union.That is why I have voted in favor of it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- After having been voted in the October plenary and approved Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 October 2016 on measures to protect against plant pests, the CommissionEuropean Commission now presents a draft Commission Implementing Directive that goes in precisely the opposite direction to the regulation.By weakening the approved legislation, it calls into question the requirements for the placing on the market of certain fruit susceptible to pests, in particular citrus fruit for processing, and black-spotted pests, among others.According to the proposal, the entry of citrus fruit would only be conditional on a mere visual inspection of the product and a declaration attesting the good health status of the fruit, and declaring that it comes from fields subject to the treatment and control of Phyllosticta citricarpa (stainblack).Unacceptable.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The rapporteur is of the opinion that the implementing directive planned by the Commission is not in line with Regulation 2016/2031.Regulation 2016/2031, as the rapporteur also correctly recognizes, actually replaces the legal basis of the planned implementation guideline RL 2000/29, but not until December 2019. However, since the protection against plant pests must not be subject to an incorrect legal assessment, I have this applicationcarried along.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution on the proposal for an implementing directive amending the directive on protective measures against the introduction into the EU of harmful organisms. This directive is part of legislation that seeks to protect plants and plant products from diseases and pests from third countries that can enter and spread within the EU, not only through illegal smuggling but also through normal imports. This is also the case with this objection. The implementing directive, against which the opposition is directed, sought to relax the measures on imports of citrus fruits in connection with the so-called black spots caused by Phyllosticta citricarpa. The problem, however, is that this directive runs counter to the regulation that has already been adopted, which will replace it in the future. I think that in these cases, when it comes to either human health, the environment, or this objection to phytosanitary safety, the basic principle that we must follow is the protection of a given value. In this case, therefore, the protection of the territory against the introduction and spread of pests into the territory of the European Union must take precedence over commercial interests. We must not allow ourselves to harm the domestic agricultural sectors by abandoning import requirements in the interests of commercial profit and thus risking the uncontrollable spread of an alien pest.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the resolution that opposes the introduction of organisms harmful to plants and plant products in order to prevent their spread within the European Union.This objection was necessary because the outbreak of bacteria (notably xyllela fasttidiosa in Italy) and the introduction of invasive species in Europe, demonstrate that it is necessary to ensure that all imports of plants or plant products are free from pests.An infected plant can destroy an entire sector or the economy of an entire region.I therefore highlight the need for the specified fruits originating in third countries to be accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate that proves that these fruits originate in a production field that has undergone appropriate treatments to prevent the spread of bacteria and pests.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution of 15 December 2016 on the draft Commission implementing directive amending Annexes I to V to Council Directive 2000/29 / EC on protective measures against the introduction into the Community of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and againsttheir spread within the Community.The resolution notes that the Commission's draft implementing directive is not in line with Union law, as it is not in line with the objective of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031, ie.identify the phytosanitary risks posed by any species, species or biotype of pathogenic organisms, animals or parasitic plants that harm plants or plant products (pests) and measures to reduce those risks to an acceptable level.I therefore believe that the proposals proposed by the Commission to remedy this discrepancy are necessary.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, the superficial control of some pharmaceuticals has led to the tragedy caused by thalidomide, a medicine that has been prescribed and administered to pregnant women.As a result of using this drug, children with malformations were born and this was happening in the 60's.These children are currently living and there are thousands of people suffering from this drug.Many of them, those who survived, cannot afford the costs of medical and social services, even though they have serious and permanent illnesses.I therefore call on the Commission to create a legal framework for all thalidomide patients to receive similar support and compensation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I would also like to begin by expressing my solidarity with the victims of this tragedy, which happened many years ago but cannot be forgotten.It is necessary to remember what the beginning of the case was and to help these victims who still live among us.It is not just a question of compensation, it is a question of practical life, when those people need help with spending on health insurance, medical expenses, they have several times higher needs, precisely when it comes to taking care of their health.I think this is something that Europe owes them, and I am very pleased that it was raised at the European Parliament and that we will be able to watch the Commission try to prepare legislative proposals so that we can specifically help these victims..

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I will follow up on what my colleagues have said.I also supported the final resolution.Personally, I believe that at a time when a particular drug harms the citizens of several European Union countries and each country then compensates these victims in a completely different way and at a different rate, everyone will probably think that it is not entirely fair and right.Here, at least a certain coordinating role can be played by the European Union and the European Commission, which can act as a mediator and try to negotiate the same and, above all, sufficiently significant compensation for all victims to enable them to lead a dignified life.That is why I supported it, but I do not believe, on the other hand, that the Commission should adopt any binding legislation here.Its role should be limited to the mediator, who negotiates the conditions for compensation, rather than to the adoption of new legislation.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
