text: - I am very pleased that the EP has today adopted a resolution on support for those affected by the side effects of thalidomide.The use of this medicine by women during pregnancy has resulted in serious harm to the fetus.On the one hand, we can consider it a plus on the part of the European institutions to deal with this indebtedness to those affected, but on the other hand, it is a shame that the problem is not resolved even after more than 50 years.That also says something about our company.I hope that the compensation will not last too long, because the injured will not live to see it.I would like to point out one more thing.I am convinced that even today, informing citizens about the side and side effects of certain medicines or medicines is not complete and consistent.I will only mention the underestimation of awareness in the use of hormonal contraception, as well as in medicines used in the medical termination of pregnancy, or in various endocrine disruptors.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I identify the provision of aid and effective health services as a priority for those affected by Thalidomide, both in light of their current and future needs. I deeply regret the daily struggles experienced by victims, and I thus support this motion for a resolution as a means to enhance pharmaceutical legislation, transparency in judicial proceedings, and treatment and support for those affected. It is essential that we right the wrongs of failed pharmaceutical monitoring of the past, thus formally recognising victims and providing adequate compensation. In doing so, and establishing a more concrete framework in this area, we may shoulder at least a percentage of the burden experienced by victims. By so doing, we show once again that the European Union, and the European Parliament in particular, stand up for the rights of the downtrodden and victimised.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: written.- Today, the European Parliament voted on a resolution on compensation for those suffering from neurosis.The resolution underlines the importance of victims being compensated for their injuries and that EU member states, as well as the pharmaceutical companies concerned, take responsibility.This is an important message that I of course support, I therefore chose to vote yes in the final vote.At the same time, I would like to emphasize that health care issues are a national competence, which the resolution does not show sufficient understanding of.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- Thalidomide is a drug invented by the German pharmaceutical industry Chemie Grünenthal which was marketed starting in 1957 as an anti-nausea and hypnotic sedative, aimed especially at pregnant women.It was withdrawn from the market because women treated with thalidomide gave birth to infants with severe congenital changes in limb development, namely amelia or varying degrees of phocomelia.It is estimated that at least 20,000 children with severe physical malformations have been born.Believing that full recognition of the requests of surviving thalidomide victims in Europe is essential, so as to guarantee their autonomy, access to medical care and an adequate quality of life, I voted in favor.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution so that the Member States and the European Commission implement a European protocol so that survivors of thalidomide are formally recognized, regardless of the country to which they belong, and receive adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Foundation. This resolution puts pressure on the German Government to expand the funding available for thalidomide victims in Germany to survivors from other affected countries, including Spain. In Spain, only the socialist government of Rodríguez Zapatero adopted measures to compensate those affected, establishing aid based on the degree of disability. Since last March, we Socialists have promoted a debate in the European Parliament to urge the current government to continue actions in this regard, having established ourselves as allies in the struggle of the Spanish survivors / victims of thalidomide so that their rights in the face of what has been the greatest medical disaster of the 20th century. Hundreds of affected victims have died without recognition or compensation. Today we have another opportunity not to condemn to oblivion the survivors of this historical injustice.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution because it requests the involvement of the German State, the European Commission and various Member States (including Spain), to develop systems for mutual recognition and compensation for victims of thalidomide, a drug produced by the pharmaceutical company Grünenthal to avoid nausea and other side effects of pregnancy, but which nevertheless ended up causing the malformation of thousands of babies throughout the continent (about three thousand only in Spain). However, I think that the obligation of the Member States is to enforce the protection of the fundamental rights of their citizens, also in the health framework. In this way, they should oblige the pharmaceutical companies that commercialized this product to assume their criminal responsibility, and alternatively, grant recognition of the condition of victims in order to access the corresponding compensation systems. Said systems must act with the maximum guarantees and facilitating bona fide access to compensation for potential beneficiaries. Finally, it is necessary in the Spanish State to review Royal Decree 1006/2010 for the granting of aid to victims, guaranteeing affordable terms and adequate financing.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on support for thalidomide victims. Since 1957, when the German pharmaceutical company Chemie Grünenthal launched thalidomide, an anti-nausea medicine, also for pregnant women, at least 20,000 children have been born with severe physical birth defects. There are more than 4,000 thalidomide victims in Europe, including 2,800 in Germany, 450 in Italy, 400 in the United Kingdom, 400 in Spain, 103 in Sweden and about 90 in Austria. 2015 The findings of a study on the health, quality of life and employment of tolidomide victims in the United Kingdom in 2006 revealed the growing physical and psychological problems faced by thalidomide victims over time, as well as their specific medical, financial and social needs. I voted in favor of the resolution in favor of the full recognition of the claims of thalidomide survivors in Europe in order to ensure their independence, access to healthcare and the maintenance of a good quality of life. I support the desire for compensation for victims, which would allow them to cover the necessary but costly and growing costs of their healthcare.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the above resolution on support for the victims of thalidomide, as I consider it necessary for their official recognition by all Member States.It is time to give fair and adequate compensation to the victims of the substance from the special fund of the German Contegran Foundation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - In the years 1950 to 1960, Thalidomide, anti nausea - vomiting drug of the German pharmaceutical company Chemie-Grünenthal was given to pregnant women. More than 20,000 babies have died or been born malformed. To date, there are believed to be over 4,000 survivors in Europe: 450 in Italy, 90 in Austria, 2,800 in Germany, 103 in Sweden, 400 in Spain, 400 in the United Kingdom. 60 years later, these survivors are still seeking justice, especially to cover the medical costs associated with their condition. I voted against the resolution of the Socialist Group which directly addresses the Member States and the European Commission to coordinate their actions, in particular with the creation of a framework protocol at European level. This motion for a resolution undermines the sovereignty of States. Our motion for a resolution sponsored by Italian MEPs Salvini, Bizzotto, Borghezio, Ciocca and Fontana calls for the creation of a European Commission assistance program to support and add value to the actions of the Member States. This motion for a resolution respects the sovereignty of the Member States, so I voted in favor.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy I wish to confirm that I voted in favour of this resolution. Fair support and compensation for Thalidomide victims is important and we should be in favour of such action.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution seeks to help victims of thalidomide, an anti-nausea medicine introduced in the 1950s. The drug marketing company has concealed side effects for pregnant women, so thousands of people around the world have been born with physical and mental illnesses as a result of the drug’s harmful side effects. Unfortunately, in a criminal lawsuit in the 1970s, the company managed to get the criminal lawsuit closed without paying damages. The injured, who are in their fifties and sixties, have reported worsening effects of their birth defects, which has induced them to incur increased health care costs and increasingly expensive therapeutic treatments. Recognizing the problem, the EU Commissioner responsible indicated that the settlement of healthcare costs for these victims should be addressed at EU level, but so far no meaningful steps have been taken. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to take steps to represent victims' interests at EU level and to provide them with resources for their healthcare, and to oblige the company to acknowledge its own responsibility and pay victims an acceptable amount of compensation in the event of a reopening. Based on the above, I supported the adoption of the motion.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this joint resolution which first of all recalls the tragedy caused by the commercialization of thalidomide at the end of the 1950s and early 1960s since this resulted in the death or malformation of thousands of newborns in manymany European countries.It then calls for Member States and the Commission to coordinate actions and measures aimed at formally recognizing and compensating thalidomide survivors.It also calls on the German government to provide access for recognized victims to the Thalidomide Foundation for the Disabled.Likewise, MEPs call for thalidomide survivors from the UK, Spain, Italy, Sweden and other Member States to be admitted to the scheme on a collective basis once their status as thalidomide victim has been accepted.in their country.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this just and necessary Resolution to try to settle the outstanding debt with the victims of thalidomide. The approved text contains several provisions that directly involve the Government of Spain in order to facilitate the identification of victims so that they can access the special fund for health of the Contergan Foundation. I have led this Resolution within my political Group, ALDE. I enlisted the support of my liberal colleagues to introduce an amendment to the text specifying the responsibilities that the Grünenthal company must assume. In this way, the German pharmaceutical company must compensate and assist the victims who have not yet been rewarded, and establish a dialogue with them. The amendment was approved by a large majority in plenary. I hope that this resolution and this amendment will contribute to ending one of the greatest injustices that I have been able to see first-hand in my parliamentary activity. In particular, the historical discrimination suffered by Spanish victims, the only ones who have not been rewarded by the company in more than 60 years, must end.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution asking the Commission to detail what measures have been taken and what will be taken at Union level to provide effective support and assistance to thalidomide victims and their families and,to extend support to all European citizens affected by thalidomide.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported and signed this Resolution on Thalidomide Victims, Who Need Recognition, so that Member States and the Commission coordinate their actions and measures with a view to officially recognizing Thalidomide survivors and offering them compensation.I have also supported the amendment presented by my group in which the Grünenthal company is asked to assume its responsibilities, compensating and duly attending to victims awaiting recognition, reviewing the procedure for recognition of victim status and initiating a dialoguewith the victims to remedy the damage caused.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- In the 1950s and 1960s, Thalidomide, an anti-nausea and anti-vomiting drug from the German pharmaceutical company Chemie-Grünenthal, was given to pregnant women.More than 20,000 babies have died or been born malformed.To date, there are believed to be over 4,000 survivors in Europe: 450 in Italy, 90 in Austria, 2,800 in Germany, 103 in Sweden, 400 in Spain, 400 in the United Kingdom.Sixty years later, these survivors are still seeking justice, especially to cover the medical costs associated with their condition.The ENF group, and in particular my Italian colleagues from the Northern League, including Mara Bizzotto, have also tabled a resolution calling for the creation of an assistance program from the European Commission to support the actions of Member States and'' bring them added value, while respecting their sovereignty.So I voted for this resolution and against the S & amp; D resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - After the German pharmaceutical industry Chemie Grünenthal introduced thalidomide, an antiemetic drug also intended for pregnant women, on the market in 1957, at least 20,000 children with severe physical malformations and phocomelia were born in Europe. The survivors of that horror are now about 4 000, of which 450 are Italian. I, together with the Northern League, have been in contact since 2014 with the European exponents of the associations that bring together Italian and European thalidomics and have always supported their battle by presenting various parliamentary activities. On March 9, during the plenary session in Strasbourg, Commissioner Andriukaitis spoke firmly to emphasize the importance of guaranteeing the victims of thalidomide financial support, medical treatment and full social inclusion. Both the joint resolution and the one presented by our group therefore collect the conclusions of that debate, confirming Parliament's full support for the victims of what can be considered, with good reason, the most serious collective disaster ever caused by a drug. Given these premises, I can only strongly support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution so that the Member States and the European Commission implement a European protocol so that survivors of thalidomide are formally recognized, regardless of the country to which they belong, and receive adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Foundation. This resolution puts pressure on the German government to extend the funding available for thalidomide victims in Germany to survivors from other affected countries, including Spain. In Spain, only the socialist government of Zapatero adopted measures to compensate those affected, establishing aid based on the degree of disability. Since the declaration of the representatives of the victims in the Committee on Petitions, the Socialists led a debate in the European Parliament in order to pressure the German Government to extend the funding available for German victims to survivors from other countries. Since then, we have been urging the current government to continue actions in this regard, having established ourselves as allies in the struggle of the Spanish survivors / victims to have their rights recognized in the face of the greatest medical disaster of the 20th century.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, in which the European Parliament points out that Parliament and the European Commission can and must now, in accordance with ethical and humanitarian standards, remedy the damage caused by failed pharmaceutical controls and subsequent concealed evidence. thalidomide tragedy. Parliament also notes that in 2016 June The German Federal Government has acknowledged that by 2017 month of January. it is necessary and possible to amend the German legislation on the thalidomide fund. Parliament therefore urges the Member States and the Commission to take coordinated action and measures to formally recognize and compensate thalidomide victims. In addition, calls on the German Federal Government to make use of the possibility provided by the forthcoming legislation amending the thalidomide fund to allow thalidomide victims identified as such under court-appointed trust schemes or beneficiaries of national government schemes to benefit from a special German health fund, the thalidomide fund for the disabled; . Parliament also urges the Commission to establish a framework protocol at European level to provide equal compensation to all European citizens affected by thalidomide, regardless of their Member State of origin, and to draw up EU assistance and support (including provisions on financial and social assistance). ) for thalidomide victims and their families.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution in which we ask the Commission and the Member States to ensure fair compensation for EU citizens who are victims of thalidomide.More than fifty years after the tragedy of thalidomide, a morning sickness medicine for pregnant women that caused their newborn babies to malform in several EU countries, victims are still fighting for fair compensation.We want actions and measures to be coordinated to officially recognize and ensure compensation for surviving victims.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: in writing. – I support this report because Thalidomide survivors should be formally recognised in all Member States concerned and finally be given adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Stiftung.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - From the late 1950s to 1961, thalidomide, a drug used at the time to reduce morning sickness in pregnant women, caused 20,000 disabled children and 100,000 people permanently damaged. The survivors of thalidomide are still waiting for adequate compensation, a form of community assistance, a public acknowledgment of their plight. We appeal to the German government to remedy a tragic mistake made sixty years ago, to find an equitable solution to the difficulties that people like him are experiencing. Thalidomide was marketed in West Germany in 1957 as an over-the-counter medicine to aid sleep and relieve symptoms of nausea in pregnant women. According to the manufacturer, Chemie Grünenthal, it was not addictive and was completely safe, even in pregnancy. By 1960 it was sold with great success in 46 countries. In 1961, the Australian gynecologist William McBride and the German pediatrician Widukind Lenz demonstrated the correlation between malformations in newborns and taking the drug during pregnancy. Consequently, thalidomide was withdrawn from the market. Today, in the light of scientific and legal research confirming the responsibility of thalidomide, the European Parliament is calling on the Commission to adopt formal recognition for victims.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution so that the Member States and the European Commission implement a European protocol so that survivors of thalidomide are formally recognized, regardless of the country to which they belong, and receive adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Foundation. This resolution puts pressure on the German Government to expand the funding available for thalidomide victims in Germany to survivors from other affected countries, including Spain. In Spain, only the socialist government of Rodríguez Zapatero adopted measures to compensate those affected, establishing aid based on the degree of disability. Since last March, we Socialists have promoted a debate in the European Parliament to urge the current government to continue actions in this regard, having established ourselves as allies in the struggle of the Spanish survivors / victims of thalidomide so that their rights in the face of what has been the greatest medical disaster of the 20th century. Hundreds of affected victims have died without recognition or compensation. Today we have another opportunity not to condemn to oblivion the survivors of this historical injustice.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution on thalidomide which requires a framework protocol at European level in which all European citizens who are victims of thalidomide receive comparable compensation, irrespective of the Member State of origin. Thalidomide represents the most serious collective disaster ever caused by a drug. It was marketed by Chemie Grünenthal GmbH in the late 1950s and early 1960s as a safe drug for the treatment of headaches, coughs, insomnia and colds. It resulted in the death and malformation of thousands of children in many European countries when taken by pregnant women. It is a scandal that, after almost sixty years, the survivors are still looking for justice and a compensatory solution that will allow them to sustain the necessary expensive treatments linked to their physical condition. The report calls for full recognition of the claims of surviving thalidomide victims in Europe, so as to ensure their autonomy, access to medical care and an adequate quality of life.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the well-known issue of thalidomide – the largest medical scandal of the 20th century. Produced by German pharmaceutical company Grunenthal, thalidomide was marketed in the 1950s as a safe drug and was used by pregnant women to ease their morning sickness, which led to 20 000 babies being born with severe deformities while another 80 000 were miscarried, stillborn or died in infancy.  The product was eventually withdrawn in the early 1960s but the trial against nine Grunenthal employees was prematurely ended in 1970 after the Federal German Government intervened to end it – subsequently meaning that no one has ever received a criminal conviction for the disaster.  Whether or not a thalidomide victim received any lump-sum payments and special monthly living allowances depends very much on the country they came from. This resolution calls on the Thalidomide Foundation (which provides funds from Grunenthal in Germany to help the victims) to be open to all victims no matter which country they are in and also calls for a protocol to ensure that all victims receive similar amounts of compensation. For these reasons I supported the resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution as many survivors throughout the EU are often unable to apply for funding to cover the costs of social services, which is currently the single biggest concern for thalidomide survivors who, now in their 50s and 60s, are going to need these services even more often in the coming years, as they become more dependent on their carers. Thalidomide survivors need increasing support for their unmet health needs, as their bodies are rapidly deteriorating owing to the nature of their disabilities and to the lack of support over the years since their birth. The resolution urges Member States and the Commission to coordinate actions and measures seeking to formally recognise and provide compensation to thalidomide survivors. I urge the Commission to create a framework protocol at European level for all European Union citizens affected by thalidomide to receive similar amounts of compensation, regardless of which Member State they are from, and to draw up an EU programme for assistance and support for thalidomide victims and their families.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- Following the release on the European market of the anti-nausea drug called thalidomide by the German pharmaceutical industry Chemie Grünenthal in 1957, at least 20,000 children with severe physical defects were born.There are thousands of people affected by these malformations (500 in Italy) who have never received full and fair compensation for the damage suffered.I definitely voted in favor.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ All victims who are yet to be recognised ought to receive proper compensation from the companies involved, which must shoulder their responsibilities. It is very important to adopt an EU-wide approach to the compensation system, since we are dealing with companies which have affected EU citizens spanning from Ireland to Spain and Sweden. There is no legitimate reason why the victims should be treated differently across the EU, and that is why they should receive commensurate compensation.  Monetary compensation alone, however, will not be a satisfactory answer. Assistance and support for the surviving victims, including their families, is vital so as to help them with unmet health needs, barriers and the stigma they face day in and day out. Thalidomide survivors have beaten the life expectancy originally set by doctors back in the 70s and 80s. However, they have been faced with deteriorating health and chronic pain as a result of their disability.  Fifty years on, the fight for Thalidomide survivors goes on. All survivors should be formally recognised in all EU Member States concerned and be finally given adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Conterganstiftung.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Thalidomide is an antiemetic drug also intended for pregnant women that was introduced on the European market in 1957 by the German pharmaceutical industry Chemie Grünenthal. The drug's side effects on pregnant women are estimated to have resulted in the birth of at least 20,000 babies with severe physical malformations. The resolution, for which I have voted in favor, calls on the Member States and the Commission to formally recognize the surviving victims of thalidomide in Europe and to provide them with appropriate compensation. In particular, since this is the most serious collective disaster ever caused by a drug, I believe it is appropriate for the Commission to establish a Community protocol that will allow all victims of thalidomide to obtain compensation of the same amount regardless of the Member State of origin. It also seems to me necessary to develop a program at European level aimed at assisting and supporting the victims and their families both financially and healthily. It also seems to me appropriate that the German Federal Government allow thalidomide survivors, recognized as such by the courts, access to the Special Health Fund for Persons with Disabilities due to Thalidomide.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We consider it essential to recognize the demands of thalidomide survivors in Europe, in order to ensure their autonomy, access to health care and a decent quality of life.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- We voted on the motion for a resolution to provide support to victims of thalidomide.It is obvious that we have to stand by citizens and relatives of citizens whose health has been damaged by thalidomide, and that is why I voted in favor.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Positive vote.Full support of our political group for the victims of the drug thalidomide, an antiemetic intended for pregnant women.The damage the drug did to the children of these women was terrible;in Europe, about 20 000 newborns have reported severe physical malformations and phocomelia.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions on support for Thalidomide victims.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I abstained on this resolution.There is no question that thalidomide victims need compensation and our support.But from my point of view, this is not a European question. The compensation is about claims that must be made directly to institutions such as the Contergan Foundation in Germany.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the measure as it urges the Commission to establish a framework protocol at European level so that all European citizens affected by thalidomide receive compensation of a similar amount, regardless of their Member State of origin, and to develop an EU program ofassistance and support (including financial and social provisions) for thalidomide victims and their families.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution because it requests the involvement of the German State, the European Commission and various Member States (including Spain), to develop systems for mutual recognition and compensation for victims of thalidomide, a drug produced by the pharmaceutical company Grünenthal to avoid nausea and other side effects of pregnancy, but which nevertheless ended up causing the malformation of thousands of babies throughout the continent (about three thousand only in Spain). However, I think that the obligation of the Member States is to enforce the protection of the fundamental rights of their citizens, also in the health framework. In this way, they should oblige the pharmaceutical companies that commercialized this product to assume their criminal responsibility, and alternatively, grant recognition of the condition of victims in order to access the corresponding compensation systems. Said systems must act with the maximum guarantees and facilitating bona fide access to compensation for potential beneficiaries. Finally, it is necessary in the Spanish State to review Royal Decree 1006/2010 for the granting of aid to victims, guaranteeing affordable terms and adequate financing.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing.- The thalidomide affair represents one of the most serious collective disasters ever caused by a drug, whose investigations to ascertain irregularities have revealed gaps in terms of pharmacovigilance by the states that have placed it on their market.I believe it is important to provide thalidomide survivors with financial support to meet their ever-increasing medical bills, recognizing the need to find an adequate solution for all survivors to ensure that their quality of life is protected.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - In view of the drama of women adversely affected by the drug thalidomide, I voted in favor of the resolution guaranteeing support for the victims of the drug. Thalidomide was used to treat nausea in pregnant women, as well as headaches, insomnia and colds in the late 1950s and early 1960s. It caused fetal deformities, particularly in the form of shortened or absent limbs. It is devastating that this has happened in many Member States and that victims are still not financially adequately secured to cope with rising medical costs. The seriousness of the problem is underlined by the fact that the case was one of the main reasons for the adoption of the EU pharmaceutical regulatory framework. I fully support the resolution asking for coordination of actions supporting victims in their efforts to obtain compensation, stepping up actions in individual countries (such as Germany or Spain) and establishing a European support program, and calling on the drug company (Grünenthal GmbH) to plead guilty and pay damages due.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Thalidomide was a drug used against nausea in pregnant women. Back in the 1950s and 1960s this drug resulted in malformations in infants and in many cases it was also fatal. As the S&D sponsor of this resolution, I am in favour of recognition and compensation to all survivors in Europe. We need to urge both Member States and the Commission to coordinate actions and take measures to formally recognise and provide compensation to Thalidomide survivors.  The German Federal Government should use the opportunity presented by the forthcoming amendment to the Thalidomide Foundation Act, to allow Thalidomide survivors who have been accredited as such by court-appointed trust schemes, or are beneficiaries of national government schemes, to access the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Stiftung. We request that Thalidomide survivors be admitted to the scheme on a group basis, where their status as Thalidomide-affected individuals has been accepted as bona fide in their own countries. The Commission needs to create a framework protocol at European level under which all European citizens affected by Thalidomide would receive similar amounts of compensation, regardless of which Member State they are from.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution, which I co-signed, as an overdue statement of support for Thalidomide victims. Many governments, and in particular the German Government, have failed in their duty of care to Thalidomide survivors. They, and Grünenthal GmbH, which has still to this day not accepted full responsibility for its actions 50 years ago, need to start working together in the interests of Thalidomide survivors.  I hope this resolution sends a strong signal that action is needed now, as Thalidomide survivors and their carers reach a stage in their lives where more assistance will inevitably be needed. They have waited long enough for proper compensation.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This resolution affirms its support for the victims of Thalidomide, a drug released in 1954 to prevent nausea in pregnant women.The drug has caused many cases of malformation of newborns, around 10,000 children have been affected, of which 5,000 are still alive.This resolution strongly condemns Member States that have been slow to take Thalidomide off the market, in particular Spain, which was the last state to ban the drug.MEPs also call on Member States to guarantee assistance, as well as adequate compensation, to victims of Thalidomide to cover the costs related to their medical and physical condition.Supporting these goals, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on support for victims of thalidomide.Frequently used in Europe during the 1950s, this drug is responsible for many birth defects.Each Member State has adopted different measures for the care of thalidomide victims.Since the extent and amount of support should not depend on the nationality of the victims, we call for better recognition of the status of thalidomide victims at European level.We also call on the company responsible for the production of thalidomide to assume its responsibilities.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- Thalidomide is a medicine which can have serious side effects when used without proper control.It can in particular be the cause of fetal malformation in pregnant women, and caused many victims in the 1960s. This resolution seeks to extend the recognition of these victims to all Member States.This recognition will therefore allow the extension of compensation measures for these victims.It is important that this public health problem is recognized and addressed at European level, which is why I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution because I am in favor of better access to restitution for thalidomide victims. This medicine made in Germany and prescribed to pregnant women against morning sickness caused many infantile malformations and even the death of newborns in the years 1950-1960. Following the revelations of the disastrous consequences of taking this drug, I find it unacceptable that today the victims are still fighting for fair compensation in several EU countries. It is important, in my view, that the citizens concerned have access to similar compensation in all Member States. To this end, there is an urgent need for the European Commission to create a framework protocol at European level, under which all EU citizens affected by thalidomide would receive such compensation. It is also important that the Commission draw up as soon as possible a European program of aid and support for victims and their families.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing. - Made in Germany and marketed in the late 1950s, thalidomide is a medicine prescribed for nausea associated with pregnancy, headaches, coughs, insomnia and colds. Pregnant women have consumed it in many European countries, resulting in death and birth defects in thousands of newborns. The scandal is all the more shocking as documents attest to failures in pharmaceutical control in the Federal Republic of Germany Fifty years later, victims are still fighting for compensation. The mechanisms provided for differ from state to state and the status of a person affected by thalidomide is not granted everywhere under the same conditions. The European Union and its Member States must ensure that all affected citizens have access to similar compensation. It is essential that the Union show solidarity, by proposing a European program of aid and support for the victims of this tragedy and their families.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted against the joint motion for a resolution from the S & amp; D group.The drug from the German laboratory Chemie-Grünenthal, supposed to treat certain disorders such as morning sickness, caused serious malformations in the children of pregnant women who consumed it during their pregnancies in the 1950s to the 1960s.Compensation and care for victims have been unsatisfactory.We are against the motion for a resolution by the S & amp; D group, which calls for the creation of a framework protocol at European level.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form.- Tiladomide is a drug used in the late 50's and early 60's.It is often used by pregnant women to relieve morning sickness, as well as colds and flu.The consequences of using it are terrible.In pregnant women it has damaged the fetus, and in other cases it has had other negative side effects.This resolution calls on the Member States to support victims of the drug.He also condemned the actions of the pharmaceutical company that launched it.That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- It is essential that the demands of thalidomide survivors in Europe are fully recognized in order to ensure their autonomy, access to health care and a decent quality of life, and that a complementary aid program should be set up.Member States to provide financial support to thalidomide victims and their families.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, of which I was a signatory, on the recognition of the victims of Thalidomide. The Thalidomide Survivors’ Campaign has worked tirelessly for many years for justice for all survivors. While there is a fund in Wales for survivors, in some countries they get no support at all, while their health and care needs are increasing. It is over fifty years now. We need urgent action from the German government.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on thalidomide as it calls for the full recognition of the claims of surviving thalidomide victims in Europe, so as to obtain comparable compensation between the different Member States that can guarantee them autonomy and access to medical care and dignifiedlife quality.The thalidomide scandal remains one of the most disastrous events in pharmaceutical history and after sixty years, the surviving victims are still seeking justice, recognition and adequate compensation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- There are still more than 4 000 thalidomide survivors in Europe today, of which: 2 800 in Germany, 450 in Italy, 400 in the United Kingdom, 400 in Spain, 103 in Sweden and about 90 in Austria.Almost sixty years, the survivors are still waiting for justice and a compensatory solution that allows them to withstand the costly treatments that their physical condition demands.For this reason, I consider it essential to fully recognize the needs of the thalidomide victims who still survive in Europe, in order to guarantee their autonomy, access to medical treatments and an adequate quality of life.The Commission should develop an assistance program to complement the action of the Member States with a view to providing financial support to thalidomide victims and their families.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- For the motion for a resolution from the ENF Group which calls for the creation of an assistance program to support and add value to the actions of member states.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Thalidomide was marketed from 1956 as anti-flu and “calming” - against sleep disorders and tranquilizers - and, later, indicated in cases of morning sickness during pregnancy. It was withdrawn from the market years later, having been associated with cases of congenital malformations. There are an estimated 10,000 to 20,000 thalidomide victims worldwide, with varying degrees of disability. Chemie Gruenhental, the company responsible for the commercialization of thalidomide, has not previously performed clinical tests. Thalidomide victims are still trying today to find a solution to support the medical expenses they have and have had due to the health complications they have and which have worsened over the years. The European Commission, in 2015, celebrated the 50th anniversary of the first pharmaceutical legislation to guarantee the safety of medicines. The thalidomide tragedy was one of the main reasons for the creation of this legislation. This resolution aims to put pressure on the competent authorities to create the necessary conditions to guarantee support to the victims of thalidomide, in all Member States. It comes at a time when the German parliament is expected to amend the law on financial support rules for survivors.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am in favor of the proposal, as it is essential that the demands of thalidomide survivors in Europe are fully recognized, in order to ensure their autonomy, access to health care and a decent quality of life, and that an aid program should be set up inwhich will complement Member States' efforts to provide financial support to thalidomide victims and their families.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on thalidomide victims. Germany should take responsibility for the government’s actions in the 1970s and allow the victims access to the survivors fund. The money is urgently needed to help care for those affected by this drug and adapt homes so they are able to live as independently as possible.  It is a disgrace that the fight for recognition from the pharmaceutical company is still ongoing. I hope that this report will enable some real progress to be made for many victims.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of the resolution is to put pressure on the German Government to extend the funding available for thalidomide survivors in Germany to those survivors from other countries concerned. The timing of the resolution is crucially important, as in January 2017 the German parliament will amend a law on the rules for providing financial support.  Thalidomide survivors should be formally recognised in all Member States concerned and be finally given adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Stiftung.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ The drug Thalidomide was marketed in the late 1950s and early 1960s as a safe drug to treat issues such as morning sickness and headaches but it resulted in the death and malformation of thousands of babies when used by pregnant women in a variety of European countries. Reports have concluded that Thalidomide survivors need an increasing amount of support for their unmet health needs, as their bodies are rapidly deteriorating owing to the nature of their disabilities and to the lack of support over the years. It is horrible that many of these survivors often are unable to get funding to cover social services costs, which is currently the single biggest concern for Thalidomide survivors. Given this, I support the resolution in urging Member States and the Commission to coordinate and take action to formally recognise and compensate Thalidomide survivors. The Commission should take action at EU level so that all EU citizens affected by Thalidomide could receive similar amounts of compensation, regardless of Member State. Lastly, I support the resolution in calling on Grünenthal to shoulder its responsibilities – by providing compensation and care to those victims who have yet to be recognised.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on support for survivors of thalidomide, a drug that causes birth defects in newborn babies, because I believe that recognizing the right of all victims, not only to moral and economic compensation but also to adequate in charge by the health systems of the request for treatment and the duty to make social rights enforceable, is an act that can no longer be postponed fifty years after the tragedy of thalidomide. With this resolution, the EP asks Germany to take an act of great responsibility, just as it commits all Member States to promote immediate interventions to ensure due attention to patients and their families. MEPs demand that surviving victims in the UK, Spain, Italy and other Member States be admitted to the scheme on a collective basis if their thalidomide victim status has been accepted in their country. The Commission should establish a framework protocol at European level so that all European citizens affected by thalidomide receive compensation of a similar amount and develop an EU assistance and support program for the victims and their families.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- I voted against the motion for a resolution.Some of the facts and sources listed therein were inconsistent or inadequate.In addition, there are already many support measures, such as the Contergan Foundation, which supports around 2,700 beneficiaries in 38 countries.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution asking the Commission to detail what measures have been taken and what will be taken at Union level to provide effective support and assistance to thalidomide victims and their families and,to extend support to all European citizens affected by thalidomide.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution so that the Member States and the European Commission implement a European protocol so that survivors of thalidomide are formally recognized, regardless of the country to which they belong, and receive adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Foundation. In Spain, only the socialist government of Rodríguez Zapatero adopted measures to compensate those affected, establishing aid based on the degree of disability. Since the declaration of the victims' representatives in the petitions committee of the European Parliament, last March, the Socialists promoted a debate in the European Parliament in order to pressure the German Government to expand the funding available for victims of the thalidomide in Germany to survivors from other affected countries. Since then, we have been urging the current government to continue actions in this regard, having established ourselves as allies in the fight of the Spanish victims of thalidomide so that their rights are recognized. Hundreds of affected people have died without recognition or compensation. Today we have another opportunity not to condemn to oblivion the survivors of this historical injustice.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted strongly in favour of this resolution that urges the Commission to create a framework protocol at EU level under which all European Union citizens affected by Thalidomide would receive similar amounts of compensation, regardless of which Member State they are from, and to draw up an EU programme for assistance and support (including both financial and welfare provisions) for Thalidomide victims and their families.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Motion for a Resolution in Support of Thalidomide Victims because I believe that such a mistake and playing with human lives must never happen again.In the 1950s and 1960s, the sedative Thalidomide was given to pregnant women against morning sickness as a completely harmless and proven drug after which unexpected long-term consequences occurred.More than 10,000 were born with severe physical defects, most often with deformities of the arms and legs, or no limbs at all.Blindness, deafness, heart problems and brain damage in children are also side effects of taking thalidomide in pregnancy.This Motion for a Resolution, which I voted in favor of, supports in every way the victims of thalidomides and calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together and speed up measures and actions to formally recognize and compensate those victims.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- Thalidomide is responsible for the death or malformation of more than 20,000 infants in Europe.While there is good reason for survivors to take legal action to cover medical costs, the proposal gives the Commission alone the power to coordinate actions, flaying national laws.So I voted against it.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution so that the Member States and the European Commission implement a European protocol so that survivors of thalidomide are formally recognized, regardless of the country to which they belong, and receive adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Foundation. In Spain, only the socialist government of Rodríguez Zapatero adopted measures to compensate those affected, establishing aid based on the degree of disability. Since the declaration of the victims' representatives in the petitions committee of the European Parliament, last March, the Socialists promoted a debate in the European Parliament in order to pressure the German Government to expand the funding available for victims of the thalidomide in Germany to survivors from other affected countries. Since then, we have been urging the current government to continue actions in this regard, having established ourselves as allies in the fight of the Spanish victims of thalidomide so that their rights are recognized. Hundreds of affected people have died without recognition or compensation. Today we have another opportunity not to condemn to oblivion the survivors of this historical injustice.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which pushes for better recognition of victims of Thalidomide at European level.This drug caused a major health scandal in the 1960s because it turned out to have serious side effects, causing fetal malformations in pregnant women.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - On 15 December 2016, at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted in favor of a resolution in support of thalidomide tragedies. The tragedy with thalidomide has been one of the main reasons for the creation of EU pharmaceutical legislation, which since then aims to ensure that medicines placed on the market guarantee a high standard of quality and safety for European citizens. Thalidomide was used from the late 1950s to the early 1960s as a treatment for morning sickness in pregnant women as well as for the treatment of headaches, insomnia and colds. This treatment has been commercially available in various European countries for several years, but it has only been shown ex post to have serious side effects, especially in pregnant women whose children were subsequently born with congenital malformations. The tragedy has affected several EU countries, whose survivors face serious, worsening physical consequences on a daily basis and indecent problems in reimbursing their treatment. The resolution was tabled following an oral question to the Commission and a plenary debate in March this year. I believe that the states concerned should change their legislation so as to adequately compensate the victims of this tragedy and at the same time provide them with the best possible care. That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: in writing. - Resolution on the victims of thalidomide, a drug recommended in the 1950s for pregnant women, which caused fetal development disorders resulting in, among others, the lack of arms in later born babies sheds new light on victims of this once insufficiently recognized drug. They live not only in France, but also in Germany, Sweden, Great Britain, Spain, Italy and other EU countries. The resolution recalls the effects of thalidomide and the responsibility of states in this regard. It calls on the Member States to treat the victims of thalidomide properly in the courts and to provide appropriate social and medical care, many of them living in poverty and without the necessary assistance. I believe that the history of thalidomide use should be remembered in approving drug safety testing and marketing procedures; risk and liability issues must be clearly defined. This story should also help advance research into the physiology and pathology of pregnancy and related education, increase access to prenatal testing and perinatal medicine, and disseminate knowledge about pregnancy prevention so that stories of this kind do not repeat themselves in the future.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution calls on the Member States and the Commission to take appropriate action to recognize and provide compensation to victims of thalidomide.It is a drug that was sold in the 1950s and 1960s as a sedative, anti-nausea and hypnotic to pregnant women.It was withdrawn from the market in late 1961, after being spread to 50 countries under forty different trade names.Women treated with thalidomide gave birth to infants with severe congenital changes in limb development, namely amelia (absence of limbs) or varying degrees of phocomelia (reduction of the long bones of the limbs).This initiative intends to ensure and guarantee assistance and support to both victims and their families and compensate them for the damage suffered.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it entrusts the compensation of victims of Thalimonide to a group action under the leadership of the Commission, bypassing national legislation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this Resolution because I consider it essential that thalidomide victims obtain fair compensation for the damages caused by the companies that fraudulently marketed it.Europe must intervene in the face of the fact that in many countries like Spain, unlike Germany, responsibility and compensation are still being denied to those affected.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in solidarity with Thalidomide victims.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The drug thalidomide was manufactured in 1960 and approved as a safe medicine for the prevention of morning sickness, headaches, insomnia and colds in pregnant women.However, taking this drug had tragic consequences for many families, as it resulted in the birth of children with severe malformations.The resolution emphasizes the need to recognize this problem in order to ensure fair compensation for victims.I supported this resolution.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The drug Thalidomide was marketed by Chemie Grünenthal GmbH in the late 1950s and early 1960s as a safe drug to treat morning sickness, headaches, coughs, insomnia and the common cold; whereas it resulted in the death and malformation of thousands of babies when taken by pregnant women in many European countries. The European Parliament urges the Member States and the Commission to coordinate actions and measures seeking to formally recognise and provide compensation to Thalidomide survivors.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- The administration of thalidomide, which was introduced to the European market by the German pharmaceutical company Chemie Grünenthal to pregnant women in the 1950s and 1960s, had catastrophic effects on human fetal development.This chemical and drug caused the birth of 20,000 children with serious physical and mental damage.There are currently 4,000 victims of the medicine in the Union, who have increased health care and social and economic security costs due to health problems.These victims undoubtedly need help, but at the same time it must be said that, in the present case, the regulatory and control activities in the marketing of the medicine for which the specific entities are responsible have failed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on support for victims of thalidomide, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 14/12/2016, and because this joint motion for a resolution is completeand documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against the joint motion for a resolution and for the proposal of our parliamentary group.The common proposal (B8-1341 / 2016) aims to coordinate the actions of the Member States and the Commission and to create a European framework protocol.It undermines the sovereignty of states, which we are opposed to.The text proposed by the ENF group (B8-1343 / 2016) has the same objective of coordination but while respecting this sovereignty.It envisages the creation of a European Commission assistance program to support and add value to the actions of Member States, which we support.These two proposals come after the consequences of Thalidomide, a drug distributed between 1950 and 1960, which caused many deaths and people born malformed.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- For a long time, thalidomide was sold as a sleeping pill and sedative under the brand names Contergan and Softenon.In the late 1950s / early 1960s, the unknown side effects caused deformities in babies.The well-known thalidomide scandal followed.Since thalidomide also has anti-tumor, anti-inflammatory and anti-blood vessel formation properties, thalidomide is still used under strict conditions for special diseases.However, since I believe it is important to support the thalidomide victims, I voted in favor of this motion.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament resolution on support for thalidomide victims.The resolution calls for victims of the use of this medicine to have access to healthcare and to maintain a decent quality of life, and to seek compensation to cover the necessary but costly and growing costs of their healthcare.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- Thalidomide was prescribed to pregnant women in the 1950s to 1960s by the German pharmaceutical industry and has produced more than 20,000 babies born dead or born malformed.To date, there are over 4,000 survivors in Europe who are now seeking justice.Resolution 1: I voted against this resolution since it undermines the sovereignty of States by wanting to coordinate the action of the Commission and the States by creating, in particular, a European framework protocol.Resolution 2: I voted for this resolution as its objective is to create an assistance program from the European Commission to support the actions of the Member States.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written.- It is now more than 50 years ago that the use of the German-made "safe" drug Thalidomid for morning sickness resulted in many thousands of children being poisoned in the womb and born with severe disabilities.Many are still waiting for fair compensation for the daily discomforts and limitations they experience as a result of Thalidomid.With this resolution, Parliament is urging the German government to provide recognized victims with access to the available financial resources so that these people have adequate resources to improve their quality of life.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ It is essential that Thalidomide survivors should be formally recognised in all Member States concerned and be finally given adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Conterganstiftung. The aim of the resolution is to put pressure on the German Government to extend the funding available for Thalidomide survivors in Germany to those survivors from other countries concerned. The timing of the resolution is crucially important as in January 2017, the German Parliament will amend a law on the rules for providing financial support. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- Following the use of thalidomide, an anti-nausea drug for pregnant women, in the 1950s and 1960s, which resulted in the death, or malformation, of more than 20,000 babies, Parliament is proposing to help the hundredssurvivors who still seek justice.The proposal presented by the Socialist Group, asking the Commission to coordinate the actions of the Member States, undermines national sovereignties, and we will therefore vote against.But we support that of the ENF group, which calls for the creation of a European Commission assistance program to support and add value to the actions of Member States.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- On the resolution of the S & amp; D group which is directly addressing the Member States and the European Commission to coordinate their actions, in particular with the creation of a framework protocol at European level, I observe that therehas undermined the sovereignty of states, I therefore vote against.On that of the ENF group which calls for the creation of an assistance program from the European Commission in order to support the actions of the Member States and bring added value, I note that it respects the sovereignty of the Member States,I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution in support of thalidomide victims.This anti-nausea substance marketed by a German laboratory was the cause of severe malformations in tens of thousands of newborns in the 1950s and 1960s. Many victims have yet to see their harm recognized.nor compensated.The text asks the German government to allow citizens of other Member States to benefit from the compensation fund for German victims, after having been recognized as victims of the drug in their own country.It calls on the Spanish authorities to facilitate the identification and compensation of thalidomide survivors.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Thalidomide is a drug that treats diseases by inducing, enhancing or suppressing an immune response, used mainly as a treatment of certain cancers or complications of leprosy. In the 1950s and 1960s it was used to treat headaches, coughs and insomnia and resulted in the death and malformation of thousands of babies when used by pregnant women across the EU. I am in favour of this motion of a resolution that will formally recognise and provide compensation to Thalidomide survivors.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution because I believe that the European Union must give a boost to the Member States so that the victims of thalidomide can be recognized and receive the necessary support.Of course, in Germany there are more people who have been affected by this substance, but we must not forget that there are victims in other EU countries, and they must be recognized both within the states and at the level ofUnion in order to benefit from the necessary aid and support.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I also support this resolution because, in my opinion, the victims of the Contergan scandal should be financially supported.The manufacturer of the Contergan, Grünenthal, was supposed to compensate the victims.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Victims of thalidomide and their families must be provided with the compensation and other support they need to improve their quality of life.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. Thalidomide was used as a medicine to fight morning sickness in pregnant women, as well as to treat headaches, insomnia and colds in the late 1950s and early 1960s. several European countries for several years and has been shown to cause serious side effects in pregnant women whose babies were born with malformations. This tragedy has affected several Member States and there the victims continue to seek solutions to cover the costs associated with their illness and physical condition, which is deteriorating over time. This shows how important it is to have effective EU legislation to ensure that the medicinal products on the market are subject to high quality and safety standards. For the above reasons, I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I supported the European Parliament resolution on support for thalidomide survivors. The resolution takes note of the fact that in September 2015, the EU marked 50 years since the adoption of the first pharmaceutical regulations in Europe in order to protect its citizens. I recall that in May 2015, a press conference was held in Brussels, with the support of all political groups, to highlight the unmet health needs of thalidomide victims. In the late 1950s and early 1960s, thalidomide was sold to pregnant women as a remedy for morning sickness, headaches, coughs, insomnia and colds, and its use has caused the death and malformations of thousands of children in many European countries. Even after the drug was withdrawn from the market, the authorities found it difficult to cope with the situation. It was difficult for them to clarify the effects of the drug, determine the number of people affected and ban it, and at the time there was no legal framework to ban drugs. The approximate number of currently living European citizens, victims of the German company Gruenenthal and its medicine is around 4,000, with the largest number in Germany around 2,700. Finally, I think that the progress of today's European pharmaceutical regulations, which is firmly based on the precautionary principle, is to be welcomed. , in order to meet high standards of quality and safety of users.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Thalidomide was marketed from 1956 as anti-flu and “calming” - against sleep disorders and tranquilizers - and, later, indicated in cases of morning “nausea” during pregnancy. It was withdrawn from the market years later, having been associated with cases of congenital malformations. There are an estimated 10,000 to 20,000 thalidomide victims worldwide, with varying degrees of disability. Chemie Gruenhental, the company responsible for the commercialization of thalidomide, has not previously performed clinical tests. Thalidomide victims are still trying today to find a solution to support the medical expenses they have and have had due to the health complications they have and which have worsened over the years. The European Commission, in 2015, celebrated the 50th anniversary of the first pharmaceutical legislation to guarantee the safety of medicines. The thalidomide tragedy was one of the main reasons for the creation of this legislation. This resolution aims to put pressure on the competent authorities to create the necessary conditions to guarantee support to the victims of thalidomide, in all Member States. It comes at a time when the German parliament is expected to amend the law on financial support rules for survivors.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. - Thalidomide was used to treat nausea in pregnant women, as well as for headaches, insomnia and colds in the late 1950s and early 1960s. The drug was used for several years before serious side effects were noticed. It caused deformation of the fetuses, especially in the form of shortened or absent limbs. This has happened in many Member States and victims are still not financially adequately secured to cope with rising treatment costs. This case was one of the main reasons for the enactment of EU legislation on supervision over the pharmaceutical industry. The resolution calls for the coordination of actions to support victims in their efforts to obtain compensation, for improving action in individual countries (i.e. Germany or Spain), for the establishment of a European support program, and calls on the drug company (Grünenthal GmbH) to plead guilty and pay appropriate compensation. For the above reasons, I supported the resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- During the 1950s and 1960s, thalidomide was prescribed to pregnant women throughout Europe as a medicine for morning sickness.This drug, made in Germany, has caused death and birth defects in thousands of newborns in many European countries.It is unacceptable that the survivors are still fighting today, almost 50 years after the events, for redress.I therefore voted in favor of this resolution to ensure that victims from other EU member states, whose status has been recognized in their own countries, have access to the special health fund created in Germany for this purpose.In addition, we ask the European Commission to put in place financial measures to best support the victims and their families.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on support for thalidomide survivors. This drug marketed during the 1950s and 1960s to treat headaches, coughs, insomnia, colds and nausea associated with pregnancy has in fact been found to be the cause of newborn deaths and severe birth defects. At the time of the lawsuit against the manufacturer Grünenthal GmbH, his guilt could not really be established due to interference in criminal proceedings. Faced with little effort since then to help thalidomide survivors, the European Parliament had already made its voice heard during its plenary session in March 2016 to underline the urgent need to come to the aid and improve quality of the lives of those affected by this scandal. This European Parliament resolution calls on the Member States and the Commission to coordinate actions and measures aimed at formally recognizing and, above all, compensating thalidomide survivors, in particular by creating a framework protocol at the European level.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- The toliamide poisoning scandal has shown how many loopholes exist in the current chemicals control system.I supported this proposal and I am convinced that if the EU has failed to provide protection against such substances, then at least we must take proper care of our victims of negligence and invest in preventing such cases from happening again.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - The drug thalidomide caused a real tragedy more than 50 years ago when it was marketed in Europe. Today, many victims are still fighting in several Member States for compensation; this situation is unacceptable. I therefore voted in favor of this text which calls on the European Commission and the Member States to coordinate their actions and measures to recognize thalidomide victims and to compensate them. In particular, Germany must allow victims to access the special health fund it has created. We also call for a framework protocol at European level to be put in place to allow any European citizen affected by thalidomide to receive similar compensation amounts. Finally, these measures must be accompanied by a European program of aid and support for victims and their families. It is urgent that Parliament be heard and that concrete and effective measures be taken as soon as possible.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing.- The consequences of thalidomide use by pregnant women on thousands of children need to be addressed.It is completely unacceptable that the manufacturer of this substance apologized to those who have to live with a disability caused by its product only in 2012. As their age increases, their health problems worsen and the cost of adequate care increases.Therefore, all those who have to live with a disability caused by thalidomide should receive compensation guaranteeing dignified living conditions, no matter what country they live in.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution because it requests the involvement of the German State, the European Commission and various Member States (including Spain), to develop systems for mutual recognition and compensation for victims of thalidomide, a drug produced by the pharmaceutical company Grünenthal to avoid nausea and other side effects of pregnancy, but which nevertheless ended up causing the malformation of thousands of babies throughout the continent (about three thousand only in Spain). However, I think that the obligation of the Member States is to enforce the protection of the fundamental rights of their citizens, also in the health framework. In this way, they should oblige the pharmaceutical companies that commercialized this product to assume their criminal responsibility, and alternatively, grant recognition of the condition of victims in order to access the corresponding compensation systems. Said systems must act with the maximum guarantees and facilitating bona fide access to compensation for potential beneficiaries. Finally, it is necessary in the Spanish State to review Royal Decree 1006/2010 for the granting of aid to victims, guaranteeing affordable terms and adequate financing.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this: Thalidomide victims should be properly compensated.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this resolution which aims to put pressure on the German Government to extend the funding available for Thalidomide survivors in Germany to those survivors from other countries concerned. The timing of the resolution is crucially important, as in January 2017 the German parliament will amend a law on the rules for providing financial support.  Thalidomide survivors should be formally recognised in all Member States concerned and be finally given adequate and fair compensation from the Special Health Fund of the German Contergan Stiftung.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution in support of the victims of thalidomide, because it is really high time that these people were compensated. The whole case has been dragging on for decades, and now is a good time for the German authorities to compensate the victims of this medicine. The medicine containing the active substance thalidomide, also known as Contergan, appeared on the market in 1957. It was considered a 'safe sleeping pill'. In the next five years, it was sold under various trade names in dozens of countries around the world (it was not registered in the former Czechoslovakia and no permit was issued for its legal extraordinary import). In November 1961, a German pediatrician openly expressed public suspicion that Contergan use could be associated with a sudden increase in the number of newborns with congenital malformations. Shortly afterwards, several hundred mothers gathered to give birth to the deformed children. The suspicion that Contergan, which until then had functioned as an "excellent sedative and sleep-free drug" without side effects and was therefore popularly used by pregnant women, was confirmed to cause severe developmental disorders of the fetus in the mother's body. That is why we want this resolution to put pressure on the German Government and the Commission to finally compensate the victims completely and for the company that has placed the medicine on the market to accept its responsibility.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Thalidomide is an active substance with sedative and hypnotic effects, which first appeared as a medicine in West Germany in the 1950s. It came on the market as a safe drug to be used to treat morning sickness, headaches, coughs, insomnia and colds, but its use during pregnancy has caused death and deformities in thousands of children. Documents from that time testify that there was a very lack of pharmaceutical control in West Germany. Unfortunately, the evidence also confirms that the state intervened in the criminal proceedings against the German manufacturer of thalidomide, as a result of which it was not possible to properly establish his guilt for the consequences, as well as civil proceedings were prevented however, they did not receive adequate financial compensation. The resolution calls on the Member States and the Commission to coordinate activities and measures for the official recognition and compensation of survivors, which would also facilitate their healthcare and improve their quality of life. Research shows that survivors need a lot of support due to their specific health needs and have problems with mobility and independent living, as they have suffered many of the consequences they face on a daily basis, and most have not had adequate care since birth. Because of all this, I myself supported the resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- There are more than 4,000 people living in the European Union who are suffering from the negative effects of taking thalidomide.We express their support for them and call on the Member States concerned to increase their assistance to them.In this context, we recall that the area of medicines policy must continue to be subject to strict control and effective regulation.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint resolution on assistance to victims of thalidomide.The Member States and the European Commission should coordinate activities and measures to formally recognize and compensate survivors.Thalidomide was introduced in the 1950s as safe and suitable for pregnant women in case of morning sickness.However, a number of negative effects were soon shown for pregnant women, which were reflected in various deformities in the children of mothers who took thalidomide during pregnancy.I therefore also support the call for the Commission to create a framework protocol at European level, which will entitle all European citizens affected by thalidomide to appropriate compensation.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
