text: in writing.Thalidomide was used as a medicine for morning sickness in pregnant women, as well as for the treatment of headaches, insomnia and colds in the late 1950s and early 1960s.This treatment has been shown to have very serious side effects for pregnant women whose babies are born with deformities.This resolution is related to the financial support of the victims of thalidomide, which is why we voted in favor.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The EU must take the appropriate steps to fully recognize the needs of thalidomide survivors in Europe, with a view to ensuring their autonomy, access to healthcare and a decent quality of life.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution, which raises the issue of the now aging victims of the thalidomide scandal to EU level, as many of them could find themselves in a more serious situation without support.The decision, in my view, rightly underscores the primary responsibility of the pharmaceutical company and the German government, but it also rightly calls on the governments of several other EU Member States, in particular the Spanish authorities, to take the necessary measures to ensure thatvictims who have been left out so far should also benefit.I trust that, through the swift action and greater flexibility called for by the decision, the victims concerned will be able to experience the value of European solidarity in concrete terms.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Ensuring the safety of medicines for the European population is one of the objectives of the European Union institutions. Without it, some medicines marketed without proper prior research can have devastating effects on those who use them in their treatment. One such case is thalidomide, marketed by the German company Chemie Gruenenthal in the late 1950s and early 1960s as a safe medicine for treating morning sickness, migraines, coughs, insomnia and colds, which led to deaths and malformations in the case of thousands of babies in many European countries. The court action of the German state did not allow the adequate compensation of the victims, neither in Germany, nor in other European states. Moreover, survivors of these treatments need increased care for their health, mobility and independent living needs. For these reasons, it is necessary to adopt regulations at EU level as soon as possible, enabling the necessary assistance to be provided to the affected persons in all Member States, as well as appropriate compensation, including from the responsible company. It is a measure more than necessary to correct an unacceptable situation; that is why I strongly support the adoption of this resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution.The demands of thalidomide survivors who have survived in Europe must be fully recognized in order to ensure their independence, access to medical care and a good quality of life.We call on the Commission to deliver on the commitments made by Commissioner Andriukaitis at the plenary session of Parliament on 9 March 2016 by establishing an assistance program that complements the action of Member States to provide financial support to victims of thalidomideand their families.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the anti-morning sickness drug Thalidomide. It was created in 1953 in Germany by the Grünenthal Group. Thalidomide was marketed in a number of European countries including Spain, Italy, Germany, the UK and Ireland and led to the birth of children with severe malformations. Thalidomide was pulled from the market in 1961 after it was linked to birth defects but many victims have only recently received compensation. The Thalidomide tragedy caused immense physical suffering and emotional hardship for the victims and their families. The drug approval regulatory framework in Europe has since greatly evolved with the overarching objective being to better safeguard human health.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a resolution on support for victims of thalidomide".I believe that the recently published reports of the institute in Germany and the United Kingdom show the need for greater support for thalidomide victims.Namely, thalidomide was a remedy for headaches, coughs and insomnia in the 1950s and 1960s.However, it was only subsequently that shortcomings in the conducted research and harmful consequences for the use of thalidomide were identified.I believe that the Member States of the European Union must submit harmonized measures in order to formally identify and implement compensation for victims of thalidomide use.Although the number of victims is not evenly distributed across all Member States, it is necessary to identify the problem at the institutional level of the European Union and respond to it adequately.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Thalidomide is a drug that was used by thousands of women 50 years ago to relieve the symptoms of morning sickness. The drug was a product of the German pharmaceutical company Grünenthal and was dispensed from 1957 to 1961 when it was finally withdrawn after it was found to cause certain deformities in children whose mothers took it during pregnancy. The use of thalidomide has caused the deaths of 2,000 children, and more than 10,000 people today live with severe injuries. What is particularly unfortunate is the fact that the company that produced the drug apologized to its victims and their families only in 2012, but did not admit the mistake. The thalidomide case was one of the main reasons for the establishment of EU pharmaceutical legislation, which led to the strengthening of the regulatory environment for the development of medical devices. I hereby call on the Commission to create a framework protocol under which all European citizens affected by this pharmaceutical disaster will receive equal financial compensation, and to establish a community to help and support all victims. The minimum that should have been done a long time ago is for Grünenthal to admit its mistake and to pay appropriate compensation to all victims. That is what we all need to stand for here, which is why I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's resolution on assistance to victims of thalidomide.Thalidomide is a drug marketed by Chemie Grünenthal GmbH in the late 1950s and early 1960s.The drug is supposed to cure morning sickness, pneumonia, colds and headaches.In pregnant women who ingested it, it caused a large number of neonatal deaths and births with deformities.Recent reports in Germany and the UK that surviving thalidomide victims need to improve their quality of life as their bodies are weak and disabled due to the effects of the drug.In an open letter, the chairmen of the European Parliament's political groups supported efforts to help thalidomide survivors.Now is the ideal opportunity to mitigate and correct the injustices committed in the past.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Not all those affected by Thalidomide in Europe have the same recognition or the same economic benefits from their Member States. Many of them have mobility problems and need special environments (adapted cars, adapted homes, etc.) to be able to develop with a certain normality. I support this proposal in order to help the people affected and their families. We cannot cure them, but we can help them live better.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- Thalidomide was used to treat nausea in pregnant women, as well as headaches, insomnia and colds in the late 1950s and early 1960s. The drug was used for several years before serious side effects were noticed.It caused fetal deformities, especially in the form of shortened or absent limbs.This has happened in many Member States and victims are still not financially adequately secured to cope with rising treatment costs.The resolution calls for the coordination of actions to support victims in their efforts to obtain compensation, for improving action in individual countries (i.e. Germany or Spain), for the establishment of a European support program, and calls on the drug company (Grünenthal GmbH) to plead guilty and payappropriate compensation.I supported this resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution asking the Commission to detail what measures have been taken and what will be taken at Union level to provide effective support and assistance to thalidomide victims and their families and,to extend support to all European citizens affected by thalidomide.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on support for Thalidomide victims because it calls on the German Government to allow those Thalidomide survivors who have been accredited as such by court-appointed trust schemes, or are beneficiaries of national government schemes, to gain collective access to the Special Health Fund of the German Conterganstiftung. It also calls on the Commission to create a framework protocol at EU level under which all European Union citizens affected by Thalidomide would receive similar amounts of compensation, regardless of which Member State they are from.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I believe that the requirements of thalidomide survivors in Europe need to be fully recognized in order to ensure their independence, access to healthcare and the maintenance of a good quality of life.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this resolution, Germany is asked to compensate all the victims of thalidomine with the fund created for this purpose.It also asks Spain to review the 2010 legislation to facilitate recognition and compensation for all Spanish victims.It is time for Europe not to forget its innocents and to help the victims of this problem with its support and commitment.That is why I believe it necessary to vote in their favor.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this resolution because it requests the involvement of the German State, the European Commission and various Member States (including Spain), to develop systems for mutual recognition and compensation for victims of thalidomide, a drug produced by the pharmaceutical company Grünenthal to avoid nausea and other side effects of pregnancy, but which nevertheless ended up causing the malformation of thousands of babies throughout the continent (about three thousand only in Spain). However, I think that the obligation of the Member States is to enforce the protection of the fundamental rights of their citizens, also in the health framework. In this way, they should oblige the pharmaceutical companies that commercialized this product to assume their criminal responsibility, and alternatively, grant recognition of the condition of victims in order to access the corresponding compensation systems. Said systems must act with the maximum guarantees and facilitating bona fide access to compensation for potential beneficiaries. Finally, it is necessary in the Spanish State to review Royal Decree 1006/2010 for the granting of aid to victims, guaranteeing affordable terms and adequate financing.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this call for EU Member States and the Commission to coordinate actions and measures to recognise and provide compensation to Thalidomide survivors. The Commission should create a framework protocol at EU level, under which all EU citizens affected by Thalidomide would receive similar amounts of compensation, and draw up an EU programme of assistance and support to victims and their families.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The year 2015 marked the fiftieth anniversary of the first European measure for a better guarantee of the safety of medicines. The tragedy of Thalidomide, prescribed in the 1950s and 1960s in particular for pregnant women and which caused serious congenital malformations, was the main inspiration. Today, in the European Union, many victims of Thalidomide see their physical and medical condition continue to deteriorate and are still looking for ways to cover the costs of their medical treatment. An oral question signed by all political groups was addressed to the Commission in March 2016, calling for better care for these victims and their families, and similar compensation regardless of the Member State concerned. This resolution follows up on this issue and calls for compensation for victims of Thalidomide to be placed on the Parliament's agenda from the start of 2017. I obviously voted in favor.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The “thalidomide generation” began to appear in the late 1950s, but it was not until 1961 that the first warning came about the cases of congenital malformations associated with the use of thalidomide. It was withdrawn from the market in Germany and England in 1961. There are an estimated 10,000 to 20,000 victims of thalidomide in the world, with varying degrees of disability. In 2012, the executive director of Chemie Gruenhental, responsible for the product, presented, for the first time, half a century later, a formal apology that was considered “inappropriate, pathetic and offensive” by the victims' defense organizations, considering that their excuses were very light, late and full of hypocrisy, since for 50 years, Grunenthal was involved in a company strategy, calculated to protect itself from any moral, legal and financial consequences. This resolution follows on from the QO and the debate, which took place in plenary in March this year. The urgent need to put it on the plenary agenda is that, in January 2017, the German parliament should amend the law on financial support rules for survivors and, serving this resolution to pressure and ask that this support be given to all victims of EU Member States.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- For a long time, thalidomide was sold as a sleeping pill and sedative under the brand names Contergan and Softenon.In the late 1950s / early 1960s, the unknown side effects caused deformities in babies.The well-known thalidomide scandal followed.Since thalidomide also has anti-tumor, anti-inflammatory and anti-blood vessel formation properties, thalidomide is still used under strict conditions for special diseases.However, since I believe it is important to support the thalidomide victims, I voted in favor of this motion.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I am very happy Parliament finally voted a resolution on the Thalidomide case, following a Commission Statement, calling on the German Government to engage with victims and survivors, and to admit all survivors to its Special Health Fund. This is a key milestone in the campaign for Thalidomide survivors across Europe that I have been supporting since my first day in Parliament, regularly meeting with victims and campaigners from the UK and other Member States.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I support this resolution because I think it is important for the victims of Thalidomide to get the recognition and support they deserve. Many errors have been made in the past, among them a lack of pharmacovigilance, and it is important that the survivors can get compensation for the harm done.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I have, of course, supported the resolution on support for victims of thalidomide. Thalidomide has also been used as an anti-nausea drug in pregnant women in the past and has caused a great deal of tragedy, as many children have been born with deformed limbs or other disabilities. At the same time, their health condition has been deteriorating over the years. That is why we called on the European Commission to coordinate measures and initiatives aimed at compensating victims of thalidomide, we called on the governments of the Member States to make every effort to set up compensation schemes for these victims and, last but not least, on the pharmaceutical company that developed the drug. to accept her guilt and compensate the victims. And while neither the confession nor the compensation mechanisms will provide health for the victims of thalidomide, we can only hope that the countries concerned, but especially the pharmaceutical companies, will take it to heart so that such a tragedy never happens again in the future.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the resolution to support victims of thalidomide because I believe that survivors should be formally recognized in all Member States and receive fair compensation from the German fund specially created for this purpose.I recall that the drug thalidomide was marketed by the German pharmaceutical company Grünenthal in the late 1950s, early 1960s as a safe medication to treat nausea during pregnancy, headaches, cough, insomnia and constipation and that it caused death ormalformations to thousands of newborns after its administration to pregnant women in many European countries.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on assistance to victims of thalidomide.Recent independent reports in Germany and the United Kingdom state that thalidomide survivors need more help for their health needs, mobility and independent living because their health is deteriorating rapidly due to a type of disability and they have not received adequate help since birth.I therefore support the call on the Member States and the Commission to coordinate action and measures as soon as possible to formally recognize and compensate thalidomide survivors.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: - Mr President, we need politicians determined to support children's access to innovative medicines, despite their cost. My fingers are therefore crossed for the plenary vote on Thursday, December 15, and for the follow-up, too, which will be given to it by the European Commission, and I greet our Commissioner, who is present today. I just read you an excerpt from the email, among all the others, that I received the day before yesterday. This one is from Ms. Heynens, one of the moms I worked with to write this resolution. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common cancerous soft tissue tumor in children and adolescents. The treatment combines chemotherapy, surgery and often radiation therapy today. Obviously, it is heavy, and because it is unacceptable that over the last ten years, only two innovative drugs specific to children have seen the light of day, we must impose this virtuous circle, force the development of treatments against cancer and other illnesses that affect children. Protecting the weakest among us is more than ever our mission, it is more than ever the mission of Europe.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I am very pleased that this resolution has passed, it is a very ethically sensitive subject.It is very good that the European Parliament is aware that we need to invest more money, more energy in quality pediatric clinical research so that we can offer small patients new and better medicines, new and better forms of treating insidious forms of the worst disease, that is, cancer.I am humanly pleased that this resolution has indeed passed, and we hope that it will be fulfilled in real life, that we will really help small, suffering patients and that, for example, today's resolution will bring them other forms of treatment that are more gentle and more effective..

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - The resolution on medicines used in paediatrics is the second topic after thalidomide that does not respect 21st century European society. It is unacceptable if sick children who may have survived die because research into medicines used in pediatrics is insufficient or because these medicines are not available. Children form a special group of the population that requires a special approach. But in the political debate on an aging population, health care for the elderly is much more voiced today. This is also important, but let us not forget that Europe is aging also because we have few children. I consider the lack of medicines used in pediatrics to be a gamble with every child's life. As a doctor, I can say that it is not easy to see a child die because we cannot give him medicine. It should also be borne in mind that where there is little medicine, someone has to decide who gets it and who doesn't. And such a burden should not be borne by any person, nor by a doctor.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé ar son na tairisceana seo i gcomhair rúin mar a rinne an chuid is mó de na Feisirí. Ach vótálamar – mar a rinne mo ghrúpa – i gcoinne an leasaithe a bhí ag an EFDD. Is rún fíorthábhachtach é seo agus cuirimid fáilte roimhe. It is a motion that is a means to promote innovation and access to help technologies in this important area of public health. A review of existing regulations on paediatric medicines will prove central to further developments, thus inducing a new phase of scientific and regulatory dialogue and cooperation in this domain.  We must therefore continue in our efforts to incentivise the market, reinforcing the extent of our commitment, whilst identifying current obstacles and the public health impact of continuing innovation in this area. Like most MEPs, I welcome this resolution and its passing here today.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- This resolution asks the Commission to propose, as contemplated in the Pediatric regulation (2007), the Regulation on pediatric medicines in due time (January 2017), which must include an analysis of the possible consequences for healthpublic.For older people, it asks that in this report they consider different factors that could improve said regulation, including full transparency of clinical results.It is for all this that I have voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use. The regulation on pediatric medicines has had a significant impact on the development of such medicines, there has been a significant increase in pediatric clinical trials and pediatric research projects, and more qualitative information is now available on the pediatric use of authorized medicines. The regulation has helped to improve the overall situation, with tangible benefits in the treatment of many pediatric diseases. And yet, in some areas, notably pediatric oncology and neonatology, insufficient progress has been made. I therefore support the resolution's call on the Commission to submit the report provided for in Article 50 of the Pediatric Regulation in good time and to request that this report describe in detail and examine in depth the obstacles currently hampering innovation in the pediatric population. I also voted in favor of the call for amendments to the Regulation to be made on the basis of those conclusions, taking due account of pediatric development plans based not only on disease types but also on the mechanism of action of the medicine, disease and drug prioritization medical needs in the field of paediatrics;

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - Many children suffering from rare pediatric diseases do not have access to specific pediatric medicines, so they are given unpredictable medicines based on experience without prior clinical research. The regulation on pediatrics has greatly improved the development of medicines and has led to progress in the field of pediatrics, but there is still much room for improvement. I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on pediatric medicines, as it is necessary to ensure that children are given medicines that can effectively treat pediatric diseases.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- There is a need to better adapt treatments to children using specific drugs and not through an adaptation, often approximate, of treatments for adults, as is still the case today.This resolution, following an oral question, seeks to amend the current regulation on pediatric medicinal products.Particular emphasis is placed on drugs developed to treat cancer in children.The current text had largely been bypassed by pharmaceutical companies, which in 10 years have released only 2 new drugs.The present text, despite clear shortcomings, is generally in the right direction by aiming to improve the regulation.FN deputy Joëlle Mélin is co-editor of the oral question and the motion for a resolution in question.I voted in favor of this proposal.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution draws the Commission's attention to the fact that, despite the incentives provided for in the previous regulation, there has been little substantial progress in research and development of pediatric medicinal products. Since the entry into force of the regulation, a total of two specific pediatric anti-cancer medicines have been registered. Unfortunately, pharmaceutical companies have used incentives (typically financial resources) to develop anti-cancer drugs that can be made primarily for children, but also allow for the therapeutic treatment of similar cancers in the adult population. Thus, in fact, again, the profit-oriented approach overshadowed the legislator's constructive and forward-looking intention. The proposal therefore calls on the Commission to draw up a report on the mid-term review of the practical operation of the regulation and to develop new incentives for companies to develop specialized medicines for the therapeutic treatment of serious illnesses intended exclusively for children. Based on the above, I supported the adoption of the proposal for a decision.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I supported, with the whole of the Socialist Group, this resolution which aims to modify the regulation on pediatric medicinal products.This resolution, approved by a large majority by the European Parliament, asks the European Commission to draw up a detailed report on the obstacles which still hamper innovation in pediatric medicines.On this basis, it will have to make the necessary proposals for changes to eliminate these obstacles.Faced with the tragedy of childhood cancer, every effort must be made to provide the most effective medical solutions.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- The Regulation on Pediatric Medicines has proven not to be entirely useful.In particular I am referring to anticancer drugs.We need a new amendment to the Regulation that addresses the current obstacles that hinder innovation in medicines for the pediatric population.For all this I have voted in favor.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution that raises issues such as the need for correct labeling and the variety of incentives needed to increase research in the field.The key points are to ensure a thorough assessment of R&D costs, along with full transparency of clinical costs and recognition of the need to assess how best to use different types of grants and funding in the field ofpediatric medications.As well as supporting the "untying mechanisms" envisaged by the United Nations to promote innovation and access to health technologies by separating the payment of the cost of the development of R&D for health technologies from the price of the product.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this Resolution on medicines for pediatric use in which the Commission is asked to present the report referred to in Article 50 of the Regulation on these medicines in due time and before January 26, 2017. This report should providean exhaustive list and detailed analysis of current obstacles to innovation in medicines for the pediatric population.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- On this text, our colleague Joëlle Mélin, from our ENF group, was co-editor of the oral question and the motion for a resolution.It appears necessary to better adapt treatments to children using specific drugs and not through an adaptation, often approximate, of treatments for adults, as is still the case today.This resolution is in fact aimed at amending the current pediatric medicinal products regulation.Particular emphasis is placed on drugs developed to treat cancer in children.The current text had largely been bypassed by pharmaceutical companies which, in ten years, released only two new drugs.The present text, despite clear shortcomings, is generally in the right direction by aiming to improve the regulation.So I decided to vote for.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The report being voted on is balanced and acceptable, so I intended to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution asking the Commission to present the report referred to in Article 50 of the Regulation on Pediatric Medicines, providing an exhaustive list and a detailed analysis of the current obstacles that hinder innovation in this area. It also urges the Commission to examine the introduction of modifications that take into account the following: pediatric drug development plans based on the mechanism of action, and not only on the type of disease; disease and drug prioritization models taking into account unmet pediatric medical needs and feasibility; Earliest and most viable PIPs; incentives to stimulate research and better serve the needs of the pediatric population, while ensuring an assessment of research and development costs and transparency of clinical results; and strategies to avoid non-prescribed pediatric use when authorized pediatric medications are available. Likewise, it highlights the advantages that the mandatory pediatric development of drugs based on the mechanism of action of a drug coupled to the biology of a tumor, and not on an indication that limits the use of the drug, would bring when saving lives in pediatric oncology to a specific type of cancer.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, in which the European Parliament discusses the use of medicines in paediatrics. Parliament called on the Commission to submit the report provided for in the regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use in good time, and emphasized the need for this report to describe in detail and examine in depth the obstacles currently hampering innovation in the pediatric population. It also emphasizes that such a sound information base is essential for effective policy-making. Parliament urges the Commission, in the light of those conclusions, to consider amendments, including a review of the regulation on pediatric medicines. These changes shall take due account of: (a) plans for the development of medicinal products for pediatric use, based not only on the type of disease but also on the mechanism of action of the medicinal product; (c) previous and more promising pediatric investigation plans; (d) incentives to increase research and address the needs of the pediatric population more effectively, ensuring that research and development costs are assessed and that clinical results are fully transparent; and (e) strategies to avoid the use of medicines. in pediatrics not as described in the case of authorized pediatric medicinal products.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- I would like to draw Parliament's attention to the fact that early pediatric investigation plans and early scientific and regulatory dialogue and cooperation with the European Medicines Agency will allow companies to optimize global pediatric development and, in particular, to make pediatric investigation plans even more feasible.work out.I supported the adoption of the motion.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: in writing. – Many children suffering from rare paediatric diseases, such as cancer, do not have access to targeted paediatric medicines. That is why I support this report. We need to foster innovation in paediatric medicines to ensure that in the future all children can be treated with medicines that have been developed for and proved effective and safe for use for children.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The Pediatric Medicines Regulation has had a significant impact on drug development for infants and children, as many pharmaceutical companies see pediatric development as an integral part of the overall drug development business. The number of pediatric research projects has increased dramatically and more high-quality information on approved drugs is available. Furthermore, the relative number of pediatric clinical trials also increased with positive outcomes. However, there are still margins for potential improvement, for example on financial rewards for the development of pediatric drugs which are too often modest in number and size, with a reward system to be reviewed to further stimulate research and development of pediatric drugs, especially in oncology, by pharmaceutical companies. We also need to promote much wider access to innovative therapies that can save the lives of children and adolescents with life-threatening diseases.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this resolution which offers valuable suggestions to the Commission for improving the regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use. The Pediatric Medicines Regulation has had a significant impact on the development of pediatric medicines. Since its inception, many pharmaceutical companies have seen pediatric development as an integral part of their overall product development business. The number of pediatric research projects has increased dramatically and more high-quality information is now available on pediatric use of approved drugs. However, this regulation has several shortcomings. Financial mechanisms of rewards and incentives for the development of pediatric medicines, such as the marketing authorization for pediatric use, are delayed and have limited effect. The current rewards system needs to be reviewed to determine how it could be improved to further stimulate research and development of pediatric medicines. In addition, pediatric investigation plans (PIPs) are too often impractical or are initiated too late for the drug. The resolution proposes a review of the current system of PIPs in order to improve them, limiting the speculation of pharmaceutical companies on the incentives offered.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which called for a loophole in the Paediatric Medicines Regulation to be closed. Pharmaceutical companies are meant to investigate whether any drug they bring to market for adults can be used for children (given the rarity of child cancers) but there is a waiver within the legislation which allows these companies not to do so if the diseases are not found in children. But often diseases in children can have the same biological mode of action as these adult diseases so should be investigated.  For these reasons I supported the resolution and hope that the Commission will act swiftly.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agree that the Commission needs to deliver the report provided for in Article 50 of the Paediatric Medicines Regulation in a timely fashion, providing comprehensive identification and an in-depth analysis of the obstacles currently hampering innovation in medicinal products targeting the paediatric population. It is very important to have a solid evidence base of this kind for effective policymaking. Based on these findings, the Commission should consider making changes, including through a legislative revision of the Paediatric Medicines Regulation, that give due consideration to amongst others mechanism-of-action-based, rather than only disease-type-based, paediatric development plans and incentives that better stimulate research and more effectively serve the needs of the paediatric population. The Commission should consider amending the Paediatric Medicines Regulation so that promising trials in the paediatric population are not terminated early because of disappointing results in the target adult population.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The oral question and the resolution adopted by the ENVI commission concern the review of regulation 1901/2006 on medicinal products for pediatric use, in particular pediatric investigation plans and pediatric oncology.The main issues addressed are the incidence of cancer in children, chemotherapy treatments and innovative therapies, the development of anticancer drugs by pharmaceutical companies, clinical trials.The elements introduced are positive and I therefore voted in favor without a doubt.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report today as I had done at committee level. Although the Regulation was a major breakthrough in pushing for paediatric medicine research 10 years ago, today there are loopholes which need to be addressed, as these are preventing development in research and jeopardising life chances. Children are among the most vulnerable members of our society and we must act accordingly to improve their quality of life. With cross-party support, this resolution is pushing for an end to deferred investment in paediatric medical research and to ensure that regulatory changes close those loopholes. Although the Commission makes the point that children’s health is very important in their work, it does not appear to be a top priority. Our future is bleaker when theirs is at risk. The Commission is not acting quickly enough upon the public’s demands and those of their elected representatives. However, an area this current motion could have pushed further on concerns increased transparency in development and medical research processes, not just with regard to clinical results. I would encourage all of my constituents and interest groups in Ireland to submit their experiences to the Commission before the consultation deadline on the 2017 Report on the Paediatric Regulation

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - The European regulation on medicines for pediatric use has established a specific regulatory framework which has had a very significant impact on the development of pediatric medicines. The regulation has contributed to significant progress in sensitive areas, such as pediatric oncology and neonatology, and has also concretely stimulated research in this area. Research has played a fundamental role in filling serious shortcomings in the health sector and has had the merit of identifying and introducing specific and authorized pediatric drugs on the market. However, most drugs currently on the market are not licensed for specific use in children. I am therefore convinced that it is necessary to invest and encourage pediatric research to give a greater stimulus to innovation in pediatric medicines. I hope that the European Commission will soon take action to take new legislative initiatives in such a fundamental area of ​​health. For these reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We call on the Commission to renew in the Horizon 2020 program the funding provisions developed to support high quality pediatric clinical research.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution on pediatric medicines is another attempt to better regulate the framework surrounding the prescribing and supply of pediatric medicines, with the aim of protecting children and the general population, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions – paediatric medicines.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The Pediatric Medicines Regulation has had a considerable impact on the development of pediatric medicines, having contributed to improving the general situation and giving rise to concrete benefits with regard to various childhood diseases. Despite the existence of more pediatric research projects, more high quality information, insufficient progress has been made in several areas, namely on oncology and neonatology. I support this resolution, which calls on the Commission to submit the report provided for in Article 50 in due time, in order to provide a complete identification and an in-depth analysis of the obstacles currently impeding the innovation of medicines for the pediatric population and to consider the possibility of making changes, namely through a legislative review of the Regulation. I argue that pediatric needs and medicines should be given priority, based on scientific data, in order to match the best therapies available to children's therapeutic needs, especially those affected by cancer, allowing the optimization of the resources used in research.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted for the resolution because I believe that the regulation on medicines for children should be revised.I support the call for the funding rules of the Horizon 2020 program to be adapted to promote quality clinical trials in children, which will also help to remove barriers that stand in the way of innovation in pediatric medicines.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution as the regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use was adopted ten years ago to ensure high quality research in the development of medicinal products intended for children and for their appropriate authorization.The measure asks the Commission if it intends to review the regulation, updating it to the new requirements.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Resolution on the Regulation on Paediatric Medicines to call on the Commission to set a specific system to boost research for innovative medicinal products for children. More resources should be allocated to research to encourage laboratories to develop paediatric indications that go beyond those designed for adult products. I, together with the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, am confident that such a system would be beneficial and life-saving for many children in Europe, especially those affected by cancer.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- This resolution asks the Commission to propose, as contemplated in the Pediatric regulation (2007), the Regulation on pediatric medicines in due time (January 2017), which must include an analysis of the possible consequences for healthpublic.For older people, it asks that in this report they consider different factors that could improve said regulation, including full transparency of clinical results.It is for all this that I have voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the proposed revision of the pediatric regulation, which entered into force on January 26, 2007. I believe this is necessary due to the shortcomings - regarding the delay in clinical trials, pediatric oncology or the small number of new medicines being authorized - identified in the implementation of the regulation.The review of the regulation should give due weight to drug priority models, earlier and easier clinical trials, and more effective incentives to stimulate research, and serve the goals of children's drug development.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Many fields of paediatric medicine suffer from lack of research and appropriately authorised medical products to treat paediatric diseases. This is why I voted in favour of this resolution as it seeks clarification from the Commission on the progress of the report as well as highlighting the areas and issues in which the Commission should, on the basis on the forthcoming report, consider a review of the Regulation to better serve the needs of the paediatric population. Many children suffering from rare paediatric diseases, such as cancer, do not have access to targeted paediatric medicines. We need to foster innovation in paediatric medicines to ensure that in the future all children can be treated with medicines that have been developed for and proved effective and safe for them.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on pediatric medicines.In Europe, cancer remains the leading cause of death in children aged one year and over.It is essential to do research for the fight against cancer, the priority of pediatric medicine.I therefore join this call for the Commission to publish, as soon as possible, a report on the obstacles to research and innovation in the pediatric medicines sector.Armed with this report, the European Union will be able to modify its policy in order to fight even more forcefully the disease among the youngest.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I believe that priority should be given to medicines developed by different companies, based on scientific studies, to meet the therapeutic needs of children, especially those affected by cancer, through the best available therapies, which would optimize the resources used for research.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which asks the Commission to better support and encourage research in the pediatric field.I am happy that Parliament is mobilizing on this urgent and essential issue.In fact, pediatric investigation is far too little developed in Europe.There is a dramatic lack of knowledge of effective treatments to combat serious illnesses in children.Specifically, the Commission is due in 2017 to publish a report on the implementation of the 2006 Pediatric Medicines Regulation and it is essential that it creates a favorable environment for pediatric investigation.Laboratories must be encouraged to complete their specific and specialized pediatric research, and constrained when they do not follow the rules.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing.- With 6,000 deaths per year, cancer is the leading cause of infant mortality by disease in Europe.Thanks to the European pediatric regulations introduced in 2006, the information on pediatric use of medicines is more and better.It has also encouraged the development of new treatments and new working methods.But the incentives for the development of specific drugs for pediatric use remain insufficient, especially in the case of specific diseases that only affect children.This is why the Commission must carry out an in-depth analysis of the obstacles to innovation in pediatric medicines as soon as possible and, on the basis of the results obtained, amend the regulation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted for this joint motion for a resolution.This resolution follows an oral question: Joëlle Melin is its co-rapporteur.The regulation on pediatric medicines would aim to produce better treatments adapted to the child, rather than rough adaptations of treatments for adults.This shortcoming is particularly evident in the treatment of cancer in children: only two new drugs have been released in ten years.The new text is not entirely satisfactory, but goes in the right direction.So we supported him.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – I voted for this file. Whilst I agree that there are still a number of matters to be discussed, such as the completion of paediatric investigation plans (PIPs), paediatric oncology and the low uptake of paediatric-use marketing authorisations, change is urgently needed.  Ultimately, we are discussing the health of society’s most vulnerable and we have a moral and ethical obligation to provide them with the highest-quality legislative protection framework possible and continuous review and scrutiny of the existing framework. Therefore, we must set clear rules, guidelines and obligations, working towards a clear goal and based on thorough assessment.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - Children are a vulnerable group of the population and differ from adults in terms of their development, physiology and psychology. Research on age and growth, as well as the availability of suitable medicinal products, is of particular importance. The regulation on pediatric medicines was adopted ten years ago to ensure high-quality research into the development of medicines for children and the proper approval of medicines used by them. The regulation achieved many of its objectives, but several weaknesses were identified in 2013 in the progress report adopted by the Commission, in particular with regard to pediatric research programs and pediatric oncology. This proposal calls on the Commission to urgently consider any possible regulatory changes that could help to improve the situation, strengthen the role of the European network for pediatric clinical research and ensure that Member States adopt measures to strengthen research. , as well as the development and distribution of medicines for pediatric use, which is why we support the proposal and vote in favor of it.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The Pediatric Medicines Regulation has had a considerable impact on the development of pediatric medicines, as pharmaceutical companies regard development for pediatric use as an integral part of the overall development of medicines. Childhood cancer remains the leading cause of death from illness in children aged one year and over and 6,000 young people die from cancer each year in Europe; two-thirds of surviving patients suffer from side effects due to existing treatments. Having said that, I agree that the Commission may introduce changes, namely through a legislative review of the Pediatric Medicines Regulation, which take due account of the need for pediatric development plans based on the mechanism of action and not only on the type of disease, models definition of priorities in terms of diseases and medicines, earlier and more viable PIPs, and incentives that stimulate more research and respond more effectively to the needs of the pediatric population.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote for: it is a question of better adapting the treatments to the children, passing by specific drugs, and not by an adaptation, often approximate, of the treatments for adults, Excellent work of Madame Mélin, co-editor of the oral question and of themotion for a resolution in the ENVI committee.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Children have often been referred to as “therapeutically orphans”, as they are often denied appropriate treatment for their specific characteristics, as well as for the diseases and conditions that specifically affect them. In 2006, Regulation (EC) No. 1901/2006 on medicines for pediatric use came into force. Although it has resulted in an improvement in the general situation and concrete benefits with regard to a number of childhood illnesses, however, insufficient progress has been made in several areas, notably in pediatric oncology and neonatology. EU legislation is still flawed. There are, for example, considerable delays in starting pediatric clinical trials of cancer drugs. The current legislative approach is not satisfactory in the case of specific and exclusive diseases of children, as well as rare diseases. There are no pediatric investigation plans (PIP) for child-specific deadly diseases, such as high-risk neuroblastoma. This is not financially attractive to pharmaceutical companies. The resolution fails to recognize the right of children to have access to adequate treatment and innovative medicines suited to their specific conditions and rare diseases. Instead of recognizing the flaws and perversities of the market, it does not suggest solutions beyond its narrow limits.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - Children are a vulnerable group of the population and differ from adults in terms of their development, physiology and psychology. Research on age and growth, as well as the availability of suitable medicinal products, is of particular importance. The Pediatric Regulation was adopted ten years ago to ensure high-quality research into the development of medicines for children and the proper approval of the medicines used. The regulation achieved many of its objectives, but several weaknesses were identified in 2013 in the progress report adopted by the Commission, in particular with regard to pediatric research programs and pediatric oncology. This proposal calls on the Commission to urgently consider any possible regulatory changes that could help to improve the situation, strengthen the role of the European network for pediatric clinical research and ensure that Member States adopt measures to strengthen research. , as well as the development and distribution of medicines for pediatric use, which is why I support the proposal and vote in favor of it.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the Paediatric Regulation should be updated, based on a review of its effectiveness since it was passed in 2007.  I support the call for more incentives that stimulate research into paediatric medicine whilst ensuring transparency of the research and development process. Science and research is an area where European level cooperation is appropriate so that knowledge and best practises can be shared.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The fact that many children suffering from rare paediatric diseases, such as cancer, do not have access to targeted paediatric medicines is not tolerable. Off-label use of medicines prescribed by doctors based on experience rather than based on targeted paediatric clinical research is still common, and many fields of paediatric medicine lack the necessary innovation in development of new medicines. The Paediatric Regulation has had a positive effect on paediatric drug development and has led to tangible benefits for a series of childhood diseases, but not enough progress has been made in a number of fields. We need to foster innovation in paediatric medicines to ensure that in the future all children can be treated with medicines that have been developed for and proved effective and safe for use for children. The Commission should deliver its report in good time and give due consideration to the system of PIPs and incentives while ensuring transparency of research and development.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ Childhood cancer results in the death of 6 000 young people each year in Europe and it is the biggest cause of death by disease in children over one year old. Treatment-related side effects are also a major problem as two thirds of those who survive suffer from side effects. To improve the situation for these children and to ensure the best framework to develop new treatments I support calling on the Commission to deliver the report on the Paediatric Medicines Regulation. There is currently a need for a comprehensive identification and an in-depth analysis of the obstacles hampering innovation in this field. Based on the report there needs to be a review of issues such as disease and drug prioritisation models, how to provide incentives that better stimulate research and more effectively serve the needs of the paediatric population – among others. The Commission also needs to review the possibility of different types of funding and rewards and how they best can be utilised to drive and accelerate paediatric drug development.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am extremely concerned about children’s health and well-being. Developing and promoting policy to support paediatricians in improving children’s services is of major importance. Every EU Member State should shape policy and practices to provide high quality and sustainable healthcare services for all children. However, I believe that this should and would be better done at a national level.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution that raises issues such as the need for correct labeling and the variety of incentives needed to increase research in the field.The key points are to ensure a thorough assessment of R&D costs, along with full transparency of clinical costs and recognition of the need to assess how best to use different types of grants and funding in the field ofpediatric medications.As well as supporting the "untying mechanisms" envisaged by the United Nations to promote innovation and access to health technologies by separating the payment of the cost of the development of R&D for health technologies from the price of the product.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that stresses the urgent need to assess how different types of funding and rewards – including the numerous tools based on delinkage mechanisms – can be best utilised to drive and accelerate paediatric drug development in areas of need.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - I regret that for a decade we did not pay enough attention to the health of our children, which is a major concern for many adult parents. Every year, 6,000 children die of cancer in Europe for lack of appropriate medicines. This is because research in pediatric medicine is insufficient due to the rigidity of existing procedures or the lack of incentives for pharmaceutical industries to invest in this area. For example, since the entry into force of the regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use in 2006, few mandatory "Pediatric Investigation Plans" have been implemented. That is why the Parliament recommends orienting the system so that they encourage laboratories - through tax incentives or extensions of patent protection - to intensify research in the pediatric field.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted for the Motion for a resolution on medicines for pediatric use because I believe that in today's modern times it is really necessary to work hard and effectively to reduce the number of malignant diseases and especially the number of deaths in children and young people, which in Europe are around 6,000 annually.This Motion for a Resolution advocates an essential area of research that will spur a whole new wave of therapies for children with malignancies.The resolution proposes that the Rules of Pediatric Treatment should be extended so that the mode of action of each drug forms the basis of any pediatric investigation - research on the use of pediatric diseases (Pediatric Investigation Plan).This Motion for a Resolution, which I voted for, emphasizes the saving of human lives and calls on the Commission to take urgent action to implement these changes through legislative revision.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- I believe it is necessary to adapt in the best way possible the treatment for children by the use of specific drugs, and not by necessarily inappropriate treatment for adults.This text seems to me, despite its imperfections, to go in the way of improvement.I voted for.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to make improvements to the current regulation to encourage research in the pediatric field, which today is far too limited.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which stems from Regulation No 1901/2006 on Paediatric Medicines. It is important to foster innovation in paediatric medicines to ensure that in the future all children can be treated with medicines that have been developed for and proved effective and safe for use for children.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - Statistics show that cancer continues to be the leading cause of death from disease in children, that 6 000 young people die from cancer each year in Europe and that two thirds of patients who overcome the disease suffer from the effects of medical treatments. Thanks to the Pediatric Medicines Regulation, there has been a development in treatments and a considerable increase in pediatric research which today provides more information on the use of pediatric medicine. Considering therefore that the pharmaceutical market offers limiting incentives for the development of medicines for pediatric use, the Commission is asked to present a report on pediatric medicines highlighting the obstacles that currently limit innovation and treatments, outline how best to use the funds to accelerate the development of treatments for different types of childhood cancer and strengthen the role of the European network for clinical pediatrics studies by ensuring that all Member States promote tools that can support the research, development and availability of medicines for pediatric use. In the name of a better future for our children and to save many young lives, I strongly support the requests made today.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution because it encourages certain pediatric treatments, particularly oncology.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- This Resolution asks the Commission to present a report in due time (January 2017) that includes an analysis of the possible consequences of said Regulation for public health, as envisaged in the Pediatric Medicines Regulation of 2006.In addition, it asks that this report consider different factors that could improve such regulation, including full transparency of clinical results.It is for all this that I have voted in favor of this Resolution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that highlights the need to develop innovative treatments for cancer patients, particularly for children diagnosed with cancer.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The regulation on medicines for pediatric use has helped to improve the general situation and led to concrete benefits in a number of pediatric diseases, but still insufficient progress has been made in a number of areas, especially in the field of pediatric oncology and neonatology.It is therefore urgent to assess how different types of funding can best be used to encourage and accelerate the development of drugs to treat those forms of cancer that occur in infants and children.The early implementation of pediatric investigation plans, early scientific and regulatory dialogue and cooperation with the European Medicines Agency enable pharmaceutical companies to improve the global development of pediatrics, so I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The Paediatric Medicines Regulation has had a substantial impact on paediatric medicine development. The Paediatric Medicines Regulation has helped to improve the overall situation and has led to tangible benefits in respect of a series of childhood diseases; whereas, however, not enough progress has been made in a number of fields, in particular paediatric oncology and neonatology. The European Parliament calls on the Commission to deliver the report provided on the Paediatric Medicines Regulation in a timely fashion and stresses the need for this report to provide comprehensive identification and an in-depth analysis of the obstacles currently hampering innovation in medicinal products targeting the paediatric population.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- 6,000 young people die each year in Europe from cancer.Two thirds of children who have overcome these diseases suffer from serious side effects of the drugs used.It is necessary for the Commission to analyze existing practices in the field of research and use of pediatric medicines and, in cooperation with the Member States, to propose measures that concentrate all assistance to strengthen medical and pharmaceutical research in this area and improve regulatory and control mechanisms in medicines research.their authorization and use.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I support the motion for a resolution on the regulation on pediatric medicines, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/12/2016, and because this motion for a resolution is complete and well-founded.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.This text aims to modify the legislation on medicines intended for children so that they are developed specifically for pediatric purposes and not a simple adaptation of treatments for adults.We support this goal.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing.- Today, we discussed a motion for a resolution on the regulation of pediatric medicines.In the EU, we have a regulation on pediatric medicines in force, which has a significant impact on the development of medicines for pediatric use.However, based on the findings, we state that insufficient progress has been made in a number of areas, especially in the areas of pediatric oncology and neonatology.We note the sad fact that more than 6,000 young people die of cancer every year.We also criticize the current mechanism whereby pediatric investigation plans are approved only after very complex negotiations between regulators and pharmaceutical companies.We call on the Commission to consider changes in the light of these findings, including through a revision of the Pediatric Regulation.I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- Childhood cancer is the leading cause of disease-related death in children over one year of age.6,000 young people die of cancer in the EU.Due to the effects of the chemotherapy drugs that are prescribed and currently administered in highly toxic doses, two thirds of the survivors suffer from treatment-related side effects and up to 50% of the survivors suffer from severe side effects.The industry lacks incentives to manufacture pediatric medicines.The applicable legal framework (EU regulation) is often not duly observed, as drugs are developed under typical pathological conditions that are fulfilled in adults but do not occur in children.This legislative framework is now to be revised with this motion for a resolution.I therefore voted in favor of this motion.

name: Alex MAYER
text: in writing. ‒ I received many letters from my constituents about this issue, including details of upsetting individual cases, so I am proud to support Parliament’s resolution on paediatric medicines. Cancer is still the biggest cause of death by disease for children in Europe, which is why we should ensure that children with cancer are not missing out on life-saving treatment. I hope that the Commission will consider this resolution and make necessary changes to the current law on paediatric medicines.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament resolution on medicines for pediatric use.The regulation on pediatric medicines has had a significant impact on the development of such medicines, with a significant increase in pediatric clinical trials and pediatric research projects.However, progress is insufficient and more resources and effective mechanisms are needed to promote research and progress in pediatric oncology.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- I was co-editor of this report.The initial text proved its very many shortcomings and drifts.Quite satisfactorily the co-rapporteurs and I went in the direction of a partial rebalancing of the text, which thus amended, did not contradict the interests of young patients.Indeed, this resolution aims to modify the regulation on pediatric medicinal products and, more specifically, to better adapt treatments intended for children by using specific medications rather than by adapting treatments intended for adults.This especially to treat cancer.I therefore voted for this text, of which I am the co-editor, going in the right direction despite the persistence of certain shortcomings.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Around 6 000 minors die of cancer each year in Europe. Out of those who survive, two thirds suffer from treatment-related side effects for the rest of their lives. The Paediatric Regulation has had a substantial impact on the development of children’s medicine, but not enough progress has been made in a number of fields, especially oncology. This is why I voted in favour of the resolution, which calls for funding and proper policies that stimulate more research into paediatric medicines, and is aimed at improving the treatments and the quality of life for child and teenage cancer survivors.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- We support this oral question which was co-written by Ms. Mélin, ENF Member of Parliament, and which asks to better adapt treatments intended for children by developing specific drugs, and not by adapting treatments for adults.The text mainly targets cancer treatments and the European regulation on pediatric treatments now in force, which has been deliberately bypassed by pharmaceutical companies.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- There is a need to better adapt treatments to children using specific drugs and not through an adaptation, often approximate, of treatments for adults, as is still the case today.This resolution, following an oral question, seeks to amend the current regulation on pediatric medicinal products.Particular emphasis is placed on drugs developed to treat cancer in children.The current text had largely been bypassed by pharmaceutical companies which, in ten years, released only two new drugs.The present text, despite clear shortcomings, is generally in the right direction by aiming to improve the regulation.I therefore vote in favor.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which encourages research into pediatric medicines, which is still far too rare, especially in the field of cancer control.Since the entry into force of the Pediatric Medicines Regulation 10 years ago, only two anti-cancer drugs for children have been placed on the market.The text asks the Commission to review the numerous exemptions which often exempt laboratories from their obligations to carry out "Pediatric Investigation Plans".He invites him to set up an incentive system for the research of drugs with only pediatric indications.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 26 January 2007 a new legislation governing the development and authorisation of medicines for children entered into force. I am in favour of this motion for a resolution regarding the Paediatric Medicines Regulation in order to increase innovation in medicinal products for children.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the abduction highlighting the obstacles that currently hamper innovation in the development of medicines for pediatric use.These findings suggest the need for a legislative revision of the Pediatric Medicines Regulation, addressing plans for the development of pediatric medicines, incentives to better stimulate research and better meet the needs of pediatric patients, and strategies to avoid the use of pediatric medicines outside marketing authorization..I consider it important to call on the Commission to consider amending the regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use so that clinical trials promising for the pediatric population cannot be terminated prematurely due to unsatisfactory results in the target group of adult patients.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I speak out clearly in favor of creating an incentive system for research into children's drugs against cancer and I support the present demand.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The development of pediatric medicines is very important and technical barriers to EU regulations that hamper innovation in the development of the best medicines must be removed.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Forms of cancer that occur in childhood are still the leading cause of death in children aged one year or older. Every year, 6,000 young people die of cancer in Europe. The current regulatory approach is unsatisfactory in the case of pediatric-specific diseases, and less than 10% of children with incurable and potentially fatal recurrence have access to new, experimental drugs that are in the clinical trial phase. Early implementation of pediatric investigation plans, early-stage scientific and regulatory dialogue, and cooperation with the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and pharmaceutical companies make it possible to improve the global development of pediatrics. In line with the provisions of the EU's third health program (2014-2020), I emphasize the commitment to improve resources and expertise for patients suffering from rare diseases. I also emphasize the importance of cross-border testing in the research of many children's and rare diseases and therefore welcome Regulation (EU) no. 536/2014 of the EP and the Council on clinical trials of medicinal products for human use, which will facilitate the conduct of such trials, and I call on the EMA to guarantee the infrastructure needed for its application as soon as possible. I call on the Commission to begin work urgently on possible regulatory changes that could improve the current situation.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The Commission published the first report on the Pediatric Regulation in 2013, which states that although there is promising progress in many areas, more time will be needed to thoroughly assess the impact of the Regulation on the development of pediatric medicines. The regulation requires the Commission to publish a second report in 2017. The purpose of this resolution is to seek clarification from the European Commission on the progress of the report, as well as to highlight areas and issues where the Commission should consider amending the Regulation. Numerous forms of cancer that affect children do not occur in adults and the industry for such forms of cancer, but also other diseases that occur only in children, has a limited financial incentive to develop special drugs for pediatric use. Many children suffering from rare childhood illnesses do not have access to targeted pediatric medications. In many areas of pediatric medicine, there is a lack of necessary innovation in the development of new drugs. The regulation has helped to improve the general situation and progress has been made on a number of pediatric diseases, but insufficient progress has been made in a number of areas, in particular pediatric oncology and neonatology. We need to encourage innovation in the development of pediatric medicines to ensure that in the future all children are treated with medicines that are effective and safe and developed just for use in children.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Children have often been referred to as “therapeutically orphans”, as they are often denied appropriate treatment for their specific characteristics, as well as for the diseases and conditions that specifically affect them. In 2006, Regulation (EC) No. 1901/2006 on medicines for pediatric use came into force. Although it has resulted in an improvement in the general situation and concrete benefits with regard to a number of childhood illnesses, however, insufficient progress has been made in several areas, notably in pediatric oncology and neonatology. EU legislation is still flawed. There are, for example, considerable delays in starting pediatric clinical trials of cancer drugs. The current legislative approach is not satisfactory in the case of specific and exclusive diseases of children, as well as rare diseases. There are no pediatric investigation plans (PIP) for child-specific deadly diseases, such as high-risk neuroblastoma. This is not financially attractive to pharmaceutical companies. The resolution fails to recognize the right of children to have access to adequate treatment and innovative medicines suited to their specific conditions and rare diseases. Instead of recognizing the flaws and perversities of the market, it does not suggest solutions beyond its narrow limits.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- 6,000 children die of cancer each year in Europe.The entry into force of the regulation on medicines for pediatric use has improved research but has not, however, made it possible to achieve significant progress in the treatment of diseases and especially childhood cancers.I therefore voted in favor of this resolution by means of which we ask the European Commission to modify this regulation as a matter of urgency in order to encourage medical research in pediatrics and to penalize laboratories that do not invest enough.in the matter.It is unthinkable that in the 21st century, in Europe, children are still the first victims of this neglect!

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text which asks the Commission to present the report on medicinal products for pediatric use in due time and which emphasizes that this report must allow a full identification and a thorough analysis of the obstacles currently hampering innovation in medicines targeting children. The adopted text also calls on the Commission to examine the possibility of amending the Regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use, including by means of a legislative revision, to take better account of the following elements: pediatric development plans which should be based on the mechanism of action and not just on the type of disease; models that should be developed to prioritize diseases and drugs to take into account unmet pediatric medical needs, incentives that should be put in place to better stimulate research and respond better to needs of the pediatric population, while ensuring that an evaluation of research and development costs is carried out and ensuring full transparency of clinical results, etc.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- Pediatric medicines must be subject to particularly strict controls.After all, the value of the issue is the health of our future - our children.I therefore supported this well-balanced document.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- Today, childhood cancer remains the leading cause of death from disease in children aged one year and over, and more than 6,000 young people die from cancer each year in Europe.These figures are alarming and unacceptable!The pediatric regulation of 2006 allowed some progress but obstacles persist in the treatment of diseases.It is unacceptable that children die because of a lack of scientific and medical research on pediatric medicines.I supported this text which calls for the Commission to evaluate the current regulation and amend it in order to improve it as quickly as possible and substantially to make it more efficient and operational.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ There is an urgent need to review the regulation on paediatric medicines. Opportunities to develop treatments and cures for serious childhood illnesses are being missed because the current regulation allows companies to avoid Paediatric Development Plans for certain diseases. The full potential of medicines is not being explored because it is not considered to be attractive enough for investors. There should be stronger obligations for research to continue and for Paediatric Development Plans to be developed for all new medicines.  Where appropriate, increased research can be supported by public money, including the EU Health Programme. There is already provision for prioritising rare diseases in the current programme, and this resource need to be fully exploited. The human cost of failing to invest in paediatric medicines is completely unacceptable.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
