text: written.- This resolution asks the Commission to propose, as contemplated in the Pediatric regulation (2007), the Regulation on pediatric medicines in due time (January 2017), which must include an analysis of the possible consequences for healthpublic.For older people, it asks that in this report they consider different factors that could improve said regulation, including full transparency of clinical results.It is for all this that I have voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I do not wish to see the EU involved in this area, however I do wish to see more development in this area.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this resolution which stems from Regulation No 1901/2006 on Paediatric medicines. It is important to foster innovation in paediatric medicines to ensure that in the future all children can be treated with medicines that have been developed for and proved effective and safe for use for children. However I voted against Amendment 1 because effectively this amendment would mean that the regulators should not oblige companies to complete paediatric studies on medicines that could possibly prove to be ineffective or unsafe. The key change brought forward by the Paediatric Regulation, which I fully support, was to oblige companies to do Paediatric Investigation Plans on all new medicines which they develop, unless a waiver is granted. The 6-month patent or SPC extension is granted to companies who complete those Paediatric Investigation Plans, regardless of whether the new medicine will be authorised for use for children. Amendment 1 effectively challenges the system of a compulsory PIP followed by a reward if the PIP is adequately completed. Companies are reluctant to complete paediatric studies because they mean additional costs for them, so it is absolutely necessary to have compulsory Paediatric Investigation Plans. This amendment was also rejected at committee level.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and success.actions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Many children with rare pediatric conditions, such as cancer, do not have access to targeted pediatric medicines. Physicians are still accustomed to prescribing drugs based on their own experience instead of accurate clinical research in the field of pediatrics. In addition, many areas of pediatric medicine lack the necessary innovations in the development of new drugs. The Pediatrics Regulation has had a positive impact on the development of pediatric medicines and has led to tangible benefits in the treatment of several pediatric diseases. But, on the other hand, almost no progress has been made in many other areas, which is why I supported the resolution calling on the Commission to specify the reasons for these shortcomings. In the future, we will need further innovations in the development of pediatric medicines to ensure better treatment options for our children. It is not just about these new medicines being able to effectively eliminate children's diseases, but above all about making them safe enough for our children.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The Pediatric Regulation entered into force in 2007 and aimed to improve the health of children in Europe by promoting the development and greater availability of medicines for children up to the age of 17. The regulation has made some progress, but it is still too slow and insufficient in many areas, especially in pediatric oncology and neonatology. Cancer remains the leading cause of death in children over the age of one, and around 6,000 children and young people in Europe die each year from cancer. The regulation also provided for a number of incentives at the time to enable the pharmaceutical industry to invest more in research and development, but these incentives were often misused by pharmaceutical companies and therefore did not produce the expected results. The resolution therefore calls on the Commission to submit a report by January 2017 on the implementation and application of the Pediatric Regulation, which is also provided for in Article 50 of this Regulation. This report should provide a comprehensive identification and in-depth analysis of the barriers that currently hamper innovation in the field of medicines for the pediatric population. In the light of these findings, the Commission should examine possible changes, including a legislative revision of the Regulation, which appears necessary. In view of all the above, I supported the resolution in plenary.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The treatment of pediatric patients must be one of the priorities of the health policy of the European Union and the nation states.We have supported increasing the efficiency of research into new drugs and their rapid introduction into pediatric practice.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The European Medicines Agency has a number of important tasks and responsibilities related to the development of pediatric medicines.These responsibilities have been assigned to her through the Pediatric Regulation of the European Union.Under the current regulatory framework, drugs have been developed in a typical pathological condition for adults that do not occur in children.Namely, childhood cancer remains the leading cause of death in children under the age of one, with more than 6,000 young people dying of cancer in Europe each year while two-thirds of survivors suffer from treatment-related side effects.The regulation is designed to better protect the health of children in the EU.I support this Report because I believe that it contributes to the improvement of the overall situation, which leads to various benefits for a number of children's diseases.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the oral question on the Pediatric Regulation.The resolution rightly calls on the Commission to consider introducing changes, including a legislative revision of the Pediatric Regulation, which will take into account pediatric development plans, priority disease and drug models, earlier and more feasible pediatric investigation plans, better incentives for more effective research.they serve the needs of the pediatric population, while ensuring an estimate of R&D costs and full transparency of clinical outcomes, as well as strategies to prevent the misuse of medicines in the field of pediatric treatment, if approved pediatric medicines already exist.Although the regulation has helped to improve the general situation, unfortunately not enough progress has been made in many areas.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The Pediatric Regulation entered into force on 26 January 2007 and its main objective was to improve the health of children in Europe by facilitating the development and availability of medicines for children aged 0 to 17 years. This resolution provides for some changes to improve the regulation, such as the prioritization of drug models, more feasible pediatric research programs as well as ensuring transparency in the research and development process regarding the needs of the pediatric population, which is why we voted in favor .

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The EU must urgently consider any possible regulatory changes that could help to improve the situation, strengthen the role of the European network for pediatric clinical research and ensure that Member States adopt measures to strengthen research, as well asand the development and distribution of medicines for pediatric use.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - Many children suffer from a rare childhood illness but do not have access to pediatric medicines. Drug use beyond the prescription prescribed by physicians is often based on experience rather than targeted clinical research. Moreover, the development of new medicines for pediatrics does not have adequate innovation and incentives in several areas. There is no doubt that the pediatric regulation has had a positive effect on the development of certain pediatric medicines and has brought tangible benefits in many areas of childhood disease, but not enough progress has been made in many areas. With these in mind, I agree that we need to promote innovation in pediatric medicines in order to treat all children with medicines that have been shown to be effective and safe. The motion urges the European Commission to review the regulation of pediatric medicines to include more than just disease-based pediatric developments, to develop disease and drug ranking models, and to develop incentives to support research. For all these reasons, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - The motion for a resolution on medicines for pediatric use is welcome because medicines without therapeutic indications are still widely used in children, in which case the risks are very high, precisely because of their particular vulnerability. Currently, the growing number of pediatric clinical trials, in addition to pediatric research projects, and the fact that the pharmaceutical industry believes that pediatric development must be an integral part of the overall development of a product highlight the need for change. current regulation of pediatric medicines. Moreover, research and innovation in the field of medicines for the pediatric population may sometimes be different from those for the adult population. Thus, the mechanism of action of a drug must be the basis of feasible pediatric development plans, based on full transparency of clinical outcomes, but also on the evaluation of research and development costs, given the benefits of a drug in terms of lives saved.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The health of European citizens is an area where the role of the European Union is very important. The use of appropriate, tested and safe medication is the key to healing in certain critical conditions. One of the most vulnerable categories in this regard is children; therefore, the approval of pediatric medicinal products must take into account the state of research in the field, so that any adverse effects are avoided as far as possible. European legislation adopted in this area in 2013 has had a positive effect on the development of the pharmaceutical industry in the pediatric sector, but in some cases more time is needed to conduct rigorous research into new medicines. For this reason, it would be useful to assess the effect of the legislation with a view to possible revisions to avoid problems that may arise in the treatment of minor patients. These reviews should continue to encourage innovation in this area, but at the same time ensure the highest possible safety of new products. It is a very sensitive area and that is why I support the adoption of the resolution on this issue.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for this proposal.We ask the Commission to present the report under Article 50 of the Regulation on medicinal products for pediatric use in due time.This report should allow a full identification and in-depth analysis of the obstacles currently hampering innovation in drugs targeting the pediatric population.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which aims to provide guidance to the Commission on where further action is needed to make the Regulation fit for purpose. In particular, the text asks the Commission to examine whether the current rewards system needs improvement, to consider drug prioritisation models and a shift to a mechanism-of-action based development strategy for cancer drugs. It places particular emphasis on paediatric oncology and rare diseases where the therapeutic needs are greatest.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a European Parliament resolution on the Regulation on medicines for pediatric use".I welcome the efforts of the European Union institutions to concentrate on researching earlier and more feasible pediatric investigation plans, especially for children suffering from various forms of tumors.As childhood tumors continue to be the leading cause of death in children, killing 6,000 young people a year, and two-thirds suffering from treatment-related side effects, additional and comprehensive investment is needed tohelped the sick more effectively.The European Union needs to concentrate more and invest more resources to help this population and to use the mechanisms at its disposal to start pediatric clinical trials of oncology medicines for children earlier.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - The aim of the Regulation on medicines for pediatric use from the very beginning was to improve the health of children throughout Europe because it enables the development and availability of medicines from birth to the age of 17. It significantly influenced the development of medicines for pediatric use, and the number of clinical trials increased, which is why I voted in favor. Many of the set goals have been met by the regulation, but some shortcomings have also been identified, such as delays in completing pediatric research and many problems related to pediatric oncology. On all other topics, we may be able to forgive possible shortcomings, but specifically in this case, when it comes to the most vulnerable members of our society, our children, there must simply be no shortcomings. I call on the Commission to consider possible legislative changes to the Regulation that will pay more attention to priority medicines, to start working on pediatric investigation plans earlier to make them more effective for all children in need, and to ensure transparency in the research and development process. Also, I believe that based on scientific data, priority should be given to pediatric needs in order to provide the best available therapies in line with the therapeutic needs of children, especially those with cancer, thus optimizing the use of research resources.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's resolution on pediatric medicines. The Pediatric Regulation has had a significant impact on the development of pediatric medicines, as most pharmaceutical companies consider pediatric development to be an essential part of the overall product development. But there is still too little done in the field of oncology because cancer in children is still the leading cause of death. Many cancers only occur in children and not in adults. And so far, based on pediatric research, only two innovative anti-cancer drugs have been approved for malignancies in pediatric patients. New drug trials and new drugs would bring life-saving benefits, so it is necessary to ensure the best available treatment methods and thus allow optimal use of research funding. In the light of the report's findings, the Commission should consider introducing amendments, including a legislative revision of the Pediatric Regulation. It would be wise to renew the provisions in Horizon 2020 regarding funding designed to support high-quality pediatric clinical research. The role of the European network for pediatric clinical research should be strengthened and Member States should ensure that measures are implemented to support research, development and availability of medicines for pediatric use.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- There is a need to better adapt treatments to children using specific drugs and not through an adaptation, often approximate, of treatments for adults, as is still the case today.This resolution, following an oral question, seeks to amend the current pediatric medicinal products regulation.Particular emphasis is placed on drugs developed to treat cancer in children.The current text had largely been bypassed by pharmaceutical companies, which in 10 years have released only 2 new drugs.The present text, despite clear shortcomings, is generally in the right direction by aiming to improve the regulation.I voted for the adoption of the text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution that raises issues such as the need for correct labeling and the variety of incentives needed to increase research in the field.The key points are to ensure a thorough assessment of R&D costs, along with full transparency of clinical costs and recognition of the need to assess how best to use different types of grants and funding in the field ofpediatric medications.As well as supporting the "untying mechanisms" envisaged by the United Nations to promote innovation and access to health technologies by separating the payment of the cost of the development of R&D for health technologies from the price of the product.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution because it calls on the Commission to deliver, as foreseen in the Regulation, the report on its application, which should include an analysis of its estimated consequences for public health, by the end of January 2017. It urges the Commission, on the basis of those findings, to consider changes, including through a legislative revision of the Regulation that gives due consideration to (a) mechanism-of-action-based, and not only cancer-type-based, paediatric development plans, (b) drug prioritisation models, (c) earlier and more feasible PIPs and (d) incentives that better stimulate research and more effectively serve the needs of the paediatric population, while ensuring transparency of the research and development process and (e) the need to avoid paediatric off-label use where authorised medicines exist.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - This proposal deals with the current status of the Pediatric Regulation, which came into force in 2007 with the aim of improving pediatric health in the Union, facilitating the development and availability of medicines for minors. It was proposed to ensure that pediatric medicines were the subject of ethical and quality research, as well as that they had a specific authorization for use and had accurate and practical information on their use in children. In addition, he wanted to achieve all this without subjecting the little ones to unnecessary trials or delaying the authorization of medicines for use in adults. Its provisions include the Pediatric Research Plan or the Marketing Authorization for Pediatric Use –to encourage research on non-patent drugs that are being used off-label–. In the almost 10 years that have elapsed since its entry into force, the Pediatric Regulation has managed to increase the number of drugs with pediatric indication in the technical sheet. However, their evaluation shows that the areas of neonatology and pediatric oncology continue to require specific attention. Thus, with the aim of continuing to improve the Regulation, I have voted in favor of this proposal.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- This resolution asks the Commission to propose, as contemplated in the Pediatric regulation (2007), the Regulation on pediatric medicines in due time (January 2017), which must include an analysis of the possible consequences for healthpublic.For older people, it asks that in this report they consider different factors that could improve said regulation, including full transparency of clinical results.It is for all this that I have voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because significantly better access to innovative therapies can save the lives of children and adolescents with life-threatening diseases such as cancer.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The “Pediatric Regulation” (EC) n ° 1901/2006 entered into force on January 26, 2007. Its objective was to facilitate the development and availability of medicines for children from 0 to 17 years old. This resolution calls on the Commission to complete and publish its report on the application of the regulation by the end of January 2017. It also calls for an in-depth review of the said regulation to include in particular a better model for prioritization of medicines, better pediatric surveys. , and increased support for research. It was possible to go further, especially in a resolution without legislative value, in particular on the transparency of the costs of research and development of pediatric medicines or the request for the integration into European legislation of the UN recommendations on the innovation and access to medical technologies. The resolution is nevertheless positive. I voted for.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The existing EU legislation on medicines for pediatric use still has several flaws that it has not been able to address. There are no pediatric investigation plans (PIP) for child-specific deadly diseases, such as high-risk neuroblastoma, however there are some PIPs for extremely rare carcinomas in children and adolescents. This is due to the fact that the approval of a PIP is encouraged based on research carried out by adult pharmacists, thus saving money in part of the study. The resolution fails to recognize the right of children to access adequate treatment and innovative medicines specific to their specific conditions and rare diseases, based on the market principle to be stimulated to address a problem of lack of resources to provide responses to a very specific population. In addition, the only concern is to find adapted cancer drugs, leaving a whole range of conditions and childhood diseases out of the requirement to respond by the pharmaceutical companies, who only investigate and put on the market what gives them answers to their interests, rather than addressing the interests of children and adolescents.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Childhood cancer is the leading cause of disease-related death in children over one year of age.6,000 young people die of cancer in the EU.Due to the effects of the chemotherapy drugs that are prescribed and currently administered in highly toxic doses, two thirds of the survivors suffer from treatment-related side effects and up to 50% of the survivors suffer from severe side effects.The industry lacks incentives to manufacture pediatric medicines.The applicable legal framework (EU regulation) is often not duly observed, as drugs are developed under typical pathological conditions that are fulfilled in adults but do not occur in children.This legislative framework is now to be revised with this motion for a resolution.I therefore voted in favor of this motion.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Around 6 000 minors die of cancer each year in Europe. Out of those who survive, two thirds suffer from treatment-related side effects for the rest of their lives. The Paediatric Regulation has had a substantial impact on the development of children’s medicine, but not enough progress has been made in a number of fields, especially oncology. This is why, together with my Socialist and Democrat colleagues in Parliament, I voted in favour of the resolution calling for funding and proper policies that stimulate more research into paediatric medicines, and is aimed at improving the treatments and the quality of life for child and teenage cancer survivors.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I fully support the resolution on paediatric medicines because there is clearly a lack of focus on children’s diseases. In general I think we have to set the right framework that offers incentives for these companies to make the large investments necessary in terms of R&D to fill this gap. The Paediatric Medicines Regulation has already addressed this problem to an extent, but revision is necessary, especially in the light of a lack in advances in paediatric oncology and neonatology. We need to do whatever we can from a regulatory perspective to ensure that new and innovative medicines can make it to the patient as fast as possible.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I, of course, supported the motion for a resolution on medicines for pediatric use. Medicines for pediatric use are an area that I have been following for a long time and which, unfortunately, despite the ten years of effective regulation at European level, has made only minimal progress. Thus, children do not have access to vital treatment, because it is not financially attractive for pharmaceutical companies to test medicines for children's use and they try to postpone their responsibilities. I therefore take the view that appropriate amendments to this regulation need to be considered and to ensure that pediatric medicines are properly and timely tested, that testing is controlled and that companies are motivated to approach testing in a timely manner. We must work together to ensure that children have access to safe medicines for serious illnesses and that they do not have to travel abroad for treatment or often use very harmful treatments that are not officially authorized for children's use.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted in favor of the oral question with resolution on pediatric medicinal products because I agree with an earlier position by the European Parliament before the revision of the Regulation on pediatric medicines that the European Commission is due to present at the beginning of next year. I regret that many children suffering from rare pediatric diseases do not have access to specific pediatric medicines. I recall that the current Pediatric Regulation has had a positive effect on the development of pediatric drugs and has led to tangible benefits for a number of childhood illnesses, but insufficient progress has been made in several areas. It is therefore urgent to promote innovation in pediatric medicines to ensure that, in the future, all children can have access to appropriate pediatric medicines. In this context, I also highlight the need to develop primary immunodeficiency tests in the Member States to screen for diseases that can be treated when diagnosed in a timely manner.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the draft motion for a resolution on the regulation on medicines for pediatric use. Children represent a vulnerable group of the population and should be given special attention, especially in terms of health. In addition, medicines for the population should also be taken seriously. I think research on medicines for children is urgently needed. This regulation was passed 10 years ago with the aim of conducting quality research for these drugs. So far, many of the objectives of this regulation on medicines for pediatric use have been achieved, but work remains to be done. Especially because this is a vulnerable group of the population - and that is children. In 2013, the Commission adopted a progress report on this case. Accordingly, she pointed out certain shortcomings. Specifically, in June 2013, the European Commission published a report on the first five years of the Regulation. This suggests that pediatric development has become more of an integral part of the overall development of medicines in the European Union. The European Commission expects to publish its final report in 2017.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the regulation on pediatric medicines.Research in pediatrics to develop effective drugs is very limited and sparse.I therefore support calls on the Commission to strengthen the role of the European network for pediatric clinical research and to provide funding sources to support research, development and availability of pediatric medicines in areas where they are most needed, in particular pediatric oncology and neonatology.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I was initially hesitant to support the report or not. In the end, I supported it for one reason, which is important to me personally, because it passed Amendment 15, which makes it clear that petitions should also focus on animal welfare issues. The Commission takes a very formal approach to these issues, reacting negatively, restrictively, and I am pleased that the European Parliament has called on the European Commission in this material to take animal welfare petitions seriously and seriously. This is an important personal topic for me. I think that in addition to the protection of human rights, the protection of democracy and so on, we, as an advanced civilization and an advanced culture, should also perceive that animals are living creatures who feel, perceive pain and need to be approached in this way and not is perceived as mere things. So I am glad that this resolution has passed and will protect animals more in the future.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it is my belief that petitions serve as a valuable indication of European citizens’ concerns in the sphere of both national and European legislation and the actions of associated authorities. Thus it is our responsibility to ensure that the framework and procedures of the Committee on Petitions is constantly evaluated and indeed improved upon. By this means we may rely on the results of the processing of petitions and its more intense role in the European Parliament and European lawmaking and revision more substantively. I acknowledge shortcomings in the processing and handling of petitions to date. However, in reinforcing our political commitment in this domain we may revise present deficiencies with regard to the timescale and effective conclusion of petitions, the establishment of a clear mandate, and the potential for the digitalisation of this field. Should said considerations be taken into account and the full potential of the European Citizens’ Initiative be realised, my colleagues and I in the EPP Group would welcome this most enthusiastically.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The PETI committee is the European Parliament's committee dealing with petitions within the European Union.A report is drawn up each year describing the activities of the aforementioned commission.The one we voted in this session referred to the year 2015. I share with the rapporteur many of the points in the report, such as the importance of the experience of those who propose and sign petitions, the importance of petitions in the legislative processand again the need to take steps forward to conclude the web portal for petitions, which allows everyone to receive information in real time on the status of petitions.For these reasons I voted positively.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report of my colleague Ángela Vallina on the work of the Petitions Committee in 2015, since it, in addition to collecting the annual activity of PETI, maintains a critical approach with the European Commission, which it urges to carry out an adequate treatment of the requests presented, as well as the information and the elimination of bureaucratic barriers for the presentation of the same and appeal to the European Commission to apply the precautionary principle in environmental matters. In addition, it refers to the scandalous legislation on mortgages and risk financial instruments in Spain, which have affected hundreds of thousands of families since the beginning of the crisis, affected by evictions, abusive clauses and the preferential scandal that was the subject of debate by the European Parliament in 2015. Unfortunately, the right wing, led by the European People's Party, managed to eliminate criticism of austerity policies in the plenary vote. However, positive aspects were maintained, such as the call for greater transparency and the implementation of participatory democracy mechanisms in the European Union, for which I voted in favor.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the activities of the Committee on Petitions 2015. The 2015 Annual Report is intended to give an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions. The Committee’s work programme is being established by citizens as they exercise their right to petition Parliament and share their concerns over various EU policies and legislation. The Annual Report aims to give a precise and full view of the work done by the Committee, it provides statistics on the number of petitions received, dealt with and closed by the Committee, the countries concerned and the matters raised. The 2015 annual statistics show that most citizens turn to Parliament for assistance with matters relating to the environment, justice, the internal market and fundamental rights. The Committee on Petitions must listen to and help solve the problems affecting its citizens because, through petitions, it can assess the impact of Community legislation on their everyday lives while making Parliament more responsive. Through the Committee on Petitions we must work to regain the trust of citizens by listening to and solving the problems that concern citizens.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - The report proposes to encourage and improve communication with citizens and to explain to them the different levels of competence (European, national and local), which means incurring expenditure to the detriment of European taxpayers. In general, he wanted to increase the resources of the secretariat of the Committee on Petitions. He also wishes to improve the fate of petitions to improve the perception by petitioners of European institutions and to explain the successes and advantages of the European project. He uses Brexit, the migrant crisis and the rise of "xenophobia and racism across Europe" as a pretext for the Committee on Petitions to prove the benefits of the European project. In other words, this report tends towards more public spending by the Committee on Petitions, claims to defend citizens except when they do not think "well" (Brexit, rejection of illegal immigration, etc.) and recognizes the role of the PETI commission as a back-up to the European Commission against the States. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe in the relevance of the Committee of Petitions as I believe issues that need to be discussed by citizens should always be discussed at a national level and not within the political structures of the European Union. For this reason, I voted against the resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I wish to underline the quality of the work undertaken by the Committee on Petitions.Its role is very important as the calendar of its activities is not modeled on that of the Commission, but set by the citizens who express their concerns about the various policies of the Union.This report is an opportunity to underline that the right to petition the European Parliament is a pillar of European citizenship.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - In its current form, the EP's Committee on Petitions is only a space for European citizens who are vulnerable to the arbitrary practices of Member State and EU bodies against EU-declared values. In 2015, 483 petitions were declared admissible and there are still many misunderstandings about the scope of the Union's activities, as indicated by the high number of petitions declared inadmissible (33.8%). Although the report states that it regrets that the petitioners still do not receive sufficient information on the reasons for declaring the petitions inadmissible, they do not see any proposal to envisage a substantive change in the rules. It is clear that the petitions system needs to be radically overhauled so that this right granted to European citizens is not arbitrarily emptied in a discriminatory manner, as was the case with professionally substantiated petitions from foreign currency creditors. Although the report contains critical elements of current practice, it does not envisage a radical renewal, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this report, which, in addition to reviewing the citizen requests received in 2015 by the Petitions Committee, highlights the importance of this form of citizen participation, and the need to provide more means to better serve the demands of society. As well as the importance of the collaboration of the European Commission, the Member States and the Ombudsman. Given the democratic gaps in the Union's operating system, I support any work aimed at increasing citizen control and participation in the political debate. I appreciate how the report highlights and gives voice to a large number of petitions on issues of great importance such as environmental issues (the most numerous); denouncing the problems and rights of the disabled; mortgage legislation. While it is true that others were left in the pipeline. The number of petitions has been cut in half, a sign of the lack of confidence in the Union. Therefore, although the inclusion of participation in the European institutions is insufficient, I am voting in favor of a report that seeks to give voice and improve this type of participation.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this report on the activities of the Petitions Committee in 2015. From our Group we have wanted to make positive the tone of Mrs. Vallina's report and have presented some amendments that reinforced the role of said committee, taking into account the large number ofrequests you receive annually.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - In 2015, 1,431 petitions were received, which represents a decrease of 47% compared to 2014 (2,714 petitions). 483 petitions were declared inadmissible; 943 petitions were declared admissible. Of these, 424 were the subject of a rapid examination and were closed after informing the petitioner and 519 petitions were left open for debate in the Committee on Petitions. The number of petitions received is small compared to the total population of the EU, which would indicate that the vast majority of citizens are not yet aware of the existence of the right to petition and its usefulness. The report proposes, among other things, to encourage communication with citizens to explain to them the different levels of competence and to increase the technical and human resources of the PETI commission by taking as pretexts Brexit, migrants or the rise of “xenophobia”. ". This report therefore encourages more spending and recognizes the role of the PETI committee as a back-up to the European Commission against states. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- According to statistics, the European Parliament received 1 431 petitions in 2015, indicating a decrease of 47% compared to the 2 714 received in 2014. After a peak in the number of petitions received in 2013 and 2014, theIn my opinion, the sharp decrease in 2015 indicates a clear reversal of the trend that should trigger an alarm bell especially in reference to proceedings that are often not very immediate and that involve uncertain times, especially in the communication by the Commission to applicants.For these reasons, I was unable to support the 2015 Annual Report of the Petitions Committee with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this annual report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions, which describes the petitions that European citizens present by exercising their right to petition the EP. The report takes stock of the commission's operation, summarizing the most relevant requests and the actions that have been taken in this regard. Some recommendations are also suggested for improving the functioning of the commission with the aim of bringing citizens closer to the institutions, in particular strengthening cooperation and the provision of information by the European Commission, national governments and national parliaments. The Petitions Committee must listen and help solve the problems that affect its citizens because, through petitions, the impact of Community legislation on their daily lives can be evaluated, while at the same time reinforcing their capacity to react. of the European Parliament helping to solve problems mainly related to the application of Union law. Petitions are a valuable source of information, detecting gaps in the application of Union law.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, in which the European Parliament examines the 2015 annual report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions. This report provides statistics on the number of petitions received, closed or pending before the committee, the parties involved in the petitions and the issues dealt with. These statistics are an important numerical tool for evaluating the committee's work. The report also addresses other aspects, such as relations with other EU institutions, national and regional authorities. From the annual 2015 statistics show that a majority of citizens turn to Parliament for help with the environment, justice, the internal market and fundamental rights. Some petitioners turn to the European Parliament to make proposals for the development of European Union policies, others to appeal against decisions taken by national authorities and to appeal against decisions of national courts. Some citizens complain about gaps in the application of EU law, such as incorrect transposition or non-compliance with European Union rules. In terms of citizenship, in 2015, as in 2014, the most active petitioners continued to be Germans, with Italians and Spaniards being slightly less active. Next on the list are citizens of Romania, Poland and the United Kingdom. Lastly, Maltese and Luxembourg nationals, who in 2015 submitted only five petitions in total.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- I would like to emphasize that petitions play an important role in the legislative process, as they identify gaps and shortcomings in the transposition of Community law and are a useful and direct resource for other parliamentary committees in their legislative work in their respective areas of competence.The increased cooperation between the Committee on Petitions and the other parliamentary committees is to be welcomed, as is the fact that petitions are dealt with more frequently in plenary.I believe that petitions should not be the sole responsibility of the Committee on Petitions, but should be the shared responsibility of all parliamentary committees.I believe that further efforts should be made to share the information needed to deal with petitions correctly.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report.The Committee has the potential to reconnect the institutions and citizens of the European Union by directly involving them in the assessment of regulations on their daily lives.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- If this report were content to make recommendations in terms of criteria for the acceptability of petitions, I could adhere to it, but since it is taking advantage of this subject to request additional expenditure in order to advocate European construction, itssuccess and its advantages, to the detriment of the sovereignty of the Member States, I can only oppose it.Therefore, I vote against this report.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – We supported this report because it gave a good summary of the PETI Committee over the past year, its successes and its failures. It also took a progressive approach criticising the austerity measures and the rise of racism and xenophobia in the EU. It also calls for a participative democracy at the EU and is rightly critical towards the European Commission and their engagement with the PETI Committee. I also supported the report because it called for more involvement in the treatment of petitions, and the maximum transparency when it comes to the open infringement procedures started by the Commission against a Member State.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The right to petition is a pillar of European citizenship. The 2015 annual report aims to provide an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions, whose calendar of activities does not correspond to the legislative program of the Commission but is established by citizens who, in exercising their right to petition at the European Parliament, express their concerns about the different policies and legislative measures of the Union. Looking at the data, it appears that 36.3% of petitions have been taken into consideration while 63.7% have been closed because the signatories continue to confuse national competences with those of the European Union, as well as the EU institutions with the Council of Europe or with the Court of Human Rights. This shows that more needs to be done to better inform citizens about the right to petition and what they can achieve by exercising this right before the European Parliament.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The right to petition is an essential element of participatory democracy for the effective protection of the right of every citizen to participate directly in the democratic life of the Union. With the help of petitions, the European Parliament can find out what problems its citizens face, provide information and help solve those problems, while also inviting the other EU institutions and the Member States' institutions to make every effort to do so. Unfortunately, the number of petitions received by Parliament remains modest in relation to the EU population, which indicates that the vast majority of EU citizens and residents are not yet aware of the right to petition and its possible usefulness as a means of attracting the attention of the EU institutions and the Member States to the issues that affect and concern them. The fact that 1,431 petitions were received in 2015, a decrease of 47% compared to 2014, during which Parliament received 2,714 petitions, confirms the failure to inform European citizens about the existence of this right. I voted in favor of this report, emphasizing once again the contribution that petitions can make in identifying gaps in EU law, as well as in assessing the effects of lack of regulation in certain areas.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of approving the PETI report on its activities in 2015. Petitions are a valuable source of first-hand information based on citizens' experiences and help to identify possible breaches and gaps in the implementation of the European Union legislation at national level. Parliament's involvement in these procedures allows for additional control over the investigative activities of the competent European institutions. However, the number of petitions received continues to be modest compared to the overall population of the European Union, indicating that the vast majority of EU citizens and residents are still unaware of the existence of the right to petition and its potential usefulness. The recent creation of an Internet portal where you can register, submit a petition and adhere to petitions already declared admissible, represents an important simplification but more needs to be done, especially to make this right known as a powerful tool for direct participation in democratic life. Furthermore, it is essential to improve collaboration with national parliaments, their competent committees and the governments of the Member States to ensure that petitions are dealt with by the authorities competent to take action.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is a summary of the activities of the Committee on Petitions from last year. The report takes a progressive approach, criticising austerity measures and the rise of racism and xenophobia in the EU. It also calls for a participative democracy at EU level and is very critical towards the European Commission. It calls for a more involvement in the treatment of petitions, or the maximum transparency when it comes to the open infringement procedures started by the Commission against a Member State. For these reasons I supported.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which analysed the activities of this Committee over the 2015 period. Its work is very important as through the Committee on Petitions we must work to regain the trust of citizens and must do so by listening to and solving the problems that concern our citizens. The Committee must listen to and help solve the problems affecting its citizens because, through petitions, it can assess the impact of Community legislation on their everyday lives while making the European Parliament more responsive, helping to solve problems mainly related to the application of EU legislation. Petitions are a valuable source of information when it comes to identifying weaknesses in how EU law is applied. In 2015, 943 petitions were admitted (65.9% of a total of 1 431) and 483 were declared inadmissible (33.8%). In 2015 the Committee on Petitions managed to completely eliminate the petition backlog that it had accumulated, which considerably boosted the quality of relations with petitioners, who saw that their petitions were now being processed more swiftly.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- This report analyzes the work that took place in the Committee on Petitions during 2015. The report clearly shows the importance of petitions as an extremely useful tool for the legislative process that allows the identification of gaps, while providing others withparliamentary committees useful and direct inputs for their activity.My vote was positive.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and believe that the Committee on Petitions has the opportunity and the great challenge, following the latest developments in the United Kingdom, to engage in a dialogue with citizens, as it has the potential to reconnect the institutions with EU citizens..

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions 2015.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The purpose of the 2015 annual report is to present a summary of the work of the Committee on Petitions. Statistics show that the majority of citizens turn to Parliament to ask for its help in matters relating to the environment, justice, the internal market and fundamental rights. Most petitions declared inadmissible are because petitioners continue to confuse European competences with national and competences of European institutions with those of the Council of Europe and those of the Court of Human Rights. I support the Vallina report, which defends the need to redouble efforts to better inform citizens about the right to petition and what they can achieve by submitting a petition to the European Parliament. I agree with the need to develop the SOLVIT network and the importance of accessing it to all the people who need it. The Committee on Petitions has the opportunity to maintain a dialogue with citizens, since, by listening to and solving the problems that concern them, it can contribute to linking the institutions and citizens of the Union.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2015 Annual Report, which is the summary of the activities of the Committee on Petitions, as it emphasizes the increasingly important role of this institution, within the European Parliament, in the legislative process.Petitions are an important indicator of citizens' concerns about decisions by national authorities and shortcomings in the application of European legislation, following an incorrect transposition of this legislation or a lack of application of Community rules.It is important that petitions are not left open indefinitely without specific investigation and that they are not a tool used incorrectly during national election campaigns.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report of my colleague Ángela Vallina on the work of the Petitions Committee in 2015, since it, in addition to collecting the annual activity of PETI, maintains a critical approach towards the European Commission, which it urges to carry out an adequate treatment of the requests presented, as well as the information and the elimination of bureaucratic barriers for the presentation of the same and appeal to the European Commission to apply the precautionary principle in environmental matters. In addition, it refers to the scandalous legislation on mortgages and risk financial instruments in Spain, which have affected hundreds of thousands of families since the beginning of the crisis, affected by evictions, abusive clauses and the preferential scandal that was the subject of debate by the European Parliament in 2015. Unfortunately, the right wing, led by the European People's Party, managed to eliminate criticism of austerity policies in the plenary vote. However, positive aspects were maintained, such as the call for greater transparency and the implementation of participatory democracy mechanisms in the Union, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - The right to petition is an essential element of participatory democracy for the effective protection of the right of every citizen to participate directly in the democratic life of the Union. However, 1,431 petitions were received in 2015, a decrease of 47% compared to 2014. This number is modest compared to the EU population. The Committee on Petitions reported better and faster processing in 2015. Annual statistics show that the majority of citizens seek Parliament's help on issues related to the environment, justice, the internal market and fundamental rights. Following the latest developments in the United Kingdom, the Committee on Petitions is facing the opportunity and a significant challenge to engage in this dialogue with citizens, with the potential to reconnect the EU institutions and citizens. I voted in favor of the activity report of the Committee on Petitions and I believe that it still has a lot of work to do to restore citizens' trust and make it a pillar for European citizens again.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The Committee on Petitions (PETI), as a parliamentary committee in direct contact with EU citizens, regularly reports on its activities in the previous year before the plenary, which can be followed by the public. The year 2015 was the first full year of the five-year legislative period that began in 2014, and tangible changes have been made to PETI’s work by streamlining the handling of petitions. All this has led to old, forgotten or lost petitions being put on the agenda, the committee deciding on the topics written in them and sending a response to EU citizens. The processing of newly received petitions is no longer hampered by the large number of petitions previously accumulated. The development of an internet portal for the electronic submission of petitions has helped to make EU citizens more aware of the possibilities offered by the right of petition. The good functioning of PETI is an important factor of trust, and EU citizens' faith in the EU institutions depends to a large extent on its work. The dialogue with citizens should be continued as it has recently begun and could be further developed, for example through new IT applications to be introduced within the Secretariat and adherence to general principles such as equal treatment of petitions. In view of the above, I supported the report. The Committee on Petitions must also adhere to these principles when considering incoming petitions concerning the Hungarian community in Slovakia, which I represent.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted against the 2015 annual report on the outcome of the Committee on Petitions due to differences and the lack of consensus on the content of the report.The Committee's Work Program is not linked to the European Commission's Legislative Work Program as it is made up of citizens who exercise their right to petition Parliament and share their concerns about specific areas of EU policy and legislation.I believe that a number of amendments should be made to the report to remove the incompatibilities in the opinion.The failure to take into account the amendments tabled by ECR experts contributed to a negative assessment of the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the citizens should always be kept as a priority in all of our decisions, both on a European and national level. The Committee on Petitions has the potential to reconnect institutions and EU citizens by directly involving them and assessing the impact of community legislation on their everyday lives. Through the Committee on Petitions we must work to regain the trust of citizens and must do so by listening to and solving the problems that concern citizens. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This own-initiative report describes the activities of the Committee on Petitions during the year 2015. The report stresses that the right to petition must strengthen the reaction capacity of the European Parliament, by helping to resolve the problems linked mainly tothe transposition and application of Union law.According to MEPs, petitions that meet the admissibility criteria are a valuable source of information for detecting possible violations of EU law.Considering that the full and complete implementation of European law is an essential condition for the effectiveness of European action, I voted in favor.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I gave my support to the text on the annual report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions during the year 2015. The right of every citizen to petition is essential.By helping European citizens to solve their problems, mainly related to the transposition and application of Union law, this right of petition makes it possible to better assess the effects of European legislation on the daily life of citizens.In order to speed up the administrative process, I stress the need for efficient and operational digitization of petition processing, allowing EU citizens to continuously monitor their processing, but also to electronically sign their own petitions.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this report.The number of petitions is down by 47% compared to 2014, even though it remains negligible compared to the population of the European Union, with only 1,431 petitions received in 2015. Since this service seems little known, the rapporteurclaims to improve communication as well as the means of the secretariat of the petitions service.Brexit, the migrant crisis and the rise of "xenophobia and racism across Europe" are taken as a pretext to justify this need for communication vis-à-vis European citizens.We cannot support a further increase in the budgetary envelope for this service, especially if it aims to support politically oriented communication.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I voted against the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. As some of you know, in this committee Ilhan Kyuchuk, a member of the European Parliament from the MRF / ALDE, submitted a petition against the ban on campaigning in a foreign language. At present, the work of the Committee on Petitions is clearly directly dominated by the ruling groups of Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Liberals, which consider only petitions that are convenient for the European status quo. This is also clear from the drop in petitions, which is half of those in 2014. My colleague Notis Marias has made 15 amendments to this report and all of them have been rejected by the representatives of the status quo.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- Any legislation, as well as activity related to immigration policies, European citizenship, the rights of people belonging to minorities, are contrary to our principles and pose a threat to the security and economy of the European Union.For these reasons, we are voting against the report of the Committee on Petitions on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written. - The 2015 annual report describes the main activities of the commission in terms of the results of the processing of petitions and its role in the European Parliament in drafting and reviewing European legislation. Petitions are a valuable barometer of citizens' concerns regarding decisions of national authorities and shortcomings in the application of Union law. It acts as an instrument of contact between the Union and European citizens. In this sense, it is necessary because it allows to give voice and to know the problems and issues that concern the European population, problems that perhaps do not reach the institutions through other channels. It should be noted that it is for this value that the Petitions Committee has that it should be tried to avoid its politicization, especially in electoral campaigns, because it is working on petitions that affect individuals or groups, and in some cases, through the partisan use of the Commission is giving the petitioners false hopes or promises that are not really possible.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Annual Report of the Committee on Petitions 2015. This report serves two purposes - to give an account of the committee’s work over the past year, and to put forward a resolution on the political and practical lessons learned. Several of my constituents in Wales have presented petitions, as I have done myself. The effective participation of citizens is vital for any democracy.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - According to statistics, in 2015, the European Parliament received 1431 petitions, which represents a decrease of 47% compared to the 2714 petitions submitted in 2014. In 2015, 943 petitions were considered admissible (65.9% of a total of 1431) and 483 were declared inadmissible (33.8%). In 2015, 63.4% of the petitions received, that is, 907 petitions, received rapid treatment, either because they were considered inadmissible (33.8%), or because, although they were admissible, they were immediately closed after transmitting information to the petitioners or after their referral to another parliamentary committee competent in the matter (29.6%). It should be noted that the percentage of petitions considered inadmissible decreased compared to 2014 (6.1% in 2015), and that the percentage of petitions considered admissible increased (5.9%). In relation to 2015, there were several changes in the list of countries of origin of petitions, with Spain still in first place, followed by Italy, Germany, Romania and Poland. However, there can be a significant increase in the proportion of Italian petitions, which went from 7.9% to 12.3%. I voted in favor.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: with this report, we tend towards more public spending by the Committee on Petitions, which claims to defend the citizens, except when they do not think "well" (Brexit, rejection of illegal immigration, etc.).In addition, it recognizes the role of the PETI commission as a back-up to the European Commission against States.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report describes the activity and work of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions. It details the number of petitions received, closed or dealt with by this Commission or on the countries or subjects in question, constituting an important quantitative tool in the evaluation of its work. During 2015, 1431 petitions were received (47% less than in 2014), 943 were considered admissible, of which 424 had a quick analysis. From the analysis made, it is noted that the majority of citizens who use this expedient to appeal to the European Parliament, seek assistance in matters related to the environment, fundamental rights, justice and the internal market. Other petitioners seek to make their proposals heard on the implementation of EU policies and still others go to the European Parliament to challenge decisions taken by national authorities and to complain against judgments of national courts. The majority denounce deficiencies in the application of European legislation, either by defective transposition of the legislation, or by non-application of Community rules, or even for violation of them. A reality that confirms the discontent and the growing distance of citizens from the European integration process. We emphasize that the final version of this report has been considerably weakened, as the right has dropped references to so-called austerity policies and their effects.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- Any legislation, as well as activity related to immigration policies, European citizenship, the rights of people belonging to minorities, are contrary to our principles and pose a threat to the security and economy of the European Union.For these reasons, I am voting against the report of the Committee on Petitions on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which highlights the main activities of the Petitions Committee. As the committee that deals directly with citizens, the committee has the potential to reconnect institutions and EU citizens by directly involving them and assessing the impact of Community legislation on their everyday lives, which is an extremely important role.  I believe there was a need to deal with some obstacles in the treatment of petitions such as the Commission’s strict interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights or the need for greater transparency on infringement procedures. The report will also bring improvements in the petitions web portal where citizens can upload their petitions. I strongly welcome the agreements reached by the majority when drawing up these guidelines and the maintenance of the same procedures and deadlines.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The right to petition is a cornerstone of European citizenship and must be respected.In this way, citizens can express their concerns about the various policy areas to Parliament.The 2015 statistics show that most citizens turned to Parliament on issues of the environment, justice, the internal market or fundamental rights.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as this report acknowledges the relevance of the Committee on Petitions.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The work programme and activities of the Petitions Committee are dictated by the petitions which are submitted to it by citizens exercising their right to petition the European Parliament. The activities of the committee for 2015 are outlined in this annual report. It also includes other important aspects such as relations with other EU institutions and national authorities; some obstacles in the treatment of petitions such as the Commission’s strict interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights or the need for greater transparency on infringement procedures. The report also calls for improvements in the petitions web portal where citizens can upload their petitions.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this report, which, in addition to reviewing the citizen requests received in 2015 by the Petitions Committee, highlights the importance of this form of citizen participation, and the need to provide more means to better serve the demands of society. As well as the importance of the collaboration of the European Commission, the Member States and the Ombudsman. Given the democratic gaps in the Union's operating system, I support any work aimed at increasing citizen control and participation in the political debate. I appreciate how the report highlights and gives voice to a large number of petitions on issues of great importance such as environmental issues (the most numerous); denouncing the problems and rights of the disabled; mortgage legislation. While it is true that others were left in the pipeline. The number of petitions has been cut in half, a sign of the lack of confidence in the Union. Therefore, although the inclusion of participation in the European institutions is insufficient, I am voting in favor of a report that seeks to give voice and improve this type of participation.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of the report, as, in addition to reviewing the activities of the Committee on Petitions, the report also took a progressive approach criticizing austerity measures and the rise of racism and xenophobia in the EU.greater involvement in dealing with reports as well as the maximum degree of transparency.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions 2015. The report is intended to give an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions. The Committee’s work programme is not tied in to the Commission’s legislative programme, being established by citizens as they exercise their right to petition Parliament and share their concerns over various EU policies and legislation. It provides statistics on the number of petitions received, dealt with and closed by the Committee, the countries concerned and the matters raised. The 2015 statistics show most citizens turn to Parliament for assistance with matters relating to the environment, justice, the internal market and fundamental rights. The Committee has the opportunity, and the major challenge, following recent events in the United Kingdom, of maintaining dialogue with citizens, as it has the potential to reconnect institutions and EU citizens. I firmly believe the Committee must listen to and help solve the problems affecting its citizens because, through petitions, it can assess the impact of Community legislation on their everyday lives while making Parliament more responsive, helping to solve problems mainly related to the application of EU legislation.

name: Peter JAHR
text: written. - In general, the Petitions Committee has had a successful year. That is why I am, of course, also pleased that the report was so well received in the European Parliament. This is a good sign that gives us courage, also for future work. Nevertheless, there are still some construction sites that should be improved in the future when processing the petitions. These are, on the one hand, increased digitization of the petition processing process and the implementation of the administrative “wave” reform. I would also like to see the petition processes depoliticized, especially in view of national election campaigns. From the experience of last year, I also find it important to clearly define the mandates of the working groups in advance. Unfortunately, not all of these EPP demands were supported by the other political groups in today's vote. I very much regret that, as this would mean that petitions would be processed even more efficiently and, above all, the petitioners would have the chance of a faster solution to their concerns.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Report on the Activities of the Committee on Petitions during 2015 because I believe that petitions play an important role in the legislative process as they point to existing shortcomings and shortcomings in the transposition of European legislation and enable other parliamentary committees to obtain useful and direct information.legislative work in the areas in which they are competent.I believe that the European Parliament should make more use of, encourage and strengthen the right to petition, because then solving the problems related to the transposition and application of EU legislation would be faster and more efficient.The report, which I voted for, states that the Committee on Petitions must restore citizens' trust by listening to and resolving the problems that afflict them.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The rapporteur's desire to improve communication with citizens and the visibility of the institutions would lead to an increase in public spending, to the detriment of these same citizens.The reasons put forward, such as Brexit or the rise of xenophobia, are all pretexts.This project is nothing more than an umpteenth attempt to rescue the community spirit, of varying geometry.I voted against.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which presents the activities of the Committee on Petitions for the year 2015. The text recalls that petitions constitute a barometer of citizens' concerns about the decisions of national authorities and the shortcomings in the process.application of Union law.It can be seen that the majority of petitioners submit complaints concerning the environment, justice, the internal market, fundamental rights and transport.We ask for a stronger commitment from the Commission in order to make the European citizens' initiative work and to develop its full potential.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- The aim of the annual report on the activities of the Petitions Committee is to provide an assessment of the petitions submitted in 2015 and the relationships with other institutions, as well as an accurate presentation.On the positive side, petitions strengthen the principle of direct democracy.On the other hand, the rapporteur regrets that the citizens of Poland and the UK are still not protected by the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.It is also emphasized that the European Citizens' Initiative is intended to further advance the integration process.For these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to give a precise and full view of the work done by the Committee on Petitions. It provides statistics on the number of petitions received, dealt with and closed by the Committee, the countries concerned and the matters raised. This report also covers other aspects such as relations with other EU institutions and with national and regional authorities. I voted in favour of this report since not only it gives an overview of the annual activities but also calls for a participative democracy in the EU and is also very critical towards the European Commission.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- On the positive side of the report, it finds it at least regrettable that the petitioners still do not receive sufficient information on the reasons for declaring their submissions inadmissible, but this is sweet, as it does not contain a proposal for a substantive change in the rules.Every well-off person is outraged, for example, by what happened in connection with the foreign currency creditors' petition last year, when the committee found the petition admissible but later arbitrarily rejected it on a completely wrong and even cynical basis.However, in the petition the EU consumer protection norms that were violated by the so-called forint conversion laws passed by the Hungarian Parliament were itemized.I am not surprised that many see the Committee on Petitions as a putty association for this reason.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it calls for an increase in the technical and human resources of the secretariat of the Committee on Petitions.However, this is for the purposes of propaganda, as it specifies that petitions must be used to explain the successes of the Union.I believe that the real intermediaries between the Union and the citizens are the MEPs, and not this bureaucratic committee.In a single weekend, I receive more citizens than this commission does in a year!

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it highlights the need for greater transparency and greater capacity for European citizens to report serious abuses of environmental, labor and consumer protection regulations that occur in the Member States.The Committee on Petitions must be the voice of Europeans in this House and it seems to me essential to continue strengthening it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that analyses the work of the Parliament’s Petitions Committee during 2015.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The purpose of the annual report for 2015 is to provide an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions.The report shall provide statistics on the number of petitions received, processed or concluded by the Committee and the countries and issues involved.These statistics represent an important quantitative tool for evaluating the work of the board.The 2015 Annual Statistics show that the majority of citizens seek Parliament's assistance on issues related to the environment, justice, the internal market and fundamental rights.According to statistics, in 2015 the European Parliament received 1431 petitions, a decrease of 47% compared to 2014. As petitions play an important role in the legislative process, as they point to existing shortcomings and shortcomings in the transposition of European legislation and allow other parliamentary committees to obtainuseful and direct information for their legislative work in the areas for which they are responsible, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing.- The European Parliament, as the only directly elected EU institution, must not only play a legislative role, but also work directly with specific citizens and groups.Petitions are a powerful tool for carrying out this work, and it must never turn into another empty formality.Therefore, I will always support any proposal that would increase the impact and authority of this important instrument of democracy.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- The Committee on Petitions enables natural and legal persons residing in the Union to exercise one of their fundamental rights - to address their requests and complaints to the European Parliament.Petitions are an important tool that provides some feedback on the perception of the EU institutions and their roles by Union citizens.The present activity report of the Committee on Petitions provides statistics and information relevant not only to the work of Parliament but also to the Commission.These findings need to be further worked on, evaluated and the results taken into account when adopting further procedures and measures.However, this fundamental right of citizens should not be abused by some populist MEPs for self-promotion, misleading and spreading untruths, which damages the reputation of their own country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 15/12/2016, and because this report is not complete anddocumented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this report.This text concerns the summary of the work of the parliamentary committee responsible for petitions in 2015.
