The rapporteur suggests increasing the budget of the PETI committee secretariat in order to deal with petitions as soon as possible.We find this increase unreasonable, given that the number of petitions handled by the committee in 2015 decreased compared to 2014. Furthermore, the report envisages the strengthening of communitarian propaganda under the pretext of the lack of sufficient information on the tools ofdemocracy accessible to European citizens.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. - Today, we have taken note of the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. This committee is important from the point of view that through it, citizens can turn to Parliament for help. The work schedule of the Committee on Petitions does not correspond to the legislative program of the European Commission, but is therefore shaped by the citizens themselves. Annual statistics for 2015 show that the European Parliament received 1,431 petitions. Most citizens ask for help in the areas of the environment, the judiciary, the internal market or fundamental rights. The rapporteur notes in the report that the biggest problem is that citizens do not receive sufficiently substantiated responses declaring their petitions inadmissible, as well as cases of delays in the committee's handling of petitions. I consider the right of petition to be an important right for every citizen to turn to the European Parliament, for example in cases of insufficient application of European rules by a Member State or non-compliance with Community rules. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the EP resolution on the work of the Committee on Petitions in 2015.I believe that this committee has an important role to play in ensuring the transparency and openness of the EP's activities and in enabling citizens to express their views on issues that concern them.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This is an annual report on the activity of the Committee on Petitions: it appears that 1,431 petitions were received in 2015, compared to 2,714 in 2014, a drop of 47%.Therefore, the rapporteur wishes to encourage and improve communication with citizens.Clearly, he wants additional resources, particularly financial and human, to be made available to the Committee on Petitions.This activity report therefore claims to defend citizens, except when they are not in line with the single thought set by the European Union.I therefore voted against this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- The right to petition is very important as a pillar of European citizenship and an element of participatory democracy.It recognizes the right of residents and citizens of the Union to express their concerns directly to the EP on policies and legislative measures affecting them.As proof, in 2015, 1,431 petitions were received by the European Parliament.These mainly concerned the environment, justice, the internal market and fundamental rights.The petitioners use this tool of democracy to voice their proposals for the development of European policies, but also to challenge decisions taken by national authorities, or to denounce shortcomings in the application of Union law.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, which highlights the main activities of the Petitions Committee that are based on citizens’ petitions to the Parliament. The Committee has the potential to reconnect institutions and EU citizens by directly involving them and assessing the impact of Community legislation on their everyday lives, which is very important.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- We vote against this report, which only asks for more expenditure from Parliament to improve the image of European institutions, in particular by maintaining a “democratic” facade, to continue to spread pro-migrant Europeanist ideas, to fight the rise of“Xenophobia and racism across Europe” and give the Committee on Petitions a supplementary role for the European Commission in its fight against the sovereignty of States.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This report tends towards more public spending by the Committee on Petitions, claims to defend citizens except when they do not think "well" (Brexit, rejection of illegal immigration, etc.) and recognizes the role of the PETI committee asthe European Commission against the States.I therefore vote against.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ As the committee which deals directly with citizens, this report highlights the main activities of the Petitions Committee, which are based on citizens’ petitions to Parliament. The Committee has the potential to reconnect institutions and EU citizens by directly involving them and assessing the impact of Community legislation on their everyday lives.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which takes stock of the activity of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions for 2015: 1,431 petitions (including 943 admissible) were received in 2015, which represents a decrease of 47%compared to 2014;424 of them were the subject of a rapid examination which provided the petitioner with relevant information;519 were left open for debate in the committee;483 were declared inadmissible.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Most citizens tend to search assistance from the European Parliament for matters regarding environment, justice, internal market and fundamental rights. I am in favour of this report regarding the activities of the Committee on Petitions taking into consideration that the right to petition the European Parliament represents a cornerstone of European citizenship.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. - From the content of the approved report, I would like to emphasize that petitioners have had access to a web portal where they can register, submit a petition, download supporting documents and join petitions that have already been declared admissible. Follow-up steps should be taken to complete the remaining phases of the petition web portal, where petitioners will be able to receive up-to-date information on the status of their petition and be notified by automatic messages of changes in the procedure - such as a declaration of admissibility, or the inclusion of the petition on the agenda of a committee meeting, including a link to the relevant webcast. I would also like to draw attention to the adoption of Regulation 910/2014 / EU on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market, with the EP Committee on Petitions and all European Union institutions receiving documents signed by electronic signatures from all 28 EU Member States.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because unfortunately the citizens of Poland are still not protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.The European integration process is to be promoted through the European Citizens' Initiative.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The 2015 report shows that most citizens turn to the European Parliament for help with environmental, legal, internal market and fundamental rights issues.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. The Committee on Petitions has the opportunity and the great challenge, following the latest developments in the United Kingdom, to develop a dialogue with citizens, as it has the opportunity to reconnect institutions with the citizens of the EU. The Committee on Petitions should listen to and help solve the problems affecting its citizens, as reports can assess the impact of Community the European Parliament’s ability to react, contributing to the solution of problems mainly related to the implementation of EU law. Petitions are a valuable source of information, as they identify gaps in the implementation of EU law. to regain citizens' trust. And we must do this by listening to and solving the problems that concern citizens.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support the Resolution on the activities of the Committee on Petitions during 2015, taking into account, inter alia, the right to petition and the fact that it is useful for Parliament to be informed immediately of what particularly concerns EU citizens and residents. , as provided for in Articles 24 and 227 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The annual report seeks to provide an accurate and complete picture of the work of the Committee on Petitions, whose work program does not coincide with the Commission's legislative program, but is determined by citizens, exercising their right to petition the European Parliament and expressing concern And. The report shall provide statistics on the number of applications received, processed or concluded by the State concerned and the issues involved. Compared to the previous year, Spain is still in first place in 2015, followed by Italy, Germany, Romania and Poland (one year ago the fifth place went to the United Kingdom). I emphasize that the right to petition the European Parliament is a pillar of European citizenship and is a valuable source of information for identifying shortcomings in the implementation of EU legislation.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The Committee on Petitions is of particular importance because it has the potential to connect the institutions and citizens of the European Union by involving them directly and also allows the impact of Union legislation on the daily lives of citizens to be assessed. The work program and activities of the Committee on Petitions are determined by petitions submitted by citizens exercising their right to petition the EP. In addition to the Committee's activities, the report mentions other aspects such as relations with other EU institutions and national authorities. We remind the Commission that because of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, citizens often expect more than what the legal provisions of the Charter strictly allow, and their expectations remain unfulfilled precisely because of this strict and restrictive interpretation of Article 51 by the Commission. I call on the Commission to adopt a new approach better adapted to these expectations. The report also calls for improvements to the internet portal where citizens can submit their applications, as this portal enhances the transparency and interactivity of the application process.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - This report describes the activity and work of the Committee on Petitions. It details the number of petitions received, closed or dealt with by the commission or on the countries or subjects in question, constituting an important quantitative tool in the evaluation of its work. During 2015, 1431 petitions were received (47% less than in 2014), 943 were considered admissible, of which 424 had a quick analysis. From the analysis made, it is noted that the majority of citizens who use this expedient to appeal to Parliament, seek assistance in matters related to the environment, fundamental rights, justice and the internal market. Other petitioners seek to make their proposals heard regarding the implementation of Union policies, and still others go to the European Parliament to challenge decisions taken by national authorities and to complain against national court judgments. The majority denounce deficiencies in the application of European legislation, either by defective transposition of the legislation, or by non-application of Community rules, or even for violation of them. A reality that confirms the discontent and the growing distance of citizens from the European integration process.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - I consider the right to petition the European Parliament to be one of the pillars of European citizenship. The aim of the Annual Report for 2015 is to provide an overview of the activities of the Committee on Petitions, the work schedule of which is drawn up by the citizens themselves in the exercise of their right of petition. The aim of this annual report is to give an accurate and complete list of the activities of the Committee on Petitions. This report also reflects other aspects, such as relations with other European institutions and national and regional authorities. Statistics show that in 2015, the European Parliament received 1,431 petitions, which is 47% less than in 2014. It can be said that previous years (2013 and 2014) were the strongest in terms of the number of petitions received. The sharp decline in 2015 (by almost half) probably reflects a change in trend following a steady increase in the number of petitions received during the last parliamentary term. Personally, I consider this fact to be a positive indicator of mood in society, which shows that EU citizens are satisfied with its work.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted for this annual report which is a summary of the work done by the Committee on Petitions.This report aims to give a precise and complete picture of the work of the Committee on Petitions;it provides statistics on the number of petitions received, processed and closed by the committee, as well as on the countries concerned and the issues raised.I would remind you that the right to petition the European Parliament is a fundamental right for European citizens, who can thus express to us their concerns regarding the various policies and legislative measures of the Union.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I have voted favorably on this annual report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions, which describes the petitions that European citizens present by exercising their right to petition the European Parliament. The report takes stock of the operation of the commission, summarizing the most relevant requests and the actions that have been taken in this regard. Some recommendations are also suggested for improving the functioning of the commission with the aim of bringing citizens closer to the institutions, in particular strengthening cooperation and the provision of information by the European Commission, national governments and national parliaments. The Petitions Committee must listen and help solve the problems that affect its citizens because, through petitions, the impact of Community legislation on their daily lives can be evaluated, while strengthening their capacity to react. of the European Parliament helping to solve problems mainly related to the application of Union law. Petitions are a valuable source of information, detecting gaps in the application of Union law.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which underlines that the role of the right of petition is to strengthen the European Parliament's ability to react, by helping to resolve problems mainly linked to the application of Union law, since petitions which fall within the fields of activity of the Union and meet the admissibility criteria constitute a valuable source of information allowing the detection of possible violations of European legislation. The adopted text calls on the Commission to make greater use of its powers to ensure the effective implementation of European legislation, in particular by using the infringement procedure under Articles 258 and 260 TFEU more quickly. It should be noted that in 2015, 431 petitions were received at the Committee on Petitions, which represents a decrease of 47% compared to 2014, during which the European Parliament received 2,714 petitions.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted for the 2015 annual report on the activities of the Petitions Committee.The 2015 annual report describes the main activities of the committee with regard to the results of the petition processing and its growing role in the European Parliament in European legislation and revision.Petitions are a valuable barometer to understand citizens' concerns about the implementation and application of European legislation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report of my colleague Ángela Vallina on the work of the Petitions Committee in 2015, since it, in addition to collecting the annual activity of PETI, maintains a critical approach towards the European Commission, which it urges to carry out an adequate treatment of the requests presented, as well as the information and the elimination of bureaucratic barriers for the presentation of the same and appeal to the European Commission to apply the precautionary principle in environmental matters. In addition, it refers to the scandalous legislation on mortgages and risk financial instruments in Spain, which have affected hundreds of thousands of families since the beginning of the crisis, affected by evictions, abusive clauses and the preferential scandal that was the subject of debate by the European Parliament in 2015. Unfortunately, the right wing, led by the European People's Party, managed to eliminate criticism of austerity policies in the plenary vote. However, positive aspects were maintained, such as the call for greater transparency and the implementation of participatory democracy mechanisms in the Union, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as to vote in favour would be acknowledging the relevance of this committee.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As the committee which deals directly with citizens this report highlights the main activities of the Petitions Committee which are based on citizens’ petitions to the Parliament. The committee has the potential to reconnect institutions and EU citizens by directly involving them and assessing the impact of Community legislation on their everyday lives. Also outlined are other aspects such as relations with other EU institutions and national authorities; some obstacles in the treatment of petitions such as the Commission’s strict interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights or the need for greater transparency on infringement procedures. The report also calls for improvements in the petitions web portal where citizens can upload their petitions.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and success.actions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the work of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. The report states that 1431 petitions were received in 2015, a decrease of 47% compared to the previous year. The number of petitions received in relation to the overall population of the Union is low, indicating that the vast majority of EU citizens are not yet sufficiently informed about the existence of the right of petition or its potential usefulness as a means of alerting EU institutions and Member States to problems affecting them. and which concern them and fall within the field of activity of the Union. The European Parliament is the only EU institution directly elected by its citizens, and the right of petition offers them the opportunity to draw the attention of their elected representatives to issues that concern them. Although the time taken to process petitions was reduced in 2015, there is still a lack of the necessary technical equipment and staff in the secretariat of the Committee on Petitions. We also consider it necessary to improve cooperation in the future with national parliaments and their relevant committees, as well as with the governments of the Member States, in particular to ensure that petitions are dealt with by the competent authorities with the necessary powers.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The right to petition is one of the fundamental rights of European citizens and residents and is enshrined in the founding treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. The purpose of the Annual Activity Report of the Committee on Petitions is to present an analysis of petitions received in 2015 and relations with other institutions and to provide an overview of the objectives achieved in 2015. In 2015, 1431 petitions were received, of which 943 were admissible, of these, 424 petitions were quickly reviewed and closed. Unfortunately, it seems that the vast majority of EU citizens are still unaware of this means by which the European institutions and the Member States can draw attention to issues and pressing issues that concern and fall within the scope of EU action, and more needs to be done to promotion. I also welcome the part of the report which emphasizes that petitions are an alternative and independent means of investigating and verifying compliance with EU law, and that this procedure is not excluded from proceedings before national courts, which is very important for citizens. The report also recognizes the important role of petitions in the legislative process, as they make it possible to identify existing gaps and shortcomings in the transposition of EU legislation, and we can do more here. Because of all of the above, I supported the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The strategy to increase public confidence in the European Union institutions should also include streamlining the European right of petition so that the citizens' initiative is properly discussed and that legitimate objections are taken into account when drafting and amending legislation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - The purpose of the annual report on the work of the Committee on Petitions is to present an analysis of petitions received in 2015 and relations with other institutions, and to present an accurate picture of the goals achieved in 2015. So far, very few applications have been received given the total population of the European Union, which means that EU citizens are unfortunately still unaware of the right to object as a possible means to point out to the European institutions certain problems plaguing Union citizens. Petitions allow institutions to listen to citizens 'problems and help solve them, because petitions can assess the impact of Community legislation on their daily lives, while strengthening the European Parliament's ability to act on citizens' demands can help solve problems mainly related to EU law enforcement. Petitions are a valuable source of information to identify shortcomings in the implementation of EU legislation. I support this report because I believe that the European Parliament is the only EU institution whose representatives are elected by the citizens, and that they are the ones who can point out certain problems of the Union and shortcomings related to the EU legislative process.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. The right to petition, introduced to facilitate the addressing of initiatives or complaints by European citizens to the European Union institutions, is an important instrument known in the EU.It can contribute to better regulation and thus have a significant impact on people's daily lives.Especially in these times, when many citizens find the EU very distant due to various crises, we need this bridge between citizens and institutions even more.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The EU has lost the trust of the people and unfortunately is not trying to create the right, simple and functional mechanisms to give weight to their speech, concerns and concerns.On the contrary, it promotes only the issues that it considers important with the aim of altering nations and Christian values.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the adoption of the report on the activities of the EP Committee on Petitions in 2015. In the year under review, the number of petitions received by the committee decreased significantly by 47% compared to the previous year, however, the Committee on Petitions , in terms of experiencing EU citizenship. The report also provides a detailed data set by Member State and important additional findings. It is clear from these that a significant proportion of the submissions concern the areas of environmental protection and social rights, which is a remarkable fact both as a left-wing Member and as a member of the ENVI Committee for my own work as a Member. I also appreciated the fact that the report points to the legal and practical constraints that limit the work and powers of the Committee on Petitions and its investigation, but also makes substantive suggestions on a number of points in order to overcome them in the future.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The 2015 Annual Report is purely an informative one, as it gives an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions. The Committee of Petitions was established by citizens to give them the possibility to petition Parliament and share their concerns over various EU policies and legislation. The report provides statistics on the number of petitions received, dealt with and closed by the Committee, the countries concerned and the matters raised. According to the statistics, in 2015 the European Parliament received 1 431 petitions. I support this report as I believe in the necessity of such an instrument in order to increase transparency in the European Union.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I spoke in favor of this report. The purpose of the 2015 annual report is to give an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions, whose calendar of activities does not correspond to the legislative program of the European Commission, but is set by the citizens who, exercising their right of petition to the European Parliament, express their concerns regarding the various policies and legislative measures of the Union. This annual report aims to give a precise and complete picture of the work of the Committee on Petitions. It presents statistics on the number of petitions received, processed or closed by the Committee on Petitions, the countries concerned and the themes addressed. These statistics constitute an important quantitative tool for evaluating the work of the committee. This report also looks at other aspects of the committee's work, such as relations with other European institutions and with national and regional authorities.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this annual report is to give an overview of activities of the Committee on Petitions, whose work is not tied to the Commission’s legislative program but based on citizens’ petitions. The Committee on Petitions listens to and helps to solve problems affecting citizens directly. The petitions can help to better assess the impact that EU legislation has on people’s daily lives by acting as a bridge between citizens and the institutions. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the right to petition represents the opportunity for citizens to express their concern for issues such as fundamental rights, child welfare, disabled people, minority rights, etc. The report serves as an excellent tool to improve its functioning.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a resolution on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015."A decrease of 47% in the number of submitted applications compared to 2013 calls into question the involvement, information and interest of the citizens of the European Union in matters of action.I support a stronger connection between the EU institutions and citizens in the work of the Committee on Petitions.I also support the search for an assurance that the Commission regularly reports to Parliament on the progress of infringement proceedings against individual Member States in order to facilitate better cooperation and to enable applicants to be informed of progress at an early stage.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015 provides a complete annual overview of the work of that committee, providing statistics on the number of petitions received, the number of petitions processed and resolved by the committee, the number of petitions by country and main petition topics.I believe that the Committee on Petitions is very important for the exercise of civil rights and the expression of citizens' concerns about a number of EU policies and laws, because in this way the democratic process started in the elections continues.However, although the Committee on Petitions is an important link between citizens and the institutions of the European Union, I believe that it should work in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality, ie it should not blame Member States for possible irregularities in areas under the exclusive competence of Member States.social policy.That is why I voted against this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the activities of the Committee on Petitions for 2015. The 2015 Annual Report is an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions. The Committee's program of activities is not linked to the European Commission's legislative program, but is tailored to citizens who, by exercising their right to petition the European Parliament, express concerns about issues in the Union's various political and legislative areas. Statistics for 2015 show that the majority of citizens turn to the European Parliament for help in matters relating to the environment, the judiciary, the internal market and fundamental rights. In 2015, 1431 petitions were received, which is 47% less than in 2014. Spain ranks first in 2015 in the number of petitions filed, followed by Italy and Germany. An analysis of the statistics on petitions shows that the main reasons for the inadmissibility of petitions are the fact that petitioners still confuse the competences of the EU and the Member States and do not differentiate between the EU institutions. The European Commission continues to be the primary partner of the Committee on Petitions in dealing with petitions, as it is responsible for monitoring the application and compliance with EU law. The key topics of the Committee on Petitions in 2015 were mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments, the environment and disability.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The Committee of Petitions and its Secretariat deal with hundreds of petitions every month. Great progress has been made in order to provide petitioners with a timely response. However, more can be done in order to make the process better. Therefore, I have proposed that all documents which have been digitally signed should be accepted by Committee. This applies to digital signatures from all 28 Member States. It is important that the process is as easy and convenient as possible, in order to remove all possible barriers for the petitioners. The procedure should be simple so that everyone can make use of it.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - The report proposes to encourage and improve communication with citizens and to explain to them the different levels of competence (European, national and local), which means incurring expenditure to the detriment of European taxpayers. In general, he wants to increase the technical and human resources of the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions to ensure a reasonable processing time. He also wishes to improve the fate reserved for petitions to make the perception by petitioners of European institutions more positive and to explain the successes and advantages of the European project. He also recalls that the Committee on Petitions warned the European Commission against the failings of States. In other words, this report tends towards more public spending by the Committee on Petitions, which claims to defend citizens, except when they do not think "well" (Brexit, rejection of illegal immigration, etc.), and recognizes the role of the PETI commission as a back-up to the European Commission against States. I voted against.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this report, which, in addition to reviewing the citizen requests received in 2015 by the Petitions Committee, highlights the importance of this form of citizen participation, and the need to provide more means to better serve the demands of society. As well as the importance of the collaboration of the European Commission, the Member States and the Ombudsman. Given the democratic gaps in the Union's operating system, I support any work aimed at increasing citizen control and participation in the political debate. I appreciate how the report highlights and gives voice to a large number of petitions on issues of great importance such as environmental issues (the most numerous); denouncing the problems and rights of the disabled; mortgage legislation. While it is true that others were left in the pipeline. The number of petitions has been cut in half, a sign of the lack of confidence in the Union. Therefore, although the inclusion of participation in the European institutions is insufficient, I am voting in favor of a report that seeks to give voice and improve this type of participation.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the annual report of the Committee on Petitions because it gives an account of the Committee’s work during the past year and it presents a resolution drawing political and practical conclusions on the basis of petitions received and examined. Taking into account the persisting context of ideological clash over the fate of the Committee, the report is a good opportunity to consolidate and even go further on strengthening the important role of the Petitions Committee.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - I voted in favor of my report on the work of the Petitions Committee in 2015 since it, in addition to collecting the annual activity of PETI, maintains a critical approach with the European Commission, which urges to carry out an adequate treatment of the petitions presented, as well as the information and the elimination of bureaucratic barriers for the presentation of the same and appeals to the European Commission to apply the precautionary principle in environmental matters. In addition, it refers to the scandalous legislation on mortgages and risk financial instruments in Spain, which have affected hundreds of thousands of families since the beginning of the crisis, affected by evictions, abusive clauses and the preferential scandal that was the subject of debate by the European Parliament in 2015. Unfortunately, the right wing, led by the European People's Party, managed to eliminate criticism of austerity policies in the plenary vote. However, positive aspects were maintained, such as the call for greater transparency and the implementation of participatory democracy mechanisms in the Union, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The right to petition the European Parliament is one of the rare institutional instruments of European citizenship. The European Parliament's Committee on Petitions collects citizens' initiatives, which constitutes a barometer for measuring their concerns. This annual report presents a complete and precise overview of the activities of the committee in 2015 and of the relations with other European, national and regional institutions. The statistics thus established show that the concerns of European citizens relate to the environment, the protection of animals, justice, the internal market, and even fundamental rights. The report is very critical of the role of the Commission, which citizens are asking in particular to better monitor compliance with the Treaties in these areas. A kind of proof of the advance of European society on its institutions concerning these questions. I voted in favor of this report presented by my Spanish colleague from GUE / NGL Angela Vallina.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - During 2015, 1431 petitions were received (47% less than in 2014), 943 were considered admissible, of which 424 had a quick analysis. The right to petition must be a fundamental instrument in the path of participatory democracy. PETI can do considerable work to explain and eventually prove the successes and benefits of the European project. In 2015 there was greater speed and efficiency in the handling of petitions. The main issues addressed are environmental legislation, violations of fundamental rights, application of justice (in particular, custody rights for minors), rights of the child, persons with disabilities and minorities, free movement of persons, discrimination, immigration, employment and animal welfare. Petitions can be a useful tool for involving citizens. However, its scope is limited and, in practice, this has been more of a democratic adornment than a real tool of popular mobilization. That is not where the EU's democratic deficit will be resolved.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. This report provided us with an overview of the PETI Committee's activities, simple statistics, but also highlighted the strengths of the petitions and pointed out the shortcomings. I have chosen to support the report mainly because the petition is a unique tool through which the citizens of the European Union can address their concerns and problems. I think that petitions help people to become more involved in public life and also reinforce the awareness that European authorities are interested in solving their problems addressed in petitions. I very much appreciate that the people of the European Union are actively addressing, in particular, the issues of environmental protection, consumer protection and justice. It is also a very positive change that the time taken to process a petition has been shortened, as well as that an internet portal has been set up through which petitions can be submitted and tracked electronically. Overall, I consider the annual report to be well drafted and comprehensible.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2015. The purpose of the 2015 Annual Report is to provide insight into the overall work of the Committee on Petitions. The report shall provide statistics on the number of petitions received, processed or concluded by the Committee, the States involved and the issues involved. The right of petition should strengthen the European Parliament's ability to act, helping to solve problems that are mostly related to the application of EU law. Petitions can assess the impact of EU legislation on the daily lives of European citizens, while strengthening the European Parliament's ability to act can help solve problems mainly related to the implementation of EU legislation, as petitions are a valuable source of information to identify shortcomings in the implementation of EU legislation. And. I support Parliament's request to the Commission for greater involvement in the Citizens of Europe Initiative so that the initiative can reach its full potential and function. The Committee on Petitions has the opportunity and challenge, following the recent events in the United Kingdom, to maintain a dialogue with citizens, as it has the potential to reunite EU institutions and citizens, putting citizens at the heart of the European project and pointing out the positive impact of EU policies.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  Mr President, further development of the aviation sector provides us with a renewed opportunity to boost Europe’s economy, strengthen our industrial base and reinforce our position of global leadership in this market. I would support this motion for a resolution as a means to harness the European aviation model, thus adapting and responding to the specific obstacles and demands of this sector. Greater regulation in the areas of efficiency, infrastructure and investment are, however, crucial if we are to realise the true potential of a consolidated European aviation strategy. I would like to conclude by thanking the Commission for its efforts to ensure that Norwegian Air can get a licence to fly from the United States to Cork and, hopefully, in due course, Shannon, in my country. It would reduce the price of flying transatlantic and give greater choice, and especially at regional airports it will be most welcome, so hopefully it will happen as soon as possible in Cork, in Shannon and maybe other airports as well.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- This motion reminds the Commission of the need to keep Parliament informed and involved in negotiations on international aviation agreements.While these agreements may be necessary to ensure minimum social, environmental and safety and consumer protection standards, they have been used more frequently in order to force down European standards through competition with third countries.Despite sharing the need for greater transparency and scrutiny, I did not want my vote to be interpreted in favor of this strategy, so I preferred to abstain.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on international aviation agreements. In the European Aviation Strategy, the Commission proposed to open negotiations on EU - level aviation security agreements with Japan and China and on EU - level air services agreements with China, Turkey and six GCC Member States, Armenia and ASEAN. The conclusion of international agreements falling within the scope of the ordinary legislative procedure requires the consent of Parliament. Similarly, when the Commission negotiates agreements between the Union and third countries or international organizations, Parliament must be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedure for negotiating international agreements. In order to be able to decide whether or not to give its consent at the end of the negotiations, Parliament must monitor the process from the outset. I am of the opinion that Parliament should be kept fully informed of the progress of the process at all stages of the negotiations from the outset and, if necessary, in confidence, and that this information should be provided to Parliament in such a way as to give it sufficient time to give its opinion. Parliament, for its part, must ensure that full confidentiality is maintained when it receives confidential information about ongoing negotiations.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - Negotiations for the future of European aviation, especially French aviation, are crucial. As a reminder, in the early 2000s, Air France alerted European and national authorities to the threat of unfair competition from Gulf carriers. It is essential to send a clear and very firm political message to the Commission so that it adopts a transparent approach vis-à-vis the EP and national authorities. It is legitimate to deplore this given its philosophy on competition and its disastrous record in terms of deregulation. I voted against the motion for a resolution of the Transport Committee which is content to ask that the Commission be transparent with Parliament and for the EFDD and ENL motions for resolutions which not only require full transparency from the Commission but also also to guarantee fair and equitable competition between air carriers through precise legal clauses.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as I do not believe the European Union should have the right to negotiate international aviation agreements on the UK’s behalf. These agreements should always be taken at a Member State level.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted for this proposal because I also believe that Parliament should be involved from the start of the procedures in the framework of the negotiations of international aviation agreements.It is therefore necessary for the Commission to send Parliament information on the launch of certain negotiations as well as the information necessary for the analysis of these agreements.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- This resolution has been negotiated between all the members of the TRAN Committee with two main objectives: to request a greater participation of the European Parliament in the negotiation of international agreements with third countries and to guarantee that the main criterion underlying any agreement is to guarantee compliance withEuropean safety standards in all its dimensions (material, technical, professional ...).We have participated in the drafting of the text as members of the Commission and I voted in favor because we fully share both priorities.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I supported this Resolution of the Committee on Transport and Tourism on international aviation agreements, the discussion of which took place at the November part-session.It highlights that, in order to be able to take a decision on whether or not to give its approval at the end of the negotiations, Parliament needs to follow the process from the beginning, and that it is in the interest of all the institutions to determine and address it soonerpossible those issues that are of sufficient importance and that call into question Parliament's willingness to give its approval.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The resolution being voted on is acceptable and seems to be well thought out.I believe there is a need for greater transparency on the part of the Commission regarding the negotiation procedures for amending and creating international air agreements and I believe that the European Parliament must be more involved in all these phases.For these reasons, I voted in favor of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - In March 2016, the Council authorized the European Commission to start negotiations on air security agreements with China and Japan, and on air services agreements with ASEAN, Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates on 7 June 2016. To this day, the Commission continues to deliberate on draft negotiating directives to open negotiations on the Union's air services agreements with China, Mexico, Armenia and the remaining four member states of the Council of Gulf Cooperation. These agreements open up the EU's airspace with some Gulf countries, which are competing unfairly by giving massive state aid to their airlines, buying European companies and operating on European flights with personnel from third countries under working conditions that do not respect the regulations. minimum European social standards. The resolution, which I supported, calls for greater participation by Parliament, standing on an equal footing with the Council, and information before and during negotiations of air agreements with third countries.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - - I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with international aviation agreements. In the European Aviation Strategy, the Commission proposed opening negotiations on aviation security agreements at EU level with Japan and China and on EU-level air services agreements with China, Turkey, six GCC member states, Armenia and the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN). The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations on aviation security agreements with Japan and China and on EU-level air services agreements with ASEAN, Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. The conclusion of international agreements falling within the scope of the ordinary legislative procedure requires the consent of Parliament. The European Parliament expects the Commission to inform Parliament's responsible committee of its intention to propose negotiations for the conclusion and amendment of international air agreements, and hopes that the Commission will reach agreements with the Council and its negotiating partners to grant Members of the European Parliament equal access to the Council. to all relevant documents, including negotiating directives and consolidated texts. Parliament acknowledges that it must ensure that full confidentiality is maintained when it receives confidential information about ongoing negotiations.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- In order to reach a joint agreement between the European Parliament and the European Commission, the Commission is required to share information on international aviation negotiations with the relevant EP committee, the Committee on Transport and Tourism.Within the framework of this, this motion for a resolution was prepared, which is also supported by the Hungarian People's Party Delegation.The motion emphasizes, among other things, that in order for Members to be able to decide at the end of the negotiations whether or not to give their consent, Parliament must follow the process from the outset.This is also in the interest of the other institutions, as it will allow them to identify and address at an early stage any concerns that, based on their weight, may call into question Parliament's willingness to give its consent.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on International Air Transport Agreements.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- This oral question from the Transport Committee, which demands more transparency in the negotiations vis-à-vis Parliament, is certainly going in the right direction, but is far from covering the whole subject.Indeed, the transfer of sovereignty from the Member States to the European Union in terms of negotiating traffic rights ipso facto entails a reversal of the balance of power with third countries: these obtain access to the whole of the world.huge European market, while they can only concede a few things in exchange, most of which have already been conceded.This type of negotiation therefore considerably weakens the positioning of European companies compared to companies from third countries.I therefore vote against this oral question.Conversely, I vote for the EFDD and ENL resolution.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this resolution because we feel that it grants more power and information to the European Parliament when international aviation agreements with third countries are being negotiated. We supported the fact that the motion for a resolution stresses that the EP has to have an access in order to fully follow the process of negotiation from the beginning and that all necessary (confidential) documents have to be given to the committee responsible. It is democratically correct that the Council and the Commission should be obliged to inform Parliament immediately and fully at all stages of the procedure. Therefore, we supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing.- In recent years, various operations involving the acquisition of shareholdings in European companies by companies from third countries have aroused discussions and provoked great emotion in public opinion.Furthermore, the Commission's forecasts have repeatedly proved too optimistic about the beneficial effects of the agreements in the aviation sector.It is therefore necessary to recall that, pursuant to Article 218 (10) TFEU, the Council and the Commission are required to immediately and fully inform Parliament at all stages of the negotiation procedures for new agreements in the sector and the Parliament is called upon to evaluatewith objectivity and freedom of conscience, whether or not the conclusion of such agreements is appropriate, in the exclusive interest of citizens of the European Union and international security.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The Commission has proposed, in the framework of the Aviation Strategy for Europe, to open negotiations on civil aviation security with Japan and China, and on EU air services agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, six Council Member States. Cooperation of the Gulf, Armenia and ASEAN. In this context, the Council has authorized the Commission to open negotiations on the above-mentioned agreements, but Parliament's approval is also required for the conclusion of international agreements in areas where the ordinary legislative procedure applies. According to the provisions in force, when the Commission negotiates agreements between the Union and third countries or international organizations, Parliament must be "immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedure". I fully support Parliament's involvement in such negotiations, which is why I am in favor of this resolution, which emphasizes the need and obligation to take Parliament's opinion into account in the context of such decisions, which are so important for the Member States.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the resolution in question which calls for greater involvement of Parliament in the negotiations the Commission is carrying out with Japan and China on air safety agreements and with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations(ASEAN), Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates on EU-wide agreements on air services.The report requires Parliament to be made aware from the very beginning of the negotiation process so that it can decide whether or not to grant approval.Indeed, it is also in the interest of the other institutions to identify and address early on any matter of sufficient importance to cast doubt on Parliament's readiness to grant approval.The further requirement is that the information be provided complete and detailed, i.e. in a way that allows him to express his opinion.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this oral question, which urges the Commission to include and inform Parliament when negotiating international aviation agreements with third countries. The Council has authorised the Commission to start negotiations on aviation safety agreements with China and Japan on 8 March 2016 and on EU-level air services agreements with ASEAN, Turkey, Qatar and United Arab Emirates on 7 June 2016. Furthermore, the Council is deliberating draft negotiating directives for opening negotiations on EU-level air service agreements with China, Mexico, Armenia, and the remaining four Member States of the Gulf Cooperation Council. The resolution stresses that EP should have an access to fully follow the process of negotiation from the beginning and all necessary (confidential) documents have to be given to the Committee responsible, thereby giving maximum transparency. There were some good amendments, including respect for sovereignty at national level and raising concerns related to opening the sky to third-party companies experiencing rapid growth at a time when many European companies are facing serious economic and financial difficulties. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- As part of the European Aviation Strategy, the European Commission has proposed to open negotiations on civil aviation security with Japan and China and on EU-wide air services with China, Turkey,Mexico, six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Armenia and ASEAN.I remember that Parliament's approval is required for the conclusion of international agreements.The criteria by which Parliament evaluates the agreements submitted to it for approval include full and mutual recognition of certification practices and procedures, the exchange of safety data, joint inspections, increased regulatory cooperation and consultations at a technical level to resolve theproblems before activating the dispute settlement mechanism.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We are voting against the proposals as we disagree on many points.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- The report is characterized by the call for Parliament to be more involved in the process of establishing international agreements in the aviation sector.The European Commission is therefore urged to implement shared and transparent paths on the issues in question.Positive vote.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions on the international aviation agreements.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Commission proposed in its strategy for Europe to open negotiations on civil aviation security with a number of countries. However, in concluding international agreements in areas to which the ordinary legislative procedure applies, Parliament's approval is necessary and, according to the Framework Agreement on relations between Parliament and the Commission, it must be immediately and fully informed in all stages of the process. I support this resolution, which emphasizes that the Framework Agreement stipulates, in particular, that Parliament should be provided from the beginning on a regular basis and, if necessary, on a confidential basis, all the detailed information relating to the ongoing process in the stages of the negotiations and expects the Commission to provide the parliamentary transport committee with information on the intention to propose negotiations with a view to concluding and amending international air transport agreements, access to all relevant documents, including negotiating directives and consolidated texts, in parallel and on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the provision as I agree with the need for an aeronautical strategy for Europe which strengthens its industrial base and the position of world leader in the air transport sector.Multimodality must be encouraged.Given the need for ever greater efficiency of existing infrastructures, as well as the rationalization of investments, it is clear that the benefits of the complementarity of all modes of transport are currently underused.I also share the need to continue improvements in the field of safety and respect for the environment.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- This motion reminds the Commission of the need to keep Parliament informed and involved in negotiations on international aviation agreements.While these agreements may be necessary to ensure minimum social, environmental and safety and consumer protection standards, they have been used more frequently in order to force down European standards through competition with third countries.Despite sharing the need for greater transparency and scrutiny, I did not want my vote to be interpreted in favor of this strategy, so I preferred to abstain.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - Numerous critical aspects are taken into consideration in this resolution. The first relates to the real risk that certain negotiations lead to unbalanced agreements unfavorable to European air carriers, in particular regarding distortions of competition originating from state aid for the benefit of certain third-party airlines. Secondly, the safety, security and quality of the services offered to passengers were considered as key elements to guide negotiations in these areas. Thirdly, it is important to talk about citizens' trust in European and national institutions, which should be in charge of defending the interests of the latter, a trust that is undermined by the secrecy with which the Commission wraps up the negotiations, as is also the case for those in act in the context of CETA, TTIP and TiSA. For these reasons, I believe that this text manages to address some of the key problems regarding international agreements in the aviation sector and therefore I am voting in favor.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- Recognizing the legitimacy of the proposed solutions, I supported the motion for a resolution on international agreements in the field of aviation.The growing importance of aviation safety agreements with Japan and China and air service agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, six Gulf Cooperation Council members, Armenia and ASEAN require negotiating directives before negotiations can begin.I find that the role of the European Parliament and its commitment motivate it to be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the negotiations.Parliament should receive regular and, where necessary, confidentiality, full information on an ongoing procedure at all stages of the negotiations from the outset of the procedure.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which asks for the involvement and consent of the European Parliament in negotiations on international agreements. However, it must also be noted that I am concerned about the Commission desire to open up Europe’s skies even further to hugely successful third-country airlines at a time when many European airlines are facing serious financial problems.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I believe that the European Commission must provide Parliament's competent committee with the necessary information on the intention to propose negotiations with a view to concluding and amending international aviation agreements.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- For an international aviation agreement to enter into force it must necessarily be approved by the European Parliament.It is imperative that MEPs be able to follow each stage of the negotiations because good coordination between the institutions reduces the time taken for the approval of international agreements.While several negotiations will open for the conclusion of international aviation agreements, in particular with China, Japan and Mexico, I voted in favor of this resolution to remind the Commission of the roleof the European Parliament in approving this type of agreement and ensuring effective negotiations.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing.- In order to reach a joint agreement between the European Parliament and the European Commission, the Commission is required to share information on international aviation negotiations with the relevant EP committee, the Committee on Transport and Tourism.Within the framework of this, this motion for a resolution was prepared, which is also supported by the Hungarian People's Party Delegation.The motion emphasizes, among other things, that in order for Members to be able to decide at the end of the negotiations whether or not to give their consent, Parliament must follow the process from the outset.This is also in the interest of the other institutions, as they will be able to identify and address at an early stage any concerns that, based on their weight, may call into question Parliament's willingness to give its consent.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - I voted against the motion for a resolution from the TRAN committee. In December 2015, the Commission presented an Aviation Strategy for Europe, involving, inter alia: - the opening of security agreements with Japan and China; - the opening of air service agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, the six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Armenia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. These agreements aim to replace the existing bilateral agreements with a single European agreement, allowing European carriers to face competition from emerging countries, particularly the Gulf. However, the Commission is uncertain about the conditions of these negotiations. In addition, precedents in this area have not been beneficial for the European Union, in particular, as regards the United States (2007), with regard to reciprocity (equity investments with voting rights in American companies by 25% maximum, against 49.9% in Europe, ban on cabotage, etc.). The ENF group, for its part, demanded more transparency in these negotiations.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - Air transport is one of the safest modes of transport, despite public opinion. However, there is much to be desired in the field of aviation safety. I welcome the start of civil aviation safety negotiations with Japan and China, as well as the agreement with China, Turkey, Mexico and six Gulf states, as well as with Armenia and ASEAN countries. Of course, we, as representatives of our countries in the EU, must be aware at all times of the conduct of these negotiations and the progress made between the negotiating parties. But care must be taken here, because the information received can be sensitive and thus sharing information can lead to the disclosure of confidential information.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on aviation agreements because it calls on the Commission to better inform and involve the European Parliament regarding its negotiations on aviation with some non-EU states. I made a commitment to my constituents in Wales that I would always work for more transparency.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The Commission proposed, in the Aviation Strategy for Europe, to open negotiations on civil aviation security with Japan and China and, at EU level, air service agreements with China, Turkey, theMexico, the six states of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Armenia and ASEAN.However, in order to be able to take its decision on the approval of the document at the end of the negotiations, Parliament has to monitor the process from the beginning because it is also in the interest of the other institutions that any reservations sufficiently important to call into question the availability of theParliament to approve the agreement are identified and addressed at an early stage.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote in favor of the EFDD and ENL motions for resolutions which not only demand full transparency from the Commission but also guarantee fair and equitable competition between air carriers through precise legal clauses.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - As part of the December 2015 “Aviation Strategy for Europe”, the European Commission opened negotiations for aviation agreements with several countries, mostly Asian. This report supports the Strategy, which we are strongly opposed to. In summary, its objective: "Increase exploitation, degrade sovereignty, promote capitalist concentration". In its various chapters - Strategy for the Air Sector, for Air Navigation, for Airports, for Ground Assistance - we find different ways to serve the interests of European multinationals in the sector; reduce operational safety standards; accentuate the security drives; subordinate work to capital. The Strategy could be said to develop in two stages: 1) to create the conditions for monopoly concentration on a European scale, thereby giving “muscle” to the large European groups in the sector; 2) creating conditions at the international level for European multinationals to colonize new markets worldwide. Goals that we repudiate across the board. The report does not hide the angry tone that liberalization does not proceed at the speed that some want. The insistence on multimodal issues and the need to standardize passengers' rights so that they are possible, gives the idea of ​​wanting to evolve to deregulation from above. We voted against.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the international air transport agreements, as the conclusion of these agreements will bring about adverse changes in both the status of safety standards and the current regime of conditions in case of potential investment in a European air carrier (reduction of the principle that 49% of its ownership must be owned by Europeans, etc.). At a time when European airlines are facing a host of financial problems, with the risk of layoffs being visible, it is at least unfortunate that the possibility of Muslim (mainly) countries entering the European aviation market on extremely favorable terms is being discussed.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The single EU aviation market has been developed through dramatic changes in the economic and regulatory landscape of air transport in Europe to the benefit of consumers and business. The creation of the single EU aviation market has also had implications for the EU's external aviation relations, leading to the development of the EU's external aviation policy. Closer international relations will not only provide access to new markets, but also allow the EU to ensure high standards of safety and security in international air transport as well as to work with others more effectively to address the impact of aviation on the environment and to safeguard fair competition in an increasingly globalised and liberalised aviation market.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing.- In order to reach a joint agreement between the European Parliament and the European Commission, the Commission is required to share information on international aviation negotiations with the relevant EP committee, the Committee on Transport and Tourism.Within the framework of this, this motion for a resolution was prepared, which is also supported by the Hungarian People's Party Delegation.The motion emphasizes, among other things, that in order for Members to be able to decide at the end of the negotiations whether or not to give their consent, Parliament must follow the process from the outset.This is also in the interest of the other institutions, as they will be able to identify and address at an early stage any concerns that, based on their weight, may call into question Parliament's willingness to give its consent.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as the Framework Agreement states that the European Parliament should receive regular and full details of all procedures during the negotiations of international aviation agreements – if necessary this should be done on a confidential basis. Given this, the Commission should provide the Parliament’s committee responsible information about its intention on negotiations to conclude and amend international air agreements. I support the resolution in expecting the Commission to reach an arrangement with the Council and with the negotiating partners so that Members of the European Parliament can have access to all the relevant documents. With these documents, the negotiating directives and consolidated texts should be included so that the European Parliament is on an equal footing with the Council. Parliamentary scrutiny of these agreements from the directly elected representatives of the people of Europe is crucial for the democratic legitimacy of these negotiations and agreements and this deficit in representation needs to be addressed.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- Different legal frameworks and bilateral air transport agreements limit international competitiveness.Competition is also often distorted by unfair subsidies or practices.Negotiations on aviation safety agreements with Japan and China as well as negotiations on aviation agreements at EU level with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates are intended to improve this situation.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- This resolution has been negotiated between all the members of the TRAN Committee with two main objectives: to request a greater participation of the European Parliament in the negotiation of international agreements with third countries and to guarantee that the main criterion underlying any agreement is to guarantee compliance withEuropean safety standards in all its dimensions (material, technical, professional ...).We have participated in the drafting of the text as members of the Commission and I voted in favor because we fully share both priorities.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution.It will promote the adoption of our standards in the aviation sector in order to best ensure the safety of European passengers and finally establish fair competition with third countries.This resolution rightly provides for technical and scientific collaboration between the EU and the other parties to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from various aircraft, whose share in global warming continues to grow.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing.- By common agreement between the European Parliament and the European Commission, the Commission is required to share information on international aviation negotiations with the relevant EP committee, the Committee on Transport and Tourism.Within the framework of this, this motion for a resolution was prepared, which is also supported by the Hungarian People's Party Delegation.The motion emphasizes, among other things, that in order for Members to be able to decide at the end of the negotiations whether or not to give their consent, Parliament must follow the process from the outset.This is also in the interest of the other institutions, as it will allow them to identify and address at an early stage any concerns that, based on their weight, may call into question Parliament's willingness to give its consent.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Motion for a resolution on international air transport agreements because I believe that the European Parliament should give its consent or criticize the conclusion or amendment of international agreements in areas subject to the ordinary legislative procedure.Whereas the Commission has proposed, in the context of an aviation strategy for Europe, the opening of negotiations on civil aviation safety with Japan and China, and on air services agreements with China, Mexico, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and ASEAN Member States.I consider it important that the European Parliament be fully informed of the further steps in the negotiations on the above-mentioned topic of international air transport agreements.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- In a context of tough competition between our aviation industry and the companies and hubs in the Gulf and Turkey, it is essential to fully understand the challenges of this agreement and to ensure its reciprocal application by the other parties.The Commission maintains the vagueness on the non-negotiable points guaranteeing fair and equitable competition, and I believe it is essential to be firm in tackling with it the basic themes inherent in these "open skies" agreements by not content with callingsimple transparency on his part with Parliament.I voted against.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: written.- It goes without saying that the SP believes that any future international aviation treaties should never have the effect of reducing the working conditions or conditions of personnel working in the aviation sector.However, we do not want to anticipate that content of the treaties now.That is why we abstained on Amendments 4 and 6.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which asks the Commission for the full involvement and full information of the European Parliament in any international aviation agreement.It is indeed important that our institution, representing the peoples, can be kept informed in real time of all the information relating to the negotiations in this major area.It is important to recall this when the Commission proposed in its aviation strategy for Europe to open, for example, negotiations on civil aviation safety with Japan and China or even agreementson air services at Union level with Turkey, China, etc.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- This resolution deals with the opening of European airspace to airlines from third countries.The original text of the Transport Committee sharply criticizes the Commission and the Council for a non-transparent approach in the area of negotiating flight agreements with third countries.I therefore agreed to this decision.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing.- In order to reach a joint agreement between the European Parliament and the European Commission, the Commission is required to share information on international aviation negotiations with the relevant EP committee, the Committee on Transport and Tourism.Within the framework of this, this motion for a resolution was prepared, which is also supported by the Hungarian People's Party Delegation.The motion emphasizes, among other things, that in order for Members to be able to decide at the end of the negotiations whether or not to give their consent, Parliament must follow the process from the outset.This is also in the interest of the other institutions, as they will be able to identify and address at an early stage any concerns that, based on their weight, may call into question Parliament's willingness to give its consent.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission adopted an Aviation Strategy for Europe in December 2015. The aim of this resolution is to open negotiations on EU-level aviation safety agreements with Japan and China and air services agreements with the following countries: China, Turkey, Mexico, six Member States of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Armenia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). I voted in favour of this resolution in order to include the European Parliament in the process of negotiation.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it is content to ask the Commission to be transparent with Parliament without ever addressing the basic problems caused by the "open skies" agreements (reciprocity, investments, rules for controlling companies,working conditions, traffic rights, clauses guaranteeing fair and equitable competition, etc.).

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- This Resolution reminds the Commission of the need to keep Parliament informed and involved in the negotiations on international aviation agreements.While these agreements may be necessary to ensure minimum social, environmental and consumer safety and protection standards, they have been used more frequently to force down European standards through competition with third countries.Despite sharing the need for greater transparency and control, I did not want my vote to be interpreted in favor of this strategy, so I preferred to abstain.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The Council authorized the European Commission to propose, as part of the aviation strategy for Europe, the start of negotiations on civil aviation safety with Japan and China and the start of negotiations on air service agreements with Mexico, Turkey and China, six member states of the Cooperation Council.The Persian Gulf, Armenia and the ASEAN member states.The European Commission is obliged to provide the competent committee of the European Parliament with information on its intention to propose negotiations for the conclusion and amendment of international air transport agreements.As the agreement should ensure that the powers and responsibilities of the institutions are exercised as efficiently and transparently as possible, I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposed, in the Aviation Strategy for Europe, to open negotiations on civil aviation safety with Japan and China, and on EU-level air services agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Armenia, and ASEAN.
