Parliament stressed that it needs to follow the process from the beginning and considered that it is also in the interests of the other institutions [that any concerns of sufficient importance] to call into question Parliament’s readiness to grant consent be identified and addressed at an early stage.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the motion for a resolution on international air transport agreements, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/23/2016, and because this motion for a resolution is incomplete and well-founded.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.The motion for a resolution, submitted to the vote of the European Parliament by the Transport and Tourism Committee, aims to increase the level of transparency of the actions of the European Commission in the field of international aviation agreements.We support this principle, but we cannot accept that the rapporteurs limit themselves to this request.Indeed, they ignore the danger of unfair competition from air carriers from Gulf countries.We proposed an alternative resolution, finding it insufficient.The motion for a resolution tabled by our parliamentary group emphasized the need to ensure fair and equitable competition between air carriers through precise legal clauses.It was, unfortunately, rejected by Parliament.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- After the Commission and the Council have been severely condemned and criticized for their intransparent approach in the area of negotiating flight agreements with third countries, I supported this motion.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament resolution on international aviation agreements. In the European Aviation Strategy, the Commission proposed to open negotiations on EU - level aviation security agreements with Japan and China and on EU - level air services agreements with China, Turkey and six GCC Member States, Armenia and ASEAN. The conclusion of international agreements falling within the scope of the ordinary legislative procedure requires the consent of Parliament. Similarly, when the Commission negotiates agreements between the Union and third countries or international organizations, Parliament must be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedure for negotiating international agreements. In order to be able to decide whether or not to give its consent at the end of the negotiations, Parliament must monitor the process from the outset. I am of the opinion that Parliament should be kept fully informed of the progress of the process at all stages of the negotiations from the outset and, if necessary, in confidence, and that this information should be provided to Parliament in such a way as to give it sufficient time to give its opinion. Parliament, for its part, must ensure that full confidentiality is maintained when it receives confidential information about ongoing negotiations.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This is a motion for a resolution from the TRAN committee on international aviation agreements with in particular the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Turkey, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates andArmenia.The purpose of this resolution is simply to ask for a clarification of the objectives and issues of the negotiations that have started since, as with CETA, TAFTA or TiSA, the Commission remains very discreet on this subject.So I voted against the first resolution of the TRAN committee as it just asks for clarification.I voted in favor of the EFDD and ENL resolution, which in addition to asking for more transparency from the Commission, also calls for the guarantee of fair and equitable competition in the aviation sector through precise legal clauses.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: written.- It goes without saying that the SP believes that any future international aviation treaties should never have the effect of reducing the working conditions or conditions of personnel working in the aviation sector.However, we do not want to anticipate that content of the treaties now.That is why we abstained on Amendments 4 and 6.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the amendments tabled by the ENF which deal with international air agreements on the ‘Motion for a resolution on international aviation agreements’. The reason behind this relates to the very difficult situation Air Malta, Malta’s national airline, is currently going through

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - Since December 2015, the Commission has undertaken to modify the rules concerning international air agreements. Despite the fact that the Chicago Convention enshrined the sovereignty of states over their airspace, the Commission is trying to obtain new negotiating mandates to simplify line openings and develop air links by replacing existing bilateral treaties with an agreement unique on a European scale The objective of the oral question being voted on was therefore to remind the Commission of the serious problems encountered by European airlines in maintaining their share in the long-haul market, in particular due to unfair competition from the countries of the Gulf. Parliament also criticized the total opacity of negotiations between the Commission and the countries with which new agreements should be signed, such as CETA, TISA and TAFTA. However, this oral question has been emptied of its content by the EPP and ECR, and only asks for more transparency from the European Commission. We will therefore vote against.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing. - The oral question was welcome given the crucial stakes involved in these negotiations for the future of European aviation, in particular France. As a reminder, in the early 2000s, Air France alerted European and national authorities to the threat of unfair competition from Gulf carriers. It is essential to send a clear and very strong political message to the Commission so that it adopts a transparent approach vis-à-vis the European Parliament and national authorities. It is legitimate to deplore this, given its philosophy on competition and its disastrous record in terms of deregulation. I am therefore voting against the motion for a resolution of the TRAN committee which is content to ask that the Commission be transparent with the Parliament and I vote for the motions for resolutions EFDD and ENL, which not only require full transparency from the Commission. , but also ask it to guarantee fair and equitable competition between air carriers through precise legal clauses.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on international aviation agreements.The text reminds the European Commission that it must involve the European Parliament from the start of the procedure for negotiating aviation agreements with third countries so that MEPs can freely decide whether or not to approve them.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution regarding international aviation agreements proposed in the Aviation Strategy for Europe which is an initiative to generate growth for European business, foster innovation and let passenger profit from safer, cleaner and cheaper flight while offering more connections.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out in favor of the resolution before us because the text strongly criticizes the Council's intransparent approach to negotiations.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.As part of the European Aviation Strategy, the European Commission can start negotiations on civil aviation safety with Japan and China and on EU-level aviation agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, the six GCC Member States, Armenia and ASEAN.The consent of the European Parliament is required for the opening of negotiations.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - In December 2015, the Commission adopted an air transport strategy for Europe. As part of the air transport strategy, it is proposed to open negotiations on signing an EU-level agreement on air safety with Japan and China, as well as agreements on air services with the following countries: China, Turkey, Mexico, six member states of the Cooperation Council. in the Gulf, Armenia and the Commonwealth of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). In the very introduction to the strategy, it was emphasized that aviation is a strong driver of economic growth, job creation, trade and mobility in the European Union. The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations on air safety agreements signed with China and Japan on 8 March 2016, and on 7 June 2016 to negotiate agreements at EU level on air services signed with ASEAN Member States. and, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. The Council is still discussing draft negotiating directives for opening negotiations on EU-level air services agreements signed with China, Mexico, Armenia and the remaining four Gulf Cooperation Council member states. As Parliament must follow the negotiation process from the outset, I support this European Parliament Resolution on international air transport agreements.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - As part of the December 2015 “Aviation Strategy for Europe”, the European Commission opened negotiations for aviation agreements with several countries, mostly Asian. This report supports the Strategy, which we are strongly opposed to. In summary, its objective: "Increase exploitation, degrade sovereignty, promote capitalist concentration". In its various chapters - Strategy for the Air Sector, for Air Navigation, for Airports, for Ground Assistance - we find different ways to serve the interests of European multinationals in the sector; reduce operational safety standards; accentuate the security drives; subordinate work to capital. The Strategy could be said to develop in two stages: 1) to create the conditions for monopoly concentration on a European scale, thereby giving “muscle” to the large European groups in the sector; 2) creating conditions at the international level for European multinationals to colonize new markets worldwide. Goals that we repudiate across the board. The report does not hide the angry tone that liberalization does not proceed at the speed that some want. The insistence on multimodal issues and the need to standardize passengers' rights so that they are possible, gives the idea of ​​wanting to evolve to deregulation from above. We voted against.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it reminds us that Parliament must absolutely be kept informed of all the progress of negotiations on aviation agreements.I say this as rapporteur for Parliament on the agreement currently being negotiated on aviation safety between the European Union and Japan.These agreements, the mandates of which were distributed by the Board little by little from the launch of the aviation strategy in December 2015, are for the most part of capital importance for our economy and especially for our companies and our aeronautical manufacturers.At the conclusion of the agreements, we will have the last word to validate or invalidate the final agreement.We must therefore now know where the negotiations are going so that we can reorient the discussions, if necessary.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - In March 2016, the Council authorized the European Commission to start negotiations on air security agreements with China and Japan, and on air services agreements with ASEAN, Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates on June 7 2016. To this day, the Commission continues to deliberate on the draft negotiating directives to open negotiations on the Union's air services agreements with China, Mexico, Armenia and the remaining four Member States of the Cooperation Council from the Gulf. These agreements open up the Union's airspace with some Gulf countries, which are competing unfairly by giving massive state aid to their airlines, buying European companies and operating on European flights with personnel from third countries under working conditions that they do not respect. the minimum European social standards. The resolution, which I have supported, calls for greater involvement of Parliament, standing on an equal footing with the Council, and information before and during the negotiations of air agreements with third countries.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- The European Commission having proposed, in its aviation strategy for Europe, to open negotiations on civil aviation security with Japan and China, and on air services agreements at the level ofUnion with China, Turkey, Mexico, six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Armenia, and ASEAN and because parliamentary approval is required for the conclusion of international agreements underareas for which the ordinary legislative procedure is applied, I supported this report which expects the European executive to inform the competent committee of the Parliament of the intention to propose the launch of negotiations with a view to the conclusion andmodification of international air agreements.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I approved the report on an air transport strategy for Europe.An air transport strategy for Europe aims to address the existing challenges for the air transport sector.The report highlights various ways in which the European economy can be strengthened and its position as a global leader in the aviation sector.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- This motion reminds the Commission of the need to keep Parliament informed and involved in negotiations on international aviation agreements.While these agreements may be necessary to ensure minimum social, environmental and safety and consumer protection standards, they have been used more frequently in order to force down European standards through competition with third countries.Despite sharing the need for greater transparency and scrutiny, I did not want my vote to be interpreted in favor of this strategy, so I preferred to abstain.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as the EU should not be involved in the sovereign airspace of the UK.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and success.actions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - In the Aviation Strategy for Europe, the Commission proposed to open negotiations on civil aviation safety with Japan and China and on EU-level air services agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, six Gulf Cooperation Council member states, Armenia and ASEAN. Parliament's consent is required for the conclusion of international agreements relating to areas covered by the ordinary legislative procedure. Therefore, Parliament will monitor this process from the outset in order to be able to decide whether to give its consent after the negotiations. Given that negotiations are taking place in the field of air transport, which is extremely important for the institutions in the field of air transport, but also for EU citizens, any doubts need to be announced in good time. We therefore expect the Commission to provide the committee responsible with information in advance and in such a way as to ensure confidentiality, as this may be sensitive information in the ongoing negotiations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's resolution on international aviation agreements emphasizes that, if Parliament is to take a decision on the approval of international aviation agreements at the end of the negotiations, it must monitor the whole process of negotiating and negotiating agreements from the outset. The framework agreement specifically stipulates that the European Parliament must be kept informed, from the outset, on a regular and, where necessary, confidential basis, of all details of the ongoing procedure at all stages of the negotiations. The resolution also points out that Parliament expects the Commission to provide information to Parliament's competent committee that it intends to propose the opening of negotiations on the conclusion and amendment of international air transport agreements in order to regulate the access of Members of the European Parliament with the Council and negotiating partners. to all relevant documents, including negotiating directives and consolidated texts, simultaneously and on an equal footing with the Council. All these provisions of the resolution are very important, as the Commission is currently negotiating twenty such agreements in a very non-transparent way, so this resolution is very important as it calls for greater involvement of Parliament in the procedures and better access to information. All this is a precondition for greater transparency, which is why I supported the resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The European Commission must inform the European Parliament in good time, comprehensively and truthfully of the negotiations it is conducting on behalf of the European Union in the field of air transport agreements.The area of aviation safety is a sensitive issue and the European Parliament must have sufficient evidence in good time before giving its consent to the relevant agreements.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - The purpose of the Report is to present a new aviation strategy for Europe. Aviation is a strong driver of economic growth, jobs, trade and mobility for the European Union and plays a key role in the European Union's economy. The sector directly employs between 1.4 million and 2 million people and contributes € 110 billion to the European Union's economy. Over the last 20 years, the liberalization of the internal market for air services and the significant growth in demand for air transport within the EU and the world have resulted in the significant development of the European aviation sector. The aim of this Aviation Strategy Report is to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the entire EU air transport network. Also, in order to support world trade in aircraft and related products, the EU needs to expand the range of bilateral air safety agreements in order to achieve mutual recognition of safety certification standards. I support this Report because I believe that the adoption of an ambitious foreign policy in aviation can contribute to improving market access and improving investment opportunities for European aviation in important foreign markets.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on rapporteur's international aviation agreements on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism.I support a greater role for Parliament in the process of adopting the various agreements, especially in the light of the various concerns and proposals that may arise at an early stage and are also important for the final approval of the agreements.Therefore, the Resolution of the Committee on Transport and Tourism rightly recalls that the Framework Agreement specifically stipulates that the European Parliament must be kept regularly and, where necessary, confidentially informed from the outset of all details of the ongoing process at all stages of the negotiations.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of the resolution because it emphasizes to the Commission that it should be accountable to Parliament for air transport agreements with the third countries concerned.We will take a stand on the text and the agreement when we have them in front of us.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution seeks to conclude aviation security agreements with Japan and China, and air service agreements at EU level with ASEAN, Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. Unfortunately, the conclusion of these agreements will lead to adverse changes to both the status of safety standards and the status quo in the event of a potential investment in a European carrier (a decline in the principle that 49% of carrier ownership must belong to .τ.λ.). At a time when European airlines are facing a host of financial problems, with the risk of layoffs being visible, it is at least unfortunate that the possibility of Muslim (mainly) countries entering the European aviation market on extremely favorable terms is being discussed.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing.- In order to reach a joint agreement between the European Parliament and the European Commission, the Commission is required to share information on international aviation negotiations with the relevant EP committee, the Committee on Transport and Tourism.Within the framework of this, this motion for a resolution was prepared, which is also supported by the Hungarian People's Party Delegation.The motion emphasizes, among other things, that in order for Members to be able to decide at the end of the negotiations whether or not to give their consent, Parliament must follow the process from the outset.This is also in the interest of the other institutions, as it will allow them to identify and address at an early stage any concerns that, based on their weight, may call into question Parliament's willingness to give its consent.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on international aviation agreements. In line with the proposals in the European Aviation Strategy, the Commission has been mandated by the Council to open negotiations on aviation safety agreements with Japan and China and to open negotiations on aviation agreements at EU level with ASEAN, Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. . I agree with the motion for a resolution that the European Parliament must follow the process from the outset. All the more so as you have to decide at the end of the negotiations whether to give your consent or not. It is pertinent to note that it is also in the interest of the other institutions to identify and address at an early stage any concerns that may call into question Parliament's willingness to give its consent. I also support the call for the Commission to allow Members of the European Parliament to have access to all relevant documents, including negotiating directives and consolidated texts, in parallel and on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ In the past 30 years the European Union has created the world’s largest and most successful single aviation market, which developed through dramatic changes in the economic and regulatory landscape. However, today the European Union is not only focusing on the internal aviation market, but also on a harmonised external aviation policy, that would benefit the EU economy and its citizens. I salute this report, although I would like to stress that these agreements should not only focus on economic gains, but also on air safety standards for crew and passengers, and the rights of employees.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution, the result of a relevant question in the Commission.In order to be able to determine whether it will grant its approval or refuse to give it after negotiations are concluded, Parliament must follow the procedure from the start.It is also in the interest of the other institutions to identify and resolve as soon as possible any problem which might dissuade Parliament from expressing its approval from the outset.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the text of the resolution on international aviation agreements. In December 2015, the European Commission detailed its intention to negotiate new air and safety agreements with some of the strategic partners of the EU. In line with the Lisbon Treaty and the increased role of the European Parliament, I find it of particular importance that the European Parliament be fully informed at all stages of the negotiations. I believe it will contribute to the success of the negotiations and broad acceptance by the citizens. I respect that the Commission leads the negotiations on behalf of the European Union and therefore agree that, for the sake of good negotiations, some elements may be sensitive, but I trust that the Parliamentarians and the staff involved will guarantee the confidential nature of such information wherever necessary.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. - The current aviation situation has seen several European and American airlines report distortions of competition originating from state aid to their respective public authorities to the benefit of certain third country airlines. If we keep in mind that, in recent years, various recruitments in European companies and in companies from third countries have sparked heated debates in public opinion, Parliament asks the Commission to protect, primarily, EU workers and passengers, by carefully evaluating the 'hypothesis of opening the European sky more to non-European companies. The situation appears even more dramatic if we consider that some of these companies are experiencing an expansion of some importance while many European companies are facing considerable financial difficulties. We therefore ask that the current regulatory situation be addressed, considering that the challenges associated with the agreements affect the safety, security and quality of the services offered to passengers and affect the future of European airlines and the aviation industry. Finally, the outcome of the negotiations must not include a downward renegotiation of the rules, with inevitable negative consequences both in terms of safety and in terms of the working conditions of employees in the sector.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the “Motion for a Resolution on International Air Transport Agreements (B8-1337 / 2016)” with regard to the 2015 European Parliament Aviation Resolution.Cooperation on civil aviation safety and air services at EU level can have positive consequences for EU citizens, but also for crew members and the aviation industry in general.Parliament should continue to be informed of procedures relating to the Union's agreements with third countries and should be allowed to veto situations where preference is given to airlines centered in non-EU countries, while European ones face financial difficulties.difficulties.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I support and hold useful air transport agreements - air safety agreements with China and Japan, and air service agreements with ASEAN countries, Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates are currently being negotiated.I believe that the care and protection of air safety is an extremely important segment, and just an ideal example of the added value that the Union can provide to its citizens.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's resolution on international aviation agreements.In its aviation strategy for Europe, the Commission proposed launching negotiations on civil aviation safety with Japan and China and on EU-level air transport agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, the six Gulf Cooperation Council member states, Armenia and ASEAN (South EastAsian nations).If Parliament is to take a decision at the end of the negotiations, it must monitor the process from the outset.From the outset, the European Parliament must be kept regularly and, where necessary, confidentially informed of all details of the ongoing process at all stages of the negotiations.However, Parliament guarantees the complete confidentiality of the information obtained.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome and support the Commission’s mandate to negotiate the future comprehensive aviation agreements and include a strong and clear fair competition clause to make sure airlines can compete on a level playing field and without unacceptable State aid and subsidies. I always insisted and will continue to insist with the Commission with the following questions: 1. Can the Commission clarify whether there is a link between accepting the fair competition clause and financial transparency elements in the future comprehensive aviation agreements, and continuing to operate in EU airspace with a licence granted by EU air carriers that third parties invested in? 2. If a Gulf carrier refuses to cooperate or to provide any information about public subsidies or financial support, what are the tools that the Commission can use with regard to traffic rights and other European airlines that operate in Europe? 3. Does not the Commission believe that in order to be consistent, there should be a clear link between safeguarding ‘fair competition’, accepting the fair competition clause provisions and checking the origins of money used in EU carriers’ investments ?

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.‒This resolution has been negotiated between all the members of the TRAN Committee with two main objectives: to request greater participation by the European Parliament in the negotiation of international agreements with third countries and to guarantee that the main criterion underlying any agreement is to guarantee compliance withEuropean safety standards in all its dimensions (material, technical, professional ...).We have participated in the drafting of the text as members of the Commission and I voted in favor because we fully share both priorities.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because it stresses that in order to be able to take its decision on whether or not to grant consent at the end of the negotiations, the Parliament needs to follow the process from the beginning.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I emphasize that, in order to be able to decide whether or not to give its consent at the end of the negotiations, Parliament must monitor the process from the outset.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - This motion for a resolution assesses a broad initiative - covering legislative measures, international agreements and other instruments - aimed at developing an aviation strategy for Europe. Starting from the recognition that the sector is essential for the European economy –and, therefore, considering it vital that it continues to be competitive and sustainable–, the text identifies three areas of action. These include the need to develop an ambitious foreign aviation policy, which guarantees fair competition for European companies and entry into growth markets, or the importance of maintaining high levels of aviation security. It supports these challenges to be faced by maintaining a strong social agenda and creating quality jobs in the sector, as well as protecting the rights of users, ensuring continuity in innovation and the development of digital technologies or helping to achieve the goals set in this matter of climate change and the energy market. With the aim of further strengthening the competitiveness of the aviation sector in the European Union, I have decided to vote in favor of this proposal.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- This motion reminds the Commission of the need to keep Parliament informed and involved in negotiations on international aviation agreements.While these agreements may be necessary to ensure minimum social, environmental and safety and consumer protection standards, they have been used more frequently in order to force down European standards through competition with third countries.Despite sharing the need for greater transparency and scrutiny, I did not want my vote to be interpreted in favor of this strategy, so I preferred to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The draft report on an Aviation Strategy for Europe supports the document made public by the Commission a year ago, which at the time received severe criticism from broad sectors of society.Basically, this is the same fundamental objective of promoting a single market for civil aviation, promoting concentration, reducing operational safety standards, enhancing security drives and data control.This idea of a “Trans-European Sky Highway” as a buzzword destined to achieve the full realization of the Single Sky cannot disguise this reality.Furthermore, we regret the fact that liberalization is not accelerating as some want.The reference to the advantages of complementarity of means of transport contrasts with the alleged advantages of introducing a liberal offensive that will only contribute to the degradation of the service and the enrichment of them as always.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- After the Commission and the Council have been severely condemned and criticized for their intransparent approach in the area of negotiating flight agreements with third countries, I supported this motion.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a resolution on international aviation agreements.This proposal followed on from the European Commission's aviation strategy, which included the proposed launch of negotiations on aviation safety and air services agreements with some Asian countries.As all these agreements are still at an early stage, we called in the resolution for the European Parliament to be kept fully and timely informed of the progress of the negotiations on them.I think that the European Parliament should be informed as soon as possible of any important progress in the negotiations, as at the end of the process it will be asked to give its consent to the conclusion of an agreement.Involving Parliament in all stages of the negotiations will make the situation easier and Parliament will be able to decide more quickly and competently.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the resolution on international aviation agreements because I agree with the European Parliament's dissatisfaction, which was not properly informed of the progress of international negotiations with China and Japan on this matter.I argue that the European Commission should take the necessary measures to improve Parliament's current information system on the negotiation of international agreements and automatically communicate to Parliament details on all stages of the process in a spirit of interinstitutional cooperation.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the motion for a resolution on the international air transport agreement. The European aviation sector can fit into a competitive global environment, and international agreements with China, Japan, Turkey, ASEAN, Mexico, GULFA members and Armenia will greatly contribute to this goal. This is to ensure that the aviation industry remains in the process of growth and benefits the European economy. EU transport agreements with these partners aim to ensure market access based on the acceptance of common rules. EU bilateral aviation agreements promote cooperation to ensure a high level of civil safety and environmental friendliness, the safety and security aspect must be at the heart of all efforts to strengthen the efficiency and effectiveness of the single European aviation market to ensure consumer confidence and global competitiveness EU aviation. Under these agreements, I believe that, according to Article 218 TFEU, the Commission and the Council should fully involve and report to Parliament at all stages of the negotiation of international air transport agreements.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to discuss the excellent draft resolution by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection that is before us today. It summarises very well the challenges involved in implementing the Union Customs Code (UCC).  As highlighted in the resolution, the customs union is a cornerstone of the European Union and is essential for the proper functioning of the single market. This, in turn, implies a need for efficient customs performance. At the same time, the demands on customs authorities are increasing. In recent years the role of customs authorities has evolved far beyond one of just collecting taxes and duties at borders. Customs now also have a range of other responsibilities linked to protecting society, preventing unfair and illegal trade, and protecting EU citizens and intellectual property rights. They must therefore combine effective controls with means to facilitate and accelerate trade. In this regard, I would like to assure Honourable Members of the Commission’s intention to uphold the Union’s strict compliance with its commitments under the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement. The UCC is designed with this in mind. The aim is a customs environment that combines the facilitation of trade with a safe and secure supply chain, while also managing new challenges such as evolving business practices. The resolution notes that changes are already planned to the legal provisions contained in the UCC package. Updates cannot be avoided when dealing with a complex and comprehensive package of legal texts. However, throughout our discussions and work on amendments we involve the Trade Contact Group as well as Member States and Parliament so that all stakeholders can assess the implications of planned changes. I should add that many of the ongoing and planned corrections and improvements are being made as a result of proposals by trade. I also note your call for a clear, coherent and ambitious customs strategy. I would like to inform you that we have been working with Member States on a governments’ communication that should be adopted at that end of this year. This communication will address the need for a strengthened partnership between Member States and the Commission in managing the customs union.  Turning to IT systems, the Commission has been working proactively with Member States for several years to streamline and harmonise the process of full automation of customs. The aim is that Member States will implement the relevant IT systems in a common and integrated way in their national IT environments. The resources available at national and EU level are under severe pressure. The Commission will address the question of the funding of customs equipment, including IT, in the impact assessment we will carry out to prepare the next generation of customs programmes in the context of the next Multiannual Financial Framework. The Commission’s work will also address the cofinancing of national and EU projects as well as the connection of IT systems in different EU domains.  The resolution mentions the need for greater risk management and controls. I would like to draw Parliament’s attention to the Commission strategy and action plan for customs risk management of 2014. Among other objectives, the action plan aims to improve the quality of advance information submitted by traders and improve inter-agency cooperation. A progress report on the action plan of July this year noted that there have been some positive results in inter-agency cooperation, in particular in the area of health and safety. However, cooperation between customs and law enforcement and security agencies is less advanced. So the implementation of the risk management strategy remains a challenge for the years to come. However, I am pleased to note the Council’s full support, in its conclusions of 6 December, for continuing work along the lines of the strategy. Customs is now also a recognised partner in our efforts to construct a security union. Turning to e-commerce, the Commission agrees that trade from e-commerce must be facilitated. At the same time, we must protect revenues, safety, security and intellectual property rights and ensure a level playing field between EU and non—EU traders. The Commission is working with Member States and traders in several fora, including the World Customs Organisation, to reach balanced e-commerce solutions. In conclusion, it is clear that the full benefits of the UCC will become evident only after full implementation. However, I would like to confirm that we are considering some form of status review of the UCC that would explain where we are with implementing IT systems and the remaining legal issues. A fully—fledged fitness check or independent impact assessment would only make sense, as the motion for a resolution notes, once all IT systems have been implemented. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! First of all, I wish you a very Merry Christmas. But the joyful wish cannot hide the fact that in the area of ​​customs policy we urgently want to draw the European Commission's attention to three key issues with this resolution. The first question of these three key questions is as follows: Does the European Commission really have a concept based on the modernized Customs Code, which was introduced to the European Parliament in 2005, then failed and was renewed in 2013 and is now being continued with the Union Customs Code? Does the European Commission really have a comprehensive plan to put this customs code into practice in all 28 - then possibly 27 - Member States by 2019? Does it understand that customs duties vary greatly in the Member States of the European Union? Some states have no significant customs revenue at all, but still have a customs administration that they would hardly need as a result. Other countries have a very high customs volume, and with globalization, of course, effective, fast, flexible, but harmoniously uniform customs processing is becoming increasingly important, and we need the Member States by our side. I would be very happy if the commission presented a very convincing concept, which is also backed up with impcast assessments, in this area. The second point that you raised, Commissioner, is the question: How do we manage to adapt customs law to the digital age in a global world in such a way that we have security for consumers on the one hand, but also at the same time Encourage trustworthy bodies in the Member States and in business to work together so that the goal is achieved, that the customs revenue that must be generated, the customs duties that are paid have to become effective in the end? What options do we have there to provide traders and economic operators with simple, flexible, fast and inexpensive systems through a uniform electronic customs system so that they can ultimately manage this process in the way that citizens, consumers and buyers want? From my point of view, this is a very central challenge because, of course, different policy areas also overlap here. The value added tax system is one thing, effective and unbureaucratic customs clearance is another. The whole thing will only succeed if the digital settlement systems of the member states are so closely networked that it actually works in the end. At the moment we simply have to realize that every country is trying to push back the date of introduction of such a system on their own so far that in the end the European Union should pay for the fun. That is why I ask the European Commission to prepare itself in good time so that the member states have actually set up these systems so that we can really implement this uniform customs policy here together with the market participants. At that point, Mr President, I will leave my first appeal.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - President! Dear European Parliament! The S-D Group also considers it essential that the European Customs Union, as one of the cornerstones of the Union, function properly and effectively and in the best possible way for the benefit of European businesses and citizens. Hopefully, the new Customs Code, introduced in May 2016 and fully implemented in December 2020, will indeed lead to greater legal certainty, uniformity and simpler customs rules in practice. This would be of particular interest to small and medium-sized enterprises, which are particularly disadvantaged by complex customs rules and procedures, so that they also have to bear additional tax burdens due to tax evasion and tax fraud by multinational companies. If there is no positive change for small and medium-sized enterprises in these areas, the competitiveness of the European Union will be significantly felt. In addition to small and medium-sized enterprises, the other priority group whose interests must be served by the new Customs Code is European consumers. The new customs legislation must therefore better protect consumers from goods that are harmful to health and the environment, and from illegal goods. In order for the new rules to truly lead to a simpler, faster and more secure customs union, we urge that the problems that arise during the transitional period be constantly monitored and that the system be adapted so that from 2021 all Member States meet the required requirements. Finally, Mr President, I wish you and all European citizens a very happy holiday and a lucky 2017!

name: Czesław HOC
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! The EU customs policy is a great challenge for the entire Commission and the European Union. On the one hand, a good customs policy is to fight mainly against illegal trade, organized crime, fraud and terrorism, while at the same time facilitating legal trade and providing citizens and businesses with a sense of security. The current resolution aims to facilitate, simplify, make the EU customs policy coherent and fair, while at the same time making customs duties effective and uniformly enforced. The point is that in the delegated acts to the Customs Code, the European Commission proposes only proportionate provisions that are designed to facilitate legitimate trade and develop European competitiveness on a global scale, and not constitute additional administrative barriers. Here are two examples of creating such barriers. Requirements for financial guarantees in the case of the so-called AEO authorized entrepreneurs who already comply with strict rules - according to many companies, these requirements should be waived. Further, simplified customs procedures for low value shipments for import and export should be maintained. On the other hand, the European Commission proposes to withdraw from the already existing customs simplifications. This runs counter to the objectives of the Digital Single Market to enable consumers and businesses to have better access to goods and services. Therefore, the ECR group supports the text of the resolution, which is intended to motivate the European Commission to intensify dialogue with the business community and to jointly create a modern, coordinated, transparent, fair, consistent, predictable and safe EU Customs Code for citizens and companies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, we know how it was. There were queues that were at our border crossings for hours. The trucks waited for hours. Rows that were miles long. I am sorry that there are no colleagues here talking about how unity within the European Union should be broken and how this Union should be destroyed. I am sorry that they are not there and that they do not hear and remember how we lived and how it was among our Member States, but that is only a political message. I want to make it clear here that what has been proposed to us by these new proposals here is something that will really, I hope, help us. The intention and goals to modernize the customs code in a way that uses digital technology is something that was very much to be expected to come on the agenda and that in that way we will have a chance for a more unified business. That business entities will have greater legal certainty, as well as that the procedure and various rules we have will be simplified, is something that the business world of the European Union rightly expects. We expect that appropriate solutions for e-commerce will also be found because it is very important. We know that today e-commerce is more and more present among the member states and the citizens of the European Union are increasingly trading in this way. In the end, I wish all of you, especially you, Mr. Chairman, a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Therefore, this Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union Customs Code entered into force on 30 October 2013, as well as all the provisions giving the Commission the power to prepare implementing and delegated acts. The code itself came into force in May this year. However, as colleagues have already said, it is part of the project of modernization of European customs in terms of comprehensive, paperless operations of all entities involved in these customs procedures. Of course, we want these procedures to be carried out with as little bureaucracy as possible, in short, completely paperless operations, simplification of certain conditions for issuing permits, with the need to ensure adequate control over these areas, because paperless operations also support opportunities for abuse. And given that the European Union is also financially dependent on customs duties and the funds it collects from customs duties, an additional effort needs to be made here in terms of both inspections and inspections. So I think this is a step in the right direction, that this information, and the law itself, is a welcome support for the unification of the customs territory of the European Union. I hope that, of course, the Member States will not have too many problems with this and that they can implement them as soon as possible. In the end, of course, dear colleagues who are in the hall, and to all of you who are also on the balconies, Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year and see you next time.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the Commissioner. We have been talking officially about customs union since 1968, but I must say that today we are far from a real customs union, because if it were a "union" we should have the same tariffs, but also the same rules. Unfortunately this is not the case, customs clearance practices vary from state to state and if we talk about sanctions we find absurdities, ranging from the payment of simple arrears to even criminal consequences in some states. What is the practical consequence of this approach? That those countries that apply the rules more lightly, in fact, do nothing but attract greater earnings to themselves and this is to the detriment of all Member States and also of citizens, as we are feeding on unfair competition practices on the one hand , but we do not protect consumers, because we allow the entry of counterfeit goods but also of bacteria, as in the case of xylella. But this resolution is welcome, with which we strongly ask for customs controls to be standardized. We also ask that the same IT system be applied in all countries to facilitate checks and the exchange of information, information that thanks to this system should also be interoperable with the health certification systems of individual Member States. Well, if we manage to create this, a real union, where all goods entering European territory undergo the same treatment, then we will be able to talk about consumer protection and a real advantage for all Member States.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the customs code is an outdated document before it is even fully implemented. It is based on ideological, free trade and globalist foundations driven by Davos and the WTO. This ideology has been rejected by many peoples and by the citizens of the world's largest economy, the United States. With Donald Trump, trade is for national development and the protection of industry. Tariffs are necessary to balance trade in the spirit of the Havana Charter for Peace in Commerce. Your Union customs code starts from a premise: the general disappearance of these duties to lead to trade facilitation. We therefore need a continuous decrease in the control rate. In this age of protectionism and tariff rearmament, the European Union is still one step behind. In addition to a new contribution from the Commission to the liquidation of our sovereign States, by strengthening the freedom for importers to clear customs wherever they want, in particular with centralized customs clearance, you encourage them to shop among customs administrations to seek the most lax. and the less observant. You also weaken our States and make them insecure. Your technological instruments - ECS, ICS -, which claim to put customs fraud into a digital equation, will never replace the instinct, experience and knowledge of the field that customs officers have: the investigation, the chain, the systematic protection . By accelerating the destruction of our customs protections, you continue to deliver our economies to unfair competition, to deliver them to the social dumping that our fellow citizens are already undergoing, you also deliver our companies to criminal organizations, to which you guarantee a perpetual rent through your ineffectiveness . Then we have the hope of Christmas, eternity in the face of temporal bankruptcy of a world in need of saving.Merry Christmas!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for this detailed debate. I would probably have to repeat myself in many ways with my predecessors, but I will mention one of the things that was not mentioned here. When the modernization of the customs union was launched in 2003 in order to establish a paperless environment, it was important that everything went fast. Perhaps, let's say, as quickly as possible so that the European Union can come to terms with the rest of the world. That is why I was pleased to read in several documents that 98% of customs declarations lodged in the European Union are already in electronic form. But, Commissioner, we live in the twenty-first century. Is 98% really a lot or a little? At a time when we are facing increasing globalization of trade and global crime or terrorism, is this number really enough? The Customs 2020 program, together with the new Customs Code, are certainly logical, correct steps in continuing to modernize the entire customs union, which exchanges information in real time. As the rapporteur has already mentioned here, it is very important that this modernization takes place in the same way across all the countries of the European Union. We need to have an overview of all goods that cross the borders of the European Union, and in the current digital age we can only have that if everything is recorded electronically and states then exchange information effectively. I therefore fully support the efforts of the European Commission and most Member States to electronicize communication between customs offices and to replace old technologies with new, reliable and, above all, secure ones. Finally, Mr President, allow me to take a short time to wish you all a happy holiday and all the best for the new year, as well as the interpreters present here, thank you for your work and I firmly believe that you need our work as well, like we need yours.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the customs union is a cornerstone of the European Union and is essential for the proper functioning of the Single Market. On 1 May 2016, traders in the European Union could see the largest change to European customs procedures in the past 20 years with the introduction of the Union Customs Code. The new legislation aims to facilitate legitimate rate, increase safety and security and rationalise, harmonise and standardise the application of custom controls and decision-making processes across Europe. Under the Union custom code, all communications between custom authorities and businesses will have to be electronic, with the goal of creating a completely paperless custom environment across the EU. It is important to have an independent impact assessment to ensure that the regulatory framework of the EU customs policy is effective, proportionate and fit for purpose, both for Member States and for trade operators. The European Commission has to step up efforts to create more uniform custom electronic requirements and risk assessment programmes at EU level in order to ensure that the arrival, transit and exit of goods in and out of the EU is registered as effectively as possible. And of course, dear colleagues, Merry Christmas and Happy New Year.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I support the proposal to set up a guidance system to address the challenges of the European Union Customs Code, which urgently needs to be reviewed in this way. There is currently a lack of clarity within the European Union and, to put it mildly, difficulties are created due to inconsistencies and legal omissions, legal issues, uncertainty and the insurmountable complexity of rules and standards in overall policy, which affect not only the economy. , but also on the citizens of the Member States of the European Union. Take, for example, a family vacation. Families traveling to four Member States who want to return home with different gifts need to do a thorough study of what and how they can move across borders, given that often available information is not clear at best. The right balance must be found between citizens and businesses, without creating unnecessary bureaucracy, imposing illegal, disproportionate penalties and sanctions. An in-depth review of the Customs Code will have huge economic and social benefits, thus ensuring a better functioning of the single market as a whole - one of the pillars of the European Union. Finally, let me wish you all a Merry Christmas, family and personal happiness.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the new Customs Code brings the concentration of customs regulations, simplification of procedures, which of course means speeding up the procedure. It defines the necessary data for the implementation of this procedure and ultimately because of all this, due to unification and simplification, acceleration leads to business simplification in general, which will of course increase the competitiveness of the European economy, all of which is part of the European Growth and Jobs Strategy. That is why this is an important topic. The topic is timely because this customs code came into force only this year and its implementation should be monitored very carefully. I therefore thank and congratulate my colleagues in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection who have proposed this item on the agenda. On the other hand, it is very important that this whole process of introducing this code is accompanied by informatization. That is why, in a way, it is such a long transition period. I especially congratulate the representative of the Commission for referring to electronic business as a very important segment, in which, of course, the implementation of this Code will also help. Finally, thank you for a beautiful and happy Christmas and New Year.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, different controls in different ports and a customs union which is such only on paper. This is what emerges when you leave these buildings and talk to those who work in European ports. Customs and counterfeiting controls are not the same in Italy or Slovenia, Spain or Estonia, France or the Netherlands and a real war is underway between European ports to grab more goods, with customs administrations that often run on the border of legality and sometimes go beyond it in order to attract as much traffic as possible. Many of the customs controls derive from European legislation. I would therefore like the Commission to investigate this phenomenon in depth because, in addition to being dangerous for citizens, it distorts the internal market and penalizes those who, like in my country, do their job well. Everyone needs to apply the law in the same way because with the free movement of goods once a product has entered Europe it can end up in any country, without further checks, and knowing this situation there are those who take advantage of it. Attention, it is not a question of individuals, but of entire administrations, entire states, entire governments that try to attract international trade flows by turning a blind eye. This is what makes it so difficult to bring the phenomenon to the fore and for the same reason you cannot simply rely on local authorities to stop it. So, from my point of view, the solution is a European Commission investigation and I wonder if there will be the courage and the will to carry it through.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, i mo thír féin nuair a dhéantar tagairt d’UCC, is é an rud a bhíonn i gceist acu ná Coláiste na hOllscoile, Corcaigh, ach dar ndóigh, san Aontas is é Cód Custaim na hEorpa atá i gceist againn. Agus ós rud é go bhfuil sé ann le fada, agus go bhfuil an saol ag athrú go han-tapaidh, an teicneolaíocht ag bualadh ar aghaidh, tá sé de cheart ag an gCoimisiún féachaint ar na rialacha agus iad a leasú, agus go háirithe chun a chinntiú go mbeidh sé níos éasca ag meánfhiontair agus fiontair bheaga gnó a dhéanamh agus tá sin an-tábhachtach. Agus chun é sin a dhéanamh beidh gá le malartú eolais, comhoibriú, rialacha soiléire agus go háirithe na modhanna oibre ceannann céanna i ngach tír. Freisin táimid ag caint gach uile lá faoi ‘Brexit’ agus nuair a fhágfaidh an Ríocht Aontaithe an tAontas, an bhfágfaidh siad an tAontas Custaim chomh maith? Má dhéanann, déanfaidh sin dochar mór do mo thír féin, Éire. Beidh sé níos costasaí an trádáil atá ar siúl gach uile lá idir Éire agus an Bhreatain agus níos measa fós, trádáil idir deisceart agus tuaisceart na hÉireann. Dá bhrí sin caithfimid súil ghéar a choimeád ar na pointí sin agus tá súil agam go n-oibreoidh siad dár leas. Mar fhocal scoir, ba mhaith liom, cosúil leis na feisirí eile, Nollaig Shona agus Athbhliain faoi mhaise a bhronnadh ar chách.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the Customs Code is the basis for the functioning of the customs union. But we must not forget how the customs union started and so did the Common Agricultural Policy, because they are mechanisms for the protection of the European Union itself, for the protection of the economy, that is why there is a customs union. Now we have reached the other end. In fact, there is no customs union! Customs duties with almost all countries have been abolished. Minimum customs duties are levied. We import duty-free oil from Tunisia, we have duty-free imports from Ukraine. So, what is needed in the first phase is to return to the real situation, that is, to a phase of protection of the European economy, by strengthening mainly the tariffs. This is the trend that is being seen in the United States by Mr. Trump. At the same time, the frauds that are taking place must stop, because there is an increase in customs policy, especially in the ports. In conclusion, Mr President, since I appear to be the last speaker, I would like to wish you, the Commissioner, colleagues a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year in 2017, as well as the interpreters. who have remained with us until this time.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all of the honourable Members for their comments and for the importance they attach to the implementation of the Union Customs Code. I believe that our two institutions share the same objective of wishing to modernise customs for the benefit of both trade and administrators. I would like to address some of the points made in the debate. It is certainly true that further work is needed, particularly with regard to new trade simplifications, such as centralised clearance, which depend on EU wide IT systems. However, I would like to underline that the Commission is committed to continue working in these areas, in close collaboration with Member States and trade representatives. You commented on the fact that the UCC was not the subject of an impact assessment. In fact, this was deemed unnecessary because a detailed impact assessment had already been carried out on the modernised customs code.  Turning to e-commerce: I would like to stress that the simplifications that existed before the UCC for express carriers importing low-value goods continue to exist during the UCC transitional period.  Finally, I would like to confirm the Commission’s commitment to continue to cooperate closely with Parliament so as to ensure that the EU customs policies indeed are effective, proportionate and fit for purpose.  I wish you all a Happy New Year and merry Christmas, and I thank you for this excellent debate today.  Dziękuję bardzo, Panie Przewodniczący!

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – A well-functioning Customs Code is essential to a well-functioning single market. This is not possible if Member States do not respect this Code or allow it to be updated to the changing situation on the ground. We need to simplify the complex customs rules and procedures which are particularly detrimental to our SMEs. We need to complete the digitalisation of custom controls well before the end of the transitional period to do so. For all this, we need action from the Council and better controls by the Member States and the Commission.  This is an area that is in theory already harmonised. I simply do not understand why we do not enforce it as such. Our borders are only as strong as their weakest point. If a trader can cheat by going to Member State A instead of Member State B, he will. If a trader knows he will get a smaller fine if he is caught in Member State A instead of Member State B, he will go there. Member States must do their jobs in a way that is standardised, no matter where you are in Europe.
